fields.headline: From cook to social worker
fields.standfirst: Diane Gooch is upgrading her skills as a care worker on an innovative in-house scheme
fields.trailText: Flexibility, lifelong learning - they're the buzzwords of today's labour market. And it's wonderful. Wonderful, that is, if you've got marketable skills, a lack of ties and the confidence, support and opportunities to progress. By and large, it's not a world inhabited by low-paid social care staff.
fields.body:
Flexibility, lifelong learning - they're the buzzwords of today's labour market. And it's wonderful. Wonderful, that is, if you've got marketable skills, a lack of ties and the confidence, support and opportunities to progress. By and large, it's not a world inhabited by low-paid social care staff.

But an innovative traineeship is giving 18 Suffolk county council staff, from a range of social care jobs, the chance to upgrade their skills and become qualified social workers.

Diane Gooch has been working for the local authority for 12 years, first as a cook, and then as a care worker, in a children's residential home and a family resource centre. "I've been very lucky with Suffolk," she says. "They sponsored people to go on a BTech in social care, one day a week for two years. I also did an HNC in social care, in childhood studies."

The more involved in her job working with teenage mothers she became, the more she loved it. But the more frustrating it became. "I was thinking that I wanted to do more but I couldn't, because I wasn't qualified as a social worker," she explains. "If there were child protection issues, for example, if she was a minor having sex, I couldn't be the case holder. So, I could never see the work right through. I would talk to a young person, but I'd have to take it to my manager." And it wasn't just the personal frustration that rankled but feeling like she was letting her clients down. "It was like having to leave the young person to someone else, when I'd got a relationship with them and I felt that, given the chance, I could do that job."

Day-release diploma
The obvious answer was to qualify in social work. However, Gooch explains that giving up her job to go to college simply wasn't an option. "My husband's been laid off three or four times. I had a child (who's now grown up). And I was worried that, if I left to do a course, I might not get a job as I'm older, nearly 50."

Luckily, Gooch's employer was setting up an in-house, day-release diploma in social work (DipSW), in conjunction with Unison, the public sector union, and Ruskin College, Oxford. Already, says Gooch, she's reaping the benefit. "We're about halfway through. I'm now a seconded senior childcare practitioner in an outreach team, preventing family breakdown, working with adolescents and families at home and school. I'm sure I was seconded because I'm doing the course."

The training partnership approach arose out of an earlier attempt to tackle a communication skills deficit. Frontline care staff weren't geared up to the increased demands of community care, such as recording client information and contributing to written reports. With the help of both Unison and the Workers' Education Association, the Suffolk training team took a practical look at procedures and created a programme of work-based courses covering information and communications technology, numeracy and literacy.

Professional ladder
This brush with training did more than ensure that forms were properly filled in. "The added value was that managers found staff were more confident and more able to take on higher level tasks. Staff felt more valued and felt they knew more about the organisation." says county training manager Paula Stott.

The DipSW builds on that experience. And, points out Stott: "It gives low-paid workers a way up the professional ladder."

Finding the time to study isn't easy and can be disruptive to home life. But Gooch says she's one of the lucky ones. "I'm very excited. I feel really lucky I've been given this privilege. You're doing the course as you're working, so you can fine tune your work and you can put things you're learning straight away. Your confidence gets boosted. You're improving your practice as you're going along. I want to be doing the best I can for myself and for the clients."

webTitle: How charities can benefit from payroll giving

fields.headline: How charities can benefit from payroll giving
fields.standfirst: Fundaisers must be proactive to reap the rewards from a government drive to increase employer donations
fields.trailText: Fundaisers must be proactive to reap the rewards from a government drive to increase employer donations
fields.body:
Charity fundraising from payroll giving is expected to increase significantly following government incentives announced earlier this year and a publicity campaign aimed at employers launched this month.

But what can charities do to make sure they take advantage of the changes and exploit the higher profile of payroll giving?

First, the changes. Payroll giving has always been one of the most tax-efficient ways for PAYE employees to donate to charity. Because the donation is deducted from gross salary the charity effectively benefits from the tax element that would otherwise have gone to the Inland Revenue.

In April, the government made schemes even more attractive by introducing a 10% supplement to all payroll donations until April 2003 and ending the £1,200 a year limit on donations. The abolition of the upper limit makes higher-rate taxpayers extremely attractive targets for charities.

These changes mean the government will add £1 for every £10 donated to charity under a payroll scheme - and this total of £11 will only cost basic rate taxpayers £7.80 and higher-rate taxpayers £6.

The government's £2m publicity campaign, which includes a mailout to 24,000 of the country's largest employers, is likely to encourage many employers to introduce schemes or more actively promote their existing schemes. In 1998-99 payroll giving raised £29m for the voluntary sector; the government's target is to increase that to £60m.

But charities cannot simply rely on the government's efforts. "Charities cannot sit back and expect to benefit but must be proactive in taking forward payroll giving strategies," says Christine Jenkins, managing director of Sharing the Caring, a payroll giving promotion agency owned by Help the Aged.

Since the agency was launched in 1987, it has found that many charities have not taken payroll giving seriously. They have considered it to be too complicated, as an Inland Revenue approved payroll giving agency is needed to handle the administration and distribute the donations to the charities concerned.

But that attitude is changing, says Jenkins, as the potential of this form of fundraising is increasingly recognised and payroll automation has made it easier for employers. Fundraisers at agencies such as Sharing the Caring persuade employers to introduce payroll giving schemes and help them with internal promotion. The agencies inform employees on the charities they represent and charge a commission to their charity clients on subsequent donations.

Christine Cryne, head of marketing at Help the Aged, says payroll giving can be a particularly good fundraising tool for less glamorous causes. She comments: "When people think of donating to charity they often don't consider older people but payroll giving means we get a chance to describe our work to employees, which leads to increased awareness and donations."

fields.headline: Get tough on racism
fields.standfirst: Race relations law will force social services to act on racism
fields.trailText: It is hard to avoid discussion of race and crime these days - and rightly so. The fact that young black men are more likely to be stopped and searched than their white counterparts has become common knowledge. Both the police and community representatives are preparing for the moment next year when the law will be brought to bear on this contrast.
fields.body:
It is hard to avoid discussion of race and crime these days - and rightly so. The fact that young black men are more likely to be stopped and searched than their white counterparts has become common knowledge. Both the police and community representatives are preparing for the moment next year when the law will be brought to bear on this contrast.

There is another aspect of life where black overrepresentation may well lead to legal action under the forthcoming amendments to the race relations act. Statistics and research have for years shown that black and Irish men are strongly overrepresented in compulsory mental health treatments of one sort or another.

There is a parallel situation with looked-after children. A group that is new to ethnic monitoring categories, children of mixed background are strongly overrepresented among those in care. The next census in April 2001, which will be the first to use this category, may well reveal some stark realities for many children from this group.

Some decisions leading to compulsory action in both areas are currently outside the reach of the race relations act. None will be in future. Equally, while research has highlighted some of the possible causes of the overrepresentation, there has been no requirement to tackle those causes. That will also change.

Social service departments, whose staff play a crucial part in both areas, will need to:
 consult with ethnic minority representatives in their local community and listen to their concerns;
 ensure that monitoring systems are properly in place so that patterns of inequality can be brought into the open;
 make sure that proper assessments pinpoint unjustifiable causes which may lie behind the imbalances in the outcomes;
 have action programmes for change, providing for new practices which will eliminate the problems;
 put in place reviews which ensure that the change is bedded in thoroughly. Change must be understood and carried through at every level, backed by staff performance appraisals so that policy changes do not remain on paper but become real practice.
Much work along some of these lines has already been undertaken in mental health and children's services. But what has happened so far has not dented the underlying problems. That work will now have to get under way.

 Gurbux Singh is chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality

fields.headline: NHS press officer
fields.trailText: NHS press officers have never been more in demand - and never more maligned. They are increasingly regarded as essential to the running of the modern health service, and yet are distrusted as "spin doctors".
fields.body:
NHS press officers have never been more in demand - and never more maligned. They are increasingly regarded as essential to the running of the modern health service, and yet are distrusted as "spin doctors".

It is the "spin" allegation, with its suggestion of untruths, black propaganda, partisan behind-the-scenes briefings, and intimidation of recalcitrant journalists that rankles with health PRs.

It may happen in Westminster, or even in the Department of Health. But, says Leigh McGowan, head of communications at the Queen's Medical Centre University hospital trust in Nottingham, spin is not in his brief.

"Our job is to present the facts," he says. "We have got to be as open, honest and available as possible. If you are seen as a devious and secretive organisation it will undermine public confidence in you."

The government's determination to make the NHS "more open and accountable" by developing the communications function is sometimes perceived as an attempt to gloss over its imperfections.

As a former journalist, Julie Sheppard, head of communications and PR at University College London Hospitals trust, is well aware of the tensions inherent in the job.

Media scrutiny

"I worked in the media, on the side of the 'angels', generating lots of' bad news for government and companies. I'm now on the receiving end. I'm conscious media scrutiny is the lever that gets change brought about and there are some uncomfortable moments where you think to yourself, as a citizen, I should let this story run and run. But it is part of my role to ensure stories do not get to the stage where the reputation of the trust is tarnished. My mantra is 'let's be transparent about things'. It's not my job to lie, dissimulate or conceal. I can't pretend to you that water is wine.'

The role of the NHS PR is not just about dealing with the press. Communications with the public and with staff - particularly in a large trust spread over several sites - are increasingly important.

Sheppard manages a four-strong team: a press manager, a corporate communications manager responsible for internal communications with 5,500 staff on six sites, a website manager, and a junior communications officer.

It can be an exciting, exacting job. An NHS PR might be editing an internal newsletter one day and dealing with the world's press the next. PRs are often on call 24 hours a day, and while it can be rewarding to work for the NHS, pay lags behind the private sector.

Junior press officers start on £11,000 - £14,000. A middle manager might earn £20,000 - £27,000 while a NHS trust head of PR could earn £30,000-£40,000. At the top pay is improving as communications is recognised as a key job within any NHS management team. Top communications staff at large NHS trusts can earn up to £50,000; those with a seat on the board can earn £60,000 plus.

National institute of clinical excellence media director Anne-Toni Rodgers is on the board. So too is Matt Tee, director of communications at the commission for health improvement.

McGowan believes that the likes of Rodgers and Tee are blazing a trail for the future of NHS communications.

"I think we have got to the point where the head of communications should have trust board director status," he says.

fields.headline: Promotion tops health agenda
fields.standfirst: Specialists are key to government priorities
fields.trailText: There has never been a better time to be involved in health promotion, says Alison Learmonth, who chairs the society of health education and promotion specialists in England.
fields.body:
There has never been a better time to be involved in health promotion, says Alison Learmonth, who chairs the society of health education and promotion specialists in England.

"During the 80s and most of the 90s people involved in health promotion were trying to work in a climate that was really quite antagonistic," she says. "Now there is much more scope for health promotion. It's tremendously exciting."

With the introduction of health improvement programmes, health action zones and healthy living centres, the government has acknowledged the importance of a social model of health, according to Andrew Rogers, manager of health promotion for West Pennine health authority. The irony is that health promotion has become everybody else's business and is carried out not only by the NHS but by the voluntary sector and other agencies.

Career structure
Donald Reid, director of communications for the the UK Public Health Association, thinks "everything is in the melting pot". The breakdown of a clear career structure in health promotion started with the Conservatives' reform of the NHS in the 90s. "Previously every health authority had its own health promotion unit, but with the introduction of the purchaser-provider split some teams moved into trusts," he says. Now, with so many different health promotion and public health programmes, there is a climate of all boundaries being broken down.

While the traditional role of the health promotion unit may be under threat, the need for individuals with training and experience in health promotion or public health could not be greater. "There is a dearth of people who have the training and experience in developing partnerships needed to bring in the sort of agenda the government wants," says Learmonth.

Jeff French, director of planning and communication at the Health Development Agency, says health promotion specialists probably still make up the majority of the public health workforce. But jobs with equally important functions, such as epidemiologists, statisticians, and public health medicine consultants also exist in public health departments. Rogers has his own list of specialists: Sure Start co-ordinator, teenage pregnancy adviser, people working in HIV prevention, people working with young offending teams.

"What I think we will begin to see over the next few years is a more comprehensive and integrated career path for people working in specialist public health roles," says French.

Learmonth agrees. "It's no longer a straightforward career ladder where you would say: 'I'll do a masters degree for two years, then I'll end up in a health promotion department, then I'll become a manager.' The opportunities are exciting, but they are in primary care, in health action zones, in local government. The challenge over the next two or three years will be to get an open, fair and accountable way of accrediting people's skills."

fields.headline: House improvements
fields.standfirst:
MPs have been
           debating timetables and modernisation, yet House of Commons reform tends
           to be evolutionary rather than revolutionary
fields.trailText:
While much of the world was turning its attention to America on Tuesday night, MPs were showing their
           usual flair for timely publicity by debating reform of the House of Commons .
fields.body:
While much of the world was turning its attention to America on Tuesday night, MPs were showing their usual flair for timely publicity by debating reform of the House of Commons .

It is not that the debate lacked passion. Both "modernisers" and "traditionalists" at Westminster believe the other side to be obtuse beyond reason. That is why progress towards reform of parliamentary procedures has been slow consensus proves elusive - despite the spur of rivalry from Edinburgh and Cardiff.

This week the row was over the latest report of the modernisation committee chaired by the leader of the commons , Margaret Beckett. The job was previously held by Ann Taylor. Both are Labour women of an older (and northern) generation who are wary of some of the "family friendly" reforms proposed by their younger sisters.

Mrs Beckett proposed two major changes. One would allow progress on every bill to be agreed in advance, with a timetable voted on immediately after second reading there would be an end to "guillotine" motions sometimes curbing debate halfway through a bill's life.

As a reform it has been around almost a decade, proposed by the Tory-led Jopling committee in 1992. Mrs Beckett argues that it will help the opposition by allowing them to choose when they want key issues debated - preferably in prime time. "The government will get its way, but the opposition will have its say", as the old saw goes. Yet the Tories opposed it. MPs were unpersuaded by Beckett's assurance that it will force governments to produce less, and better-drafted, legislation (the Lords is awash with amendments at this time of year).

The second change voted through by Labour's impregnable majority (271 to 152 on a quiet night) will allow votes due to be taken after 10pm government orders of a routine kind will be taken in a batch. That too caused a row because votes will be detached from the arguments. But Liberal Democrats such as chief whip Paul Tyler, long an advocate of more effective scrutiny of legislation and more effective accountability by ministers to parliament, voted with Labour.

There will be another row tonight over proposals from the liaison committee - made up of the chairs of all 30-odd select committees - for big changes to the way committees are run. Some are acceptable to ministers. But they loathe the idea that three senior MPs on the liaison committee, whose chairman is the shrewd Labour veteran Robert Sheldon, should take over control of the membership of select committees, currently exercised with brisk and partisan efficiency by the party whips.

Yet whips often remove the independent-minded or expert members in favour of the malleable. Critics respond that it would replace an accountable form of patronage with one which seeks to take the politics out of politics again.

That is a thread which runs through the reform debate. Reformers are accused of naivety, of being almost as executive-minded as the Blairites. That is unfair to many, though the Commons is full of new MPs with no experience of backbench power of the kind that allowed eight "whipless" Tory Eurosceptics to bring John Major to his knees.

Reformers accuse traditionalists of sentimentality and a reluctance to admit that troublemakers' capacity to derail legislation is limited. No wonder, interject the likes of Tam Dalyell, when Labour-backed reforms in the Tory years took away most of the resourceful backbenchers' weapons. It is never easy to reform parliament, which is better at exhorting others to change their ways than reforming itself.

fields.headline: Local finance proposals have limited effect
fields.standfirst: Patrick McCurry assesses green paper proposals on the modernisation of local government finance
fields.trailText: Patrick McCurry assesses green paper proposals on the modernisation of local government finance.
fields.body:
What does the green paper cover?
The green paper includes government consultation proposals on capital finance, the business rate and council tax, plus the system for distributing central government grants to local authorities and the future funding of education and other services.

What is the background to the proposals?
Some of the proposals, such as the power to vary business rates, flesh out policies announced in the 1998 local government white paper. The green paper also takes on board a number of the recommendations made in Lord Rogers' urban taskforce report.

How radical are the proposals?
Not very. The government has not agreed to rearm councils with the power to set business rates, which was removed with the introduction of the poll tax. In fact, the green paper states that the current balance of funding between local and central sources of revenue does not need to change. This is a view that many in local government would dispute, arguing that local autonomy and accountability are reduced by the lack of discretion over funding at local level. The most radical proposal is to remove constraints on borrowing for capital projects, which could free up spending on transport, housing, libraries and other sectors. The government also proposes to allow councils to levy a supplementary business rate, after consultation with local businesses.

What about capital investment and borrowing?
The green paper acknowledges that the present system of capital controls has constrained effective investment by local government. Under the proposals, local authorities will no longer need government approval for borrowing, although the government will keep reserve powers allowing it to intervene in exceptional circumstances. When considering borrowing, authorities will have to show the impact on revenue and establish their own ratios based on a set of centrally produced "prudential indicators", covering measures such as debt-to-revenue ratios. The regime will be underpinned by a requirement for councils to operate within balanced budgets. Councils will also have to consult their communities about investment plans.

Will central government grant distribution change?
The paper acknowledges that the current standard spending assessment formula for distributing grants is too complex and rigid. It consults on a number of potential improvements. These include simplified formulas for all or part of grant distribution, specific grants to target resources and local public service agreements, which are to be piloted and which could lead to extra funds for those authorities that perform well against the standards of their agreement.

What about business rates?
Councils will gain limited powers to set a supplementary rate, in consultation with local businesses, while the extra funds raised must be used in agreement with local companies. The supplementary rate could be used to fund town improvement schemes which were recommended in the urban taskforce report.

And council tax?
The green paper proposes the introduction of a fixed revaluation cycle every six, eight or 10 years. In shire areas, where county councils account for 80% of the council tax bill but district councils send bills out, the government seeks views on whether county councils should take over responsibility for billing to improve accountability.

When could the green paper's proposals be introduced?
Responses to the consultation are due by December 8. If the government is re-elected, the proposals could become law early in the next parliament. The paper says the earliest possible date for the introduction of changes to the revenue grant system would be 2003-04.

webTitle: Is stress a sign of weakness?

fields.headline: Is stress a sign of weakness?
fields.standfirst: Hugh Robertson answers your questions about workplace stress and its remedies
fields.trailText: Hugh Robertson answers your questions about workplace stress and its remedies.
fields.body:
What is stress?
The usual definition is: "The reaction people have to excessive demands or pressures, arising when people try to cope with tasks, responsibilities or other types of pressure connected with their jobs, but find difficulty, strain or worry in doing so." Stress is very common. One in five people say they are either very or extremely stressed at work. It is one of the biggest causes of ill health in the workplace, making half a million people ill every year.

Surely a bit of stress doesn't hurt?
Whatever your employer may say, stress is not good for you. It is neither a natural part of life nor necessary to get the job done well. Nor is it an inevitable result of work or something that just affects the weak. You are not to blame if you suffer stress. There is a difference between challenge, stimulation, pressure and stress.

Who is at risk?
Any job can cause stress. It is not something that just affects executives or managers. The main reason for stress is a lack of control, and that affects low-paid employees most. Also it is not just about overwork. Monotony can also be stressful.

What causes it?
Some of the most common causes of stress are: dealing with clients or the public; cuts, reorganisations and lack of job security; poor working conditions; threats of violence, harassment and bullying; lack of childcare or flexibility; lack of control over the work; too demanding a job or too high a workload; monotonous or boring work; lack of training; excessive hours and shiftwork; general frustration with managers who just will not listen or cannot do their job. Stress should not be a normal part of working life. No one should suffer ill health because of the work they do.

What are the symptoms?
Stress can affect both our bodies and our minds. It affects everyone differently, but the main symptoms are depression, anxiety, and difficulty sleeping and constant fatigue. Often people suffering from stress will get headaches, backaches, skin rashes and even ulcers. People often try to reduce these symptoms through the use of alcohol, sleeping pills or cigarettes.

What effects can stress have?
In the long run, stress can lead to heart disease and high blood pressure. Because of the way stress is sometimes perceived as a "weakness" or "not coping", a lot of people will not admit to suffering from stress. This can make matters worse.

What are employers' legal duties?
Employers have a duty to ensure employees' health, safety and welfare at work and this includes preventing stress. They must assess the risk of stress and bring in measures to reduce that risk. But stress is not an issue an employee can easily take up with an employer alone; in fact, this in itself can be a very stressful thing to do. Union safety representatives have a legal right to take up health and safety matters on employees' behalf. So, if you have a problem with stress, let your union know. You may need changes to your job, more training or more support and your safety representative can approach your employer on your behalf.

 Hugh Robertson is head of health and safety at Unison

fields.headline: Manager misses health frontline
fields.standfirst: Senior posts mean less job satisfaction
fields.trailText:
Name Andrew Rogers
Job health promotion manager
Salary around £40,000
fields.body:
Name Andrew Rogers
Job health promotion manager
Salary around £40,000

Andrew Rogers has experienced a north/south divide of his own during the development of his career.

When he studied for an honours degree in human ecology at Huddersfield University in the mid-80s it included a one year placement in Oldham health promotion unit.

On completion of his degree he moved south to get a job as a health promotion officer at Aylesbury and Buckinghamshire where he focused mostly on health promotion in the workplace.

After two years he returned north to work as an HIV prevention co-ordinator in Blackburn, but less than a year later he moved south again to manage the Aylesbury unit.

Another three years on he was back north to Tameside and Glossop health authority to manage the health promotion unit there, and when his health authority was merged with Oldham's in the early 90s he secured the post of heath promotion manager for the new West Pennine authority.

"It's a great job," Rogers says, but seniority in the profession is accompanied by less job satisfaction. "When I was younger I used to run heart-saver courses ­ teaching community groups to do resuscitation. I got immediate payback from that because I received reports every time someone I taught helped save somebody's life."

webTitle: Charities fail to take advantage of new tax rules

fields.headline: Charities fail to take advantage of new tax rules
fields.standfirst: It is six months since Gordon Brown launched  tax changes to encourage  donations to charity as part of its Getting Britain Giving Campaign. But charities - and the public - seem to have been slow on the uptake.
fields.trailText: It is six months since Gordon Brown launched tax changes to encourage donations to charity as part of its Getting Britain Giving Campaign. But charities - and the public - seem to have been slow on the uptake.
fields.body:
It is six months since Gordon Brown, the chancellor, changed tax rules to encourage donations to charity as part of its Getting Britain Giving Campaign. But charities - and the public - seem to have been slow on the uptake. The lack of knowledge about the changes surprises Neil Jones, director of communications at the Charities Aid Foundation. "Some charities," he says, "still don't know how the changes will affect them."

David Tyler, director of Community Matters, a body that supports smaller voluntary organisations, concurs. "Not many community organisations have taken advantage of the changes. Most of it doesn't make any difference to our members. It is quite cumbersome, so small charities won't bother." Illustrating the confusion, Tyler believes that charities have to fill in complicated gift aid forms. In reality, charities can design their own forms with a space for name, address, donation and one sentence declaring that the donor is happy for the charity to reclaim tax.

Even some medium sized organisations say it is still early days. Mark Astarita, director of fundraising at the National Deaf Children's Society says the charity is starting to benefit from extra money, but he does not believes the public understands the changes. He says the charity needs to market the new rules in its publications.

Meanwhile his wife Gill Astarita, director of development at Action for Blind People, says her charity has benefited from two donations of shares worth £68,000. "These came out of the blue, but we have just done a mailshot to promote the gift of shares." Another option might be to target tax advisers, she says.

Moving up the foodchain, a consortium of large charities has joined forces to target supporters with a mailshot coordinated by Pell and Bales, the marketing agency. Oxfam, the NSPCC, UNICEF, Marie Curie Cancer Care, the Red Cross and WWF-UK shared the cost of the mailing to explain the changes to supporters. There was a 36 per cent response rate to the mailing, which asked people to return a form giving permission to reclaim tax on their donations. Karl Holweger, chief executive of Pell and Bales, says the results were very good. "The key was keeping the message simple and not asking for money at the same time. We are now moving into a new phase involving smaller organisations."

What are the key changes?

Change: No minimum limit on gift aid. You can now recover tax on any donation.
Action: Ask donors for their name and address and to confirm they are tax payers either in writing or verbally.

Change: Companies no longer have to deduct tax from their gift aid donations.
Action: Ask corporate donors to pay the gross amount direct to the charity.

Change: The Government will add 10% to payroll giving donations up to April 2003.
Action: Tell employers about the changes and arrange times to speak to staff.

Change: People can give certain shares and securities to charity and get tax relief.
Action: Market this particularly to wealthy donors.

Change: Tax exemption for the profits of certain trading and fundraising activities.
Action: Check the conditions for exemption and seek professional advice if necessary.

Change: Various VAT reliefs.
Action: Check if your charity is eligible.

What could this mean to you?

 If a donor gives you £100 your charity can claim £28.21

 If an employee gives you £50 this will equal £55 with the Government's 10% bonus

 If a donor gives you shares valued at £1,000, they will save £400 on capital gains and £400 on income tax

fields.headline: Keeping young people healthy
fields.standfirst: Sports background leads to new goal
fields.trailText:
Name Craig Piggott
Job health promotion specialist
Salary circa £16,000
fields.body:
Name Craig Piggott
Job health promotion specialist
Salary circa £16,000

If Craig Piggott had been even a few inches taller than 1.68m (5ft 6in) he might have been leading the Sunderland FC forward line. But after two years of battling with 1.90m (6ft 3in) centre halves he left his football apprenticeship and took up health promotion.

"I'd worked closely with the physio at Sunderland and learned that football is not just about talent, but also about looking after your body. I studied part-time and then did a sports degree at Manchester University which included nutrition and healthy lifestyles. I thought: 'Yeah ­ this is the field I want to get into.'"

When a part-time post came up in his current workplace, Tees and District health promotion service, he took it but had to wait over a year before he got a permanent job. At first Piggott was involved in health promotion in the workplace, highlighting the importance of smoking and drugs policies. More recently he has worked with schools and young people on sex education, drugs education and dental care. Sensitivity to parental concerns is paramount which means that sex and relationship roadshows first have to win the approval of teachers, then parents and only then, if the go-ahead is given, are they presented to pupils.

Now Piggott is studying for an MSc at Leeds University. He wants to become a health promotion specialist, and work with young people in Teesside and Darlington.

webTitle: Charity careers: get that first job

fields.headline: Get a job with a good cause
fields.standfirst: Working in the voluntary sector is no longer a soft option
fields.trailText: A job in charities used to be seen as a soft option, something to slip into after a career in the City or armed forces.
fields.body:
A job in charities used to be seen as a soft option, something to slip into after a career in the City or armed forces.

Today top charities are run by professionals who manage budgets of over £50m, employ thousands of staff and act as advisers to government.

Larger charitable organisations offer a range of opportunities from IT to fundraising, from web development to frontline service management. The voluntary sector as a whole employs over 485,000 employees. So how do you get one of these jobs?

The first step is to find out what motivates you. In a value-led environment where salaries may not match the private sector it can be important to feel motivated by a cause. With 180,000 registered charities, the choice is enormous.

If you are uncertain about making the leap into the sector you could try volunteering to learn more about it. The organisation Working for a Charity offers courses introducing the sector and arranges placements. Director Elaine Smethurst comments: "Getting volunteering experience shows you are determined and sets you apart from other applicants."

Local volunteer bureaux have details of volunteering vacancies in your area or you can search on SocietyGuardian.co.uk's volunteer jobs section. If you do not have time to volunteer now, think about what you have done in the past that could count as volunteering. Tony Lee, chief executive of the Muscular Dystrophy Campaign, says: "Sell your volunteering experience. Most of us have done something on a voluntary basis and employers are keen to see that you understand what it is like to be a volunteer as they are a key resource."

The next step is to target your CV. Think of your experience, paid or unpaid, in terms of skills which could be transferable to a charity: communications, management, budgeting, IT. Then keep an eye on the jobs section of this site, hawk yourself around charity recruitment agencies and fire off speculative applications to charities that meet your specification.

When you find the perfect vacancy, make sure you meet the charity's requirements to the letter. NSPCC recruitment manager Carole Mickleburgh says: "As long as someone meets the person specification they would stand as good a chance as anyone already in the voluntary sector."
fields.bodyText: A job in charities used to be seen as a soft option, something to slip into after a career in the City or armed forces. Today top charities are run by professionals who manage budgets of over £50m, employ thousands of staff and act as advisers to government. Larger charitable organisations offer a range of opportunities from IT to fundraising, from web development to frontline service management. The voluntary sector as a whole employs over 485,000 employees. So how do you get one of these jobs? The first step is to find out what motivates you. In a value-led environment where salaries may not match the private sector it can be important to feel motivated by a cause. With 180,000 registered charities, the choice is enormous. If you are uncertain about making the leap into the sector you could try volunteering to learn more about it. The organisation Working for a Charity offers courses introducing the sector and arranges placements. Director Elaine Smethurst comments: "Getting volunteering experience shows you are determined and sets you apart from other applicants." Local volunteer bureaux have details of volunteering vacancies in your area or you can search on SocietyGuardian.co.uk's volunteer jobs section. If you do not have time to volunteer now, think about what you have done in the past that could count as volunteering. Tony Lee, chief executive of the Muscular Dystrophy Campaign, says: "Sell your volunteering experience. Most of us have done something on a voluntary basis and employers are keen to see that you understand what it is like to be a volunteer as they are a key resource." The next step is to target your CV. Think of your experience, paid or unpaid, in terms of skills which could be transferable to a charity: communications, management, budgeting, IT. Then keep an eye on the jobs section of this site, hawk yourself around charity recruitment agencies and fire off speculative applications to charities that meet your specification. When you find the perfect vacancy, make sure you meet the charity's requirements to the letter. webTitle: How a US community foundation operates

fields.headline: How a US community foundation operates
fields.standfirst: Vice-president of the New Hampshire Charitable Foundation, Alan Cantor, shares his experience of fundraising stateside
fields.trailText: Vice-president of the New Hampshire Charitable Foundation, Alan Cantor, shares his experience of fundraising stateside.
fields.body:
Comparing the US experience of community foundations with other parts of the world is not simple, partly because US tax laws encourage charitable giving in one's lifetime and through one's estate.

Though we would like to think that charitable people would give with or without a tax incentive, tax deductibility influences most major gift decisions in the US. The final months of the year can be frenetic with people trying to give something away before the clock rings in the new year, ruling out the chance for charitable deductions the year after that.

That said, many of us feel that community foundations have flourished in the US. That's because most donors do not contribute to communal funds which support general charitable purposes.

Rather, the vast majority of the dollars we receive are directed to projects of particular interest to the donor. A donor might create a fund to support after-school recreation in her small New Hampshire town. A second might contribute to a fund to conserve environmentally sensitive lands throughout the state. A third may create a fund to support scholarships for women in their 30s or 40s seeking job training.

A community foundation covers all those funds and more - there are over 1,000 funds totalling $220m - under the umbrella of a single institution. Donors can specify what they want to support with minimal overheads and no legal expenses.

So the causes a community foundation should concentrate on are those that the donors, not the foundation, care about. As we work with donors, we try to help them focus on exactly what they hope their gift will accomplish, and we then structure their fund to meet those needs.

We don't encourage them to support the paramount needs of the region. We let the donors set the parameters and then help them refine their goals and connect to other community efforts.

In short, we're not fundraisers. Instead, we're in the donor services business: helping donors meet their philanthropic needs.

One last bit of advice: attorneys, accountants, and financial planners know best who has significant assets and who is in a position to share that wealth. We, like most US community foundations, work closely with these professional advisers, serving as a resource and offering ways in which their clients can make effective gifts.

fields.headline: Charities need business brains
fields.standfirst: Commercial skills are in demand in the voluntary sector
fields.trailText:
Name Tony Lee
Age 51
Job chief executive officer
Salary around £50,000
fields.body:
Name Tony Lee
Age 51
Job chief executive officer
Salary around £50,000

When Tony Lee was made redundant from his job as operations director for the NatWest bank he decided to try his luck with the voluntary sector. After six months he landed a job as chief executive at the Muscular Dystrophy Campaign.

Lee finds the skills he learned in the private sector are still useful. "The voluntary sector isn't run as a business but commercial skills are necessary to run a charity in a professional manner," he says.

He claims a contrast between the sectors is that the commercial world is much simpler as there are far fewer stakeholders. As a medical research charity, the Muscular Dystrophy Campaign has to consider researchers, families, clinicians, donors and companies as its key stakeholders.

"They all have a slightly different angle and I have to represent the charity so that they can empathise with it," comments Lee.

The downside of moving from the private to the voluntary sector is less money.

But Lee claims: "I feel good about my job. It is about making a difference and providing a service for people who need support."

fields.headline: Last drag for tobacco ads?
fields.standfirst: Plans to ban tobacco advertising have survived a European court reverse
fields.trailText: Plans to ban tobacco advertising in the UK have survived a European court reverse
fields.body:
Ministers are determined to ban tobacco advertising in the UK, despite a European court ruling overturning a Europe-wide ban, and in the face of powerful commercial interests.

No sooner had the European court of justice overturned the 1998 EU directive banning tobacco advertising and sponsorship, than public health minister Yvette Cooper announced that Britain would go it alone with a ban.

The government has promised to push through legislation curbing tobacco sponsorship and promotion before the end of the current parliament. Banning tobacco advertising is a manifesto commitment, and a key part of the government's programme to improve public health, reduce health inequalities, and tackle cancer.

The government's determination may also reflect residual embarrassment over the Ecclestone affair in which Labour accepted a £1m donation from Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone while coincidentally handing to Formula One a three-year exemption from the tobacco sponsorship ban.

Ironically, the European court ruling could mean a stricter ban than the directive proposed. "There is definitely a silver lining because the government can now redraft the advertising ban to close the various loopholes and remove the unnecessary Formula One compromise," said Clive Bates, director of Action on Smoking and Health (ASH).

A tobacco timeline
May 1997 Labour's election manifesto promises to ban tobacco advertising.
July 1998 EU directive on tobacco advertising becomes law, requiring all member states to legislate to implement the directive by July 2001.
June 1999 The government publishes draft proposals to ban tobacco advertising "by the end of the year".
October 1999 Tobacco companies win a high court injunction preventing implementation of the ban.
December 1999 The court of appeal overturns the injunction but tobacco companies apply to the House of Lords to have the appeal judgement overturned.
June 2000 The European court of justice (ECJ) is advised by its advocate general that the Directive should be annulled.
October 5 2000 The ECJ annuls the 1998 directive. The government announces plans to press ahead with a domestic ban. The European Commission is expected to attempt to reintroduce a ban as a public health measure.

fields.headline: US community foundations
fields.standfirst: American community foundations have set an example others are keen to follow, writes Sean McDougall
fields.trailText: American community foundations have set an example others are keen to follow, writes Sean McDougall
fields.body:
The idea of forming community foundations first took root in Cleveland, Ohio, in 1914. Since then around 600 foundations across the US have built up collective assets, called endowments, totalling more than $24bn.

The foundations invest the money and use the returns to support a wide range of good causes. Last year they made grants of more than $1bn.

Foundations across the US range from Ann Arbor, a sleepy university town in Michigan, which has about $40m in endowment, to Cleveland community foundation, which holds over $1.5bn.

The foundations are represented by two national organisations - the Council on Foundations and Community Foundations of America. Some are organised on a statewide basis as well. In Michigan, foundations banded together in this way to launch the first statewide advertising campaign, directed at financial advisers whose clients want to make tax-efficient gifts to charity.

As in the UK, these gifts can take many forms. There are so called "donor advised funds" that allow maximum participation in the grant-making process. Field of interest funds let donors specify a range of causes that they want to support.

Unrestricted funds can be allocated to any charity or voluntary organisation in the area. Often, these funds are named after the company or individual that established them, building goodwill that lasts for decades.

American community foundations have proved adept at responding to changes in the age profile of the wealthy. One of the fastest expanding is based in Silicon Valley whose young programmers and software engineers want to give something back to their communities. As these companies have expanded overseas, many have sought to support their new host communities as well.

Community foundations have also democratised giving and are seen to be leaders in philanthropy. They have challenged what was once a small pool of private and corporate foundations by helping individuals to establish funds in the name of a family, small company, cause or locality.

Although American community foundations have 70 years' head start on their British counterparts, and operate in a somewhat different philanthropic environment, the idea has proved readily transferable. It is taking root in Canada, Mexico, South Africa, Central and Eastern Europe and Australia.

 Sean McDougall is communications manager at the Community Foundation Network.

webTitle: The wider role of community foundations

fields.headline: Laying the foundations for community revival
fields.standfirst: Community foundations have the potential to play a big role in neighbourhood renewal
fields.trailText: Community foundations have the potential to play a big role in neighbourhood renewal
fields.body:
Community foundations are set to enjoy a record-breaking year, making grants of more than £21m and reaching a £100m endowment target by the end of December 2000. Community foundations work in a specific geographical area to help identify local community needs and promote and support charitable activity.

They were first established in the US more than 90 years ago and some 500 communities now benefit from local funding that should last for ever. In the UK, community foundations have existed for only two decades, but already 30 have been established, with another 30 currently being developed.

The aim of a community foundation is to build a permanent endowment fund with a large enough balance to make grants on an ongoing basis, rather than lurching from year to year from one funding crisis to another. Foundations hope to attract donations from local businesses and wealthy individuals. They also sometimes administer grant giving on behalf of family and business trusts.

The Community Foundation Network (CFN) exists to promote the concept of community foundations throughout the UK. Latest figures show that foundations have grown 15-fold and have added nearly £80m to their total endowment since statistics were first compiled in 1992-3. There are now 30 community foundations across the UK, as well as 29 associate organisations which are on the way to becoming foundations but as yet lack sufficient endowments to become fully fledged members of the CFN.

Clare Brooks, the CFN's development manager, says it takes up to two years to develop a community foundation. Anyone with an interest in their local area can attempt to set one up - from high sheriffs and business leaders to voluntary sector gurus. "The important thing is to have a long standing commitment to the local area," says Brooks.

After having the initial idea, the next step is to talk to local people, key movers and shakers, and generate support for the proposal. "You have to be really sensitive and bring people on board," adds Brooks.

Charities are often criticised for amassing reserves, but the purpose of a community foundation is to build up an endowment so that grants can be made in perpetuity. 'It is a delicate balance," Brooks says. "Grants must be made thoughtfully and donors' wishes must be respected." If a donor does not wish to give to an endowment, they can instead give to so-called "flow-through funds" that provide for immediate needs.

The growth of some foundations has been exponential. At the end of last year the Essex community foundation had capital assets of £600,303. Now it has amassed almost £4m. The Birmingham and Heart of England foundation has almost trebled in size during the year. And the Foundation for Greater Manchester has increased its funds by £2m following a local newspaper campaign and an offer of matched funding from the Duke of Westminster.

fields.headline: Tonight scores with feature on Megan's law
fields.trailText: Tonight with Trevor McDonald's feature on the parents of murdered child Sarah Payne boosted the ratings for the ITV show last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Tonight with Trevor McDonald's feature on the parents of murdered child Sarah Payne helped boost the ratings for the ITV current affairs show last night.

Reporter Fiona Foster travelled with the Payne's to the US, to see how Megan's Law - under which a register of known paedophiles is available to parents - works there.

The Payne's are backing a campaign to have a similar law introduced in the UK.

Ms Foster's report from the US, along with coverage of the on-going flood crisis, helped Tonight to average 6.6m and a 34% share last night from 10.15pm, according to unofficial overnights.

The show has averaged 5.5m on its four previous outings this autumn.

Tonight was undoubtedly also helped by the inheritance it received from Coronation Street, which ran from 9.45pm to accommodate ITV's live coverage of Manchester United's successful bid to progress to the knock-out stage of the Champions' League.

The Big Match had 8m and a 34% share from 7.30pm, while Coronation Street followed up with 10.5m and a 43% share.

But the BBC1 scheduling team will be pleased after a nifty bit of counter-scheduling at 7.30pm, where Celebrity Ready Steady Cook beat ITV's football coverage over the half-hour to 8pm.

The special, which featured The Weakest Link host Anne Robinson, pulled in 8.4m and a 37% share, while The Big Match was averaging 7.3m.

Later on, BBC1 was far less competitive, with an Only Fools & Horses repeat averaging 5.9m - a 24% share - from 8.35pm - followed by Crimewatch UK, with 6.3m and a 26% share.

On another busy news day, an average of 2.9m - 31% of the available audience - watched BBC2's afternoon coverage of chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-budget statement (2.40-4.45pm), in which he gave away £5bn to hauliers, motorists and pensioners.

Later, the BBC1 Six O'Clock News had a whopping 8.1m and a 37% share, as people tuned in to catch up on Mr Brown's give-away and the latest on the recount in the US presidential election. That was nearly two million up on the Six's Wednesday average audience over the last month.

fields.headline: Raising hope in a sink estate
fields.standfirst: The Isle of Dogs community foundation is bringing greenery and skills training to local people
fields.trailText: The Isle of Dogs community foundation is bringing greenery and skills training to local people.
fields.body:
From the balcony outside his high rise flat, Nadim looks down at a kid twirling around slowly on a broken roundabout. It has no safety railing and a hole in the middle the size of a child. It's midday on a Thursday. The child should be in school. Nadim should be in work.

To the left of the flats he can see Canary Wharf and hear the constant sound of new buildings being constructed. To the right the Millennium Dome fills his vision. Yet most people on this sink estate in Poplar are out of work. The inappropriately named Robin Hood estate has one of the highest unemployment rates in the country.

A woman meanders along the path between blocks of flats. Apparently she's an addict who was evicted from the 8th floor. This floor is known locally as a drug-dealing centre. The woman has now been relegated to the ground floor. Apparently she doesn't even recognise her own son and daughter after a brain haemorrhage.

In the middle of the blocks is a green hillock - created by shovelling up the rubble left over after building the flats in the 1970s and scattering some grass seed on it. The estate is flanked by a flyover and the Blackwall Tunnel, so this hillock is the only recreation area for the residents. Some of the older ones have never used it as the slope is too steep to be accessible.

But thanks to an ingenious funding application by the Isle of Dogs community foundation, the site will be turned into a "village green". By securing regeneration money and match funding from the Millennium Greens Trust, the foundation has accumulated £80,000 to redevelop the site. Local children have decided on the theme for the recreation area - dinosaurs and reptiles.

Garden furniture is being designed locally in keeping with the theme. A path leading up to the top will resemble a snake but also make it easier for older and disabled people to access the summit. A safe play area will be incorporated into the landscaping. Children from the local school are going to plant seeds and adults will be trained in horticulture in an attempt by the charity to encourage ownership and prevent future vandalism. Tommy Walsh, star of BBC TV's Ground Force gardening programme lent his support to the scheme at a photo call with local children.

Although it will improve the environment, the so-called village green isn't enough. The chair of the community foundation, Chris Mossop, who is also vice-president of a major bank in the area, says: "I'm proud of the contribution which local companies have made but they could do much more."

Meanwhile, on the money it has raised, the Isle of Dogs community foundation is funding an IT training centre for local residents on the estate. A new room has just been kitted out in the centre for internet training. The foundation also helps to fund a drop-in play centre so parents can attend college courses or have a break from looking after children. In total the foundation made over £750,000 in grants last year to around 100 diverse local organisations.

Sean McDougall, media and information services manager at the Community Foundation Network, the umbrella body of community foundations, says the foundation is able to fund projects at a local level and provide consistent support because of building up an endowment.

Sean McDougall, media and information services manager at the Community Foundation Network, the umbrella body of community foundations, says the foundation is able to fund projects at a local level and provide consistent support because of building up an endowment.

fields.headline: Policing asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: Kent police aim to treat asylum seekers with sensitivity, writes Juliet Shedden
fields.trailText: Kent police aim to treat asylum seekers with sensitivity, writes Juliet Shedden
fields.body:
Motorway service stations may not seem the most obvious place to find illegal immigrants. Reports tend to concentrate on refugees entering the country in the back of lorries, such as the 58 Chinese refugees who died in June.

But service stations are common places to find refugees, who are dropped off by lorry drivers and found by the police after a tip-off from a member of the public, according to Chris Eyre, superintendent and area commander of south-east Kent police. More often than not, the asylum seekers are waiting for the authorities to arrest them so that their applications for asylum are processed more quickly.

While other forces take refugees straight to the Home Office in Croydon, Kent police arrest them and escort them to Dover police station, where they are questioned and remain in custody, sometimes for up to eight hours. Officers from the Immigration Service then assess their right to asylum.

With Dover on its doorstep, and 6,000 immigrants arriving each month, Kent police can make up to 100 arrests at a time, and that is a strain on resources. Eyre has fought hard to get extra funding, and requests for more staff have resulted in the appointment of two officers. "We could take an extra 50 but we would still be understaffed," he says.

In October 1999 Kent police developed a strategy to cope with the influx of refugees. Officers are trained to understand the customs and culture of the aslyum seekers and the political situation from which they have fled. Other constabularies such as Northumbria, Devon and Cornwall have followed suit by introducing the training for their officers.

Plain clothed officers maintain contact with the aslyum seekers' community by visiting guesthouses and drop-in centres. Specialist officers are also trained to react to racist attacks and encourage asylum seekers to report any racist incidents to the police.

However Eyre says victims of crime often prefer to keep quiet. "Many asylum seekers believe that if they report an incident to a police officer it will adversely affect their application for asylum." Kent police have introduced "incident books" into guesthouses, so that racist incidents can be reported in an informal manner and without naming the people involved.

Reports about asylum seekers perpetuate racist opinions, says Eyre. "An article in the Star newspaper was talking about 'Slovak gypsies', it sounded like 1930's Germany.That legitimises racism, it makes our job difficult, adding to the constant pressure."

In a attack on the government's record on race relations, the UN expressed "deep concern" over the number of racist attacks in Britain. Eyre believes national papers should cover these issues more responsibly.

He suggests that police need a new approach to integrate asylum seekers into communities, following the decision by the Home Office in April to disperse asylum communities into new areas. Some police forces in Britain are ill equipped and inexperienced in policing this area.

Kent police has drawn up a "good practice guide" in conjunction with the Refugee Council, which has been distributed as a working draft to police around the country. But, says Eyre: "It is easy to see it on paper, but we need to make a change in how people are working on a day to day basis. It is hard work to make principles turn into working practices."

fields.headline: The cost of asylum
fields.standfirst: Juliet Shedden reviews the government's investment in initiatives to support asylum seekers
fields.trailText: Juliet Shedden reviews the government's investment in initiatives to support asylum seekers
fields.body:
In April this year the Home Office established the National Asylum Support Service to support the growing number of asylum seekers entering the country. NASS, as the new service is known, is administered privately by the US firm Sodexho and funded by the Home Office.

The department is also to receive an extra £600m to recruit more staff to deal with asylum claims, taking the number involved from 6,500 earlier this year to 11,000 over the next two years. The extra money comes on top of a £400m a year budget increase over the next three years announced in the comprehensive spending review.

All this expansion is needed to cope with a backlog of 102,870 people seeking asylum in this country. By January, the government wants 70% of all new asylum claims to receive an initial decision within two months. A further four months is to be allowed for appeals. It currently takes 13 months on average for an asylum case to be resolved.

Last year London boroughs spent £300m looking after 68,000 asylum seekers but they have been warned not to be complacen about the service they offer. The Audit Commission's report A Balanced View found that less than a third of London boroughs had a long-term strategy for coping with asylum seekers and fewer than a quarter had carried out a detailed assessment of their needs.

The report showed that some boroughs were spending up to four times more than others. For example, Westminster spent £450 per week supporting families but Haringey only spent £100 per week. The reason for these discrepancies is not known and there is a little correlation between a borough's wealth, the amount spent per asylum seekers and the level of services available.

webTitle: Using the Human Rights Act in campaigns

fields.headline: Opening doors
fields.standfirst: Kendra Inman examines how charities can use the Human Rights Act in campaigns
fields.trailText: Kendra Inman examines how charities can use the Human Rights Act in campaigns.
fields.body:
The government wants the Human Rights Act to change hearts and minds as well as practice. It hopes to create a climate in which organisations take care not to infringe the rights of others.

Help the Aged already campaigns for improved rights for older people. The charity sees the Act as offering further opportunities to improve the lot of older people in Britain. The Act's potential in this area was highlighted at a seminar last month.

Article 14 of the Act focuses on discrimination. The definition is a broad one. It says that the rights and freedoms in the European convention on human rights should be enjoyed by everyone without discrimination on grounds such as sex, race, colour, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, association with a national minority, property, birth or other status.

Age isn't explicitly stated but barrister Murray Hunt points out that the phrase "any other status" has been interpreted by the court in Strasbourg as leaving the door open for the courts to add other grounds on which to ban discrimination. The court has yet to examine whether age discrimination could also be outlawed.

The mandatory retirement age is a good example of a rule that could be challenged under Article 12 or Article 14 in the future, Hunt thinks.

There is also room for older people to fight health authority or local council decisions such as those governing where people live. Articles eight and 14, the measures covering private and family life and discrimination respectively could be used by someone who wants to be cared for in their own home rather than be moved into residential care. The burden would be on the public authority to justify moving the client against their will.

When it comes to mental health problems, Article five - the right to liberty - and Article 6 (1) - the right to a fair trial - could be used to beef up the rights of people who "lack capacity".

The charity Victim Support has been looking at how the Act can help victims and witnesses of crime, and the opportunities it might provide to enforce existing measures which have been introduced to benefit them.

If the police fail to protect people at risk from domestic violence or racial harassment in instances where there is a known threat, by a known person, there could be grounds for taking a case under the Act. It could also provide redress in cases such as the murder of Stephen Lawrence, where the police failed to investigate properly.

The Act could be used to shore up new legislation such as the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999 which provides for vulnerable witnesses to have access to measures such as video links to allow them to give evidence comfortably in court. At the moment even if such facilities are available in courts, they are not always used.

Article 3, which prohibits degrading treatment, and Article 8, which ensures privacy, also hold out the promise of improving the treatment of witnesses and victims. Cross-examination can be oppressive and intimidating at the hands of some barristers. It could also be argued that the disclosure of counselling or medical records without someone's knowledge infringes their right to privacy.

Balancing the rights of defendants with the rights of victims and witnesses is important. But there is still considerable mileage for improving the treatment of those who get a raw deal from the criminal justice system.

fields.headline: European lobbying lessons for charities
fields.standfirst: Liz Clements explains how to raise your charity's profile in Brussels
fields.trailText: Liz Clements explains how to raise your charity's profile in Brussels.
fields.body:
Why lobby in Europe?
The voluntary sector receives substantial amounts of funding from European Union programmes and is increasingly affected by EU legislation and policy. The EU dimension is one that can no longer be ignored and many British voluntary organisations are already active at EU level, working with European commission civil servants and members of the European parliament to advance the sector's concerns. If you need to consider lobbying in Europe, don't be put off by the complicated structures and procedures of the EU institutions. There are many sources of information and a plethora of Brussels-based voluntary sector networks that can offer advice.

The European commission

The commission is the EU's civil service and has responsibility for policy formulation and for drafting legislation. Each department or directorate general (DG) has responsibility for a specific policy area and is headed by a commissioner. To lobby effectively, you need to identify the DG dealing with your policy area and the relevant officials within that DG. Commission civil servants are accustomed to receiving visits from lobbyists, so if you have the resources to make a trip to Brussels, take advantage of the opportunity to do some face-to-face lobbying.

The European parliament

Most of the parliament's work is done in committees, and it is worth building contacts with members of the European parliament who sit on the committees most relevant to your areas of concern. In addition, there is a range of parliamentary intergroups. These bring together MEPs with a common interest in a specific issue or policy field. Working with an intergroup can be an effective way to raise the profile of your issues. MEPs have much easier access to official documents than voluntary organisations and can often be persuaded to intervene with commission officials on specific issues. Commissioners attend a Question Time session so, just as at Westminster, a parliamentary question can be an effective way to raise an issue. If you intend to visit the European parliament frequently, apply for a long-term visitor's pass. It gives you access for one year. Details of the application procedure are available from the Office of the Quaestors in the European parliament, or via the London office of the parliament.

The council of ministers
The council of ministers is the executive of the EU and takes the final decisions on legislative proposals. The day-to-day work of the council is carried out by the sectoral groupings of member state ministers who meet regularly throughout the year. To lobby effectively at EU level, you need to maintain contact with UK ministers and Whitehall civil servants with a European brief. Although the bulk of policy formulation takes place in Brussels, the member state governments have the final say.

The UK Representation in Brussels

The UK Representation in Brussels (UKREP) is the UK government's mission to the EU. UKREP is a good source of information regarding the agendas of the sectoral council meetings and the progress of legislative projects.

Brussels networks
Voluntary organisations across the EU work together in networks because they have recognised that, in order to have impact, policy and legislative proposals must have the support of a number of member states. Several of the more established networks have secretariats based in Brussels and maintain websites that publish information about current lobbying projects.

Useful information sources

Vachers European Companion is a regularly updated guide to EU institutions with useful names and contact numbers. A directory of MEPs and the European parliament calendar can be obtained from the library of the parliament's London office. The weekly newspaper European Voice focuses on the work of the EU institutions.

 Liz Clements is the European officer at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations. She previously worked for various international development agencies as a lobbyist on EU trade and aid policies. She makes regular lobby visits to Brussels.

fields.headline: Sustainable support systems
fields.standfirst: Community foundations could ensure that neighbourhood renewal is sustained
fields.trailText: Community foundations could ensure that neighbourhood renewal is sustained
fields.body:
Community foundations were first set up in the US more than 85 years ago as an ongoing way to help local community initiatives. Today 600 communities benefit from local funding which should last forever.

The idea is for the foundation to build an endowment fund from which it can make grants, rather than operating on an ad hoc basis, trying to raise finance from year to year, from one funding crisis to another. Foundations seek donations from local businesses and wealthy people, and sometimes administer grant giving for family and business trusts.

The UK has only caught on to this idea in the last two decades but already 30 foundations have been set up across the UK and another 30 are being developed.

Community foundations in the UK have given out more than £21m of grants so far this year, the highest level ever, and aim to hit a £100m target for endowment by the end of December. Each community foundation works in a specific geographical area to help identify local community needs and promote and support charitable activity.

The Community Foundation Network (CFN) exists to promote community foundations in the UK. The latest figures show that foundations have added nearly £80m to their total endowments since statistics were first compiled in 1992-93.

Clare Brooks, CFN's development manager says it takes up to two years to develop a community foundation. Anyone can set one up. "The important thing is to have a long-standing commitment to the local area," says Brooks. The next step is to talk to local people and movers and shakers to generate support for the idea. "You have to be really sensitive and bring people on board," Brooks adds. CFN usually advises that the foundation should make a few grants to demonstrate the impact it can make.

Charities are often criticised for amassing reserves but the purpose of a community foundation is to build up an endowment so that grants can be made in perpetuity. Brooks says: "It is a delicate balance, grants must be made thoughtfully and donors' wishes must be respected."If a donor doesn't want to give to an endowment, they can give to so-called "flow-through" funds for immediate needs.

The growth of some foundations has been phenomenal. At the end of last year the Essex community foundation had capital assets of £600,303. It has now amassed almost £4m. The Birmingham and Heart of England foundations have almost trebled in size during the year. And the Foundation for Greater Manchester has increased its funds by £2m, following a campaign in the local newspaper and an offer of matched funding by the Duke of Westminster.

fields.headline: Payroll giving gains favour
fields.standfirst: Charities are increasingly benefiting from regular donations by marketing their cause to company staff
fields.trailText: Charities are increasingly benefiting from regular donations by marketing their cause to company staff
fields.body:
A growing number of employers are introducing payroll giving schemes or actively promoting existing ones - which can sometimes lead to a major increase in donations.

Accountancy firm Deloitte & Touche, for example, increased its number of payroll givers from 40 to 560 in two years, following a scheme relaunch, while Tesco increased its givers from 1,000 to 6,000.

It is not only new incentives introduced by the government that have led employers to take payroll giving more seriously. It is also the growing recognition of the importance of corporate citizenship and a realisation that giving schemes can improve staff relations and provide good company PR.

But while payroll giving is becoming more widespread, there is also increasing competition among charities. Sharing the Caring, which promotes payroll giving and has about 100 charity clients, half of which are national and half regional, is turning down some new charities because it can only represent a limited number when visiting employers.

Christine Jenkins, managing director of Sharing the Caring, argues that charities must take more responsibility for developing links with companies, perhaps using agencies for internal canvassing once an employer has agreed to set up a scheme.

Stephen Haxby, corporate fundraising manager at United Response, which works with people with learning difficulties, agrees that the market is becoming more crowded. "Like legacy fundraising, there's growing competition and you have to spend more to make an impact on potential donors," he says.

This means taking out advertisements in company magazines and investing in good design for literature distributed to employees by payroll giving agencies.

Low churn rate
United Response is also trying to develop good relationships with staff at payroll giving agencies to help them learn more about the charity and thereby represent it more effectively in presentations to employees."We're also targeting employers that we already have links with, such as housing associations, as well as companies in our local area," he adds.

As with any fundraising, balancing investment with returns is an important factor. United Response's average payroll donation is £5 a month, while it pays its agency £40 for each donor. "As we keep them for several years, on average the fee is reasonable," says Haxby, adding that the "churn rate" for donors is relatively low, at 10% a year. "It's also a relatively predictable and low-maintenance form of fundraising," he says.

As with other forms of fundraising, it is difficult for small and medium-sized charities to compete with the large voluntary organisations that can invest huge sums, not just on fundraising campaigns but also on general awareness raising.

"It's tough for charities like us," Haxby says, "but we can achieve a lot by looking at how to improve relationships with donors, such as keeping them more closely informed about what we're doing with their donations."

Wolverhampton-based Compton Hospice employs a fundraiser 20 hours a week to approach local employers - including schools - about payroll giving, and also uses the agency Caring Together.

Judy Polkinhorn, head of fundraising at Compton Hospice, says:"We are trying to develop a more holistic approach so that if a company does not want to set up payroll giving we can suggest other ways they may want to give us help."
