fields.headline: Top ten fundraising tips
fields.standfirst: Howard Lake offers advice for newcomers on how to raise money for charity
fields.trailText: Howard Lake offers advice for newcomers on how to raise money for charity.
fields.body:
1. The first rule of fundraising is don't be afraid to approach the "right people" for money, ie those who are sympathetic to your cause. You need to carefully consider how much to ask them for. Some will be able to donate money; some their time; others may leave a legacy or bequest.

2. This means researching people before approaching them. Ask yourself: "Does this person or organisation have an interest in my charity?"

3. Ask people who have already given, but think about when they last donated. Do not ask them for money a week afterwards.

4. To encourage people to donate regularly, suggest that they set up a monthly direct debit.

5. Ask people to give tax efficiently with a "gift aid" form. This form has been in use since 1989 but the minimum donation was recently reduced to £1.

6. Ask other people to help you. Challenge members of your charity's board of trustees to "give, get, or get off".

7. Communicate regularly with your supporters. You may use direct mail, but do not mass produce letters. Write to your supporters personally, and tell them how their money is being spent. This will encourage them to continue donating.

8. Think about how you might address different audiences and seek donations from different sources, eg grant-making trusts, individuals, the national lottery, the UK government, Europe and fundraising events.

9. Do not forget to learn your charity law. There are a number of requirements, responsibilities and duties you need to know about before you begin to raise funds. For information contact the Charity Commission which provides up to date guides.

10. Finally, do not forget to thank donors. This is just as important as asking for money. It is polite, ethical and good business. It is also an effective way of making donors feel good about supporting your charity.

 Howard Lake heads Fundraising UK which operates the UK Fundraising website.

webTitle: Old prejudices still blight women managers

fields.headline: Old prejudices still blight women managers
fields.standfirst: Helen Froud examines the pressures and choices facing the few women bosses in the public sector
fields.trailText: Helen Froud examines the pressures and choices facing the few women chiefs in the public sector.
fields.body:
Public sector employers have an enviable reputation for providing equality of opportunity for women. But the private sector is catching up. The national management salary survey 2000 by the Institute of Management and consultancy Remuneration Economics shows that 9.6% of women are at director level in the private sector - compared with 10.3% in the public sector.

And a ground-breaking study of women chief executives in local government, sponsored by PriceWaterhouseCoopers, has shown that female public sector managers feel as vulnerable and isolated as they did 20 years ago. According to the research, women still feel judged by their physical appearance rather than their ability and it seems that what a senior woman wears is as important as what she does at work.

Pam Fox, joint author of the study with Mike Broussine and a visiting research fellow at the University of West of England, tells of an aspiring chief executive who overheard a member of a selection panel say: "You can tell she's hard by the shape of her lips". She adds that men and women perceive senior women as lacking charisma and presence, especially if they are physically small, or young-looking.

That's not all. The Equal Pay Act has been in force for 25 years in December 2000, but womens' pay in the public sector still falls well short of equality. The latest figures, drawn from 1999, shows public sector women still earning only 81.7% of the salary of their male colleagues. Only teachers, with a strong national pay structure and an industry-specific review board come anywhere close to parity, at 89.9%.

Across local government, from social services to environmental health, and from waste disposal to clerical work, traditional divisions of labour persist along gender lines. Women are over-represented in professions that rarely make it to the top, such as social care and human resources. And while a growing number of women are entering public accountancy and law - common backgrounds for public sector chief executives - relatively few make it to the top of their professional tree.

But the Fox-Broussine research also found that women are making up their own rules for career advancement. And that can only be good news for men and women alike. No longer forced down a traditional path of unbroken career advancement, many new women at the top have moved from one employment sector to another, gaining valuable experience as they go.

Wider perspective
One example is Stella Manzie, chief example of the newly formed unitary local authority in West Berkshire. A Cambridge graduate with a degree in English, Manzie has worked for the now-defunct Association of County Councils and also as private sector management consultant. 'The fact that I don't come from a particular professional background has given me a wider perspective', she says. 'My private sector experience taught me to deliver work to a tight timescale and on budget, and has given me credibility.'

So how can senior and aspiring women make that all-important career move? Rita Sammons, a former president of the Society of Chief Personnel Officers in local government, suggests that women take time out to develop themselves and their career. "Get involved in national projects, high-profile partnerships and network", she says. "If you raise your profile, people will remember you - there are still so few senior women around.' Sammons suggests that women should aim high: "The next step is probably easier than you think. If it isn't, decide what support you need to get there."

Public sector headhunters agree with her, and advise women to be more demanding when they look for career advancement. Maurice Smart from local government headhunters TMP Worldwide says that too few women ask for the help they're entitled to. "If you apply for a job through a professional recruitment consultancy, make sure you get measured feedback both on your application and your interview performance", he says. "Women often understate their achievements on their CV and don't include enough hard facts."

Smart suggests that women need to make sure their CV works hard for them. "Don't be shy about telling a future employer about budgets you've managed, productivity gains you've achieved or changes you've made" he says. "Ask for advice on how to tailor your application to the vacancy."

 For further information on the research project, contact: pamfox@business84.freeserve.co.uk

webTitle: Social regeneration: the Isle of Dogs community foundation

fields.headline: Social regeneration: the Isle of Dogs community foundation
fields.standfirst: A charity's success stems from encouraging local groups to match its spending on projects aimed at enlivening the community
fields.trailText: A charity's success stems from encouraging local groups to match its spending on projects aimed at enlivening the community.
fields.body:
This month we focus on a charity based in one of the poorest parts of London, whose income is growing exponentially. The Isle of Dogs Community Foundation (ICDF), which is 10 years old, describes itself as a social regeneration agency involving partnership between the community, public and private sectors. It aims to create vibrant communities in Millwall and Blackwall through grants for training and employment, education and community development.

In 1998/99 the foundation made grants of £1.2m to more than 100 local groups, serving 23,000 people. In the previous year, grants totalled £469,000.

Last month the IDCF approved a further £1.15m in grants for local organisations. The three projects which will benefit from the latest round are Outreach Work in Blackwall and Millwall led by the Docklands Outreach Company, an employee volunteering scheme led by the East London Business Alliance and Green Spaces Initiative led by Trees for London. The foundation has itself received Single Regeneration Budget (SRB) funding worth nearly £3.8m from the government.

The foundation is currently completing new SRB and ESF bids and it continually campaigns for extra funds so that organisations can build their comunities for the future.

Local companies such as Barclays Capital, Canary Wharf Group, Credit Suisse First Boston, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, State Street Bank, Trinity Mirror, Euler Trade Indemnity, Citibank and Texac contribute to the foundation's success.

Chris Mossop, chair of the foundation, says: "Local support for the IDCF has been a major factor in developing the regeneration process on the island, but much still remains to be achieved."

Earlier in the year the IDCF installed computer equipment at 20 community organisations on the Isle of Dogs to allow greater internet access and, in the long term, to set up a local online community.

Mossop says: "It is only by presenting people with opportunities for self-development, that we will be able to reverse some of the significant underachievement that can lead to the more profound problems in the area."

In the coming year, IDFC's attention will be focused on:

 Supporting community groups in their bids for IDCF, SRB and other grants, and by helping them implement and deliver their projects.

 Working in partnership with the East London Business Alliance to promote employee volunteering; providing professional support to community and voluntary sector groups, and developing mutually beneficial relationships between islanders and the local business community.

 Identifying and supporting the development of bids for additional funding such as European funds, to enable community and voluntary groups to continue to provide and enhance their services for local people. Capacity building is the key to the development and success of local community groups.

Mossop concludes: "The task ahead is a serious one and whilst the need for day to day support in the community can be provided through the grants process - beyond it lies a more deep-rooted need to identify and support initiatives that can really make a difference."

 For further information about the foundation, call: 020 7345 4444.

webTitle: Analysis: National Audit Office report on the dome

fields.headline: Millennial hall of shame
fields.standfirst:
David Hencke examines the damning conclusions reached by the Audit Office report

Full text: National Audit Office report
fields.trailText: David Hencke examines the damning conclusions reached by the Audit Office report.
fields.body:
Lord Falconer - Tony Blair's close friend, former flatmate and minister of state at the Cabinet Office - is under growing pressure to resign after today's publication of the National Audit Office report into the £1bn Millennium Dome fiasco.

The report condemns the project for grossly miscalculating the number of potential visitors - now 4.5m instead of the promised 12m - and not having robust financial controls . As a result the loss of income from both sponsorship (down nearly £50m) and income meant it was bailed out with £179m of lottery cash this year.

The report condemns the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, and the Millennium Commission, which oversaw the operation of the dome, and accuses ministers of failing to get a grip on the issue.

The report indicates that culture secretary Chris Smith, the chairman of the Millennium Commission who twice had to overrule his director and order cash to save the collapsing enterprise, realised something was badly wrong as early as February this year. He tried to get Lord Falconer to get things put right. This will be probably enough to save him from further embarrassment.

Lord Falconer, however- according to the correspondence released - promised to sort everything out last March but ended up being totally shocked at the shambles revealed in September after the dome failed to find a buyer.

The report explains in stunning detail how Lord Falconer - who attended the board meetings of the company- was kept informed of the steadily deteriorating situation by the external auditors, Ernst and Young, but still told parliament that everything was OK and the dome was not insolvent.

Later advice by the new chief executive, David James, warned that the attraction had been running as a technically insolvent organisation since February.

As for the company directors of the failed enterprise, in May they applied for a special government indemnity to ensure they would not be out of pocket if the whole project went belly-up half way through the year. They got their way in June - two months before another £100m was into the dome.

webTitle: Gore team cite 'substantial irregularities' with vote

fields.headline: Gore team cite 'substantial irregularities' with vote
fields.standfirst: Graphic: see the Florida ballot paper
fields.trailText: A conclusive answer to who will be the next US president looks unlikely to emerge imminently, even though the crucial recount in Florida, where the vote is on a knife edge, is expected to finish today.
fields.body:
A conclusive answer to who will be the next US president looks unlikely to emerge imminently, even though the crucial recount in Florida, where the vote is on a knife edge, is expected to finish today.

Delays of days, or even weeks, on a clear outcome look increasingly likely with the Democrats alleging serious irregularities with the layout of the voting paper in some counties in Florida.

Within Florida, Al Gore has trimmed 843 votes off George W Bush's lead, thanks to disputed results coming in from Palm Beach County.

Mr Gore, the vice president, gained 1,189 votes from Palm Beach County, compared with 346 votes gained for Mr Bush. With 32 of the state's 67 counties finishing their recounts on Wednesday, that meant Mr Gore cut Mr Bush's lead by more than half, leaving the vice president just 941 votes behind the Texas governor.

The recount in Florida was expected to finish by the end of the day, but, if it is very tight, there could be a delay of days while postal votes are accounted for. Whoever, wins in Florida would gain 25 electoral college votes - enough to be declared president.

However, William Daley, Mr Gore's campaign chairman, today called for four disrict counties in Florida to be hand counted.

"Technicalities should not determine the president of the United States, the will of the people should," Mr Daley said in Florida, where some voters say that confusing ballots may have led them to vote for Pat Buchanan when they meant to support the vice president.

Mr Daley said that the 19,120 votes in Palm Beach County which have been ruled invalid for being punched twice, amounted to a "disenfranchisement".

"We've come to believe that there are serious and substantial irregularities resulting from the ballot used only in one county," added the former secretary of state, Warren Christopher, dispatched to Florida to protect the Gore campaign's interests.

Mr Daley said they were not trying to hold up the process but attacked the Bush camp for "blithely dismissing the disenfranchisement as being the usual type of mistake made in elections".

In his short statement yesterday, Mr Gore did not say that he would accept the result of the Florida recount and there is a possibility that he may mount a supreme court challenge if the White House is awarded to Mr Bush.

The recount in Florida was triggered by state law because Mr Bush led Mr Gore by less than one-half of 1%.

Allegations of voting improprieties surfaced late on Tuesday and continued yesterday, ranging from missing and confusing ballots to problems with tabulations and voter intimidation.

"If there are concerns, let the process work," said Jeb Bush, governor of Flordida and the younger brother of the Republican nominee. "But don''t over exaggerate things."

Throughout the state, Democrats and some voters complained of irregularities in the election. In Palm Beach and Osceola counties, Democratic party lawyers and voters said that ballots were confusing because of their configuration.

Officials in Palm Beach earlier announced that 19,120 ballots in the presidential race were tossed out before they were counted because more than one candidate was picked. Only 3,783 voters made that mistake on the US Senate portion of the ballot.

"That total is a high number," said Palm Beach County Commissioner Carol Roberts, who is part of the canvassing board that is conducting the recount.

In Miami-Dade, Broward, and other counties, the Gore campaign complained about delays in the delivery of ballot boxes to counting places.

Democrats set up a toll-free number where Florida voters could report irregularities. Mr Daley said they would support voters making legal moves to address the "disenfranchisement".

Civil rights activists Jesse Jackson and Kweisi Mfume, the president of the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People, said that they received complaints that blacks had difficulty voting.

They said that some voters were told that there were no more ballots, or that polls were closed.

Jeb Bush said that he has seen no indications of fraud. But Mr Mfume called for federal marshals to oversee the ballot recount and asked the US justice department to investigate.

The latest Florida totals before the recount, including all absentee ballots that had been received, showed Mr Bush with 2,909,135 votes and Gore with 2,907,351 - a difference of 1,784 in a state with 8.75m registered voters.

Even as the recount proceeded, elections supervisors waited for the undetermined number of overseas ballots, primarily from military personnel and their families.

The state counted about 2,300 overseas ballots in the 1996 presidential election and allows 10 days to count them, as long as they are postmarked no later than election day.

Because of his vested interest in the outcome, the Florida governor removed himself from the panel that will certify results of the recount.

The other members of the panel - the secretary of state, Katherine Harris, and state elections director Clay Roberts - are also Republicans.

But the state's top Democratic official, the attorney general, Bob Butterworth, expressed confidence that the recount will be fair.

"All of us recognize the importance that every vote is correctly counted," Mr Butterworth said. "I can also assure the rest of the nation that there's no way governor Jeb Bush or secretary of state Harris would certify election results ... if they had any doubt at all that the election was not in perfect order."

Democratic Party officials and hundreds of voters complained about the way ballots in Palm Beach County were arranged.

Voters punched holes in the middle of the ballot, while candidates were alternately listed to the left and then the right.

"It was virtually impossible to know who you voted for," said Mark Hirsch, a 30-year-old business executive who voted for Green party candidate Ralph Nader.

Some Gore supporters in Palm Beach County said they feared that they mistakenly voted for Reform party candidate Pat Buchanan.

Mr Gore carried the county by more than 110,000 votes, but the 3,407 votes for Buchanan were by far the most of any Florida county, and almost 20% of his total vote in the state.

However, Republicans noted that the ballot was approved by Democrat Theresa LePore, the county supervisor of elections.

The state counted about 2,300 overseas ballots in the 1996 presidential election and allows 10 days to count them, as long as they are postmarked no later than election day. Because of his vested interest in the outcome, the Florida governor removed himself from the panel that will certify results of the recount. The other members of the panel - the secretary of state, Katherine Harris, and state elections director Clay Roberts - are also Republicans. But the state's top Democratic official, the attorney general, Bob Butterworth, expressed confidence that the recount will be fair. "All of us recognize the importance that every vote is correctly counted," Mr Butterworth said. "I can also assure the rest of the nation that there's no way governor Jeb Bush or secretary of state Harris would certify election results ... if they had any doubt at all that the election was not in perfect order." Democratic Party officials and hundreds of voters complained about the way ballots in Palm Beach County were arranged. Voters punched holes in the middle of the ballot, while candidates were alternately listed to the left and then the right. "It was virtually impossible to know who you voted for," said Mark Hirsch, a 30-year-old business executive who voted for Green party candidate Ralph Nader. Some Gore supporters in Palm Beach County said they feared that they mistakenly voted for Reform party candidate Pat Buchanan. Mr Gore carried the county by more than 110,000 votes, but the 3,407 votes for Buchanan were by far the most of any Florida county, and almost 20% of his total vote in the state. However, Republicans noted that the ballot was approved by Democrat Theresa LePore, the county supervisor of elections. webTitle: Councils aim for community leadership role

fields.headline: Councils aim for community leadership role
fields.standfirst: Local authorities expect to become leaders of their communities but fear a loss of control of key services
fields.trailText: Local authorities expect to become leaders of their communities but fear a loss of control of key services
fields.body:
No one yet knows if the government was really serious about the idea of bypassing councils in the funding of education and social services.

Frontline first funding, as it is called, only ever existed as a series of leaks to the national and trade press, probably handed out by officials at the Department for Education and the Department of Health.

But that was enough to keep councils holding their breath for more than six months, as they wondered whether the axe would fall during this summer's slew of policy announcements.

In the event, the comprehensive spending review, local government finance green paper and NHS national plan did not dismember councils, but the anxiety they created is a sign of just how nervous local government has become about its future.

There is widespread agreement that councils need to reassess what they do and take on a new role as community leaders. But there is equally widespread disagreement about what a community leader should do.

Local government has been moving away from its role as a large-scale service provider for some time. This process was accelerated by the Conservative compulsory competitive tendering regime, which forced councils to move towards an enabling role.

An influential think tank, the New Local Government Network, wants this process to continue with councils becoming strategic bodies capable of resolving local problems and joining up the work of other agencies to improve the lives of their citizens.

The Local Government Association takes a softer line. While it has always fought to defend the role of the council in service delivery, it argues that service provision is just one way to achieve the right outcomes.

"Community leadership involves councils working in partnership with local people and organisations to develop a shared vision for the future for their locality, identifying immediate priorities for action and then working together to make a difference in local communities," says chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham.

The LGA cites a Devon county council scheme as an example of good practice. The county is training residents in the basics of consumer law, turning them into watchdogs with direct lines to trading standards officers. The association also highlights a Durham county council scheme that involves local communities in a wide partnership backed by funding from the Millennium Commission that is designed to regenerate the area's coastline.

The government is beginning to provide powers to promote community leadership. Its recently passed Local Government Act hands councils a power to promote the social, environmental and economic well-being of communities. This is in effect a legal framework that allows authorities limited freedom to do anything not prohibited by law.

Legislation expected in the Queen's Speech could add further powers. A bill to take forward the NHS plan could increase the role councils have in scrutinising the health service, and if the government decides on a housing bill, it may emphasise the role of authorities in ensuring that local housing needs are met.

Ministers have not, however, defined what they want from community leading councils, hoping that local government can develop its own definitions. This leaves authorities in a double bind, in which the government may give strategic powers with one hand and take away high-spending services with the other.

The comprehensive spending review, NHS plan and local government finance green paper may not have been as apocalyptic as some feared, but they did set out plans for the separate identification of school and local education authority budgets and raise the possibility that social services could be transferred into new care trusts. If councils are to fend off a creeping erosion of their powers, they must grab and lead the debate over community leadership.

fields.headline: Boost for child tax credit
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Some 5m families could be up to £520 a year better off if the chancellor delivers on a promise to increase the new family tax relief, the children's tax credit, which is due to replace the married couple's allowance next April. CTC, which will will be available to married or unmarried couples and single parents with at least one child under 16 living with them, is due to reduce the amount of income tax families pay by up to £442 a year or £8.50 a week when it is first introduced.
fields.body:
Some 5m families could be up to £520 a year better off if the chancellor delivers on a promise to increase the new family tax relief, the children's tax credit, which is due to replace the married couple's allowance next April. CTC, which will will be available to married or unmarried couples and single parents with at least one child under 16 living with them, is due to reduce the amount of income tax families pay by up to £442 a year or £8.50 a week when it is first introduced.

But the chancellor indicated yesterday that he intends to improve this deal. "I believe in the coming Budget we can offer a larger tax cut for families," he said. "My aim is to increase the family tax cut to £10 a week, in total a £520 a year tax cut."

Child Poverty Action Group director Martin Barnes said the £1.50 a week increase in CTC was welcome, but limited. "The chancellor has demonstrated in the past his dogged and persistent commitment to families and children. But sadly there was very little new in this statement today. The government still has a mountain to climb if it is to achieve its goal of eradicating child poverty. We look forward to a more ambitious programme to tackle child poverty in the next full Budget."

The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children also said more was required to end child poverty.

"We need a coherent national strategy for preventing and eradicatting child poverty," a spokesman said. "At its core must be a new minimum in come standard to maintain the health and well-being of the most vulnerable children."

The National Council for One Parent Families was more buoyant in its response, describing measures announced by the chancellor as an, "excellent boost" for lone parents. In particular, it welcomed news that the government's new deal for lone parents programme is to receive a £23m injection to extend it to all lone parents who are out of work or who are working less than 16 hours a week.

At present the voluntary programme, which gives lone parents a comprehensive package of advice on job search, training and in-work benefits plus financial help with child care, travel costs and course fees, is restricted to lone parents who claim income support. From autumn 2001, it will be extended to include those who, for whatever reason, are unable to claim this means-tested benefit.

"It's very good news for these 150,000 lone parents who will benefit greatly from the help available," said the council's policy and research officer Alison Garnham. "They'll be very pleased that they can get the help everyone else receives."

For details on CTC, call the government's tax credit helpline on 0845 300 1036. Lone parents wanting to take advantage of the new deal should contact their local job centre.

The speech in full
Part 1: the economy
Part 2: the fiscal stance
Part 3: families and pensioners

fields.headline: More money on the table for the elderly
fields.standfirst:
Basic weekly income rises 
Lobbyists unsatisfied

Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday gave a cash boost to the elderly - raising pensions and increasing the winter allowance. But the chancellor refused to bow to calls for restoration of a long-term link between the state pension and earnings.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday gave a cash boost to the elderly - raising pensions and increasing the winter allowance. But the chancellor refused to bow to calls for restoration of a long-term link between the state pension and earnings.

The chancellor said that the basic rate for single pensioners would rise by £5 a week next April, taking the total to £72.50.

Pensioner couples will see their basic weekly total rise next year by £8 to £115.90. He said rises in 2002 of £3 for single pensioners and £4.80 for couples would further boost pensioner income.

There will also be an immediate increase in the winter fuel allowance. Each pensioner household will get a cheque worth £200, compared to £100 last year and the £150 expected before yesterday's announcement.

Pensioner groups welcomed the inflation busting rises but vowed to carry on their fight to link rises in the state pension with rises in earnings. Jack Jones, president of the National Pensioners' Convention, said: "We also need to end the reliance on means-tested benefits. The announcement only comes about because of the pressure put on the government by the pensioner movement."

Help the Aged said pensioners would be reassured but not satisfied with the package. "It fails to give an adequate guarantee about the long-term value of the basic state pension, which is being left to wither on the vine."

From April the government's pensions top-up - the minimum income guarantee - will provide £92.15 for single pensioners and £140.55 for couples. The chancellor said the rate was likely to increase to at least £100 for a single pensioner and £154 for a couple by 2003.

"The government's tax and benefits reforms will mean that next year the average pensioner household will be £580 - over £11 a week - better off since 1997," the Treasury said.

The chancellor presented his concessions as transitional arrangements before the introduction of the pension credit in 2003. The credit is designed to prevent pensioners on low incomes from missing out on benefit rises announced as part of the minimum income guarantee.

At the moment extra income from savings or a small private pension is offset against benefits, wiping out some or all of the income support payments added to the state pension under the guarantee.

The chancellor said yesterday that from April 2003, when the credit is introduced, single pensioners with a total income of less than £130 will be allowed to keep their benefits. For couples the threshold will be £200.

The introduction of the mimimum income guarantee and the pension credit have been criticised by pensioner groups. Help the Aged said the increasing use of benefits to boost pensioner income would "turn even more older people into form-filling supplicants".

Social security secretary Alistair Darling is today due to outline the detailed workings of the credit.

webTitle: Mental health and the Human Rights Act

fields.headline: Rights to know
fields.standfirst: Health workers must get to grips with the Human Rights Act, writes Andrew Parsons
fields.trailText: Health workers must get to grips with the Human Rights Act, writes Andrew Parsons.
fields.body:
What is the Human Rights Act?
The Human Rights Act came into force on October 2 2000. It incorporates directly into English law most of the provisions of the European Convention on Human Rights.

What does the Act do?
The Act gives all persons certain basic human rights (which are known as "articles" and are listed at the end of the Act). Some are absolute rights and others are qualified, which means there may be situations where infringement of these rights are justified.

Who does the Act apply to?
The Act applies to all authorities undertaking public functions. This will certainly include the NHS and probably also include private sector mental health care providers looking after NHS patients.

What rights are relevant to mental health law?
The rights most likely to be relevant to mental health law are:

Article 2 - the right to life;

Article 3 - the prohibition of inhuman and degrading treatment;

Article 5 - the right to liberty;

Article 6 - the right to a fair hearing;

Article 8 - the right to a private family life;

The First Protocol - the right to peacefully enjoy possessions.

Why are these rights relevant to mental health law?
Article 5 (the right to liberty) has an exception for the detention of persons of unsound mind. However, the European court of human rights in Strasbourg has already held that to be lawful such a detention must:

 be based on medical opinion;

 be a confinement for a mental disorder;

 continue only for as long as the mental disorder persists;

 be in accordance with the law - in the UK it must therefore be in compliance with the Mental Health Act.

The detention of patients under Sections 2 and 3 of the Mental Health Act (which allow patients to be detained for assessment and treatment) is likely to comply with these requirements. There are however doubts about detention under Section 136 (which allows the police to remove mentally disordered persons from a public to a safe place) or Bournewood (a recent House of Lords case that confirmed that mentally incapacitated and compliant patients could be detained without the need to "Section" them).

Whether any particular treatment is likely to breach Article 3 (the prohibition of inhuman and degrading treatment) will depend on the facts of the case. The European court has already considered whether force feeding a patient is inhuman and degrading (the court held it was not), and whether giving a patient a cheaper psychiatric drug with worse side effects than a more expensive one was inhuman treatment (the court ruled it was).

Article 8 (the right to private and family life) is likely to have implications for mental health in several areas. Patients are likely to rely on this article to ensure that they get visits by family and children, and long-term patients could use it to press for conjugal rights and to ensure that children are not detained without their parents' consent. This article may also be used to challenge powers of search (in conjunction with the right to the peaceable enjoyment of possessions).

Article 6 (the right to a fair hearing) will clearly be applicable to mental health review tribunal hearings, but it is likely that it will also be relevant to hospital managers' hearings. Although these hearings are intended to be informal, there will be an increased need to ensure that the principles of natural justice are observed and that the parties are on a level playing field. This may be done by ensuring that reports are available to everyone in sufficient time (and adjourning the hearing if this is not the case).

The most obvious implication of Article 2 (the right to life) is the issue of suicide. The European court has already held that the article requires hospital authorities to take positive steps to secure an individual's right to life. Where clinical practice permits attempted or actual suicide, this article is likely to be relied on as an additional or further basis for a claim.

So what will the courts do? Can't the Mental Health Act be relied upon?
The courts are required to interpret English law to give effect to the rights set out in the Human Rights Act. In doing so they must take account of European court case. Existing English law (including the Mental Health Act) may, therefore, be interpreted differently from now on.

To give effect to human rights, the courts may make orders requiring authorities to take action, or refrain from acting in breach of the Human Rights Act. Where this is an insufficient remedy, they may also award damages. However, if a judge finds that it is impossible to construe existing English law to give effect to the Human Rights Act, he may make what is known as a "declaration of incompatibility" which authorises a minister of state to change the existing English law by statutory instrument.

What should I do about the Act?
It is important that staff know the implications of the Act. Your initial steps should include a review of policies and procedures to ensure that they are compliant with the Human Rights Act, seeking legal advice where appropriate.

 Andrew Parsons is head of health at Radcliffes solicitors

webTitle: How to stage a party conference event

fields.headline: How to stage a party conference event
fields.standfirst: The party conference season may be over but some people are already planning for next year, writes Sophie Howells
fields.trailText: The party conference season may be over but some people are already planning for next year, writes Sophie Howells
fields.body:
As a leading national disability organisation, Scope has more than 10 years' experience of holding receptions at the annual party conferences. This year, we held a reception at the Labour Party conference to launch our report, Speak for Yourself, which calls for greater state investment in the provision of communication aids for speech impaired people.

Receptions and fringe events at political party conferences can be excellent vehicles for getting campaign messages across in an informal setting, but their purpose must be clear. What's more, they cost money, so you must think hard about the tangible benefit, as you will be competing with hundreds of other fringe events. Planning is essential.

If you want to use a gimmick, make sure it is right for the audience and gives the right impression about your organisation. Wherever possible, involve people who can talk from a personal point of view. At our fringe reception a young woman spoke to the audience through a speech synthesiser. This is much more powerful for an audience than listening to politicians and charity representatives.

Venues book up months in advance, so start looking almost a year beforehand. If possible, use a venue within the security zone as few weary politicians, journalists or other potential guests are likely to be prepared to walk far.

Accessibility also needs planning. Scope has found, many times over, that venues which claim to be accessible to disabled people have overlooked basic needs. Make sure venues are checked out thoroughly by disabled people before booking them. Ask a disability organisation for advice. Signers for deaf people in the audience should be booked months in advance through the conference organisers. A hearing loop is another essential, as is ensuring that the lighting in the room will be bright enough for people with visual impairments.

It is very unusual for a venue to allow a reception without the organisation using their "hospitality", ie a few party snacks and wine. This will increase the cost even if most charities opt for the cheapest choices. The best option for a charity is to try to secure a sponsor.

Finally, on the day, ensure that everyone representing your organisation is briefed on the key messages and has a role allocated to them. Your event is an extermal representation of your organisation's professionalism.

Useful tips to remember:

Do:
 get your event into the fringe guide. Deadlines are at least five months ahead
 brief all speakers and emphasise the beauty of short speeches
 send out invitations at least a month in advance and follow up
 remember to turn off your mobiles and pagers during speeches to avoid embarrassing interruptions
 invite a minister to speak if you're using the reception to get a campaigning message across
 brief caterers for the event on the needs of disabled guests
 ask all guests to sign in - this is vital for following up interest that could be of great benefit to your organisation

Do not:
 leave people standing alone
 forget to allocate chaperones for VIPs
 invite anyone at the last minute who doesn't have a security pass - they won't get in
 be disappointed if only a handful of MPs and ministers turn up; the competition is fierce between receptions, so if you get a dozen, you are doing well.

 Sophie Howells is press and PR officer at Scope.

If possible, use a venue within the security zone as few weary politicians, journalists or other potential guests are likely to be prepared to walk far. Accessibility also needs planning. Scope has found, many times over, that venues which claim to be accessible to disabled people have overlooked basic needs. Make sure venues are checked out thoroughly by disabled people before booking them. Ask a disability organisation for advice. Signers for deaf people in the audience should be booked months in advance through the conference organisers. A hearing loop is another essential, as is ensuring that the lighting in the room will be bright enough for people with visual impairments. It is very unusual for a venue to allow a reception without the organisation using their "hospitality", ie a few party snacks and wine. This will increase the cost even if most charities opt for the cheapest choices. The best option for a charity is to try to secure a sponsor. Finally, on the day, ensure that everyone representing your organisation is briefed on the key messages and has a role allocated to them. Your event is an extermal representation of your organisation's professionalism. Useful tips to remember: Do:  get your event into the fringe guide. Deadlines are at least five months ahead  brief all speakers and emphasise the beauty of short speeches  send out invitations at least a month in advance and follow up  remember to turn off your mobiles and pagers during speeches to avoid embarrassing interruptions  invite a minister to speak if you're using the reception to get a campaigning message across  brief caterers for the event on the needs of disabled guests  ask all guests to sign in - this is vital for following up interest that could be of great benefit to your organisation Do not:  leave people standing alone  forget to allocate chaperones for VIPs  invite anyone at the last minute who doesn't have a security pass - they won't get in  be disappointed if only a handful of MPs and ministers turn up; the competition is fierce between receptions, so if you get a dozen, you are doing well.  Sophie Howells is press and PR officer at Scope.

fields.headline: Success for carers' campaign
fields.standfirst: Emily Holzhausen, public affairs manager of the Carers National Association, presents a successful campaign example
fields.trailText: Emily Holzhausen, public affairs manager of the Carers National Association, presents a successful campaign example.
fields.body:
The Carers National Association (CNA) has raised awareness of issues affecting carers to such an extent that a new act has been introduced in parliament, extra funding has been secured for carers and changes in benefit payments have been made.

The CNA has had a number of successes recently with:
 the Carers and Disabled Children Act 2000, which gives new rights to carers and should promote more choice for them
 an extra two years ringfenced funding of £185m for breaks for carers in England announced on September 27, 2000
 a £191m package of changes to carers' benefits, announced on October 3, 2000. This is the first set of major changes to carers' benefits for more than 15 years.

The latter announcement fulfils six of CNA's top 10 campaign aims for the Fair Deal for Carers campaign. This campaign aimed to secure a better income for carers and began with the launching of research, Caring on the Breadline, in June 2000, which surveyed more than 2,000 carers on the financial cost of caring. The success cannot be attributed to the Fair Deal campaign alone, but to years of campaigning on this particular issue. The CNA does not believe that, once the campaigning target has been reached, the campaigning should stop. In fact, the campaigning takes on a very different, more subtle form. This second stage of campaigning is just as important as achieving the initial goal.

Now we have secured the changes outlined above, the next step for us will be to focus on implementation; empowering local groups with the knowledge they need to ensure carers know about the changes and explaining what difference it is going to make in their lives. In terms of the benefits changes, it will focus on take-up campaigns.

Empower local groups
We will also be providing information to empower local groups to work with the public authorities that will make the changes happen. Activities will include running training events for local authorities and other key stakeholders and working very closely with colleagues in the voluntary sector and health sector to ensure optimal implementation for carers.

We then monitor the implementation stage and feed this information back to the government, and to our local groups. They then know what the key campaigning issues are and many take very effective action locally using this information as one of their tools.

Most of this secondary campaigning is carried out through the provision of information, events, advice and training.

In short, my top tips for successful campaigning are:
 identify your issue
 gather your well balanced and well researched evidence
 run your campaign
 if you secure your goal, celebrate your success with others, then work with others on implementation
 monitor implementation
 give feedback to government and local groups, refining your information and your implementation campaign accordingly
 review the campaign after a certain period to identify new areas for action.

fields.headline: Cancer plan places NHS under scrutiny
fields.standfirst: The government's reputation rests on improvements in cancer care
fields.trailText: More than any other clinical priority, the government has staked its credibility on tackling cancer, one of Britain's biggest killers and one of the health service's most shameful failures. Patrick Butler examines the national cancer plan.
fields.body:
More than any other clinical priority, the government has staked its credibility on tackling cancer, one of Britain's biggest killers and - in terms of its lamentable record in treating the disease - one of the health service's most shameful failures.

The national cancer plan, launched with great fanfare by health secretary Alan Milburn at the Labour Party conference, puts in place a strategy that promises to bring the UK's record on the disease into line with the rest of western Europe.

The plan will serve as a barometer, measuring the state of the NHS. As it states: "The ability of the NHS to modernise and reform its cancer services is a litmus test for the health of the NHS as a whole."

At the heart of the plan is a series of, on the face of it, ambitious targets related to waiting times, together with an aspirational "ultimate goal" of a maximum one-month wait between urgent referral for suspected cancer and the start of treatment. According to Mr Milburn: "The plan will develop cancer services in this country that compare with the best in Europe. By 2010, our five-year survival rates for cancer will compare with the best in Europe."

Such promises are a hostage to fortune, even though many of the performance targets set by the government will not have to be met until 2005 - towards the end of a second electoral term. It will not be an easy ride. The plan is being launched against a backdrop of years of underinvestment in staff and equipment that has created comparatively poor cancer survival rates, particularly for the worse off, and wide geographical variations in access to and quality of treatment. And while the waiting time targets represent an improvement on current NHS performance, specialists say even if they are met they will not put the NHS on a par with other European countries.

"The targets are reasonable given the state of the NHS, but soft compared to Holland and France. In France you would expect a consultant appointment in a couple of days not a couple of weeks," says Gordon McVie, director general of Cancer Research campaign.

The success of the plan is tied inextricably to the far-from-guaranteed success of the government's NHS reforms. In particular, it depends on plans to hire thousands more nurses, doctors and scientists. Ministers aim to recruit 1,000 extra cancer specialists, as well as more radiographers and nurses, by 2006.

But Professor McVie warns more needs to be done sooner. "We have asked for 600 oncologists (specialist cancer doctors) in three years; they have promised 1,000 in six years. We should be going abroad now to get these extra doctors."

fields.headline: Sharing out the health budget
fields.standfirst: Steve Brown explains how national NHS budgets are divided between health authorities
fields.trailText: Steve Brown explains how national NHS budgets are divided between health authorities
fields.body:
As a result of the budget top-up for the NHS in March, health authorities received an average 8.9% cash increase in their allocations.

But residents expecting to see those increases locally may be surprised to find that allocations vary widely. Increases this year ranged from 10.8% for Kensington, Chelsea and Westminster health authority to a more modest 8.2% for the Isle of Wight.

The reason for these unequal increases, paradoxically, is the search for equity - the cornerstone on which the NHS is built. In short, NHS allocation policy seeks to ensure the neediest areas get a bigger share of resources.

When the NHS was created, funding was allocated according to the location of the hospitals the service inherited. Since 1971 the health service has introduced a succession of resource allocation formulae to divide funds between regions, and more recently health authorities, based on the size and age of their populations. Over the years "capitation" formulae were refined to take account of the relative health needs of different populations and the different costs of providing health care around the country.

The existing formula in England was introduced in 1996-97, although a wide-ranging review was launched in 1998. A new formula, likely to be introduced in 2003-04, aims to produce a fair distribution of resources between health authorities and primary care groups and trusts, which are taking over the commissioning of acute and community care.

So-called 'needs-weighted' capitation formulae provide target allocations, towards which health authorities are gradually moved. This means that over time, money flows away fom above-target health authorities (for example, in the relatively wealthy shire counties in the south-east) to below-target authorities (inner-city areas, deprived areas in the north of England).

Scotland has just completed a national review of resource allocation and plans to replace its 20-year old formula with one devised under the guidance of the review chairman, Sir John Arbuthnott. This will allocate over £4bn between 15 health boards. As in England, no board will face cuts: each will receive growth money, some more than others. But there will be winners and losers.

Although in percentage terms the Western Isles will receive the biggest increase, Greater Glasgow will get the biggest cash rise as the new formula takes more account of inner-city deprivation. The allocations for 2001-02 have taken a major leap towards "parity", with Glasgow receiving a 7.7% cash increase compared to an average 6.5% for Scotland.

Wales and Northern Ireland also use weighted capitation formulae and both are under review.

fields.headline: What is the Compact all about?
fields.standfirst: Paul Barasi, compact officer at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, explains
fields.trailText: Paul Barasi, compact officer at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, explains.
fields.body:
You are given two weeks to fill out grant forms and then left waiting to hear for months, even after the financial year has started?

You are given hardly any time to respond to a Government consultation document and then your views are ignored?

For the first time there is a written commitment that these kinds of things should not happen. Under the Compact Funding Code, the Government is committed to give three months' notice of funding decisions and issue cheques on time. The Compact Consultation Code also commits the Government to 12 weeks consultation, better feedback and statements on how proposed legislation will impact on the Voluntary Sector.

The Compact is an agreement made in November 1998 between the government and the voluntary sector to improve their relationship for mutual advantage. According to the Compact, it is a way of "Getting it right together". The Compact does more than set out a shared vision and key principles. It paves the way for five codes of practice to make the agreement operational.

The power of the Compact

The voluntary sector has seen agreements before: with local authorities in pre-Compact days. These collapsed because they did not link with the policy agenda, lacked political ownership and were too one-sided. The difference now is that Government recognises it needs voluntary organisations for policy delivery especially given the explosion in partnership programmes. And local government needs them too as key partners on their new community strategy duty.

Both the government and voluntary sector agree that funding and consultation are at the heart of their relationship. Codes on these topics were the first to be published, in May 2000. The other three, on volunteering, black and minority ethnic organisations, and community groups, are expected early next year.

If the Compact has a new improved recipe then its vital ingredient is having undertakings on both sides. But it will only work if it does not remain a secret ingredient because these have to be carried out. Much of the government's credibility for honouring the Funding Code rides on compliance by the Department of Health and especially on its major funding programme (Section 64 grants).

What if the government breaches its Compact undertakings? It's a bit like Lord of the Rings - five codes and one Compact to bind them. The Compact is not actually a legally binding document but it has robust compliance and review mechanisms all the same, starting with monitoring by the voluntary sector's working group on the Compact. Recourse to mediation or the ombudsman is also possible. And then there is the annual meeting with ministers, which leads to an annual report to parliament and includes an annual action plan to ensure the work is taken forward.

A key test is whether the voluntary sector believes that its relationship with the government is improving. A survey after the Compact's first year showed that one third of the sector already thought that it had.

Challenges ahead

What are the key national challenges?
 Compact and Codes being known and used across Government and the Sector.
 Concerted action for Compact to infiltrate Department of Health and NHS.
 Meaningful mentions of Compact in Government policy documents.
 Producing a protocol on partnership and contracts.

What are the key challenges for local Compacts?
 Being an effective tool for getting multi-agency partnerships working properly.
 Underpinning the sector getting involved in best value and community strategy.
 Benefiting Black and minority ethnic groups and small unfunded community groups.
 Carrying through action plans which deliver community benefit too.

fields.headline: 'A car drove into my ambulance'
fields.standfirst: Rachel Sarfas advises an ambulance paramedic that the car driver, not the ambulance service, is liable for the injuries caused by the accident
fields.trailText: Rachel Sarfas advises an ambulance paramedic that the car driver, not the ambulance service, is liable for the injuries caused by the accident
fields.body:
Q. I am an ambulance paramedic. The ambulance I was in was pulling up in traffic when it was struck from behind by a car. I was in the back of the ambulance looking after a patient and was thrown forward, receiving a heavy blow to my arm and jarring my back. Months later I am still in considerable pain and have been unable to return to work. Is the ambulance service liable for the accident or the driver of the car?

A. The driver of the car is liable and you should make a claim against him or her. It does not appear that the driver of the ambulance was in any way at fault and therefore you would not have a claim against your employer.

Compensation is awarded for pain, suffering and for earnings that you have lost as a result of the accident. Assessments will need to be made of your likely ability to return to work, or to find alternative work, when and at what level of pay.

The claim will be for your full loss of earnings either into the future - if the medical evidence is that you will not return to work at all - or to the date when it is estimated that you will return to work or get other employment. If you are able to return to some type of work, but the pay level is lower, you should be able to claim the difference.

 Rachel Sarfas is managing partner at Thompsons Solicitors

webTitle: 'I cut my hand on a needle. What now?'

fields.headline: 'I cut my hand on a needle. What now?'
fields.standfirst: You can sue your employer but only if you act within three years, writes Rachel Sarfas
fields.trailText: You can sue your employer but only if you act within three years, writes Rachel Sarfas
fields.body:
Q. I am a housekeeping assistant at an NHS trust. Recently I was emptying a waste bin and as I lifted a rubbish bag by its neck I felt a sharp pain in my hand and dropped the bag in shock. I realised that I had been stabbed and when I looked to see what it was, I discovered that a dirty needle was sticking out of the bag. I was told by the nurse who cleaned my hand that there was nothing to worry about, but since then I have been unable to sleep properly and have been worrying constantly that I may have caught a disease. Can I sue the trust?

A. Needlestick injuries are among the most common that employees who work for hospitals can receive and the public sector trade union Unison has campaigned to make hospitals use a kind of needle that cannot cause this kind of injury when discarded. It is only possible to recover compensation for these injuries if it can be shown that the employer was at fault.

Used needles should not be left in unmarked rubbish bags and your trust is responsible for training staff so that they know this. So if the bag was not marked, then you probably do have a case.

Thompsons recently took a case very similar to yours in which an auxiliary worker was cut by a scalpel and a syringe. When the bag she lifted was opened it was found to contain several used syringes. The victim was given blood tests, which all proved negative, and she also received telephone counselling from Occupational Health. If you haven't been offered blood tests and counselling you should ask for them.

Eventually the case was settled for £750, although the trust did not admit liability. That is the average compensation payout in these cases and although the money cannot properly compensate for your injury and the worry that you have been through it can make it easier to cope.

If you are a member of a trade union then your first step should be to contact your union rep to see whether you are entitled to help under the union legal assistance scheme. If you are not then you should contact a specialist personal injury law firm such as Thompsons. Your initial interview is free of charge.

Please remember that if you do wish to pursue a claim for personal injuries against the person or organisation responsible that there are very strict time limits. Generally speaking, you must start court proceedings within three years of your accident or the court will not consider your claim.

 Rachel Sarfas is managing partner at Thompsons Solicitors.

fields.headline: Health under media spotlight
fields.standfirst: Press officers need a thick skin
fields.trailText:
Name Julie Sheppard
Job head of communications and PR
Salary £40-£50,000
fields.body:
Name Julie Sheppard
Job head of communications and PR
Salary £40-£50,000

Julie Sheppard worked as a TV journalist specialising in science and medical documentaries, and as a food industry specialist for the Consumers' Association, before joining the University College London Hospitals (UCLH) trust.

She says her knowledge of the NHS and her experience of journalism made her well aware of the pressures of the job. As a big London teaching trust (and controller of former health secretary Frank Dobson's local hospital) UCLH is under constant, and often unfavourable, media scrutiny.

"I'm not a whinger about the media. It is their job to make us feel uncomfortable, and they do that. Without the media scrutiny of the NHS over the last two years you would not have had the NHS plan."

Sheppard warns that NHS PRs need "thick skin, a sense of humour and a capacity to see the bigger picture."

The job can be demanding. She is on call 24-hours a day for one week in three, a period during which she cannot leave London. And if a major story breaks "your working day can extend very significantly".

But she enjoys the variety of the job and the excitement of dealing with the big stories. "Not one day is the same and the range of issues is vast." After the Paddington rail crash she conducted live interviews with press and radio from the hospital incident room as the ambulances arrived with the crash victims.

fields.headline: Adrenalin rush of NHS PR
fields.standfirst: There's never time to get bored when health hits the headlines
fields.trailText:
Name Leigh McGowan
Job head of communications
Salary £40,000- £50,000
fields.body:
Name Leigh McGowan
Job head of communications
Salary £40,000- £50,000

Leigh McGowan worked as a management trainee in the printing industry, in the motor trade, and in events organisation for an advertising agency before his first public relations job, at East Lindsey district council in Lincolnshire.

He moved to Nottinghamshire county council, where he became head of publicity, before joining Nottingham's Queen's Medical Centre University hospital trust (QMC) in 1993.

His first big task came a year later when the world's media descended on Nottingham to cover the Abbie Humphries story. Abbie was the baby abducted from QMC's maternity unit by a woman impersonating a nurse. She was eventually reunited with her family, but not before 250 journalists and camera crews had set up camp at the hospital.

The experience is "deeply ingrained" on his memory. "I recall at the final press conference, when Abbie's mother walked in holding her baby, the whole room exploded into applause and you had hardbitten journalists standing there with tears running down their faces."

"One of the great things about this job," he adds, "is you never have time to get bored. If you are an adrenalin junkie, it's a job for you. If not, don't bother."

What qualities make a good NHS PR? "I look for a bright personality, the ability to think on your feet, self-confidence and a sense of humour," says McGowan.

The rewards are good, adds McGowan. "I have only been in health for seven years but it's the most enjoyable and exciting job I have ever had."

fields.headline: Nice work
fields.standfirst: The first 15 findings on the effectiveness of drugs and medical technology of the  National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice)
fields.trailText: The first 15 findings on the effectiveness of drugs and medical technology of the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice).
fields.body:
1 Coronary artery stents: small, tube-like devices used to prevent the narrowing of blood vessels following balloon angioplasty, a heart disease intervention.
Cost: Nice says it is difficult to say.
Patients with angina or those who have had a heart attack should normally receive a coronary artery stent following angioplasty.

2 GP IIb/IIIa inhibitors: drugs administered to reduce blood clotting.
Cost: £31m a year.
The drugs should be given to high risk patients who have had a minor heart attack, have unstable angina or are undergoing a balloon angioplasty.

3 Hearing aids: electronic devices to aid those with hearing impairment.
Cost: £50m per year.
Nice says there is not enough evidence to support the introduction of digital hearing aids, though analogue aids should be available throughout the NHS.

4 Hepatitis C: Interferon alpha and ribavirin, drugs used to treat hepatitis C.
Cost: At least £18m a year.
Interferon alpha and ribavirin should be combined to treat the majority of patients over 18 with moderate to severe hepatitis C.

5 Implantable cardioverter defibrillators: 2in square devices implanted in the upper chest that monitor and control heartbeat.
Cost: £25m to £35m per year.
Should be available on the NHS for patients who have had a heart attack or who have a sustained irregular heartbeat.

6 Inhalers: an assessment of the devices available to treat chronic asthma in under fives, including hand-held inhalers and spacer systems and nebulisers, which deliver medication through a facemask.
Cost: No change.
Nice recommends the routine availability of metered dose inhalers and spacer systems. If this is not effective, nebulisers can be considered.

7 Liquid based cytology (LBC): an alternative to the current pap cervical smear test, which works in a similar way but may reduce errors and the need for repeat smears.
Cost: £18.2m a year.
LBC could bring significant benefits but there is insufficient evidence to support national implementation. Further investigation is needed.

8 Ritalin or Equasym: brand names for the drug methylphenidate which is used treat hyperactive children.
Cost: £44m a year.
The medicine should be given to children with attention deficit disorder.

9 Artificial hip joints: these are inserted surgically into the hip to replace diseased or damaged joints.
Cost: a saving of £8m a year
Nice recommended the NHS should use less expensive "cemented prostheses", as they last longer.

10 Proton pump inhibitors: drugs used to treat dyspepsia - discomfort or pain in the abdomen or upper chest - and ulcers by suppressing acid production in the stomach.
Cost: A saving of up to £50m a year.
Nice believes the drugs should only be available on the NHS for certain ulcers. Doctors should reduce doses once the ulcer has healed.

11 Removal of wisdom teeth:
Cost: a saving of £5m a year.
Healthy wisdom teeth should not be removed unless other problems with the mouth mean they must be extracted.

12 Rosiglitazone: an alternative to insulin in the treatment of type II diabetes, which normally appears in the over 40s.
Cost: £14.5m a year.
Patients should be given rosiglitazone and another drug, metformin or a sulphonylurea, as an alternative to insulin, if they are unable to take metformin and sulphonylurea in combination or if this combination does not reduce their blood glucose.

13 Taxanes (breast cancer): group of drugs that can be used to treat cancers by limiting the disease's progression.
Cost: £16m a year.
The two drugs available in the UK, docetaxel (Taxotere) and paclitaxel (Taxol), should be prescribed by the NHS.

14 Taxanes (ovarian cancer): paclitaxel (Taxol) is used to treat women with ovarian cancer.
Cost: £7m a year.
The drug should be available as a standard, initial therapy, though it may also be given to those who have not previously received paclitaxel, those whose cancer has recurred or where the cancer resists other therapies.

15 Zanamivir (Relenza) : a drug that aims to reduce the duration of a bout of flu.
Cost: £10m to £15m a year.
Relenza should not be prescribed because the numbers of patients used in the clinical trials were too small. However, the guidance was issued under Nice's rapid appraisal system and a more detailed review is currently taking place.

fields.headline: Turning pensioner poverty around
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown should relink pensions to earnings, writes Peter Townsend
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown should relink pensions to earnings, writes Peter Townsend
fields.body:
History's defining moments come not only in war. The BBC TV series Britain's Finest Hour showed that the whole country was brought together in the summer of 1940 through the extraordinary courage displayed by a few fighter pilots, the stoicism and improvisation of millions during the evacuation of Dunkirk and subsequent bombing, and the statesmanship of a beleaguered Winston Churchill.

Since then, the defining moments have been harder to agree. One came immediately after Margaret Thatcher won the 1979 election. She announced that the earnings link with pensions and other social security benefits would be abandoned. This was the biggest cut by far of any of the measures introduced in the 1980s and 1990s. It prompted the fastest increase in inequality and child poverty experienced in Britain in the last hundred years - a sharper trend by far than in any other member country of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. There was no such thing as society.

The link had been established after decades of working-class campaigning. It ensured "trickle down," so that the poor would have some share of growing prosperity. Through collective insurance people achieved a measure of security on which to build their futures. Similar conditions and rules applied to all. Collective insurance was, and has remained, overwhelmingly popular.

Of course, Thatcher's decision lay at the heart of all the other measures of neo-liberal economic theory that were taken - to cut public expenditure, income tax and trade union powers, deregulate, privatise public services and target, or means-test, the arbitrarily defined poor. Under various names these policies now apply across the world. For rich and poor countries alike the result is our biggest global problem - of growing inequality and instability. Will the autumn of 2000 be another defining moment? The engines of social polarisation and growing poverty have not yet been put into reverse. For three years, the chancellor of the exchequer has had the glittering opportunity of giving Britain cohesion and minimally adequate living standards. Since May 1997, he has at times seemed to be edging towards that objective - to reduce neo-liberal inequality and act for one nation. But he has not yet operated on all four cylinders.

Missing has been action to restrain or tax excessive earnings, widen and strengthen public service, and modernise and extend social insurance for big population groups - measures that even the international agencies are now beginning to acknowledge as worthwhile.

Pensions policy lies at the heart of the system required to make the Government's anti-poverty strategy work. This is not just for current pensioners in poverty, whose numbers have continued to grow since 1997. It is for those 47m people not yet of pensionable age, especially women.

The problem goes back to 1996. Chancellor Gordon Brown planned to privatise middle-income pensions, and give those who could not afford to pay for them a means-tested "guaranteed" minimum pension. The "guarantee" is illusory and the proposed pensioner credits, like other tax credits, are another form of means-testing. The measures cannot cover the relevant populations efficiently or provide adequate incomes.

Indeed, events from British history, such as the inquiries at the time of the Beveridge Report and Harold Wilson's experiment with a minimum income guarantee in the 1960s, shows they are unlikely to work. And United Nations studies of large-scale privatisation, as in Chile and Mexico or the transition economies, give mainly negative testimony.

Gordon Brown had left himself room to manoeuvre by saying that the basic state retirement pension, now £67.50 for the single pensioner, would remain the "foundation" of pension policy. He increased pensions yesterday but refused to take structural action. Unless the link is restored, and social insurance reinforced, the foundation will continue to slip, and the major losers will be not today's but tomorrow's pensioners, especially women, because so many have low and interrupted earnings.

The mark of statesmanship is to pursue an imaginative and well documented plan that will work for the good of the people and not for the good of a misconceived global market. Churchill was a maverick who could rise magnificently to an ominous situation - at the cost of abandoning former shibboleths.

Intransigence does not work. I fear the chancellor is continuing to push policies from which even the international agencies are beginning to withdraw.

fields.headline: This wasn't just egg on faces - it was a monster omelette
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It was a long night's voyage into fog - and the great battle fleet of TV flagships was lost, sunk without trace and apology. By Peter Preston.
fields.body:
It was a long night's voyage into fog - and the great battle fleet of TV flagships was lost, sunk without trace and apology. American television is fond of showing the election that newspapers called wrong, Harry Truman waving the headlines of his non-defeat by Dewey. This, 52 years later, was payback time, a debacle of million dollar gadgetry and pseudo-science.

Soon after 8pm eastern time on Tuesday (1am Wednesday British time) the networks, one after the other, processed the exit polls and gave Florida's 25 electoral college votes to Al Gore. It was a crucial projection. Had he been the predicted loser there, many Americans might have finished their beer and gone to bed early. Now he looked like a possible winner.

But just under two hours later George W Bush, surrounded by indignant family, could be glimpsed claiming that "the people actually counting the votes have come to a different perspective. I'm pretty darned upbeat about things".

Within 10 minutes CBS, ABC and CNN, with NBC traipsing behind, put Florida back in the undecided column, where it lay for another four hours until the networks called a Bush win.

But soon Mr Bush's supposed 50,000 lead in Florida had turned to a paltry 1,000. Florida, and the election, was once more too close to call.

Television, in short, had spent 10 hours of running up and down hill, claiming certainty, building edifices of punditry and prognostication along the road, then demolishing them in a trice. Even the two exhausted candidates had no other information to go on at the end, and the information was humiliatingly duff.

What went so abjectly wrong? All the giant TV corporations in America, with their feeds around the world, rely on thousands of field workers from the Voter News Service who stand outside polling stations and ask a random sample of exiting voters to fill in a form saying how they cast their ballots and answer subsidiary questions about their motives. Those results, fed into computer models back at the networks, allow the TV channels to name winners or losers as soon as the real polls close.

That is extremely convenient. It makes a better show and, in theory, delivers a clear verdict before the mass viewing audiences go to sleep. The gratification of knowing is almost instant. You skip the dragging boredom of the real count and real numbers.

But what if, as Voter News Service reported, "the vote is strange"? What if there's a tangle between the data going in and the projections coming out? What if the swiftly increasing numbers of people here claiming postal ballots, people who never go near a polling booth, don't echo the trends of the people who appear in person?

Then you have egg on your face.

It has happened in small ways before with Senate races. This time, however, the result is a monster omelette. The men who would be president have been put through a ridiculous, essentially phoney ordeal. A watching audience around the world has been force fed ersatz omniscience. There will, in the American way of things, be a terrible inquest. The voices who want exit polling abolished are already loud.

Very little from the longest night of punditry survived into the light of day. Reports of a monster turnout - a repeatedly claimed triumph for resurgent democracy - proved wildly overblown. Bush versus Gore barely scrambled above the 49% apathy of Clinton versus Dole four years ago.

The commentators' favourite talking point - What if Gore wins the electoral college but Bush wins the popular vote? - looked apposite enough, but was entirely the wrong way round.

What wisdom survived? Only the banal. "Florida does not mean Gore is going to win the election - but it does mean we're in for a long night", said an already weary Dan Rather on CBS.

"The analogy isn't threading the needle any longer, it's a pinball machine," said Mac McLarty on NBC.

"This is going to be a painful night for the person who loses," said Judy Woodruff on CNN.

And a universal anthem: "Because we're calling a race too close to call, doesn't mean it's close."
