fields.headline: Voluntary groups 'optimistic' about neighbourhood plans
fields.standfirst: There is an air of optimism in the voluntary sector about the government's neighbourhood renewal strategy as it promises more jobs, less crime and better public services, writes Julian Dobson. But will it deliver?
fields.trailText: There is an air of optimism in the voluntary sector about the government's neighbourhood renewal strategy as it promises more jobs, less crime and decent public services, writes Julian Dobson. But will it deliver?
fields.body:
Darwin's law of natural selection is that to survive you need to be fitter and more adaptable than your rivals, it also helps if you're lean, mean, agile and intelligent. Whether the government's national strategy for neighbourhood renewal meets such exacting criteria remains to be seen.

Having been in gestation rather longer than an elephant, the crowds eagerly awaiting its birth are still not sure whether we're going to get a whippet or a woolly mammoth.

It started with the simple idea of transforming Britain's most deprived neighbourhoods and addressing the endemic problems that have frustrated 30 years of regeneration initiatives.

The national strategy, formulated by the social exclusion unit, aims to achieve four central outcomes: more jobs, better educational attainment, less crime and better health. It will do so through four key methods: reviving local economies; reviving communities, ensuring decent public services; and encouraging leadership and joint working.

Put like that, it sounds straightforward and common sense. It also provides a beacon of hope for voluntary and community organisations that for years have felt left out in the power struggles between central and local government.

Street credibility
For possibly the first time, the voluntary and community sectors are the key to the success of a major government strategy. They have been involved in preparing the 18 policy action team reports that the Social Exclusion Unit has spawned, on everything from neighbourhood management and community self-help to arts and sports. If the strategy is to work, it is the voluntary sector's contacts with residents and community groups that will give it street credibility.

But between conception and delivery, the strategy has started to turn into a monster. Part of this has been due to the commendable decision to expose it to the most comprehensive consultation process seen in years. Bits have been added in response to valid criticisms, and there are still more demands for recognition of this interest group or that problem.

The draft strategy, released in April, sets out 30 separate key ideas distilled from the hundreds of recommendations by the policy action teams. Among the most important for the voluntary sector are:

 To establish a national centre for neighbourhood renewal;

 To train residents and professionals and to spread good practice;

 To establish local strategic partnerships to oversee renewal projects and bring partners together;

 To involve local organisations in the direct delivery of public services.

Chancellor Gordon Brown has already set up the financial framework for achieving much of this. Local authorities and government departments will need to abide by public service agreements, promising them flexibility and additional resources in return for delivering specific targets.

The new deal for communities, an intensive programme designed to tackle deprivation in the worst-hit neighbourhoods, gets £1.3bn over the next three years. Meanwhile an £800m neighbourhood renewal fund will be divided between the 88 most deprived local authorities, which will be free to choose how they spend it - as long as they put local strategic partnerships in place and meet the targets set out in their public service agreements.

Given that the government is starting to put its money where its mouth is, it's no wonder there's a mood of optimism among much of the voluntary sector. The mood is encapsulated in the response from the Urban Forum, an umbrella group for voluntary organisations working in deprived areas, to the consultation on the neighbourhood renewal strategy.

The forum says: "The draft national strategy for neighbourhood renewal is the most far-reaching, analytical and exciting development yet undertaken by this government, and the most impressive report on neighbourhood renewal in many people's living memory. The draft strategy is full of good ideas, stimulates the imagination and provides an excellent starting point for policies and actions that can turn round deprived neighbourhoods."

Whether the government's national strategy for neighbourhood renewal meets such exacting criteria remains to be seen. Having been in gestation rather longer than an elephant, the crowds eagerly awaiting its birth are still not sure whether we're going to get a whippet or a woolly mammoth. It started with the simple idea of transforming Britain's most deprived neighbourhoods and addressing the endemic problems that have frustrated 30 years of regeneration initiatives. The national strategy, formulated by the social exclusion unit, aims to achieve four central outcomes: more jobs, better educational attainment, less crime and better health. It will do so through four key methods: reviving local economies; reviving communities, ensuring decent public services; and encouraging leadership and joint working. Put like that, it sounds straightforward and common sense. It also provides a beacon of hope for voluntary and community organisations that for years have felt left out in the power struggles between central and local government. Street credibility For possibly the first time, the voluntary and community sectors are the key to the success of a major government strategy. They have been involved in preparing the 18 policy action team reports that the Social Exclusion Unit has spawned, on everything from neighbourhood management and community self-help to arts and sports. If the strategy is to work, it is the voluntary sector's contacts with residents and community groups that will give it street credibility. But between conception and delivery, the strategy has started to turn into a monster. Part of this has been due to the commendable decision to expose it to the most comprehensive consultation process seen in years. Bits have been added in response to valid criticisms, and there are still more demands for recognition of this interest group or that problem. The draft strategy, released in April, sets out 30 separate key ideas distilled from the hundreds of recommendations by the policy action teams. Among the most important for the voluntary sector are:  To establish a national centre for neighbourhood renewal;  To train residents and professionals and to spread good practice;  To establish local strategic partnerships to oversee renewal projects and bring partners together;  To involve local organisations in the direct delivery of public services. Chancellor Gordon Brown has already set up the financial framework for achieving much of this. Local authorities and government departments will need to abide by public service agreements, promising them flexibility and additional resources in return for delivering specific targets. The new deal for communities, an intensive programme designed to tackle deprivation in the worst-hit neighbourhoods, gets £1.3bn over the next three years. Meanwhile an £800m neighbourhood renewal fund will be divided between the 88 most deprived local authorities, which will be free to choose how they spend it - as long as they put local strategic partnerships in place and meet the targets set out in their public service agreements. Given that the government is starting to put its money where its mouth is, it's no wonder there's a mood of optimism among much of the voluntary sector. The mood is encapsulated in the response from the Urban Forum, an umbrella group for voluntary organisations working in deprived areas, to the consultation on the neighbourhood renewal strategy. The forum says: "The draft national strategy for neighbourhood renewal is the most far-reaching, analytical and exciting development yet undertaken by this government, and the most impressive report on neighbourhood renewal in many people's living memory. The draft strategy is full of good ideas, stimulates the imagination and provides an excellent starting point for policies and actions that can turn round deprived neighbourhoods."

fields.headline: The Millennium Dome
fields.standfirst: Politicians and managers involved in the Millennium Dome project have been savaged in a damning report by the government's own National Audit Office. Derek Brown and Patrick Butler explain
fields.trailText: Politicians and managers involved in the Millennium Dome project have been savaged in a damning report by the government's own National Audit Office. We explain.
fields.body:
What does the National Audit Office say?
It criticises "weaknesses in financial management and control" at the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome. It says that visitor number targets were "ambitious and inherently risky".


How many people have actually visited the dome?
The NMEC says that it has welcomed its four-and-a-half millionth visitor this week. That was its last estimate for the whole year, issued when it applied for the £47m grant in September.


How many had it hoped to welcome?
It originally aimed to attract 12m visitors in the first year; this figure was swiftly downgraded to 10m just four weeks after launch. This month, the dome's organisers, the NMEC, announced that it expected to attract just 4.5m paying visitors over the year. Even in its best month, July, when 606,000 people visited, figures trailed targets by 4,000 a day.


How much has the dome cost?
It cost £700m to build, including £400m from lottery funds and £160m from commercial backers such as British Airways. It received a £60m subsidy in January and a £29m subsidy in May, after which NMEC said that the dome was "fixed" and that it would need no more handouts. However, in August it received a £43m advance" on the £106m sale of the site to leisure and entertainment developers Dome Europe. The injection of £47m that was announced in September was aimed at keeping the dome solvent and open for business until the end of the year, bringing total spending to around £870m so far. By December, the final bill for the dome is expected to reach £1bn.


Hasn't the dome been flogged off?
In July, Dome Europe and its financial backers, Nomura International, beat off five rivals to win the right to buy the Greenwich site for £106m and begin redeveloping the dome from 2001. It announced plans to invest £800m to create an "urban entertainment resort", combining "enthralling interactive attractions", shows, cultural events, hotels and restaurants, and educational "experiences". But Nomura now maintains that it has not signed the contract to buy the dome, and that it needs to study the dome's new financial projections to see if its own ambitious plans remain viable.


How does the dome's performance compare to other millennium project attractions?
Scotland's showcase millennium attraction, Dynamic Earth in Edinburgh, which opened in July 1999, had exceeded its annual visitor target of 434,000 by May 2000. It cost £34m, of which £15m came from the lottery. The Lowry Centre in Salford, which opened in April 2000, cost £106m, of which the lottery contributed £68.9m. It aimed to attract 77,000 visitors over 12 months. It attracted 70,000 in its first week and 420,000 in its first five months. The Tate Modern art gallery in London, which received £50m from the Millennium Commission, anticipated 2m-3m visitors in its first year. Since it opened in May, over 2m visitors have passed through its doors.

webTitle: Long consultation leads to neighbourhood strategy

fields.headline: Long consultation leads to neighbourhood strategy
fields.standfirst: The government's neighbourhood renewal strategy has been a long time coming. Nicola Hill reviews its progress
fields.trailText: The government's neighbourhood renewal strategy has been a long time coming. Nicola Hill reviews its progress
fields.body:
The government has taken its practice of consultation to the extreme with its neighbourhood renewal strategy. The cabinet's social exclusion unit first launched a report looking in to the problems in deprived neighbourhoods in September 1998. After that, 18 policy action teams (PATs) were set up to look at different elements such as anti-social behaviour and unemployment. These PATs in turn issued reports with recommendations. The consultation period on the reports ended in June this year.

Feedback from this process is now being incorporated into the final document, which will be published in mid-December. This will be known as an action plan and it is aimed at practitioners who will be implementing the strategy.

But it is not all talk, there is money in it as well. In October this year, John Prescott and Gordon Brown announced a £800m neighbourhood renewal fund (NRF). At the same time, they published yet another consultation paper, which sets out the government's proposals on how the fund will operate. The money will be available for the three financial years from April 2001 to March 2004 with £100m in 2001-02, £300m in 2002-03 and £400m in 2003-04. The government insists that communities will have a vital role in developing strategies for tackling deprivation in their own neighbourhoods, and deciding how these targets will be met locally.

Guidance was also issued alongside the NRF consultation on the establishment of local strategic partnerships (LSPs). LSPs will be set up across the country (not just in NRF areas) to bring local service providers together with voluntary, community and private sector groups to work together to tackle the problems facing individual neighbourhoods.

In our special report we look at reaction to the consultation, who will deliver the strategy and how conflicts may be resolved.

fields.headline: Mr Brown goes to town
fields.standfirst:
This should take the punch out of protest

Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: In what was in effect, if not in name, a pre-election budget, Gordon Brown yesterday managed to combine fiscal prudence with measures to give unprecedented benefits to pensioners and enough concessions to take the wind out of the hauliers' revolt.
fields.body:
In what was in effect, if not in name, a pre-election budget, Gordon Brown yesterday managed to combine fiscal prudence with measures to give unprecedented benefits to pensioners and enough concessions to take the wind out of the hauliers' revolt. It was a masterpiece of precision engineering, if not of oratory, as he scattered fresh titbits to savers, small businesses, schools (£200m), the green lobby (by reducing duties on a petrol most people had never heard of) and families. It was the culmination of four hard and often unpopular years as he relentlessly shook off of Labour's traditional reputation for spending what it has not got. This time he retains a massive £16bn budget surplus (before counting the £22.5bn from the radio spectrum auction) and after announcing the new measures. This will probably - but not certainly - avoid the need for the independent Bank of England, which he set up to prevent pre-electoral profligacy, to raise interest rates in the run-up to the spring election.

It will be pensioners who, metaphorically, will be dancing in the streets. Mr Brown has not done enough to satisfy the likes of Jack Jones and Barbara Castle, who want a permanent restoration of the earnings link. But he has done much better than that. He has earmarked an extra £2.6bn out of the unbudgeted £5bn increase in tax revenues to be spent on an unexpectedly large boost to pensions. The money, absolutely rightly (because it is five times as effective as a scattergun approach) is going mainly to those in need. The minimum income guarantee is going up to £92.15p a week, with future rises linked to earnings growth. But the basic pension will also go up by more than the rate of inflation (by £5 a week in 2001 and another £3 a week the following year). The winter fuel payment will also rise - by £50 to £200. By rectifying some of the gross injustices inflicted on pensioners in recent years, Mr Brown will not only endear himself to the left of the party but may also win back dissatisfied pensioners - 49% of whom, according to the Guardian/ICM poll, have been thinking of votingTory, compared with 29% favouring Labour. Most pensioners actually favour an across-the-board increase, so Mr Brown's measures turn out to have been a shrewd compote of politics and social justice.

Which is more than can be said for his policy towards the hauliers. This is to give away only enough to make it difficult for them to go ahead with their planned action, while at the same time adopting measures that could be justified even if no threat existed. Freezing fuel duties is reasonable after years of above-inflation increases and the proposed reductions in ultra-low sulphur diesel (and petrol) are completely justified on environmental grounds, as is the reduced vehicle excise duty for 8.4m cars with engines under 1,500cc. Hauliers' complaints about unfair competition from Europe (where they have to pay expensive tolls) has been ingeniously met by proposing a "vignette" system to ensure that non-British lorries pay their fair share for using British roads. Could there be a similar scheme for gallery and museum charges? Elsewhere he unleashed another barrage of measures to bolster small businesses (and try to attract their political loyalty), including help on the taxation of stock options which has got the dot.com companies in such a tizzy.

Economically, Mr Brown has used the "fiscal prudence bonus" to fund extra spending above what had been announced in the budget. This is the money that drops from the sky because he has been so prudent that things nearly always turn out better than expected. As of now, he has used all the bonus up - but if his recent luck continues, a fresh windfall seems bound to emerge between now and the election. That would open the way for another "prudent" budget conjuring up a final tax cut of some kind before the election. Meanwhile, the economy is in rude health. Unless something nasty happens externally- like a post-electoral recession in the US economy - Labour will, unprecedentedly, go to the polls against a backdrop of economic stability. Normally, the Treasury forecast of a 7.5% rise in exports next year would be contested because of the strong pound. But the strong pound did not prevent an 8% export rise this year. Luck as well as prudence is smiling on the chancellor - at least for the moment.

fields.headline: Just how corrupt is cricket?
fields.standfirst: On Thursday November 9 Tim de Lisle, editor of wisden.com and until recently of Wisden Cricket Monthly, went on line to answer your questions. Here is how it went
fields.trailText: 1 Naz1 asked How deep does the corruption in cricket go, and how long has it been going on for?
fields.body:
1 Naz1 asked How deep does the corruption in cricket go, and how long has it been going on for?

Tim de Lisle replied If I knew that, there would be no need for Sir Paul Condon, and his team of detectives, and all the match-fixing inquiries. Wisden doesn't have any inside knowledge (happily), although we hear the press-box rumours. My guess is that corruption has gone wide rather than deep, and has always been spread quite thinly. It feels as if there has been an avalanche of match-fixing and betting stories, yet when you think about it, there are still only a few matches which are definitely known to have been fixed. Even Hansie Cronje has only admitted to tampering with a few games. Mike Atherton said last summer that there was only one match he had played in that felt fixed (no, he didn't say which one), so that's one out of 102 Tests plus 50-odd one-day matches. Of course, this doesn't mean there isn't a problem. A cancer is still a cancer even if not many people have it. The standard view on how long match-fixing has been going on, repeated in Pakistan's Qayyum Report, is around 20 years. But do remember that cricket has a very long history and that it was associated with betting, and chicanery, long before it acquired its connotations of fair play.

2 miner49er asked How do you call England's forthcoming Test series against Pakistan?

Tim de Lisle replied As a defeat! England have improved a lot under Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher, but they are no more than a mid-table team at the moment and their away form is very poor - the only team they have beaten away from home in the last decade is New Zealand, when they were less strong than are now. Pakistan are wildly unpredictable but England seem to bring out the best in them, and as you say, England are just not designed for turning pitches. If England come out with a result better than 0-2, they will have done well.

3 Meatloaf asked Is Marcus Trescothick the future of English cricket?

Tim de Lisle replied I hope so, but have tried to avoid saying so, because prophecies like that have a way of being the opposite of self-fulfilling. Trescothick made the perfect start to his international career, and it wasn't just his scores (a string of 70s and 80s) that were encouraging. He exuded the sort of relaxed positivity that most England batsmen take years to display. He left the ball very well, which is crucial for a lefthander, but he also gave it a good thump off both the front and back foot. And he was making runs on surfaces that were green and treacherous, unlike the nice flat tracks he is used to at Taunton. Today's innings of 93 in Peshawar confirms the feeling that his bubble is not about to burst, although there is bound to be a bad patch some time - I just hope the selectors keep faith with him, as they have failed to with so many young players.

4 Dug asked What future vision do we need if Test cricket is to remain a viable and lively sport? What are your views on such innovations as lights in poor playing conditions?

Tim de Lisle replied The sad irony of the match-fixing imbroglio is that Test cricket is actually in a very healthy state. The last decade has been a golden age, with several of the great new-ball combinations of all time in action simultaneously -- Ambrose and Walsh, Wasim and Waqar, Donald and Pollock, and now the mouthwatering trio of McGrath, Brett Lee and Gillespie. We have two of the greatest spinners in history, in Warne and Muralitharan; two of the greatest batsmen, in Lara and Tendulkar; and one of the strongest personalities, in Steve Waugh. And several of the closest results in history have taken place in the last few years. So there is no problem with the game's vitality. Viability is more of a worry: crowds in some countries have fallen away or defected to the one-day game. The answer is for ICC to adopt the Wisden World Championship or something very like it(see next answer), so as to add meaning to every Test. And yes, they should certainly be open-minded enough to switch the lights on.

5 aloo2000 wrote Tim, do you feel the current Wisden Test table truly reflects the standings of the teams? I feel the flaws are that it does not: (1) consider the difference between a tight series and a total washout, or (2) distinguish home advantage and away disadvantage.

Tim de Lisle replied I think it's a pretty good reflection. I certainly haven't seen a better one - and I speak as one who didn't invent it (that was Matthew Engel). It's certainly not perfect, and I agree with you to an extent about (2) -- an away win is usually a lot harder to pull off than a home one. But I'm not bothered about (1) -- it's the nature of sporting tables that they don't reflect the closeness of the game, unless the game remains close to the very last, and ends up as a draw or tie. Man Utd get the same number of points for a 1-0 win as for a 5-0.

6 KenDavro wrote What football team do you support?

Tim de Lisle replied As you might guess from the last answer, I support Man Utd. I'm a typical supporter: I live about 200 miles away and have only been to Old Trafford (the footballing one) once, when, naturally, they lost. But I can claim reasonable longevity. I fell for them because of George Best. The first game I remember was when they beat Northampton Town 8-2 in the Cup, in 1969-70 I think, and Best scored six. What I saw in them then - fabulous flair and excitement, most of it generated by players who were not bought - I still see, as long as Roy Keane is injured or suspended.

7 tentoone wrote Congrats for rescuing WCM from Col. Blimp territory. We look forward to similar innovation on the site. Perhaps there will be scope with a more provincial woops I mean less provincial approach on line given the more cosmopolitan audience. The focus on English County cricket, while it sells the mag locally, is of little interest to those who want to focus on REAL first class cricket!!! Regards from Oz

Tim de Lisle replied Thanks. Yes, we are hoping to do something similar with the website, and yes, we will certainly try to be more cosmpolitan. Already, about half of our emails come from outside the UK, so the site will reflect that. Sorry you don't feel that county cricket is first-class. Still, at least it boosts the bank balances of some of your guys.

8 JGK wrote Do you have any jobs going that involve copious amounts of watching cricket and writing the occasional article or commentary?

Tim de Lisle replied I wish. We do manage quite a lot of watching, but it's mostly on the telly. Making pages, whether for the web or the magazine, is largely done from offices. And even the people in the press box work hard -- the day may have a gentle start but it has a furiously busy end. If you want an easy life, don't be a cricket writer. If you want an interesting life, do. And yes, we will have some jobs going soon -- details will be posted on wisden.com.

9 JR Canning wrote Who is the best batsman you have seen?

Tim de Lisle replied Viv Richards, because he was the most fearsome, the most dominant -- although if TV had moved a little faster, and I had seen Sunil Gavaskar make one of his 13 hundreds against West Indies during the same era, I might well have gone for him. Richards's figures were certainly helped by the fact that he never had to face Holding, Roberts, Garner and Croft. But he wasn't really about figures, he was about power and strength and attitude, and nobody surpassed him in those areas. Of today's batsmen, my favourite is Brian Lara, whose huge backlift expands the possibilities of every ball he faces.

10 Naz1 wrote Do you think Lord MacLaurin was highly hypocritical when he didn't call Alec Stewart back home, considering that he wanted several Pakistanis banned just before a Test series tour which has enough controversy and history as it is?

Tim de Lisle replied Yes, there was a whiff of hypocrisy, but if MacLaurin had called Stewart home, there would have been a worse smell, of sheer injustice. It would have been a case of two wrongs not making a right. Stewart has not been accused of match-fixing, nor is he under suspicion of it. He has been accused of taking money for information, the same thing that Shane Warne and Mark Waugh admitted to, and dating from the same period -- the early to mid-Nineties, which was a more innocent time. Warne and Waugh weren't banned, so it would be very rough justice for Stewart to be, even if the case against him had been proven. MacLaurin's series of statements was inept, which is perhaps preferable to being unjust.

11 NeoLeo wrote What do u suggest can be done to create Pakistan-like cricket craziness in England?

Tim de Lisle replied Abolish football.

12 NeoLeo added By the way, would the scrapping of the tie-wearing tradition help?

Tim de Lisle replied Yes, I think it would. It's a very odd idea, that the spectators should be more formally dressed than the players. I wouldn't want to stop anyone wearing a tie if he wants to, but I can't for the life of me see why it should be compulsory in any part of the ground. Many City firms have managed to break free from this tradition: why can't MCC?

13 chisibm wrote So do you think Stewart is guilty?

Tim de Lisle replied No, I don't. I can't see why he would lie about it if he was. He has more to lose by lying than by admitting to the alleged offence -- which, at the time, was not an offence at all. He is not a devious person. I could be wrong, of course: the terrible legacy of Cronje is that you don't know who to believe any more. But given the choice, I would rather be too credulous than too cynical.

14 ScottM wrote What's this 'major expansion' of the website all about, then?

Tim de Lisle replied It's about trying to give you something bigger, though not huge, and much better, ready for the next English season. Two umpires do first session then the third umpire and one of the two does the next and then the 3rd umpire and other do final, that way each umpire does two sessions a day, surely if he's less mentally tired he'll make less mistakes?

Tim de Lisle replied Good idea. The third umpire is ridiculously under-used. And the two men in the middle are out there for far longer than the players, who are usually a lot younger and fitter than them.

16 Pedant wrote Are you familiar with the Rodney Ross method for Test team rankings? It can be found on the Cricinfo site, under the Database section. It is similar to your own Wisden World Championship, and uses home and away series results over the past few years. However, it gives more credit for comprehensive victories as opposed to narrow wins, and it also makes a distintion between home wins and the more difficult away wins. In my opinion, it gives more realistic rankings. For instance, at present it has the West Indies and New Zealand in joint fifth spot. I feel that this gives a better indication of these two teams' current position in Test cricket, compared to the equivalent Wisden rankings (3rd and 7th respectively).

Tim de Lisle replied I wasn't familiar with the Ross rankings but I am now. Something we all felt when we were launching the Wisden table, this time four years ago, was that it should be simple. As I said in another answer, I have alot of sympathy with the idea that away series wins should be rewarded. But I haven't been able to convince Matthew Engel of that. West Indies are a peculiar problem at the moment. I suspect that wherever they were in our table, it would feel wrong to some people, because they are two completely different teams at home and away. At home, they haven't lost their most recent encounter with anybody, not even Australia (2-2 in 1998-99). But away, as you know, they have suffered a series of heavy defeats. The same used to be true of India, and I remember Mike Atherton saying he thought their position (usually fifth or sixth) flattered them. But the great thing is, the table is objective. It simply goes by the most recent pair of meetings between each pair of teams. And thanks to the increase in the volume of international cricket, there are fewer old series in there -- last English winter (1999-2000), something like 16 series results in the table were replaced. So if New Zealand continue their improvement, they will soon go up by more than the two places they have already climbed.

18 mintcake1974 wrote 'new' wisden.com...At the moment, you have one long strip of text, with headings, it does not stand out at all. But I am sure that will be rectified? When will things hopefully appear on the web? How will it co-exist with the magazine? What will make me 'subscribe' to both?

fields.bodyText: 1 Naz1 asked How deep does the corruption in cricket go, and how long has it been going on for? Tim de Lisle replied If I knew that, there would be no need for Sir Paul Condon, and his team of detectives, and all the match-fixing inquiries. Wisden doesn't have any inside knowledge (happily), although we hear the press-box rumours. My guess is that corruption has gone wide rather than deep, and has always been spread quite thinly. It feels as if there has been an avalanche of match-fixing and betting stories, yet when you think about it, there are still only a few matches which are definitely known to have been fixed. Even Hansie Cronje has only admitted to tampering with a few games. Mike Atherton said last summer that there was only one match he had played in that felt fixed (no, he didn't say which one), so that's one out of 102 Tests plus 50-odd one-day matches. Of course, this doesn't mean there isn't a problem. A cancer is still a cancer even if not many people have it. The standard view on how long match-fixing has been going on, repeated in Pakistan's Qayyum Report, is around 20 years. But do remember that cricket has a very long history and that it was associated with betting, and chicanery, long before it acquired its connotations of fair play. 2 miner49er asked How do you call England's forthcoming Test series against Pakistan? Tim de Lisle replied As a defeat! England have improved a lot under Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher, but they are no more than a mid-table team at the moment and their away form is very poor - the only team they have beaten away from home in the last decade is New Zealand, when they were less strong than are now. Pakistan are wildly unpredictable but England seem to bring out the best in them, and as you say, England are just not designed for turning pitches. If England come out with a result better than 0-2, they will have done well. 3 Meatloaf asked Is Marcus Trescothick the future of English cricket? Tim de Lisle replied I hope so, but have tried to avoid saying so, because prophecies like that have a way of being the opposite of self-fulfilling. Trescothick made the perfect start to his international career, and it wasn't just his scores (a string of 70s and 80s) that were encouraging. He exuded the sort of relaxed positivity that most England batsmen take years to display. He left the ball very well, which is crucial for a lefthander, but he also gave it a good thump off both the front and back foot. And he was making runs on surfaces that were green and treacherous, unlike the nice flat tracks he is used to at Taunton. Today's innings of 93 in Peshawar confirms the feeling that his bubble is not about to burst, although there is bound to be a bad patch some time - I just hope the selectors keep faith with him, as they have failed to with so many young players. 4 Dug asked What future vision do we need if Test cricket is to remain a viable and lively sport? What are your views on such innovations as lights in poor playing conditions? Tim de Lisle replied The sad irony of the match-fixing imbroglio is that Test cricket is actually in a very healthy state. The last decade has been a golden age, with several of the great new-ball combinations of all time in action simultaneously -- Ambrose and Walsh, Wasim and Waqar, Donald and Pollock, and now the mouthwatering trio of McGrath, Brett Lee and Gillespie. We have two of the greatest spinners in history, in Warne and Muralitharan; two of the greatest batsmen, in Lara and Tendulkar; and one of the strongest personalities, in Steve Waugh. And several of the closest results in history have taken place in the last few years. So there is no problem with the game's vitality. Viability is more of a worry: crowds in some countries have fallen away or defected to the one-day game. The answer is for ICC to adopt the Wisden World Championship or something very like it(see next answer), so as to add meaning to every Test. And yes, they should certainly be open-minded enough to switch the lights on. 5 aloo2000 wrote Tim, do you feel the current Wisden Test table truly reflects the standings of the teams? I feel the flaws are that it does not: (1) consider the difference between a tight series and a total washout, or (2) distinguish home advantage and away disadvantage. Tim de Lisle replied I think it's a pretty good reflection. I certainly haven't seen a better one - and I speak as one who didn't invent it (that was Matthew Engel). It's certainly not perfect, and I agree with you to an extent about (2) -- an away win is usually a lot harder to pull off than a home one. But I'm not bothered about (1) -- it's the nature of sporting tables that they don't reflect the closeness of the game, unless the game remains close to the very last, and ends up as a draw or tie. Man Utd get the same number of points for a 1-0 win as for a 5-0. 6 KenDavro wrote What football team do you support? Tim de Lisle replied As you might guess from the last answer, I support Man Utd. I'm a typical supporter: I live about 200 miles away and have only been to Old Trafford (the footballing one) once, when, naturally, they lost. But I can claim reasonable longevity. I fell for them because of George Best. The first game I remember was when they beat Northampton Town 8-2 in the Cup, in 1969-70 I think, and Best scored six. What I saw in them then - fabulous flair and excitement, most of it generated by players who were not bought - I still see, as long as Roy Keane is injured or suspended. 7 tentoone wrote Congrats for rescuing WCM from Col. Blimp territory. We look forward to similar innovation on the site. Perhaps there will be scope with a more provincial woops I mean less provincial approach on line given the more cosmopolitan audience. The focus on English County cricket, while it sells the mag locally, is of little interest to those who want to focus on REAL first class cricket!!! Regards from Oz Tim de Lisle replied Thanks. Yes, we are hoping to do something similar with the website, and yes, we will certainly try to be more cosmpolitan. Already, about half of our emails come from outside the UK, so the site will reflect that. Sorry you don't feel that county cricket is first-class. Still, at least it boosts the bank balances of some of your guys. 8 JGK wrote Do you have any jobs going that involve copious amounts of watching cricket and writing the occasional article or commentary? Tim de Lisle replied I wish. We do manage quite a lot of watching, but it's mostly on the telly. Making pages, whether for the web or the magazine, is largely done from offices. And even the people in the press box work hard -- the day may have a gentle start but it has a furiously busy end. If you want an easy life, don't be a cricket writer. If you want an interesting life, do. And yes, we will have some jobs going soon -- details will be posted on wisden.com. 9 JR Canning wrote Who is the best batsman you have seen? Tim de Lisle replied Viv Richards, because he was the most fearsome, the most dominant -- although if TV had moved a little faster, and I had seen Sunil Gavaskar make one of his 13 hundreds against West Indies during the same era, I might well have gone for him. Richards's figures were certainly helped by the fact that he never had to face Holding, Roberts, Garner and Croft. But he wasn't really about figures, he was about power and strength and attitude, and nobody surpassed him in those areas. Of today's batsmen, my favourite is Brian Lara, whose huge backlift expands the possibilities of every ball he faces. 10 Naz1 wrote Do you think Lord MacLaurin was highly hypocritical when he didn't call Alec Stewart back home, considering that he wanted several Pakistanis banned just before a Test series tour which has enough controversy and history as it is? Tim de Lisle replied Yes, there was a whiff of hypocrisy, but if MacLaurin had called Stewart home, there would have been a worse smell, of sheer injustice. It would have been a case of two wrongs not making a right. Stewart has not been accused of match-fixing, nor is he under suspicion of it. He has been accused of taking money for information, the same thing that Shane Warne and Mark Waugh admitted to, and dating from the same period -- the early to mid-Nineties, which was a more innocent time. Warne and Waugh weren't banned, so it would be very rough justice for Stewart to be, even if the case against him had been proven. MacLaurin's series of statements was inept, which is perhaps preferable to being unjust. 11 NeoLeo wrote What do u suggest can be done to create Pakistan-like cricket craziness in England? Tim de Lisle replied Abolish football. 12 NeoLeo added By the way, would the scrapping of the tie-wearing tradition help? Tim de Lisle replied Yes, I think it would. It's a very odd idea, that the spectators should be more formally dressed than the players. I wouldn't want to stop anyone wearing a tie if he wants to, but I can't for the life of me see why it should be compulsory in any part of the ground. Many City firms have managed to break free from this tradition: why can't MCC? 13 chisibm wrote So do you think Stewart is guilty? Tim de Lisle replied No, I don't. I can't see why he would lie about it if he was. He has more to lose by lying than by admitting to the alleged offence -- which, at the time, was not an offence at all. He is not a devious person. webTitle: The Millennium Dome: a troubled history

fields.headline: The Millennium Dome: a troubled history
fields.standfirst: Full text of National Audit Office report
fields.trailText: The management of the Millennium Dome was harshly criticised today in a National Audit Office report. Here's how the saga unfolded:
fields.body:
The management of the Millennium Dome was harshly criticised today in a National Audit Office report. Here's how the saga unfolded:

1994: John Major's Tory government first considered building an enormous dome to mark the new millennium. The idea met with initial resistance, but was later revived.

1995: A committee of MPs - including the current Tory leader, William Hague - approved the building of the dome.

January 1997: The Conservative government's deputy prime minister, Michael Heseltine, pleaded with Tony Blair to back the Millennium Dome project. At first Mr Blair refuses to give his approval - then relents.

May 1997: Labour won the general election. The New Millennium Experience Company was formed to run the dome. The company was alerted to the need for greater operational expertise. According to the National Audit Office: "The marketing strategy relied on the dome selling itself ... NMEC did not appear to have any contingency plans for what to do if the dome failed."

June 1997: The Treasury attempted to kill off the proposed dome at a meeting of newly-elected Labour Cabinet ministers. But the proposed £580m project was saved by the intervention of Peter Mandelson, then minister without portfolio.

June 1997: The millennium commission said it was concerned about the business plan submitted by NMEC.

June 1997: Eric Sorensen, the then millennium commission chief executive, advised commissioners to plan for 8m dome visitors rather than 12m. He warned that there "could not be any certainty about the final cost" of the project.

November 1998: The NMEC forecast that its net grant requirement was £441m rather than the original £399m.

February 1999: After a request from the government, the NMEC agreed to allow free access to the dome for up to 1m schoolchildren. The National Audit Office said this led to revenue losses of £7m.

August 1999: The government was advised that additional cashflow funding was probably necessary to "get the company through the period November 1999 to February 2000".

November 1999: NMEC had used up all but £7m of the commission's £449m grant. Ticket income was expected to exceed the budget, but only by £14.5m. NMEC assumed it would receive 43% of its year 2000 ticket sales in the first three months of the year, despite disappointing advance sales.

December 1999: In a bid to complete the dome and open it on time by December 31, NMEC had spent £586m of its £758m budget.

January 2000: It was clear there would be no surplus from ticket sales, so surplus sponsorship income and the revenue contingency were exhausted.

February 2000: The culture secretary, Chris Smith, wrote to Lord Falconer, the minister with responsibility for the dome, after NMEC chief executive Jennie Page was ousted. He said the NMEC board had not confronted the problems facing the dome or provided leadership. Mr Smith said this was "extremely serious" with regard to financial matters. "Either the board did not see, or it chose to discount the warning signs of the cash-flow difficulties," he wrote.

February 2000: NMEC may have been insolvent since this time, the company's new chief executive David James told the National Audit Office.

February 2000: An extra £60m of lottery money was allocated to the dome.

March 30 2000: Former NMEC chairman Bob Ayling wrote to Mr Smith: "The target of delivering 10m visitors and a break-even budget  cannot be guaranteed."

May 2000: An extra £29m of lottery money was allocated to the dome.

August 2000: An extra £43m of lottery money was allocated to the dome.

September 2000: An extra £47m of lottery money was allocated to the dome.

September 6 2000: Millennium commissioner the Earl of Dalkeith told Lord Falconer that the commission had repeatedly raised questions with NMEC on a range of issues. He wrote: "We have been frustrated by the company's responses, many of which we have perceived as reflecting unchecked resistance by the executive."

webTitle: How charities can lobby within the law

fields.headline: How charities can lobby within the law
fields.standfirst: Charities may only court politicians in a carefully defined, responsible manner
fields.trailText: Charities may only court politicians in a carefully defined, responsible manner
fields.body:
Officially, charities cannot lobby. That's according to charity commission guidelines. However, the National Council for Voluntary Organisations is organising a lobby conference this month, hundreds of charities organised fringe events at this year's party political conferences and charities are increasingly using the internet to make their voices heard.

What the charity commission says:
The charity commission states that courts have decreed that seeking or opposing changes in the law or government policy or decisions, whether in this country or abroad, are political purposes and not, therefore, charitable.

However, a charity can engage in political activity if:
 There is a reasonable expectation that the activity will further the stated purposes of the charity, and so benefit its beneficiaries, to an extent justified by the resources devoted to the activity
 The activity is within the powers that the trustees have to achieve those purposes
 The activity is consistent with these guidelines, and the views expressed are based on a well-founded and reasoned case and are expressed in a responsible way

Top tips for getting your message across:

Phil Hope, Labour MP
"A personal approach is best. Build up a relationship with your local MP. Involve them in local events, especially if they can get their picture in the local paper. For example, the other week, I abseiled down a tower for RNIB - that was fun and it was money and profile raising.

"Another tack is to join the all-parliamentary group best suited to your cause. This gives you access to select committees and parliamentary procedures."

Nusrat Ul-Ghani, parliamentary and public affairs officer, Breakthrough Breast Cancer
"I worked on the Debate of the Age campaign for Age Concern in my previous job. That campaign worked because of the weight of the information I was passing on to government. We had research from focus groups, more than 1,000 events and evidence from a group of voluntary organisations.You also need to come up with an alternative policy suggestion, not just moan about existing policy.

"Now I work as part of the Breast Cancer Forum with 10 other charities. To lobby effectively you need to channel a number of charities through one medium. Other tips are to make contacts at all levels, committees, all party groups and press home your point until they are sick of you!"

Emily Holzhausen, Carers National Association
"Make sure you present a balanced case, know your background. Engage local people in your cause. It is important to know what action to take at the different stages of a campaign. The four steps of a campaign are: get the cause on the agenda; broaden the agenda; once successful, work with the rollout of the campaign and, when it is done, review and give feedback."

Richard Davids, public affairs officer, Cancer Research Campaign
"Three weeks before the government announcements on cancer at the Labour party conference, we launched a pledge card that we sent to all MPs. We also had a photocall outside the Houses of Parliament. One of the pledges, 'matching charitable funding pound for pound', was used by Tony Blair in his keynote speech to conference."

Build up a relationship with your local MP. Involve them in local events, especially if they can get their picture in the local paper. For example, the other week, I abseiled down a tower for RNIB - that was fun and it was money and profile raising. "Another tack is to join the all-parliamentary group best suited to your cause. This gives you access to select committees and parliamentary procedures." Nusrat Ul-Ghani, parliamentary and public affairs officer, Breakthrough Breast Cancer "I worked on the Debate of the Age campaign for Age Concern in my previous job. That campaign worked because of the weight of the information I was passing on to government. We had research from focus groups, more than 1,000 events and evidence from a group of voluntary organisations.You also need to come up with an alternative policy suggestion, not just moan about existing policy. "Now I work as part of the Breast Cancer Forum with 10 other charities. To lobby effectively you need to channel a number of charities through one medium. Other tips are to make contacts at all levels, committees, all party groups and press home your point until they are sick of you!" Emily Holzhausen, Carers National Association "Make sure you present a balanced case, know your background. Engage local people in your cause. It is important to know what action to take at the different stages of a campaign. The four steps of a campaign are: get the cause on the agenda; broaden the agenda; once successful, work with the rollout of the campaign and, when it is done, review and give feedback." Richard Davids, public affairs officer, Cancer Research Campaign "Three weeks before the government announcements on cancer at the Labour party conference, we launched a pledge card that we sent to all MPs. We also had a photocall outside the Houses of Parliament. One of the pledges, 'matching charitable funding pound for pound', was used by Tony Blair in his keynote speech to conference."

fields.headline: Cancer: the issue explained
fields.trailText: More than any other clinical priority, the government has staked its credibility on tackling cancer, one of Britain's biggest killers and - in terms of its lamentable record in treating the disease - one of the health service's most shameful failures.
fields.body:
More than any other clinical priority, the government has staked its credibility on tackling cancer, one of Britain's biggest killers and - in terms of its lamentable record in treating the disease - one of the health service's most shameful failures.

The national cancer plan, launched with great fanfare by health secretary Alan Milburn at the Labour Party conference, puts in place a strategy that promises to bring the UK's record on the disease into line with the rest of western Europe.

The plan will serve as a barometer, measuring the state of the NHS. As it states: "The ability of the NHS to modernise and reform its cancer services is a litmus test for the health of the NHS as a whole."

At the heart of the plan is a series of, on the face of it, ambitious targets related to waiting times, together with an aspirational "ultimate goal" of a maximum one-month wait between urgent referral for suspected cancer and the start of treatment. According to Mr Milburn: "The plan will develop cancer services in this country that compare with the best in Europe. By 2010, our five-year survival rates for cancer will compare with the best in Europe."

Such promises are a hostage to fortune, even though many of the performance targets set by the government will not have to be met until 2005 - towards the end of a second electoral term. It will not be an easy ride. The plan is being launched against a backdrop of years of underinvestment in staff and equipment that has created comparatively poor cancer survival rates, particularly for the worse off, and wide geographical variations in access to and quality of treatment. And while the waiting time targets represent an improvement on current NHS performance, specialists say even if they are met they will not put the NHS on a par with other European countries.

"The targets are reasonable given the state of the NHS, but soft compared to Holland and France. In France you would expect a consultant appointment in a couple of days not a couple of weeks," says Professor Gordon McVie, director general of Cancer Research campaign.

The success of the plan is tied inextricably to the far-from-guaranteed success of the government's NHS reforms. In particular, it depends on plans to hire thousands more nurses, doctors and scientists. Ministers aim to recruit 1,000 extra cancer specialists, as well as more radiographers and nurses, by 2006.

But Prof McVie warns more needs to be done sooner. "We have asked for 600 oncologists (specialist cancer doctors) in three years; they have promised 1,000 in six years. We should be going abroad now to get these extra doctors."

webTitle: We will dwarf Sky, says NTL

fields.headline: We will dwarf Sky, says NTL
fields.trailText: 5pm: Barclay Knapp, the chief executive of cable operator NTL, has said his company will eventually overtake BSkyB and dominate the non-terrestrial TV market.
fields.body:
Barclay Knapp, the chief executive of cable operator NTL, has said his company will eventually overtake BSkyB and dominate the non-terrestrial TV market.

Mr Knapp made his comments at a presentation of the company's third quarter results, which revealed losses of over £500m.

"I hope people realise that cable will have a competitive advantage. Our network has a superior capacity and reliability to any other in the country. Sky will reach its target of 7m customers, but cable should pass 12m in the next few years," said Mr Knapp.

Mr Knapp added that the NTL cable network has added more viewers than Sky's over the past two years, and will continue to do so in the future.

NTL has signed a five year carriage deal with BSkyB, but the company is intent on winning the subscriber war with its closes rival.

BSkyB are currently well ahead in the battle with 4m digital customers, with NTL's total standing at 325,000.

fields.headline: Praise for health production-line
fields.standfirst: A London health centre is winning accolades for its levels of efficiency
fields.trailText: A London health centre is winning accolades for its production-line levels of efficiency
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair opened it last year. Health secretary Alan Milburn chose it as the symbolically important venue from which to announce the NHS national plan earlier this year.

The Central Middlesex Ambulatory Care and Diagnostic Centre (ACAD) may not boast the snappiest of names, but such heavyweight political endorsement means it is one of the most fashionable sites in the NHS.

The centre, which is pioneering a revolutionary "production-line" approach to routine operations, even received a citation in the NHS plan as a model of good practice. As a result, dozens of doctors and managers, not to mention ministers from the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly, have visited the centre in Park Royal, north-west London, in the past few months.

It easy to see why New Labour has adopted the £19m centre as an icon of NHS modernisation. It promises speedy, bureaucracy-free diagnosis and treatment, providing a greater volume of care, more efficiently. The key to ACAD's success is the way it has "re-engineered" the treatment of patients from diagnosis through to discharge, making the most efficient use of staff, facilities, and technologies.

Dr Giordano Abondatti, ACAD clinical director, says the process of carrying out routine elective operations to treat varicose veins, hernias and the like is similar to running a factory production line. One of the major innovations has been changing the skill mix of the "production-line" workers. Previously rigid traditional demarcations between "nurses' work" and "doctors' work" have been blurred. Acting under agreed protocols, nurses have been trained to carry out procedures previously reserved for doctors such as preoperative assessments, x-rays and electrocardiograms.

Dr Abondatti argues that this allows doctors to target their skills more tightly. "Doctors have monopolised healthcare. But that is like using a bunch of highly trained graduate engineers to assemble Ford Fiestas."

There have been mixed reactions from the staff to the new ways. Nurses have generally been enthusiastic about taking on more clinical responsibilities. Some doctors have been less keen to hand over duties.

But the results have been encouraging, even opening up the tantalising prospect of making that staple of NHS winter crises, cancelled elective operations, a thing of the past. Traditionally district general hospitals have integrated emergency and non-urgent care. This means that at times of high pressure, such as winter flu crises, elective beds are commandeered for emergency work, forcing non-urgent work to be cancelled and inflating waiting lists.

Because ACAD is a stand-alone elective centre, with its own onsite theatre, bed and diagnostic facilities it is barely affected by such pressures. "We did not cancel anybody's operation during this year's winter beds crisis," says ACAD manager Jean Silkoff.

The centre has developed a more flexible, patient-friendly approach. Patients can choose a date for their operations. It runs a "one-stop" breast cancer clinic in which women can be tested and diagnosed during a single visit.

The centre is also demonstrably more efficient. While the cost per patient is the same as a traditional district hospital, its avoidance of cancelled operations means it is treating up to 10% more patients a year.

"We haven't cracked it yet. We are still very much at the beginning," insists Dr Abondatti. But ministers appear to have decided already that it is the way forward. They have ordered a further 19 ACAD-style sites to be built by 2004.

webTitle: Chime Communications picks up three new companies

fields.headline: Chime Communications picks up three new companies
fields.trailText: Lord Bell's Chime Communications has acquired three new companies in a £24m shopping spree, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Lord Bell's Chime Communications has acquired three new companies in a £24m shopping spree.

The three companies are Roose & Partners, an advertising agency whose clients include Nestle Rowntree and Bass Brewers; Quentin Bell Organisation, the PR agency for Royal Mail and British Gas; and the creative consultancy Girardot Partners.

"Each agency is a strong brand name in their business area and they will sit well alongside the other industry-leading brands that we have established within Chime," the company said in a statement.

Chime agreed a deal worth up to £13.6m to acquire Roose & Partners. The company, which is most famous in the industry for its Bodyform ads, is one of the last remaining independent UK ad agencies.

Chairman Ted Roose said: "We've been approached many times but this is the only time I've got excited about it.

"Chime has a very good reputation and this deal allows us to preserve our own style and culture, which is what our clients have bought into and like."

The acquisition of Quentin Bell for up to £8.4m consolidates Chime's position as the biggest player in the UK PR market. Lord Bell added that Chime was also looking at further acquisitions in PR, particularly in the US.

fields.headline: Chopper,  Cropper, and  Coppers
fields.trailText: TAYLOR TINKERS
fields.body:
TAYLOR TINKERS

When Peter Taylor was appointed caretaker coach of England last month, he promised to blood several of the young bucks from his U-21 squad during the friendly against Italy. "But that means Carl Cort leading the line doesn't it?" screamed the Fiver, as we experienced one of our "pass the tablets mother, our legs are feeling woozy" moments. Fortunately that particular moment passed - the miracles of modern medicine, eh? - and today we felt strong enough to take our rightful place, just behind Brian Woolnough's towering bouffant, in the England press conference.

What we heard was most interesting - although if you're a England international over 30 and you don't play for Aston Villa you should look away now. Peter Taylor's New England contains no Adams, no Keown, no Wise, no Ince and no Sheringham. And there's no place for Andy or Joe Cole either. Instead, come on down Michael Ball, Wes Brown, Nicky Butt, Frank Lampard, Paul Robinson, Alan Smith and Seth Johnson... because the time is right.

However, Taylor was quick to reassure Adams and chums that this was no November revolution. "I've decided to go with players of 30 years or younger because it's a friendly and it's worth experimenting," the caretaker explained. "It's worth taking a chance. If this had been a qualifying game I definitely would have kept more experience in the squad," he nervously continued, as if haunted by the spectre of a wild and menacing Middlesbrough midfielder.

England squad for next Wednesday's friendly against Italy in Turin: Anderton (Tottenham), Ball (Everton), Barmby (Liverpool), Barry (Aston Villa), Beckham (Man Utd, capt), Brown (Man Utd), Butt (Man Utd), Carragher (Liverpool), Dyer (Newcastle), R Ferdinand (West Ham), Fowler (Liverpool), Gerrard (Liverpool), Heskey (Liverpool), James (Aston Villa), Johnson (Derby), Lampard (West Ham), G Neville (Man Utd), P Neville (Man Utd), Owen (Liverpool), Parlour (Arsenal), Phillips (Sunderland), Robinson (Leeds), Scholes (Man Utd), Smith (Leeds), Southgate (Aston Villa), Wright (Ipswich).

A BIT TOO KEANE TO CRITICISE

Coronation Street's Roy Cropper, owner of popular Weatherfield eaterie Roy's Rolls, isn't the only Roy in the Manchester district with a word or two to say about popular bread-based snacks. Local footballer Roy Keane, for example, has been loudly opining about prawn sandwiches, and what they stand for, as part of a maniacal salvo aimed at fans who dared to criticise Manchester United's stuttering Big Cup performance against Dynamo Kiev last night.

"Away from home our fans are fantastic, what I'd call the hardcore fans," a clearly upset Royston could be heard telling BBC Radio above the loud stomping of feet. "But at home they have a few drinks and some prawn sandwiches but they don't realise what is going on out on the pitch. Our fans away from home are as good as any but at home you sometimes must wonder do they understand the game of football?" he demanded in a whiney bleat.

"Some people come here to Old Trafford and I don't think they can spell football never mind understand it," continued Keane from the safety of the intellectual hothouse that is the United dressing room. "One or two stray passes here and there and they are on players' backs and it's not on!" It certainly isn't, Roy. Although if United passed the ball last night as well as you're passing the buck now, those spoilt folk who pay your wages wouldn't have a leg to stand on, would they?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"My visit to the dentist turned out to be a good one. The wisdom tooth cracked a little bit but it came out without any problem" - Rangers defender Bert Konterman remembers the good times.

LAUGHING ALL THE WAY TO THE LEEDS

Now that Leeds are officially the best team in Europe, it's about time they went crazy in the transfer market. They certainly don't have to worry about money any more, because having qualified for the second matchleaguephase of Big Cup, they've just been given an extra £10m by those avuncular chaps at Uefa. You can almost hear David O'Leary whooping in a quasi-religious manner from here.

"Progress to the next phase was the main concern, with the financial side almost secondary," explained Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale, lighting a fag from a burning £50 note. "But we said to the stock exchange that we would reinvest the money we made in [Big Cup] in the squad."

West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand is top of manager Dave's shopping list - after all, you can't seriously embark on world domination without a ball-playing defender who goes to sleep for, on average, seven minutes per match. It's rumoured that West Ham are finally prepared to accept Leeds' £15m bid, so Rio could be playing in a Leeds shirt very soon.

Sadly, until the big deal is sorted out, all Leeds fans have to look forward to is the arrival of cheapo Brann Bergen strikers Azar Karadas and Thorstein Helstad. After all, there's no fun to be had with players who cost less than £10m. What's Mark Viduka ever done, for example?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Celtic and Rangers are slugging it out to sign Liverpool striker Titi Camara, reports Teamtalk.

Lazio have given a cryptic response to rumours that Chelsea have made a £22m bid for Czech Republic international Pavel Nedved, reports onefootball. "We do not confirm and we do not refute the offer," Lazio vice-president Dino Zoff commented. "But until next June, Nedved will remain at Lazio."

Paolo Di Canio has turned down a £5m move to Manchester City.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Tests have shown that the site of the 2002 World Cup final in Japan has been polluted with high levels of potentially dangerous toxic waste. A spokesman for the SYS Citizen's environmental survey team said: "The situation is quite serious and we are very much concerned about holding the World Cup final on this contaminated site. We cannot accept a reckless approach without taking sufficient measures to protect the environment and the health risk to the citizens of the neighbourhood and also the visitors of the World Cup final."

Geoffrey Richmond has received a bumper crop of applicants for the vacant manager's position at Bradford City. "I'm delighted with the quality of applicants," he claimed. "There are some big names amongst them who've not been speculated upon in the media."

Manchester United, Arsenal and Leeds will be kept apart in tomorrow's Big Cup draw. The group winners and runners-up have been ranked according to their Uefa coefficient with the top four seeds, headed by holders Real Madrid, in Pot 1.

Pot 1: Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, Valencia, AC Milan.
Pot 2: Deportivo La Coruna, Arsenal, Anderlecht, Sturm Graz.
Pot 3: Lazio, Manchester United, Spartak Moscow, Paris Saint-Germain.
Pot 4: Olympique Lyonnais, Galatasaray, Panathinaikos, Leeds.

Rudi Voller has been appointed manager of Germany until after the 2002 World Cup.

Former Norwich and Everton boss Mike Walker has been appointed the new manager of Cypriot club Apoel Nicosia.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 5: Live Euro-Vase Football - Slovan Liberec v Liverpool (6.45pm)
Gerald Houllier's team face the plucky Czech part-timers (or pub team, if you're Trevor Brooking).

Football Night - Slovan Liberec v Liverpool (12.40am, 4.20am)
And again. And again! Steady on Channel 5, this isn't Football League Review on Sky, you know.

Dutch Football (1.10am)
Spookily beamed into your bedroom exactly 69 minutes after European Blue Review finishes.

Argentinian Football (2.45pm)
Velez Sarsfield Vinegars v Boca Big Boys.

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (7pm)
Hang on a second! What's happened to Fifa TV?

Live International Schoolboy Football - Scotland v Northern Ireland (7.30pm)
Hmmm. It's not here either. We're getting suspicious.

You're on Sky Sports! (10pm)
First Burnside and now Sepp Blatter. What's so wrong with slapheads appearing on TV?

Spanish Football (11pm)
It's not as if they're ginger or anything.

Fifa TV (2.30am)
Ah! At last we can get our weekly fix of footballing bureaucracy, back-handers and bribery.

British Eurosport: Live Uefa Football (8pm)
More good news - at last there's a match on Eurosport which isn't from the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.

webTitle: Climate change: World may be warming up faster

fields.headline: World may be warming up even faster
fields.standfirst:
Scientists warn new forests would make effects worse
Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Global warming could be faster and fiercer than expected, and new forests to soak up the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide may not help, according to research today from British scientists.
fields.body:
Global warming could be faster and fiercer than expected, and new forests to soak up the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide may not help, according to research today from British scientists.

Their computer models predict a rise in global average land temperatures of up to 6C in the next century, 2C higher than previous forecasts.

The scientists foresee an Arctic in which sea ice in September is reduced dramatically to a couple of large floes in the middle of clear ocean. They forecast in Nature that bacteria will release carbon dioxide from warmer northern soils faster than forests can take it up. The rainforests of the Amazon will turn into arid savannah, releasing even more carbon dioxide.

The 10 warmest years since records began have been in the past two decades. This year is expected to emerge as the fifth warmest ever. But during these two decades global average temperatures have risen by less than 1C.

The new studies from the Met Office's Hadley centre for climate prediction point to temperatures never experienced in human history, and only matched in the era of the dinosaurs. "We have had warmer periods in the past," said Geoff Jenkins of the Hadley centre. "But the rate of warming is quite unprecedented." Nations of the world will meet in the Hague later this month to discuss ways of cutting carbon dioxide emissions to 5.2% below 1990 levels by 2012. Climate scientists point out that cuts of 60% are needed - and even if these were achieved now, the world would still warm by at least 1C, and sea levels would go on rising for a century.

Nations have been talking of "carbon sinks" - new forests planted to absorb the extra carbon dioxide and cool the world. But the latest papers in Nature suggest that forests planted in Canada and Siberia would increase warming, making things worse.

"The storms and floods being experienced across the UK are a wakeup call to the serious environmental threat posed by climate change," said the environment minister, Michael Meacher. "Public opinion has underestimated just how drastic and severe these phenomena are, and it has brought it home to people better than a million political speeches. We have got to build on that understanding and get agreement to much tougher action."

Uncertainties about global warming rest on doubts about feedback. Snow and ice reflect sunlight back into space - and when these melt, dark ocean and forest absorb more sunlight and step up the rate of warming.

On the other hand, more heat could mean more water vapour which could mean more clouds, reflecting more sunlight into space, thus cancelling some of the warming. With more carbon dioxide in the air, forests would grow more lustily, taking it up again and storing the carbon as wood and reducing the world's warmth. But water vapour is also a powerful greenhouse gas - and the effect of more vapour could cancel the cooling effect of the clouds.

The latest research in Nature shows that forests would continue to mop up carbon dioxide until 2050 - but by then, soil bacteria would be releasing ever increasing amounts of carbon dioxide, and global warming would accelerate. All these scenarios assume a "business as usual" world in which nations go on burning fossil fuel at an increasing rate.

"There are something of the order of seven gigatonnes - 7bn tonnes - of greenhouse gases being emitted. On current trends, by 2100, within the lifetime of our grandchildren, it could be 35-40 gigatonnes," said Mr Meacher. "The implications of that are mindblowing."

•A Foreign Office unit designed to prevent conflict over environmental issues was launched last night in London. The environmental policy department will help negotiations on climate change, forests, trade in endangered species, and biodiversity.

fields.headline: Channel 5 news struggling
fields.trailText: 4.30pm Channel 5's 6pm news is facing the axe as the broadcaster's directors consider moving the poorly performing evening show to an earlier time.
fields.body:
Channel 5's 6pm news is facing the axe as the broadcaster's directors consider moving the poorly performing evening show to an earlier time.

Channel 5 controller of new and current affairs Chris Shaw is believed to favour a move to 5.30pm to avoid clashing with the 6pm news on BBC1 and ITV.

The review of the news comes as speculation mounts that Channel 5 will not renew presenter Andrea Catherwood's contract when it ends in December.

Ms Catherwood has not proved as popular as her predecessor Kirsty Young, who left to join ITV in January, and is reported to be keen to get back into the field. She is in Washington covering the US elections for Channel 5 and will meet with the channel's bosses to discuss her future when she returns.

Channel 5's evening news has performed dismally in the ratings against BBC1's BBC News, also broadcast at 6pm.

When the station launched more than three years ago, the ground-breaking news bulletings, featuring Miss Young perched on a desk, could pull in up to a million viewers.

Last night just 400,000 viewers tuned in to the Channel 5 show, a tiny fraction of the 8m who watched BBC News.

A Channel 5 spokesman said: "We are always looking at what would be the best time slot. There are no imminent announcements planned but clearly it's hard for it to achieve its potential in the slot it is in."

The switch would represent the third move for Channel 5's evening news since the channel launched in 1997. It has already moved from 8.30pm to 7pm then to 6pm. But the broadcaster could face difficulties with the Independent Television Commission if it tried to move its news out of prime time to 5.30pm.

The television watchdog previously blocked an application to broadcast its news before 6pm, but that situation may have changed now that BBC1 and ITV have moved their news broadcasts.

webTitle: South African police on attempted murder charges

fields.headline: South African police on attempted murder charges
fields.standfirst: SABC coverage of the incident
fields.trailText: Six white policeman are to appear in court in Pretoria today charged with attempted murder after the South African Broadcasting Corporation showed a "training video" of black prisoners being used as bait for police dogs.
fields.body:
Six white policeman are to appear in court in Pretoria today charged with attempted murder after the South African Broadcasting Corporation showed a "training video" of black prisoners being used as bait for police dogs.

The victims, all believed to be illegal immigrants, are seen screaming in pain and begging for their lives as the animals tear into their flesh while officers of the North-east Rand police dog unit laugh and taunt them as "kaffirs".

The safety and security minister, Steve Tshwete, ordered the arrest of the policemen, who include an inspector and a sergeant.

"I am horrified and outraged after viewing scenes of blatant brutality and racism committed by a small group of members of the South Africa police service," he said.

"I have become aware of the fact that pockets of racism do indeed exist, but I am shocked to know that some members can act like this."

The video was shot two years ago at an abandoned mine dump and has only just been given to the SABC, presumably by another policeman.

The three immigrants are shown sitting in a vehicle. One is ordered out and told to run as the first dog is let loose. The policemen are heard shouting "Take the bastard" and "Fuck him up" as the dogs tear at his legs.

The dogs are then set on other detainees, who scream for their lives.

At one point an Alsatian goes for a man's throat and genitals. As he tries to fight it off, one of the policemen kicks his hands away and stamps on his stomach and groin.

There is little doubt that the six policemen enjoyed inflicting pain. They are repeatedly shown laughing as their victims scream, and the dogs are referred to as "kaffir biters".

The video has further undermined public confidence in the police force, which is widely seen as incompetent and corrupt, and its white officers as racist.

It is also a reflection of the hostility to immigrants from other African countries, which the human rights commission has described as one of the most worrying forms of racism.

webTitle: How much can you pay for ...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for ...
fields.standfirst: ... a watch?
fields.trailText: ... a watch?
fields.body:
Ever heard the adage "Time is money"? Well, it's certainly true where Patek Philippe watches are concerned. The platinum version of their 5100 range will set you back a cool £22,670. The World Time incorporates two rings, one making up the clock face, the other bearing the names of cities in the 24 time zones.

When arriving in Japan, simply line up Tokyo with the 12 o'clock position and the watch does the rest. The manually wound Ten Days model, meanwhile, has - wait for it - a 10-day power reserve. The platinum models have a diamond set discreetly at 6 o'clock which, I am assured, is the ultimate in stealth wealth.

At £1,500 the Technomarine Millennium is the cheapskate option, but what it lacks in price it makes up for in ghetto-fabulous style. Designed by Stephen Webster, it is ostentatious to the max and going down a storm on both sides of the Atlantic. Leather straps in lurid colours offset the diamond faces to perfection; it has been rumoured that Puff Daddy recently left a New England store with 30 of the things.

 Available from the Patek Philippe store in 15 New Bond St, W1, 020-7493 8866 and Harrods.
