fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
Tights

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tights
fields.body:
It's one of those mornings. You've just upended your cappuccino in the in-tray, got blueberry muffin crumbs on your computer keyboard and to top it all there's a ladder in your tights that a basketball player could walk under. But never fear - mytights.com is a user-friendly site that promises a same-day, desk-to-door delivery service on orders before 12pm.

They stock all the major brands - Aristoc, Chamois, Dior, Pretty Polly - and allow you to search by occasion, finish or denier. A colour selection wheel advises according to skin tone, and the site provides a handy glossary on less familiar terms such as "graduated compression". There's even an advice section for men, offering such gems as: "Buying hold-ups is a safer option than stockings, and almost as sexy!"

If it's Parisian glamour you're after, look no further than sensuelle.co.uk. Collections are divided into catwalks such as Jazz or Classic and once you've realised they scroll horizontally instead of vertically, you're off. At £20 to £30 a pair, it's not cheap, but delivery is free, and the French terms do wonders for the morale, making even tummy control (ventre plat) sound sexy. There's a particularly interesting little patterned number designed by Jean Boggio which incorporates the fairy tale of Puss in Boots.

You could be forgiven for mistaking agentprovocateur.com for a porn site, with its red interior, flash graphics and scantily clad ladies. As you might expect, the hosiery department offers only stockings and hold-ups. Think Pretty Woman - go on, indulge yourself!

webTitle: Consumer: Retailers aim for better service

fields.headline: Are you being served?
fields.standfirst: Long queues, rude or indifferent staff - all part of the shopping experience. But consumers are in revolt over shoddy service, and finally a few canny retailers are wising up. Helen Jones reports
fields.trailText: Long queues, rude or indifferent staff - all part of the shopping experience. But consumers are in revolt over shoddy service, and finally a few canny retailers are wising up. Helen Jones reports.
fields.body:
Are you happy with the service you are getting? The answer is probably: "Not very." But are you prepared to pay for better service? A growing number of companies think you are.

The average British consumer spends 73 hours a year queuing, according to research from retail consultants Atwood SB. "Shopping should be a pleasurable experience but all too often it's a pain," says Atwood SB's president, Trevor Edwards. He says that more than half of all consumers have walked out of a shop because they were so disgusted by the service they received. Long queues and rude or indifferent staff are due to the fact that "retailers are focusing too much on low prices. They keep prices low by cutting back on staff and not adequately training the staff they have," says Edwards.

However, we are increasingly willing to complain about bad service. Paul Edwards, chairman of the Henley Centre consumer consultancy, says that research indicates that 56% of consumers have complained about poor service or faulty goods in the past year - up from 39% in 1997.

"It's partly because our expectations have risen. In the past only Marks & Spencer offered a no-questions-asked, money-back guarantee, now everyone offers that and the goal posts have moved," he says.

Companies are starting to realise that they have to improve standards. Many major retailers now employ undercover shoppers who travel around stores observing levels of customer service and then report back to head office.

Mike Godliman, of retail analysts Verdict, says that retailers also recognise that consumers have changed. "In the past, people bought things because they needed them. Now most people have the necessities of life so retailers have to persuade them to buy clothing, electrical goods and other things that they don't really need. So good service becomes much more important."

While there is no doubt that service is a real issue for consumers, would we pay more for higher standards? Edwards believes that we would. He says only one in eight shoppers looks for the cheapest prices rather than service and quality when shopping. "There is lots of evidence that people will go elsewhere and pay a little bit more for better service."

Airlines have always charged for superior standards of service. BA for example, has recently introduced a premier card which ensures that you will get the best possible service from the airline. The bad news is that it is only offered at BA's discretion to its most important customers.

American Express has introduced the black "Centurion" card which will get you into fully booked restaurants and offers complimentary upgrades on 15 airlines, for an annual fee of £550. The only problem is that you have to earn around £150,000 a year to qualify.

And Lloyds TSB has introduced private banking. This provides customers with a personalised service and helps them make the most of their money, However, charges are higher than on an ordinary current account and there is an additional quarterly charge of £35.

"Banks, telecommunications companies and retailers are already taking steps to identify high spenders. In general 20% of their customers generate 80% of their profits and so they are extremely valuable," says Godliman.

He adds that, in future, supermarkets may provide a better standard of service to high-spending customers. "At the moment the people spending least - those with just a basket of shopping - get a special queue and get served quicker."

Supermarkets may soon offer loyalty cards with embedded micro chips to high spenders. These customers will then be identified as soon as they walk into the store and could get help with their shopping, a VIP queue, special offers and help loading their car or if they prefer, free home delivery.

According to Edwards, there is no doubt that "people will be prepared to pay more for better service" but he adds that the service will have to be exceptional. "If people are paying for the privilege of better service then it will have to live up to expectation or companies could find themselves facing some very angry customers."

fields.headline: Capital Radio's profits up
fields.trailText: Capital Radio, home of Chris Tarrant has shrugged off the earnings fears sweeping the media sector by boosting profits on the back of a rise in advertising sales.
fields.body:
Capital Radio, home of Chris Tarrant and Dr Fox, has shrugged off the earnings fears sweeping the media sector by boosting profits on the back of a rise in advertising sales.

Pre-tax profits for the year were £41.3m have almost doubled in the year, up from £37.7m in 1999, with advertising revenue rising by 14.6%.

The bumper profits at the largest radio group in the country contrast sharply with the fortunes of other media companies.

Shares in media companies such as Granada Media have been hit recently by warnings about falls in advertising revenues.

Peter Harris, finance director of Capital Radio, said: "Advertising revenues in the short term will be uncertain, as shown by Granada Media's recent troubles.

"But in the long term, radio is still very cost effective for advertisers. The TV market is fragmenting, whereas radio is consolidating."

Mr Harris added that UK commercial radio will undergo the same consolidation process as ITV, which now has two dominant players in Granada Media and Carlton Communications.

However, he said the government's forthcoming whitepaper on communications reform needs to recommend a change in ownership rules if the radio market is to be shaken up.

Mr Harris said the reform may take some years to be implemented, but Capital will be at the forefront of any attempt to gain pole position in the commercial radio sector, with Emap and GWR close behind.

The owner of Capital FM and Xfm has made a series of acquisitions in the past year, including Border Television's radio assets and the Beat 106 station in Scotland, and has invested heavily in its digital and internet operations.

Mr Harris added that the government should take a more hands-on approach to digital radio, and announce a date for the analogue switch-off.

Pre-tax profits for the year were £41.3m have almost doubled in the year, up from £37.7m in 1999, with advertising revenue rising by 14.6%. The bumper profits at the largest radio group in the country contrast sharply with the fortunes of other media companies. Shares in media companies such as Granada Media have been hit recently by warnings about falls in advertising revenues. Peter Harris, finance director of Capital Radio, said: "Advertising revenues in the short term will be uncertain, as shown by Granada Media's recent troubles. "But in the long term, radio is still very cost effective for advertisers. The TV market is fragmenting, whereas radio is consolidating." Mr Harris added that UK commercial radio will undergo the same consolidation process as ITV, which now has two dominant players in Granada Media and Carlton Communications. However, he said the government's forthcoming whitepaper on communications reform needs to recommend a change in ownership rules if the radio market is to be shaken up. Mr Harris said the reform may take some years to be implemented, but Capital will be at the forefront of any attempt to gain pole position in the commercial radio sector, with Emap and GWR close behind. The owner of Capital FM and Xfm has made a series of acquisitions in the past year, including Border Television's radio assets and the Beat 106 station in Scotland, and has invested heavily in its digital and internet operations. Mr Harris added that the government should take a more hands-on approach to digital radio, and announce a date for the analogue switch-off.

webTitle: Charities must market volunteering to the young

fields.headline: Charities must market volunteering to the young
fields.standfirst: Young people look for fun, friends, and the opportunity to learn new skills when considering volunteering, says Patrick McCurry
fields.trailText: Young people look for fun, friends, and the opportunity to learn new skills when considering volunteering, says Patrick McCurry.
fields.body:
Michael Norton, executive chair of the charity Changemakers, heads the International Year of Volunteers sub-group on young people. He argues that voluntary organisations must look more closely at what they offer young volunteers and how such volunteering is marketed and organised.

As well as helping others, "young people want to know what they will get out of the volunteering, whether that be new skills, friends or a more impressive CV," he says. "Young people respond to things that are targeted at them and are expressed in their language. For example, they often don't respond well to the word volunteering."

TimeBank, which matches volunteers with their favourite pastimes and interests, found in a survey of 8,000 of its volunteers this summer that 84% had not volunteered before.

TimeBank refers to its volunteers as "time givers", notes Stephen Howlett, a researcher at the Institute of Volunteering Research. "Voluntary organisations must recognise that younger people don't necessarily want to make a long-term commitment," he says.

Zoe Speakman, network development worker at Student Volunteering UK which is researching student volunteering, says many charities could market volunteering more effectively by stressing that it is fun. It is also worth promoting the opportunity to gain experience of soft skills, such as dealing with people, which are increasingly important for careers: "Even in areas like accountancy, employers are looking for staff with those kinds of skills so that they can deal with clients effectively."

Perhaps some charities neglect to "sell" volunteering opportunities because they believe volunteers should only be motivated by altruism, says Speakman.

Student Volunteering UK is organising the first Student Community Action Week in February next year in connection with the International Year of Volunteers. The aim is to publicise and encourage volunteering.

At the British Trust for Conservation Volunteers, which works with 130,000 volunteers a year, there is growing recognition of the need to understand what motivates young people and an attempt to involve them more in the running of the organisation. BTCV recently announced that volunteers would automatically become members, instead of having to pay an annual fee, and would receive newsletters as well as the right to vote in internal elections.

"This is a way of showing how much we value our volunteers and developing links with them," says spokeswoman Helen Mitchell, adding that through questionnaires and other communications the charity hopes to build up a picture of the young people that volunteer. "We want to find out what they're looking for, whether that's helping the environment or getting new skills for their CV," she says.

She accepts that BTCV, like other charities, has been affected by the fall in unemployment: "We used to get lots of young people volunteering, who had time on their hands because they were looking for jobs but that's changed."

The BTCV initiative, she says, is the next step on from initiatives like TimeBank: "We're looking at how you build relationships with volunteers once you've recruited them."

webTitle: The new breed of mental health worker

fields.headline: Recruitment net widens
fields.standfirst: A wider range of people could soon be recruited to work in mental health, writes Laurence Pollock
fields.trailText: When the government's national plan for the NHS was launched, stories about more doctors, nurses and beds grabbed the headlines.
fields.body:
When the government's national plan for the NHS was launched, stories about more doctors, nurses and beds grabbed the headlines.

The plan is a big document, however, with considerable detail. The nuts and bolts about mental health turn up in chapter 14 and there is a strong emphasis on service delivery at the primary care level. Ministers want more early intervention in mental health problems. They also believe the necessary skills can be acquired by people other than specialist community mental health nurses and psychiatrists.

The national plan states: "One thousand new graduate primary care mental health workers, trained in brief therapy techniques of proven effectiveness, will be employed to help GPs manage and treat common mental health problems in all age groups, including children."

Service users
The Department of Health says training and recruitment over the next two years will mean new workers in place for year three of the spending review (2003-04).

But where is the new breed to come from? The government's mental health "tsar", Louis Appleby, suggests psychology graduates. An expert in psychiatric nurse training, Kevin Gournay, believes that service users, those who have experienced mental illness and used mental health services, could be recruited. Meanwhile, there is wariness among more well established professionals such as community psychiatric nurses.

The new policy rests on a perception that early intervention in mental illness is crucial and currently under-resourced. A patient's condition can deteriorate rapidly if the orthodox and time-consuming route through GP, consultant psychiatrist and then treatment is followed. The new primary care mental health workers would target "common" illnesses, such as panic attacks, agoraphobia and depression, delivering so-called "brief interventions" - basic cognitive therapy rather than medication-based solutions.

A whole new type of health professional raises numerous questions about training, links with other staff and where the new recruits will come from. Appleby, appointed this year as the government's national director for mental health, says many of the details are still under discussion. He has said that psychology graduates could be an obvious source, though other social science disciplines might also be appropriate.

Logical step
Currently, psychology graduates find their way into a wide range of fields. Some, who would prefer a career in clinical psychology, are thwarted by the competitive entrance requirements and might consider training for the new posts. Others might be seeking higher pay than offered by the health service. Sally Coombes, for example, a second year student at Warwick University, said the new role was a "logical step" for someone doing psychology but it was not for her. "I'm looking at jobs in the city or banks," she says.

Gournay, the iconoclastic professor of psychiatric nursing at King's College London Institute of Psychiatry, would cast the net wider. Alongside graduates and practice nurses, he suggests that service users be brought into the frame.

He is patron of the charity No Panic, which offers telephone support to people affected by panic attacks. No Panic counsellors include those who suffer from the condition.

"We have evaluated the help given by some of the No Panic workers using brief cognitive therapies and the outcomes are really good. Evidence from the United States suggests users can be become good case managers," he says.

Enthusiastic
Gournay acknowledges that many mental health professionals have worries but he is an enthusiast for the plan. His reputation among some community psychiatric nurses as "the anti-Christ" is only half affectionate.

Brian Rogers, professional officer for the Community Psychiatric Nurses' Association, warns that the new staff "must have something specific to do". He argues: "The health service should be appointing 'local champions' who will speak for mental health, as primary care is developed over the next few years."

Rogers may have put his finger on something. Primary care is set for big shake-ups with the spread of primary care trusts, and then health and care trusts embracing social services. The new mental health workers will have to find their feet at a turbulent time. They will need all the help they can get.

fields.headline: How to stay cool in a crisis
fields.standfirst: PR consultant Adam Woolf advises on how to keep your organisation under control when a crisis erupts
fields.trailText: PR consultant Adam Woolf advises on how to keep your organisation under control when a crisis erupts.
fields.body:
However well your organisation is run, the unexpected can happen. Things can go wrong. Then, when the media starts to ask nasty and awkward questions, they can get worse. There is no one way of dealing with a crisis and negative media interest. There are, however, general principles that will help you to judge what to do when the media has got hold of a bad story.

1. Do not presume the media is against you. The media is like a mirror, it reflects legitimate public concern. Always try to think how the public would react.

2. Bad press is never pleasant, but the key is to figure out how this negative publicity will affect your reputation with key audiences. In order to do this, you need to know who your key audiences are and think through how they would react to the story. Do not judge the impact on the size of the headline.

3. Try to judge issues and your own organisation as an objective outsider would, not as a committed insider. You will need to gauge the value of the story. First and foremost, find out if it is true. Act as the journalists would. Find out the facts before you decide what to do.

4. Always acknowledge public concern, even if you think it is misplaced. In retail, the customer is always right. In PR and crisis management, the public is always right. You may need long term strategies to change public perceptions. You cannot confront or change them during a crisis.

5. Always respond decisively. Try to remember that actions speak louder than words. The public does not want statements and press releases. It wants your charity to take action. In this sense, what you do is more important than what you say.

6. Establish clear communication lines and areas of responsibility within your charity. Never be rushed into talking to the media, but never be paralysed because no one has the authority to speak to the press and make crucial decisions.

7. Have a crisis management plan ready that deals with the practical side of coping with high levels of media interest. This would look at the various issues that you would face if you attracted substantial media interest.

The plan would specify details such as who would initially deal with telephone calls from the media. If you already have a press or publicity officer could they cope? What extra resources will you need? Who will make the decisions?

Should your organisation ever be in the glare of negative publicity, you will be stressed and extremely busy just trying to react to what's going on. A ready made plan will help to keep your head clear, outline what to do and who needs to do it.

8. Try to get as much warning as possible. A crisis management plan should also evaluate and investigate your own organisation. It should ask where the organisation is vulnerable to negative press coverage and what can be done about it in advance.

9. Seek advice and help. Dealing with the media is not a science. Decisions are largely based on experience, common sense and intuition.

10. Don't try to be too clever. Even Alastair Campbell gets things wrong. Do not try to use clever news management techniques to get you out of trouble. Unless you know what you are doing, you will only make things worse.

fields.headline: NTL trebles its losses
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: NTL, the UK's largest cable operator, has nearly trebled its losses as it plays catch-up in the UK Digital TV market, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
NTL, the UK's largest cable operator, has nearly trebled its losses as it plays catch-up in the UK Digital TV market.

The US-listed company said the total of UK digital subscribers had risen 40% to 325,00 in the three months to September, and it was on target for 500,000 by year-end.

NTL remains some distance behind BSkyB, which has over 4m digital subscribers and has also suffered deep losses in the chase for viewers.

The company's third-quarter deficit deepened from $278m (£195m) to $770m (£542m), with its debt burden currently hovering around the £7bn mark. NTL said the figures reflected the cost of rolling out its UK digital TV service.

NTL recently pulled out of a £328m pay-per-view deal with the Premier League, amid rumours that the deal was a loss-maker.

And last week, it announced it would cut 1,300 staff from its UK workforce.

The company's trump card remains its cable network, which covers 50% of the UK and has the likes of BSkyB and Universal Studios queuing up to use it.

"We expect these short-term higher integration and digital rollout expenses to continue through to the second quarter of 2001," NTL said.

The £11bn company added that its ntlword internet service had added more than 235,000 subscribers, taking the total to 380,000. The company added that it is now the third-largest internet service provider in the UK.

fields.headline: Dawn Airey at Forty
fields.standfirst: Happy Birthday Dawn. Like the goat, this executive's Capricorn ambition means her influence peaks in 2009, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.trailText: Happy Birthday Dawn. Like the goat, this executive's Capricorn ambition means her influence peaks in 2009, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
In the eleventh century, Arabic astrologer Al-Biruni observed that Scorpios are 'pleased with themselves', and as Scorpio Dawn Airey (November 15 1960) celebrates her fortieth birthday, she has good reason to feel smug. Recently appointed as Channel 5 controller, she has the backing of its main shareholder, RTL, and a fifty percent budget increase.

Scorpio - symbol of sex, power and secrets - seems to be flavour of the month in the television world. Rival Lorraine Heggessey at BBC1 is four years older but has a birthday one day later (November 16 1956), locking the two women into deadly rivalry in the ratings war. Think Lady Macbeth and the Queen of Spades.

So what advice might the old astrologers give to Airey? Writing about the Scorpio temperament in 1910 astrologer Alan Leo comments: "you are a firm and powerful character, arising from the silent force within. You possess magnetic power, critical perception and ability to judge keenly, but when not fully under control, your character will be rather exacting, jealous and proud".

Airey's fun-loving, frank and cheeky style expresses her provocative Uranus in fiery Leo, and a striking feature in her horoscope is a square aspect of this rebellious planet to her Sun. Uranus rock boats but this could be dangerous for someone with public responsibility. Alan Leo declares: "It is bad for public position, popularity, the good will of the world generally; and causes broken ties of all sorts in business, marriage and friendship", and Charles Carter thunders in 1930, "individualistic to the point of anarchy...(the person) will, by some foolish act, destroy the fruits of his own work...he will perhaps suddenly and without reason go off at a tangent and either abandon or gravely injure the construction he has raised".

All of which sounds worrying for steady Taurean Richard Eyre, director of strategy and content at RTL, especially since he has a Uranus contact with Airey. However, she does have a dose of practical and conventional Capricorn which lets her move into the mainstream when she chooses. Like the goat, this Capricorn ambition could pitch her upward until the influence peaks with the highest possible profile in 2009.

But will she shock everyone and blow out with Uranus before then? A critical period is her astrological mid-life crisis on the Uranus half-cycle, lasting from spring until Christmas 2002. For now, she is running on her lucky Venus-Jupiter conjunction. Carter observes that this "tends to popularity, but appeals to the less thoughtful and serious elements of the population". Sounds like Channel 5?

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

webTitle: Council tenants stand firm against transfer

fields.headline: Council tenants stand firm against transfer
fields.standfirst: Lewisham's independent housing commission fails to win over residents on transfer, writes Laurence Pollock
fields.trailText: Lewisham's independent housing commission fails to win over residents on transfer, writes Laurence Pollock.
fields.body:
The right to buy your council home marked its 20th anniversary this year after two decades that have transformed public housing policy.

But the question of what council tenants really want - including a shift to a new landlord - will not go away. The uncertainty can leave staff hanging in the balance, while tenants claim they have to fight to make their voice heard.

The majority of British homes are now owner occupied and councils' scope for building has been heavily restricted. Registered social landlords (RSLs) have become the main providers of new social housing.

The present government has encouraged this policy, urging councils to consider transferring stock to other landlords. The green paper, "Quality and Choice", wants councillors to adopt a more strategic role rather than acting as providers.

While a transfer can only happen with tenants' consent, the repair of thousands of dilapidated properties could depend on their transfer to RSLs, which can borrow money while councils remain financially boxed in.

There is cynicism about tenants' consultation in some quarters. But in south London, Lewisham council believes it is finding new routes to the future through an independent housing commission.

Chaired by Lord Filkin, the commission set out to "think outside the box" on housing policy and provide an evidence-based set of options. It included professionals and representatives of policy areas outside housing. In open session it heard witnesses, including government ministers, and filed a report calling for "better quality, more choice and sustainable communities with a wide range of homes, tenure and income groups".

But did the commission really think beyond current possibilities? The borough's action plan, based on the commission's report and its own public consultation, is in the mainstream of current Whitehall thinking.

It recommends housing management partnerships for a third of the stock, and considering an arms-length company for housing management. It also raises the possibility of future stock transfer and using the private finance initiative.

Lewisham already had plans to transfer stock in one area turned down by the tenants. And earlier this year, the government rejected its request to be included in the 2000-01 stock transfer programme.

Jean Kysow, chair of the Federation of Lewisham Tenants' and Residents' Associations (Feltra) says: "We had to argue and fight before the commission would take evidence from us and from the private tenants. There were no tenants on the panel, except for one from the citizens' panel. The housing commission has not come up with any new thinking - except that the council should talk with its tenants."

She adds that tenants' groups have given Feltra a mandate to oppose the earlier proposed stock transfer of 7,200 homes at Forest Hill, Rushey Green and Brockley.

Councillor Gavin Moore, who sat on the commission for the authority, denies that Lewisham tried to block Feltra from submitting or presenting evidence. The council had set up the commission to reflect the move away from the old council structure, with its traditional housing committee, and to draw in people from a diverse background. The aim was to see housing in the context of broader strategies, such as planning and the environment.

Moore insists that stock transfer was "not the all-consuming issue that people expected it to be". If a transfer of staff takes place, he argues, Lewisham has a good record of dealing with them professionally. "At the end of the day I have a huge confidence in our housing staff but we need to find ways of liberating skilled housing management."

One Unison activist said that staff had been left in continuous uncertainty but they were not under any illusion about what the council wants to achieve. "The problem with the housing commission was the brief. They were not going to come out and say the council is the best provider. Neither the staff nor tenants were treated as stakeholders," he says.

"We had two proposals for housing transfers and then the housing commission was set up. People are very demoralised and fed up with the suggestion from certain councillors that we do not do a good job."
fields.bodyText: The right to buy your council home marked its 20th anniversary this year after two decades that have transformed public housing policy. But the question of what council tenants really want - including a shift to a new landlord - will not go away. The uncertainty can leave staff hanging in the balance, while tenants claim they have to fight to make their voice heard. The majority of British homes are now owner occupied and councils' scope for building has been heavily restricted. Registered social landlords (RSLs) have become the main providers of new social housing. The present government has encouraged this policy, urging councils to consider transferring stock to other landlords. The green paper, "Quality and Choice", wants councillors to adopt a more strategic role rather than acting as providers. While a transfer can only happen with tenants' consent, the repair of thousands of dilapidated properties could depend on their transfer to RSLs, which can borrow money while councils remain financially boxed in. There is cynicism about tenants' consultation in some quarters. But in south London, Lewisham council believes it is finding new routes to the future through an independent housing commission. Chaired by Lord Filkin, the commission set out to "think outside the box" on housing policy and provide an evidence-based set of options. It included professionals and representatives of policy areas outside housing. In open session it heard witnesses, including government ministers, and filed a report calling for "better quality, more choice and sustainable communities with a wide range of homes, tenure and income groups". But did the commission really think beyond current possibilities? The borough's action plan, based on the commission's report and its own public consultation, is in the mainstream of current Whitehall thinking. It recommends housing management partnerships for a third of the stock, and considering an arms-length company for housing management. It also raises the possibility of future stock transfer and using the private finance initiative. Lewisham already had plans to transfer stock in one area turned down by the tenants. And earlier this year, the government rejected its request to be included in the 2000-01 stock transfer programme. Jean Kysow, chair of the Federation of Lewisham Tenants' and Residents' Associations (Feltra) says: "We had to argue and fight before the commission would take evidence from us and from the private tenants. There were no tenants on the panel, except for one from the citizens' panel. The housing commission has not come up with any new thinking - except that the council should talk with its tenants." She adds that tenants' groups have given Feltra a mandate to oppose the earlier proposed stock transfer of 7,200 homes at Forest Hill, Rushey Green and Brockley. Councillor Gavin Moore, who sat on the commission for the authority, denies that Lewisham tried to block Feltra from submitting or presenting evidence. The council had set up the commission to reflect the move away from the old council structure, with its traditional housing committee, and to draw in people from a diverse background. The aim was to see housing in the context of broader strategies, such as planning and the environment. Moore insists that stock transfer was "not the all-consuming issue that people expected it to be". If a transfer of staff takes place, he argues, Lewisham has a good record of dealing with them professionally. "At the end of the day I have a huge confidence in our housing staff but we need to find ways of liberating skilled housing management." One Unison activist said that staff had been left in continuous uncertainty but they were not under any illusion about what the council wants to achieve. "The problem with the housing commission was the brief. They were not going to come out and say the council is the best provider. Neither the staff nor tenants were treated as stakeholders," he says. "We had two proposals for housing transfers and then the housing commission was set up. People are very demoralised and fed up with the suggestion from certain councillors that we do not do a good job."

webTitle: English sides kept apart in Champions League draw

fields.headline: English sides kept apart in Champions League draw
fields.trailText: Manchester United, Arsenal and Leeds will be kept apart in tomorrow's draw for the Champions League second phase in Geneva.
fields.body:
Manchester United, Arsenal and Leeds will be kept apart in tomorrow's draw for the Champions League second phase in Geneva.

Teams from the same country cannot play each other, while clubs who were in the same first-round group will also be separated.

The 16 teams have been divided into four pots - the first two containing the eight group winners and the other two made up of the eight runners-up.

One team will be taken from each pot to make the second phase groups. The group winners and runners-up have been ranked according to their UEFA coefficient with the top four seeds, headed by holders Real Madrid, in pot 1. Arsenal are in pot 2, United pot 3 and Leeds pot 4.

Arsenal are the likeliest of the three Premiership sides to be given a favourable draw, while Leeds could be faced with another tough group. David O'Leary's side could be drawn with the likes of Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, Valencia, Deportivo La Coruna and Lazio. Leeds, though, will be relieved to know that Galatasaray are also in pot 4. However either United or Arsenal could be landed with an unwanted trip to Istanbul.

Pot 1: Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, Valencia, AC Milan. Pot 2: Deportivo La Coruna, ARSENAL, Anderlecht, Sturm Graz. Pot 3: Lazio, MANCHESTER UNITED, Spartak Moscow, Paris Saint-Germain. Pot 4: Olympique Lyonnais, Galatasaray, Panathinaikos, LEEDS.

webTitle: Taylor names Beckham captain of youthful looking England squad

fields.headline: Taylor names Beckham captain of youthful looking England squad
fields.trailText: Caretaker coach Peter Taylor has appointed David Beckham as England captain for next week's friendly against Italy after deciding to temporarily cull most of Kevin Keegan's old guard.
fields.body:
Caretaker coach Peter Taylor has appointed David Beckham as England captain for next week's friendly against Italy after deciding to temporarily cull most of Kevin Keegan's old guard.

Taylor has dropped Tony Adams, Martin Keown, Paul Ince and Dennis Wise and named several of his former U-21 players in the squad instead. These included Everton's Michael Ball, Manchester United's Wes Brown and Nicky Butt, Derby's Seth Johnson, West Ham's Frank Lampard and Leeds duo Paul Robinson and Alan Smith.

In fact, there are just two players aged over 30 in the 26-man squad - Aston Villa's David James and Gareth Southgate, who only passed the milestone a couple of months ago.

"I've decided to go with players of 30 years or younger," Taylor admitted. "I've spoken to all the players who were in the last squad and not in this one, and from the response I've had they fully understand.

"I've decided to go with players who have not been tried because it's a friendly and it's worth experimenting. I think there are a lot of players who have been in the senior squad and been progressing nicely. It's time to have a look at them."

But Taylor has surprisingly decided not to have a look at Andy Cole or Joe Cole, although the later is deemed worthy a place in the U-21 side. "I felt with Joe there's no doubt he's going to be an excellent England player," said Taylor. "But I think Joe will be better off playing in the England Under-21s."

There were words of comfort for the senior players however, with Taylor admitting he would have included some them if it had been a World Cup qualifying match.

"The thing I said to Martin Keown and Dennis Wise was that they've got enough experience already," he claimed. "This is a friendly and it's worth taking a chance. If this had been a qualifying game I definitely would have kept more experience in the squad."

England squad for next Wednesday's friendly against Italy in Turin: Anderton (Tottenham), Ball (Everton), Barmby (Liverpool), Barry (Aston Villa), Beckham (Man Utd, capt), Brown (Man Utd), Butt (Man Utd), Carragher (Liverpool), Dyer (Newcastle), R Ferdinand (West Ham), Fowler (Liverpool), Gerrard (Liverpool), Heskey (Liverpool), James (Aston Villa), Johnson (Derby), Lampard (West Ham), G Neville (Man Utd), P Neville (Man Utd), Owen (Liverpool), Parlour (Arsenal), Phillips (Sunderland), Robinson (Leeds), Scholes (Man Utd), Smith (Leeds), Southgate (Aston Villa), Wright (Ipswich).

webTitle: Treasury minister Melanie Johnson on the Getting Britain Giving campaign

fields.headline: 'How we'll boost charity coffers'
fields.standfirst: Melanie Johnson, economic secretary to the Treasury, tells Nicola Hill how the government plans to get Britain giving
fields.trailText: Q. How will the government achieve its aim of doubling the amount of money donated through payroll-giving to more than £60m a year by April 2003?
fields.body:
Q. How will the government achieve its aim of doubling the amount of money donated through payroll-giving to more than £60m a year by April 2003?

A. Firstly, we have removed a lot of barriers to giving, through restructuring payroll and gift aid packages, so people can now give more easily to charities in the UK. We are trying to get as much information out as possible about the ways in which people can give to encourage take-up of the campaign. Our aim is to increase access to payroll giving from 1 in 5 to 1 in 3.

We are spending £2m over three years promoting the campaign. So far we have run advertisements to launch the campaign and mailed 23,000 medium to large-sized employers to encourage them to establish payroll-giving schemes.

Q. How will you be promoting other aspects of the campaign, such as donating shares and gift aid?

A.There is already a phone line and a website so people can find out more. We are also trying to set up a phone line for charities so they don't have to ring the Inland Revenue and Customs and Excise about issues they need to sort out. The aim is to have a one-stop shop for people ringing in with queries. And we are trying to get much wider publicity through the direct mailings that we have already done. We will be targeting the regional and local press as well.

Q. Will the government be evaluating and monitoring the impact of the campaign and if so, how?

A. We will be looking closely to see how it is going at every stage. A tremendous number of organisations attended the launch, which was a good start. We have also commissioned research with the National Council for Voluntary Organisations and Charities Aid Foundation to look at awareness of tax relief and patterns of giving.

Q. Do you see this campaign as primarily the government's responsibility?

A. We have been working with charities because we think it is important to work together and obviously they have had a lot of input into the arrangements. We had a lot of feedback from our consultation about the whole charities' taxation package. And in fact we went a lot further than we intended because of what charities said to us. It is important that we work together with charities to maximise the effect, but charities are all hugely enthusiastic about it anyway.

Q. Do you think the tax relief offered in the Chancellor's review goes far enough; is there any scope for further tax relief, particularly on VAT?

A. VAT is a European tax and it is not something we can change in terms of exemptions, which is one of the issues. The exemption arrangements are enshrined in European law and we can't provide a new tax relief unilaterally.

Q. Should the government engage in a wider programme of education about tax, for example inserting an information sheet about tax efficient giving in self-assessment forms?

A. I'm not sure that putting something in people's tax returns is a good idea as people complain about how much information there already is with their tax forms.

Q. Charities Aid Foundation administers loans for people who can't donate money but are happy to give money as a short-term interest free loan for social investment. Could there be tax relief for this activity?

A. When we did the review, the feedback did not emphasise this area. I'm not sure about this as a matter of principle as there is a difference between loans and donations. A loan is something you may want back at some future point. This may limit charities' ability to expand and they have to plan for the money going again. So we have some hesitation about whether that is a particularly useful idea from the charities' point of view.

Q. Is anything going to be introduced to offset the impact of the abolition of advanced corporation tax (ACT)?

A. There is a transitional relief scheme for charities. We think the position on ACT will be less detrimental to charities than they might have argued. But the Getting Britain Giving Campaign is worth about £400m a year, so that is quite a big chunk going back into their coffers. And with payroll-giving, because there are no limits, the more charities can maximise the take-up, the more we are committed to handing out including the 10%.

 Payroll Giving helpline 0845 604 9000

fields.headline: A lesson to learn about dogma and pragmatism
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Silicon Valley, 8pm. Tired of American tea and TV and in need of some British company. No problem - the great technology successes here are littered with British talent. In the past there was no alternative. Under the previous government, British technology entrepreneurs had to head west. Little venture capital and, until recently, the lack of "exit routes" via an IPO on the London Stock Exchange were but two of the barriers to technology entrepreneurs.
fields.body:
Silicon Valley, 8pm. Tired of American tea and TV and in need of some British company. No problem - the great technology successes here are littered with British talent. In the past there was no alternative. Under the previous government, British technology entrepreneurs had to head west. Little venture capital and, until recently, the lack of "exit routes" via an IPO on the London Stock Exchange were but two of the barriers to technology entrepreneurs.

Now there has been an explosion in UK technology, with a number of global public technology companies outside the country. In Europe, the UK, Scandinavia and Germany dominate the new economy technologies. Has this revolution happened due to New Labour and Gordon Brown's policies or despite them?

Perhaps the treasury has helped by keeping out of it all. An effort has been made to keep red tape down, and on a global scale the UK fares reasonably well on this front. However, this sector has also witnessed perhaps one of the most catastrophic errors in taxation policy. Let me qualify that by saying that true policy errors are rare. But occasionally a simple, old-fashioned, and potentially industry-threatening mistake is made.

This was the case with the national insurance liability on employee share options. Giving these options is a necessary part of the new economy and seems consistent with the principles of the "stake-holder economy". The basic error was not about how much tax was paid, but how and when it was calculated.

Moving options from a capital gains basis to a PAYE basis has made it difficult to run a high-growth technology company in a very volatile sector. Finance directors often see their liabilities oscillate daily as the notional gains from the options changed with volatile markets. And often this liability would be much more than the cash balance of the company. This has made UK companies falsely appear to be underperforming in relation to their US counterparts - and this counts in the highly competitive US markets. Gordon Brown acknowledged the approaching problem early on, but did not react as fast as he should. Was it, as some feel, a lack of political stomach to take on the inevitable (if inaccurate) soundbite pot shots about fat cats and millionaires? If that were the case, risking a vital sector over such expediencies should cause great concern. Whilst the mountain was cleared in the end, the undercarriage certainly picked up a lot of foliage. There is tangible evidence that American companies located their European operations elsewhere, as anyone flying through Schipol will know only too well. And the steady and progressive movement towards awarding share options to employees in the UK was, sadly, greatly damaged. A lesson learnt about dogma and pragmatism, perhaps?

In future, how could Gordon Brown encourage entrepreneurialism? There is now a good venture capital industry in the UK, but it is very weak at the sub-£50,000 seed finance level - the realm of the "business angels". In the US, this first injection of funding to start up business often comes from relatives. Uncle Joe and Auntie Maud in the US often have that kind of money and will risk it on tech. In the UK, Uncle Jim and Auntie Doris tend to have less and it stays in the building society. Perhaps taxation policy could help here? There must be a direct relationship between the breadth of the investment base and the height of the pyramid that is achievable by UK technology companies.

The Labour government and Gordon Brown have presided over one of the greatest advances in the application of UK technology expertise to commercial success seen for over 30 years.

 Dr Mike Lynch is chief executive of Autonomy, the Cambridge-based intelligent software company.

Part 2: the fiscal stance
Part 3: families and pensioners

webTitle: Young people targeted by Year of Volunteers campaign

fields.headline: Young people targeted by Year of Volunteers campaign
fields.standfirst: The International Year of Volunteers aims to reverse a loss of interest by young people in volunteering. Will it work?
fields.trailText: Next month sees the UK launch of the United Nations' International Year of Volunteers (IYV2001). What difference can such initiatives make to voluntary organisations?
fields.body:
Next month sees the UK launch of the United Nations' International Year of Volunteers (IYV2001). What difference can such initiatives make to voluntary organisations?

Leading figures in the voluntary sector argue that, for younger people in particular, the nature of volunteering is changing. There is more emphasis on dipping in and out of volunteering and a growing focus on what the experience offers to individuals donating their time.

For example, recent ventures such as TimeBank, which offer more flexible volunteering opportunities and have a sophisticated internet presence, claim to have accessed a large proportion of younger people among a group of first-time volunteers.

The IYV launch is being organised by a consortium of staff from volunteering agencies funded by the Home Office. The initiative's aim, says spokeswoman Lene Holling, is to provide a framework for voluntary organisations to promote volunteering.

She accepts that there are significant barriers to increasing the level of volunteering in the UK and one of the IYV consortium members, the National Centre for Volunteering, is researching the obstacles and promoting action to overcome them. One of the hardest nuts to crack is attracting young people, as research shows a steep decline in young volunteers in the late 1990s. Growing time pressures at work and in higher education and a reaction against the sometimes rigid and "worthy" nature of traditional volunteering are thought to be behind the drop.

The IYV initiative is organising media campaigns, workshops and research studies, including specific work on identifying the barriers to recruiting young volunteers. But some in the voluntary sector are sceptical about how successful big campaigns such as the IYF, or other initiatives sponsored by the government, can be.

An officer at one of the large national volunteering organisations, who asked not to be named, says: "For us volunteering is a local activity and does not lend itself to large, UN-backed schemes or to a government programme approach."

He points to the government's Millennium Volunteers scheme to encourage volunteering by young people, funded with £48m from the Department for Education and Employment . "Anecdotal evidence suggests Millennium Volunteers has not been as successful in recruiting young people as they'd hoped and there's a danger that as soon as something is sponsored by the government it becomes 'unsexy' to young people," he adds.

fields.headline: Eleven O'Clock show faces axe
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The show that made Ali G a household name is facing the axe from Channel 4, writes Jessica Hodgson..
fields.body:
The axe is hanging over TV's Eleven O'Clock Show because of falling ratings.

The Channel 4 show, which became a sensational hit because of spoof rap interviewer Ali G, is on the danger list because of falling ratings and problems with star presenters.

It never really recovered after Sacha Baron-Cohen decided to leave the show to front his own chat show and develop his own movie.

Original presenters including Daisy Donovan and Iain Lee have also gone on to do other things.

Asked whether he was going to recommission the show, director of programmes Tim Gardam was non-commital.

"I have not decided yet," he said.

Channel 4 is to carry out the ultimate test to find the difference between the sexes by getting men and women to swap gender for three months as part of its winter line-up.

In Boy Meets Girl, four men and four women are followed on their 90-day progression from one sex to the other. In the first episode they undergo psychiatric tests and visit a gender consultant and two are eliminated from the experiment.

They are then given training, both physical and psychological, and change their wardrobes. By the last of the series' three episodes, only four volunteers remain.

Other programmes include TalkBack Productions' adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's Sword Of Honour, featuring award-winning actor Daniel Craig and big-screen veteran Leslie Phillips.

Channel 4's winter drama line-up also features Teachers, a light-hearted look at young teachers in Bristol starring This Life's Andrew Lincoln, and Metrosexuality, about an unconventional family in London's trendy Notting Hill.

The season also includes returning comedy hits like Trigger Happy TV and Spaced.

fields.headline: Local Asians fill nurse shortage
fields.standfirst: Bradford hospitals had trouble recruiting Asian nurses until they sought help from a local school
fields.trailText: As if trying to attract potential nurses into a low-paid, stressful profession wasn't hard enough, hospitals in Bradford faced a further problem: a reluctance among young Asian women to consider nursing as a career.
fields.body:
As if trying to attract potential nurses into a low-paid, stressful profession wasn't hard enough, hospitals in Bradford faced a further problem: a reluctance among young Asian women to consider nursing as a career.

South Asians account for around 17% of the population covered by Bradford health authority, and many of them are of Pakistani origin. But while Asian families would encourage their daughters to go into medicine, with its university education, career opportunities, good pay and high status, nursing was seen as a poor relation.

"Nursing isn't really seen as an appropriate career for Asian women. And for some Muslims it was seen as taboo for women to nurse men," says Wendy Eastell, assistant head of development for nursing and midwifery at Bradford Hospitals NHS trust.

Last year the trust, together with two neighbouring trusts, the health authority and the predominantly Asian Belle Vue school launched a Preparation for Nursing initiative aimed at attracting young Asian women to the profession.

Jan Lee, assistant head teacher at Belle Vue but currently seconded to the health authority, says: "We wanted to make nursing and midwifery an 'honourable profession', and hopefully persuade some of the girls to choose nursing as a career."

Nurses went into the school to talk about nursing to the girls and their families. The centrepiece of the initiative was a buddy scheme in which 17 and 18-year olds doing A-levels or GNVQs volunteered to shadow a qualified nurse on her ward duties. The girls were given a nurse's uniform, and required to spend two hours a week of their own time on the wards for 12 weeks. They had to keep a record of their experience, and report back at the end of the programme.

"On the whole it was a very positive experience. They realised that nurses had a much more positive input into the medical side of things than they had expected, and that it wasn't a traditional 'doctor's handmaiden' image," says Eastell. "Early on they began to get a feeling of being useful, and of being needed by the patients, which was satisfying. They also realised just how much help they could be from a language point of view in translating for the nurses."

On the first programme, which ran from September to December 1999, six students opted to go into nurse training. A subsequent Preparing for Midwifery programme persuaded three of the six girls on the programme to choose midwifery as a career.

"The girls had not considered nursing. It was just a word mentioned in careers lessons. But Preparation for Nursing made it more than just a word. I like to think we have made a small contribution to nursing recruitment," says Lee.

She says that collaboration between the NHS and the school, students and their families was essential to the success of the programme. The initiative was chosen by ministers to be a national NHS beacon site as "an outstanding example of good practice" that was making "a real difference to patients in the NHS".

The health authority is now looking at extending the initiative to cover other areas suffering from skills shortages, such as physiotherapy and radiography, and at introducing it into more local schools.

"It is an undoubted success, and we are going to continue with it," says Eastell.

fields.headline: From volunteer to staffer
fields.standfirst: Giving up your free time is a good way to gain vital experience
fields.trailText:
Name Natasha Upton
Age 23
Job sports fundraising assistant
Salary under £20,000
fields.body:
Name Natasha Upton
Age 23
Job sports fundraising assistant
Salary under £20,000

Natasha Upton graduated in 1998 from Southampton Institute of Higher Education with a degree in business and law.

As part of her degree she did a course on children and the law which helped her decide that she wanted to work for a children's charity, preferably in child protection.

After two years of struggling to find a job in the charity sector she realised the only way in was to volunteer. 'You can have as much enthusiasm in the world but without experience you get nowhere,' she says.

Upton started volunteering at the charity Children in Crisis. She saw an advertisement and had a couple of weeks to spare before going on holiday. 'It gave me a great insight and the atmosphere was so nice, and so different from the corporate sector,' she comments.

On her return Upton decided to go on the foundation course with Working For A Charity. This involves seven days of seminars with a twenty-day placement in a host charity.

All the students on Upton's course were offered jobs in the sector and Upton now works at the Starlight Children's Foundation. There she organises fundraising opportunities with runners in the London and New York marathons and coordinates the charity's own fitness campaign.

In the long term, she would like to move into outreach work with a children's charity and gain a masters degree in child protection.

Her top tip: 'If you volunteer for a charity, be pushy to get experience, otherwise you could end up doing all the photocopying!'

webTitle: A beginner's guide to the internet

fields.headline: A beginner's guide to the internet
fields.standfirst: Search engines are the key to unlocking the internet, writes Juliet Shedden
fields.trailText: Search engines are the key to unlocking the internet, writes Juliet Shedden
fields.body:
The internet is potentially a vast and invaluable resource. But it may be hard to evaluate whether the information you get is the information you want. The steps below will help you decide.

Doing your search

 If you already know the URL (internet address) that you are looking for, type this in to the location box at the top of the page.

 If not, perform a keyword search - to do this, you must use a search engine.

 To find a search engine, click the 'search' button on your tool bar. This will take you to numerous search engines and you can choose one that you like.

 Type in your keyword or phrase and press 'search'. To define a search, put the words in inverted comas or speech marks. Sometimes it is worth using more terms, rather than less.

 If your chosen search engine does not come up with the results you want, try using another.

Evaluation

There are four things you need to ask about your source to ensure reliability.

1. Authority
 Is it clear who or what company or organisation is responsible for the site you have found? For example, if you look at the bottom of SocietyGuardian's page you will notice that it displays the Guardian Newspapers Ltd 2000 trademark.
 Check for addresses and telephone numbers.
 Ask yourself about the motives, qualifications and aims of the company or organisation responsible for the website.

2. Accuracy
 Are the sources for any factual information clearly listed for verification?
 Look for spelling mistakes and grammatical errors. They indicate a lack of quality control and may produce inaccuracies.

3. Objectivity
 Is the information biased?
 Is the information free of advertising?
 If not, are the adverts clearly distinguishable from the text?

4. Currency
 Check the dates on the page to establish how recently the material was posted.
 Find out when the page was last revised and how regularly it is updated.
 Check for an archive of older material.

Universal Resource Locators

URLs generally end with the following:

.gov - government (can usually be trusted for official facts)
.org - usually advocacy groups (organisations trying to influence public opinion)
.ac - academic (UK)*
.edu - academic (USA)*
.mil - military
.co - company (usually UK)
.com - company (usually USA, but also infiltrating the UK)
.net - personal sites

*Academic sites may represent individual students, rather than the institution. The longer the URL, the less official and reliable the site is likely to be.

Internet services that provide information

Email: The internet provides several facilities for carrying information, but email is the most common. Emails can be sent anywhere in the world within minutes, and they are popular because of their speed. Emails can be in the form of text, images or sounds but not all emails are private, so be cautious when sending confidential information this way.

Mailing lists: Mailing lists work through email. They are the electronic equivalent of subscribing to a magazine. SocietyGuardian has its own mailing list - why not subscribe for free? Most websites will offer this facility.

Newsgroups: Newsgroups offer public discussion space, but you will need special software (Newsreader) to access, read or contribute to messages. However, if you are using Netscape or Outlook to surf the net, they will automatically download this software for you. There are over 70,000 newsgroups on every conceivable subject. Use Dejanews.com to find a newsgroup of interest.

fields.headline: Fresh start for social services
fields.standfirst: The government has a new strategy for beginning an overhaul of the country's social services, writes Linda Steele
fields.trailText: The government has a new strategy for beginning an overhaul of the country's social services, writes Linda Steele.
fields.body:
Postcode prescribing may be the bane of the NHS, but postcode variations have spurred the government to shake up social care in England.

"Some of the most serious complaints by users of social services are about inconsistencies and variations in services between one part of the country and another - often between neighbouring councils," according to A Quality Strategy for Social Care, published by the Department of Health in August.

The strategy proposes national standards backed by research, local accountability and, at its heart, training and development for qualified social workers and other social care staff. Also sketched out are a Social Care Institute for Excellence (SCIE), to provide guidance on good practice, and periodic professional re-registration, akin to that recently introduced for doctors.

These form a crucial step on the government's path to remodelled personal social services. Other moves aimed at raising and regulating quality include a general social care council for registering professional staff, a national care standards commission, and service frameworks to set national standards and suggest service models for health and social services. The Health Act 1999 provides for better integrated services through health and social services partnerships.

Public confidence
Alongside the national initiatives, the document makes it clear that, where quality of care is concerned, the buck stops with the social services director. It reminds councillors that they have responsibilities for "continuous improvements" in quality because of councils' new duty to achieve "best value" in services.

"The real point is we need to be able demonstrate that we are sound organisations," says former Association of Directors of Social Services president Jo Williams. "We need to turn around public confidence."

She's only too aware of the battering social work's image has had and believes the strategy document may offer a fresh start. "We need to say how we build relationships, help people rebuild lives. We need to be able to demonstrate the positive outcomes and what a difference we can make. If we can demonstrate that, we'll be able to hold our heads up."

Local authorities will now become "learning organisations", committed to training and continuing personal development for all social care staff. And, says the strategy: "Ownership of the research agenda needs to be broadened ... to encourage research activity at a local level."

A learning and research culture has been "slow in coming", says Sue Balloch, reader in health and social care at the University of Brighton. Staff shortages, a lack of cover and overwork are partly to blame. "The conditions of work are just not conducive. One of the problems is just getting the job done," she says.

Understandably, Ms Balloch is among many who have welcomed the strategy. It is up for consultation, which ends on November 21, and the devil may yet be in the detail. "Still outstanding is an exposition of how all the new bodies will work together. There's a start, but a lot of questions are still to be answered," says Jennifer Bernard, chief executive of the Central Council for Education and Training in Social Work.

One of those questions is a recurring issue - money. The government sidesteps the issue, for example in relation to funding training, by arguing that it's up to the employers "as part of their ongoing management responsibility for the service". Williams feels this isn't good enough. "We need to look at what is good value and how much good services cost. And the government and local government can't keep ducking it. Real quality costs money. We all know you get what you pay for."

fields.headline: Cracking the compact code
fields.standfirst: Key elements of the compact progress report and how to have your say
fields.trailText: Key elements of the compact progress report and how to have your say
fields.body:
The code of practice on consultation and policy appraisal, or compact code, was published in May 2000. It laid out a commitment from the government and the voluntary sector to build in sufficient consultation time when deciding on policy; to write documents in simple language; to analyse the results and to give feedback.

To check whether you feel the code is working, ask yourself the following:

 have government policy changes which affect your organisation been made with your consultation?
 have government consultation documents referred to the compact (where relevant)?
 12 weeks is the standard period for consultation; have you been given this?
 have any consultation documents identified or missed the likely impact of proposals on the sector?
 have you received feedback after responding to consultation?

If you want to give feedback on your experience of consultation, contact the compact secretariat .

The code of practice on funding was published in May 2000. It set out 10 key points for an effective funding framework including respect for the sector's independence, support for its infrastructure, improved co-operation and consistency between departments and clarity in funding conditions. To check whether it is working ask yourself the following questions:

 has any bid for new legislation compliance costs been included in your government funding?
 for strategic funded organisations: has the annual review process with government considered roll-forward arrangements for multi-year funding?
 for project funded work: have your organisation core costs been met appropriately?
 for national organisations: have you been consulted before launch of a new government funding programme in your field?
 for all government grant aided organisations: have you received three months advance notice of funding and are you receiving regular advance payments?

Again, give any feedback to the compact secretariat.

The black and minority ethnic code should be published early next year. The draft document has been circulated to 5,000 voluntary and community groups after initial consultation with 850 black and ethnic minority voluntary organisations. The draft is available via NCVO's website. Its key promise is:

A new partnership between government and the BME Sector which offers:
 joint commitment to taking forward the race equality agenda at all levels
 better consultation and participation in policy and implementation
 recognition of the role, contribution and needs of the sector
 fair funding and funding-plus capacity-building, developing infrastructure and sustainability
 with the aim of making a positive difference in the relationship between government and the BME sector and improving outcomes for BME communities.

The voluntary and community action codes are in a draft state and can be seen on the NCVO website. The former is due to be published in February 2001 but there is no set date for the latter. The main undertaking of the draft is to ensure that all proposed legislation is assessed for its impact on volunteering and community activity. Other government commitments include identifying aspects of existing policy and practice that create barriers to volunteering.

Guidelines on local compacts are now available from the compact secretariat. They cover:

 how to make a start
 what works and what doesn't
 setting up a steering group and identifying preliminary issues
 what a local compact can cover (funding, consultation, partnership) implementation, compliance and review
 appendices on explaining the compact simply, funding local compact work, local government and the modernising agenda, partnership working

For further information on the compact, contact:
Paul Barasi, compact development officer, NCVO Email: paul.barasi@ncvo-vol.org.uk
For copies of all compact materials contact: NCVO Helpdesk on 0800 2798 798

fields.body:
"Exciting", "fascinating" and "cutting-edge" are terms used by NHS librarians to describe a profession that has been transformed by the increasing demand for evidence-based healthcare.

The change has been phenomenal, says Anne Brice, who chairs the continuing professional development panel of the NHS regional librarians group.

"Librarians are no longer seen as just providing a support service. It's brought us centre stage, as evidence-based practice requires real expertise in handling information and knowledge. And it's focused attention on the skills that people need in order to formulate questions, locate, find, judge and appraise evidence."

The transformation has begun to dilute the traditional vertical career path of NHS librarians within libraries. There is still a need for accreditation from the Library Association but NHS librarians are beginning to take on other roles in the health service such as managing research and development programmes, teaching the use of information systems, or working in clinical effectiveness teams.

NHS library adviser Veronica Fraser, who works in the information policy unit of the NHS executive, says electronic technology has played a pivotal role in this transformation, causing a reappraisal of the value of knowledge and of the information broker role of librarians. The NHS is establishing a national electronic library for health (a pilot will be launched on November 27) which is designed to provide instant access to high-quality evidence via the NHSNet intranet and the internet.

Shane Godbolt, head of library and information development in the London region's north Thames area, says clinicians often have neither the time nor the skills to find the evidence they need to make fully informed choices in critical clinical situations. This is where librarians come into their own.

He recalls an incident in which a clinical librarian was asked to find out whether there was a suitable drug regime for a patient who was epileptic, schizophrenic and heavily pregnant. The turnaround time on this inquiry was one hour. A mistake in such circumstances could have been hugely costly in financial and human terms.

Clearly, NHS librarians lead more exciting lives than in the past but is there room at the top to allow for career development? No more than in the past, it seems. There are only eight NHS regional librarian posts in England and no directly equivalent posts in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Recommended salaries for health sector library staff Director of health libraries/regional librarian £39,280 Deputy/associate or assistant director of health libraries £22,150-£33, 225 Health authority, faculty or trust librarian £18,825-£26,560 Assistant librarian £16,505-£18,825 Senior library assistant £11,075-£15,505 Library assistant £8,860-£11,075

 These salary bands do not take into account London weighting and other benefits.

Source: The Library Association

fields.headline: Union law applies to charities
fields.standfirst: Voluntary sector workers have union rights too under a law passed last year, writes Geoff Martin
fields.trailText: Voluntary sector workers have union rights too under a law passed last year, writes Geoff Martin
fields.body:
As a trade unionist organising in the voluntary, independent and charity sector, I have felt that there have been times over the past 10 years when I almost needed armed protection just to carry out the basics of the job.

I am sure that it will hit a raw nerve when I mention the long list of employers in what we still insist on calling the voluntary sector that have the most right-on policies imaginable on service delivery but act like 19th century mill owners towards their staff.

On several occasions I have been escorted from the premises simply for trying to provide representation at a grievance or a disciplinary hearing. Luckily for me, and for tens of thousands of employees, those days are now at an end.

From September 4, all staff acquired the right to trade union representation at grievance and disciplinary hearings under the terms of the Employment Relations Act 1999. As long as the employee makes a "reasonable request" for a union rep to be present, they cannot be refused, regardless of whether the union is recognised or not.

Workers in the statutory sector have had this right for years as part of nationally agreed terms and conditions. But in the burgeoning non-statutory sector it is a breakthrough for staff and union officials such as me, who will no longer have to suffer the indignity of being bounced off the premises like a 15-year-old trying to get into a nightclub.

Know your rights
Well, that is the theory anyway. Since the law was changed, I have come across two organisations that are completely ignorant of the new law - or which claim ignorance - and still think they can make up their employment practices as they go along. My union, Unison, has acted swiftly to shunt them back into line.

That experience raises the question of how many workers are still being denied representation because they have not heard of the law. It is at this point that I burst into an a capella version of that great Clash song from the early 80s Know your Rights - a scary prospect for dodgy employers right across London.

All of this is great for the individual facing a formal hearing in front of the boss. But what about the workforce as a group rather than as isolated wage slaves? Here things are even more interesting under the 1999 Act. The staff of an organisation can now legally enforce union recognition if they can prove that more than 50% are union members or if they can win a ballot with a minimum turnout of 40%.

This is the best route to securing decent terms and conditions because it gives us the right to collective bargaining, consultation and negotiation. Good employers have nothing to fear from what is universally regarded as a modern and progressive approach to industrial relations. Bad ones will be dragged into the 21st century eventually.

And that brings me back to where I started. As someone who has worked in the voluntary sector for nearly 17 years, I know very well the debilitating impact that shaky funding and constant insecurity can have on your morale and your health. The last thing you need on top is a gung-ho, hire-and-fire industrial relations atmosphere.

As a trade unionist in the non-statutory sector I'm looking forward to the day when I can hang up the body armour but we are not there yet.

 Geoff Martin is the secretary of Unison's London voluntary and independent sector branch.
