fields.headline: Dome 'shambles' criticised by audit office
fields.standfirst: Full text: National Audit Office report
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome was badly managed, with "risky" visitor number targets and "weak" financial management, according to a damning official report published today.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome was badly managed, with “risky” visitor number targets and “weak” financial management, according to a damning official report published today.

The National Audit Office report into the dome sets out a catalogue of management failures.

Visitor number targets were “ambitious and inherently risky”, according to the report.

It was “clear that the task of managing the project had been complicated by the complex organisational arrangements put in place from the outset, and by the failure to put in sufficiently robust financial management”, the report concluded.

There had been “weaknesses in financial management and control” at the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, the report said. NMEC had been unable “to track and quantify fully the contractual commitments it has entered into”.

The company “experienced difficulty in establishing the full extent of its liabilities through to solvent liquidation and handover to a new owner”.

The report was “a serious indictment of those involved with this ill-fated project”, said Tory MP David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee.

The main cause of NMEC’s difficulties was “the failure to achieve the visitor numbers and income required,” said the National Audit Office head, Sir John Bourn.

Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office minister responsible for the Dome, stressed it was Britain’s premier paying attraction despite the failings cited by the National Audit Office. Welcoming the report, he said: “The government recognises that mistakes have been made during the Millennium Experience project and these have been highlighted in the NAO’s report.

“However, we should not lose sight of what has been achieved. The dome is the number one pay-to-visit attraction in the UK, with over 5.4m visits so far - with visitor satisfaction ratings among the industry’s highest.”

He said the dome had triggered the “regeneration of the once-contaminated Greenwich peninsula”.

An NMEC spokesman said: “We welcome the report as a comprehensive account of the circumstances surrounding the development of the dome, particularly its trading performance since opening on January 1 and its requirement for additional millennium commission funding.”

He added: “The report makes clear that the need for additional funding arose principally as the result of a significant shortfall in visitor numbers as compared with the original forecast. NMEC is pleased to announce that it has this week welcomed its 4.5 millionth revenue-generating visitor, which was the figure estimated for the whole year when the last grant request for £47m was made in September.”

The report followed a blistering row in the House of Commons yesterday between Tony Blair and William Hague. The Tory leader raised the matter of how much lottery money had gone into the dome - but the prime minister angrily pointed out that Mr Hague had been on the committee that approved the building of the project in 1995.

Both party leaders sought to blame the other for the dome’s ill fortune, with Mr Blair saying he was prepared to accept criticism from the public on the dome, but not from Mr Hague.

Originally, the Dome’s finances were based on 12m visitors coming to the attraction in the year 2000. But disappointing attendances early on caused a series of downward revisions of this total to the present target of around 6m.

When the dome opened, NMEC received £449m of lottery funds from the millennium commission. Since then, a further £179m of lottery money has been poured into the dome.

• Eight people were today due to appear at Belmarsh magistrates court in London in connection with the botched multi-million-pound diamond heist at the Millennium Dome. The men, from south east London, Kent and East Sussex, are charged with attempted robbery. Two others arrested in connection with the raid were released on police bail and a third man was still being questioned, Scotland Yard said.

fields.headline: £30,000 each for heads to repair schools
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Head teachers are to get up to £30,000 each to spend tackling urgent repairs to school buildings after the chancellor found that not all the money from the windfall tax had been spent.
fields.body:
Head teachers are to get up to £30,000 each to spend tackling urgent repairs to school buildings after the chancellor found that not all the money from the windfall tax had been spent.

Gordon Brown told the Commons that the "head teacher of every primary school will receive a cheque for between £4,000 and £7,000. The head teacher of each secondary school will receive, for the smaller schools £10,000... for larger schools £30,000."

The cash will go directly to heads, who will be able to spend it on capital projects of their choice such as redecorating classrooms.

The Department for Education and Employment said the money would be available direct to schools in the next few weeks, although they will have up to 18 months to decide how to spend it. The unexpected boost comes after education and employment secretary David Blunkett announced at the Labour Party conference that £7.8bn would be spent on renewing more than 7,500 schools in England.

The money will be allocated using a formula based on pupil numbers but could lead to some schools getting double the amount they were expecting this year.

The extra £200m will go to schools throughout Britain although the lion's share, £167m, has been earmarked for England. The funding is part of an investment programme worth more than £2bn this year, rising to £3bn in 2003-04. In 1996-97, the last year before the general election, the Conservatives spent £683m on school repairs.

Mr Blunkett said: "We inherited a situation where less than £700m a year was being spent on crumbling buildings and widespread disrepair. We are now investing over three times that amount each year and, as today's announcement shows, we are giving all heads greater flexibility in deciding how the money is spent."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "This is a one-off cash payment and it is going to have to be spent on repairs and equipment. But it is very welcome and underlines that the government is keen to give money direct to schools."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of School Masters/Union of Women Teachers, also welcomed the extra cash, although he said some of it might have been kept back to help fund "the looming teachers' pay crisis".

Also in the Pre-Budget statement, £5m from the new National e-learning Foundation is to be used to provide children from low-income families with laptop computers. Mr Blunkett said the move would help bridge the "digital divide".

"This new investment gives children at risk of being on the wrong side of the digital divide the extra - individual - opportunities to learn what a laptop can bring."

He urged the private sector to stump up more money for the scheme.

fields.headline: Courts close in on Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet was placed under court supervision on Wednesday and ordered to limit his travels in a surprise move by a Chilean judge. The move may be a prelude to ordering the house arrest of the 84 year old general - who has been free since his return to Chile in January.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet was placed under court supervision on Wednesday and ordered to limit his travels in a surprise move by a Chilean judge. The move may be a prelude to ordering the house arrest of the 84 year old general - who has been free since his return to Chile in January.

The decision by judge Luis Correa Bulo came in response to a petition by a judge in neighbouring Argentina who ordered the arrest and extradition of Pinochet and 6 other high ranking secret police agents. The 6 men and 1 woman are charged with planning the 1974 murder of Carlos Prats, a commander in chief of the Chilean army who opposed the 1973 military coup that installed Pinochet as maximum ruler. The car bombing murder of a fellow army General has long been a divisive issue within the Chilean military, now that loyalty to Pinochet was waned, those resentments are coming forth.

"I think Pinochet will be prisoner within a week," said Maria Angelica Prats, daughter of the assassinated General Prats. Maria Angelica has been closely involved in the 26 year long effort to seek justice for the murder of her parents, both of whom were living in Buenos Aires when a car bomb killed them instantly. "His arrest has already been ordered in Argentina, whether he is taken there or not is a later issue," she said.

While few legal analysts here believe that the 84 year old Pinochet will be extradited, the possibility of house arrest remains strong as does the advances being made in the 160-plus cases against Pinochet for crimes committed within Chile. Despite massive efforts by the Pinochet defence to have the charges dismissed or to use Pinochet's alleged ailments as a foil against judicial investigations, the evidence against the former dictator keeps piling up.

In the past several days, numerous agents from the Pinochet regime have come forward to admit their participation in murders with the defence that they are "loyal soldiers" who worked for "hierarchical organisations". In less than a week the code of silence among Pinochet's field level agents has been shattered. For decades, these men had refused to cooperate with judges or prosecutors, but when several received life sentences earlier this year, a new strategy based upon the loyal soldier theory was formalised, this week it was launched.

fields.headline: PR: outsource or stay inhouse?
fields.standfirst: Adam Woolf looks at the options available to charity organisations for improving their public relations
fields.trailText: Adam Woolf looks at the options available to charity organisations for improving their public relations.
fields.body:
Discovering that your charity needs to improve its public relations work is one thing. Doing something about it is another.

There are three main options available to charities: retaining a public relations agency, using freelance consultants or recruiting specialist staff inhouse. Many charities go for a combination of two of these options. Some use all three.

Budget
There are strengths and weaknesses with all three options. However, the first thing you need to sort out is your budget.

Lyn Smith, chair of Fifth Estates, the non-profit section of the Institute of Public Relations, explains: "There is no such thing as a free press release. A lot of people think PR is free. It is not. It costs time and money. While it is cheaper than advertising, it should not be seen as a cheap option."

Agencies do, however, have their advantages. PR is not a science. It is based on intuitive judgements backed up by skills and experience. Agencies work with a number of diverse organisations. This means they often have more experience in dealing with different issues. Also, their advice is often more objective because they are not bogged down in the day to day running of the charity.

Agencies are also better resourced. They have the staff, the equipment and the contacts to handle media relations smoothly and effectively. The senior management of the charity is also less likely to ignore the advice of an agency because they are paying for its services.

Downside
However, there is a downside. Agencies usually seek 12-month contracts, based on the number of days retained by the charity each month. Of course, fees are negotiable, but the cost may seem high compared with the cost of employing staff.

While some agencies do other pro-bono work, charities should be wary of agencies promising the earth. They seldom deliver because other accounts that bring in fees will always be their priority.

One common complaint is that agencies never have a real grasp of the charity and what it stands for. This can be an issue if the charity suffers from negative press. The agency may not understand the full implications of bad publicity. It may, therefore, give advice that is inappropriate.

Inhouse staff may resent the charity committing funds to agencies when their pleas for more resources have been turned down. Another complaint is that a charity might only see the directors of a PR agency once a year, when it is pitching for its business.

More committed
Inhouse PR teams are often more committed. They also have a more intimate understanding of what the charity does and what makes it tick. Many charities are unwilling to trust their image and profile to outside agencies. They therefore employ PR teams inhouse.Yet building an inhouse PR team is rarely a cheap option, and with good PR staff in high demand, salary costs are rising.

Inhouse teams can also use freelance consultants for help and advice on specialist areas. They also use them as sounding boards for creative ideas and as backup during peak times.

Smaller charities may also opt for individual freelancers who can be hired on a project-to-project basis. Freelancers do not have high overheads, so their rates are cheaper than agencies. The downside is they may not be available when you need them.

For many charities, it is hard to choose which option to go for. Dyrol Lummard, deputy director of the Media Trust, which matches charities with media professionals willing to donate their skills, says getting good advice before you make any decisions is crucial: "Regardless of whether you come to us or pay for a consultant, it is always worth getting an external person in to do an initial audit. They offer a fresh perspective and guide you on what to do next," he says.

There are three main options available to charities: retaining a public relations agency, using freelance consultants or recruiting specialist staff inhouse. Many charities go for a combination of two of these options. Some use all three. Budget There are strengths and weaknesses with all three options. However, the first thing you need to sort out is your budget. Lyn Smith, chair of Fifth Estates, the non-profit section of the Institute of Public Relations, explains: "There is no such thing as a free press release. A lot of people think PR is free. It is not. It costs time and money. While it is cheaper than advertising, it should not be seen as a cheap option." Agencies do, however, have their advantages. PR is not a science. It is based on intuitive judgements backed up by skills and experience. Agencies work with a number of diverse organisations. This means they often have more experience in dealing with different issues. Also, their advice is often more objective because they are not bogged down in the day to day running of the charity. Agencies are also better resourced. They have the staff, the equipment and the contacts to handle media relations smoothly and effectively. The senior management of the charity is also less likely to ignore the advice of an agency because they are paying for its services. Downside However, there is a downside. Agencies usually seek 12-month contracts, based on the number of days retained by the charity each month. Of course, fees are negotiable, but the cost may seem high compared with the cost of employing staff. While some agencies do other pro-bono work, charities should be wary of agencies promising the earth. They seldom deliver because other accounts that bring in fees will always be their priority. One common complaint is that agencies never have a real grasp of the charity and what it stands for. This can be an issue if the charity suffers from negative press. The agency may not understand the full implications of bad publicity. It may, therefore, give advice that is inappropriate. Inhouse staff may resent the charity committing funds to agencies when their pleas for more resources have been turned down. Another complaint is that a charity might only see the directors of a PR agency once a year, when it is pitching for its business. More committed Inhouse PR teams are often more committed. They also have a more intimate understanding of what the charity does and what makes it tick. Many charities are unwilling to trust their image and profile to outside agencies. Inhouse teams can also use freelance consultants for help and advice on specialist areas. They also use them as sounding boards for creative ideas and as backup during peak times. webTitle: Time to talk up children's homes

fields.headline: Time to talk up children's homes
fields.standfirst: Residential childcare requires highly skilled social workers, writes Daphne Statham
fields.trailText: It is time we started talking up residential childcare. The evidence is that working in children's homes requires some of the highest skills and personal qualities in social care.
fields.body:
It is time we started talking up residential childcare. The evidence is that working in children's homes requires some of the highest skills and personal qualities in social care.

Most children who need support remain with their own families or in foster care, and the numbers in residential care have greatly reduced. The result of this good policy is that young people in children's homes have usually had very damaging experiences and may have had their difficulties compounded by failures in other parts of the care system.

The media and the public need very little information to understand that the work is hard and demanding, but this is rarely offered. Why is residential care so stigmatised?

It is undeniable that some workers betrayed those they were entrusted to care for and that it took young people rather than professionals, in the main, to reveal the appalling abuse. Nothing can put right the fact that some of those young people paid with their lives and others with a lifetime of lost opportunities.

But a bad press for residential childcare has persisted for years, in spite of evidence, including evidence from young people and their families, that good residential care can be liberating, and can keep family relationships healthy. Behind the bad image is a belief, often held by others in social care, that only family-based care is good for children. And this may be combined with a suspicion that anyone wanting to nurture other people's children outside a family is at least odd and at worst a potential abuser.

Finally, there is the apparently high cost of residential care. "Apparently" because other parts of the care system are not fully costed and the longer term costs of poor care, in terms of careers in crime, poor physical and mental health and low educational achievement are not taken into account.

Family-based care is what the vast majority of children need, but a whole range of support is necessary to tailor support to specific needs. Residential childcare is a small, but significant resource. When used well, it can prevent the breakdown of family relationships and offer some young people an option they prefer.

We are reaching the point when staff doing the most skilful job in social care are being undermined by public criticism and pinned down by rigid procedures. The very relationships between staff and young people that create the possibility for the young person to flourish are increasingly hard to maintain because of the ways staff have to operate to survive.

Expert practitioners tend to leave when they cannot do the job well. The risk is that we will replace them with staff who can do no more than hold on to young people for long enough for them to fend for themselves as young adults. If this happens, it will confirm them on a path toward social exclusion.

There are hopeful signs. Examples of high quality residential childcare do exist. They focus on outcomes, a respect for human rights and the young people's values. They have a commitment to a philosophy and model of therapeutic working. More investment will be going into residential childcare training and this group of staff will be among the first registered with the general councils. New legislation is extending the time for supporting young people when they leave care. This should reduce the effects on vulnerable young adults of the sudden withdrawal of support when they move out of residential homes. These positives could start to stop the rot in residential childcare.

webTitle: Charlie's Angels dialled up by Nokia

fields.headline: Charlie's Angels dialled up by Nokia
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Charlie's Angels use them, but will movie buffs buy in to Nokia's latest product placement? Claire Cozens reports
fields.body:
They have already persuaded the glamorous Charlie's Angels to use them.

Now Nokia bosses are cashing in on its cunning product-placement in the new Hollywood blockbuster with a TV campaign starring Charlie's Angels stars Cameron Diaz, Lucy Liu and Drew Barrymore.

The mobile phone company is working hand-in-hand with the makers of the new Charlie's Angels film in a multi-million pound marketing major marketing push timed to coincide with the film's UK cinema release later this month.

The TV, press and on-line campaign will try and persuade fashion-conscious consumers that the new 8210 model is the latest must-have accessory.

"This film is very relevant for the UK market because Charlie's Angels was one of the main hit series of the seventies. It's a bit of fun really but the film is just right for Nokia because there's a strong style element and they've introduced a lot of technology and made it very contemporary," said head of marketing Alison Brolls.

A TV, press and web advertising campaign for the Nokia 8210 launches on November 24 and will feature clips from the film of the Angels using the phone. Nokia is also organising in-store promotional tie-ins, taking in Carphone Warehouse and Nokia stores, and bringing out a limited edition mobile phone carrying Charlie's Angels branding.

The deal with Columbia Pictures, the maker of the new film, is the latest in a series of Nokia product placements. Nokia made its screen debut in the 1987 blockbuster Wall Street and the company also provided the futuristic Nokia handset used by Keanu Reeves in The Matrix.

webTitle: Cause and effect goes down the pan

fields.headline: Cause and effect goes down the pan
fields.standfirst: By James Meek
fields.trailText: One swallow doth not a summer make. But two swallows might attract a research grant, and three are enough to work up a paper in a marginal journal of climatology, with a title such as "Statistical correlation of the incidence of  Hirundo rustica with the onset of warm weather in a temperate region". If you want to tell me that paper has actually been written, don't bother. I'm sure it has.
fields.body:
One swallow doth not a summer make. But two swallows might attract a research grant, and three are enough to work up a paper in a marginal journal of climatology, with a title such as "Statistical correlation of the incidence of Hirundo rustica with the onset of warm weather in a temperate region". If you want to tell me that paper has actually been written, don't bother. I'm sure it has.

In recent weeks there have been papers published about how women can't throw as well as men (based on 25 people chucking balls into buckets), a slime that can find its way through a maze, and how monkeys can become cannabis addicts (you have to turn them into cocaine addicts first).

The habits of far-out research - suspiciously small test groups, the combination of elements from two unrelated fields (slime and mazes), the questionable use of animals, the triumphant proof of something we knew already - prompt the question: how did they get the money to do that? Haven't they got better things to do? And should the scientists be nominated for an Ig Nobel Prize?

The 2000 Ig Nobels were awarded at Harvard University, as they have been annually since 1991, in parallel with the real Nobels. The criteria are simple: they are for "achievements that cannot or should not be reproduced". The chairman of the Ig Nobel board of governors, Marc Abrahams, cites the 1996 biology winners as a classic example of "cannot be repeated": Anders Barheim and Hogne Sandvik found that leeches have their appetite stimulated by sour cream, are made drunk by beer, and are often killed by garlic.

Ig Nobel winners sometimes have to wait years for their achievements to be recognised. The prize for public health won by Jonathan Wyatt, Gordon McNaughton and William Tullet came seven years after their groundbreaking paper "The collapse of toilets in Glasgow" was published in the Scottish Medical Journal. The abstract of their research was a model - evidence of a crisis, analysis of the cause, and a chilling conclusion: "Three cases are presented of porcelain lavatory pans collapsing under body weight, producing wounds which required hospital treatment. Excessive age of the toilets was implicated as a causative factor. As many toilets get older episodes of collapse may become more common, resulting in injuries."

The 2000 psychology prize went to two United States researchers for "Unskilled and unaware of it: how difficulties in recognising one's own incompetence lead to inflated self-assessments". Richard Wasserug took the biology award for "On the comparative palatability of some dry-season tadpoles from Costa Rica". He ate them, and reported that they were neither dry nor seasoned.

Sir Michael Berry, of Bristol University, was honoured for physics along with Andre Geim of the Netherlands for making a frog and a sumo wrestler levitate inside a powerful magnet. The chemistry prize went to an Italian-American team for discovering that, biochemically, romantic love may be indistinguishable from a severe obsessive-compulsive disorder. ("Alteration of the platelet serotonin transporter in romantic love". Ah, amore.) The British Medical Journal published the paper that won the prize for medicine ("Magnetic resonance imaging of male and female genitals during coitus and female sexual arousal") and proudly announced the award in the next issue.

Praise also to Chris Niswander of Arizona, who scooped the computer science award with his software PawSense, which detects when a cat is walking across your computer keyboard. ("PawSense analyses keypress timings to distinguish cat typing from human typing. PawSense normally recognises a cat on the keyboard within one or two pawsteps.")

The Ig also awards peace and literature prizes. Britain scooped gold for peace, with the Royal Navy created laureate for its plan to replace live-shell firing practice with sailors shouting, "Bang!" Jasmuheen, aka Ellen Greve of Australia, won the literature prize for her books on Breatharianism, which explain why we don't ever need to eat food.

"The Ig honours the great muddle in which most of us exist much of the time," says Abrahams. "Life is confusing. Good and bad get all mixed up. Most people go through life without ever being awarded a great, puffy prize to acknowledge that, yes, they have done something. That's why we award Ig Nobel prizes. If you win one, it signifies to one and all that you have done something. What that thing is may be hard to explain."

webTitle: Time to challenge complacency about racial equality

fields.headline: Time to challenge complacency about racial equality
fields.standfirst: A change in the law will force the public sector to do something about racial equality
fields.trailText: You don't have to be around at the top of organisations for very long to know the signs that demonstrate a lack of interest in something as crucial as race equality.
fields.body:
You don't have to be around at the top of organisations for very long to know the signs that demonstrate a lack of interest in something as crucial as race equality.

I am not talking about the obvious statistics that show inequality still rules the roost. We can all see those. We know them only too well. What I am talking about is the failure of all too many in the higher reaches of the public sector to make sure those results are changed.

Soon after I took up the post of chairman at the Commission for Racial Equality this summer, I spoke at a conference for local authorities. Hilary Armstrong, local government minister at the Department of the Environment, was there to speak, along with leading figures from the Local Government Association. But when I looked across the audience of several hundred, I did not see the council leaders nor the chief executives who hold the real power. Unfortunately, it is still like that in institution after institution in the public sector.

Yes, things are changing. There is a new buzz to equality work. Ministers are pushing for commitments and action plans. The Lawrence inquiry report has given an added impetus. There are now targets for improving the participation of ethnic minorities in the workforce of key public sector areas. The government's important Race Equality and the Public Sector document, issued in April, outlines ways in which failure to deliver equality by public services will be brought out into the open over the next few years, with the regular publication of statistics and the results of opinion surveys.

In a sense, though, this is not really the issue. We know what the problem is. We may not know all the details, but who can deny that discrimination continues to take place, or that ethnic minority members of the public face inequalities in many areas of their lives?

The big question is: what are people in positions of power doing to change this?

Just take local government. Section 71 of the Race Relations Act uniquely picks out local authorities as bodies that should be seeking to deliver racial equality. But it does not provide any means of enforcing this provision. Surprise, surprise, 25 years after the act came into force, only half of Britain's local authorities are practising basic equal opportunities measures such as monitoring their employment. Bad as that might appear, it is better than in other parts of the public sector.

The complacency that lies behind this most unsatisfactory situation is, I predict, about to be blown apart.

 First, there are the measures that will bring the problems out into the open - performance indicators using ethnic origin data, Race Equality and the Public Sector indicators and opinion surveys, the steady development of ethnic monitoring on employment and service delivery and, in the longer term, the results of the 2001 census. Britain has made great strides on equality - all this data will point the spotlight at how many more we still need to make.

 Secondly, there are the new powers in the race relations (amendment) bill, due to be law by the end of the year. This legislation means that action will have to replace talk. If it does not then enforcement will follow. The government is to be congratulated for rising to this vital challenge and putting in place a law that will mean real change has a real driver.

At the Commission for Racial Equality I am determined that we will be up to the challenge of making sure everyone in the public sector knows what they need to do, knows how to do it and knows that they must do it. The question I ask is: can we see the same determination from leaders across the sector?

 Gurbux Singh is chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality

webTitle: Race bill will have huge impact on social services

fields.headline: Race bill will have huge impact on social services
fields.standfirst: Social services departments must wake up to the importance of the race relations (amendment) bill, writes Gurbux Singh
fields.trailText: Social services departments must wake up to the importance of the race relations (amendment) bill, writes Gurbux Singh
fields.body:
It is hard to avoid discussion of race and crime these days - and rightly so. The fact that young black men are more likely to be stopped and searched than their white counterparts has become common knowledge. Both the police and community representatives are preparing for the moment next year when this contrast will be something that the law will be brought to bear upon.

Black over-representation in another aspect of life may well lead to legal action under the forthcoming amendments to the Race Relations Act. Statistics and research have for years shown that black and Irish men are strongly overrepresented in compulsory mental health treatments.

Stark realities
A parallel situation arises concerning looked-after children. A group that is new to ethnic monitoring categories, those of mixed background, is strongly over-represented among children in care. The next census in April 2001 - which will be the first to use this category - may well reveal some stark realities for many children from this group.

Some decisions leading to compulsory action in both areas are currently outside the reach of the Race Relations Act. None will be in future. Equally, while research has highlighted some of the possible causes of this over-representation, there has been no requirement to tackle those causes. That will also change.

Social service departments, whose staff play a crucial part in both areas, will need to:
 consult with ethnic minority representatives in their local community and listen to their concerns;
 ensure that monitoring systems are in place so that patterns of inequality can be brought out into the open;
 make sure that assessments are introduced to pinpoint unjustifiable causes which may lie behind the imbalances;
 have action programmes for change, providing for new practices which will eliminate the problems;
 put in place implementation reviews which ensure that the change is bedded in thoroughly. Change must be understood and carried through at every level and backed by staff performance appraisals so that policy changes do not remain on paper but become real practice.

Much work along some of these lines has already been undertaken in mental health and children's services. But what has happened so far has not dented the underlying problems. That work will now have to get under way.


 Gurbux Singh is chairman of the commission for racial equality.

fields.headline: Bill imposes duty to work for racial equality
fields.standfirst: The race relations (amendment) bill will impose a positive duty to promote racial equality on public bodies, writes Gurbux Singh
fields.trailText: The race relations (amendment) bill will impose a positive duty to promote racial equality on public bodies, writes Gurbux Singh
fields.body:
The talk this autumn has been of the Human Rights Act and the sea change it is expected to bring to the delivery of justice in Britain. Similarly historic changes are likely to arrive in the wake of a so far little noticed, but fundamental piece of legislation about to be finalised by parliament.

The race relations (amendment) bill is due to get its key Commons debate in November and will be law by the end of the year, making two fundamental additions to existing legislation.

The Race Relations Act will effectively be extended to cover everything that a public body does. Until now, regulatory action by a public body has escaped the reach of the Act.

The sort of cases that individuals will in future be able to take to court include:

 law enforcement by a police officer;
 decisions on compulsory treatment of a patient under the Mental Health Act;
 decisions on street trading licences;
 actions concerning children in care.

This in itself is a big change. More importantly, the new Act will impose a positive duty on public bodies to work for race equality. Hospitals, schools, the police and the rest of the criminal justice system, the whole of local government and the national government machinery, public funding bodies - the list is long when it comes to the public services that will be covered by this provision. The measure will touch on many aspects of everyone's lives.

Setting targets
The bill itself will simply lay out this duty in a very general form. The home secretary will issue regulations putting flesh on the bones and indicating what is necessary in the way of monitoring, setting targets and pushing through change.

Draft regulations will be put out to consultation in the opening months of the new year. Further detail will come in codes of practice from the Commission for Racial Equality. Critically, the CRE will be given the power to take action when a public body fails to deliver - and various public inspection bodies, such as the Audit Commission, may use their reports to highlight poor performance.

Combined with the Human Rights Act and European directives on equality, this is a major step in the direction called for in the comprehensive report from the Commission on the Future of Multi-Ethnic Britain - a "move from 'multicultural drift' to a purposeful process of change".

 Gurbux Singh is chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality

fields.headline: NHS taskforce reflects 'inclusiveness' policy
fields.standfirst: The wide range of appointments to NHS taskforces is based on a drive to win support from all quarters, writes Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: The wide range of appointments to NHS taskforces is based on a drive to win support from all quarters, writes Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
The "big tent" inclusiveness so beloved of New Labour's approach to making and implementing policy is not only alive and well in the NHS - as the lineup of the modernisation taskforce members reveals, it is positively thriving.

No fewer than 143 "frontline" NHS staff, as well as a host of familiar names from staff and patient lobby groups, have been appointed to the 10 taskforces which are charged with driving forward Labour's NHS plan.

This is on top of a 31-strong modernisation board responsible for assessing the progress of the NHS plan, producing an independent annual report and advising ministers.

Many of the 170-odd taskforce members were among the 100 NHS and patient representatives who served on five modernisation action teams, whose deliberations earlier this year fed into the NHS plan.

The taskforces and the board will work alongside the modernisation agency announced in the NHS plan in July. The agency, which will operate in each NHS region, will oversee the redesign of services in local trusts to make them more patient-friendly and efficient.

"Many of the taskforce members are leading-edge modernisers - managers, clinicians and patients, who, because they know the NHS, are in the best position to help us with the task of reforming the NHS," says health secretary Alan Milburn.

But can a board handpicked by the secretary of state to advise him be truly independent? Is it just an ideologically friendly kitchen cabinet created to impose a veneer of consensus around a politically contentious group?

There have also been reservations about the make-up of the board, on the grounds both that it rewards Labour sympathisers, and also brings inside potential critics such as the BMA, therefore neutralising them.

Certainly, there is a core of Labour sympathisers. Both Birmingham University oncologist David Kerr and Breakthrough Breast Cancer chief executive Delyth Morgan have shared a Labour party conference platform with ministers in recent years.

Tom Coffey, the south London GP, is a party activist and longtime cheerleader for New Labour. Chai Patel, chairman of Westminster Healthcare, helped fund the pro-modernisation lobby, NHS Network. But there are surprise appointments too, notably the maverick proto-moderniser Roger Thayne, chief executive of Staffordshire ambulance service, who will sit on the coronary heart disease taskforce.

His anti-establishment outspokenness has, in the past, managed to alienate most of the UK ambulance service and large parts of the Department of Health, as well as former health secretary Frank Dobson.

Thayne has survived because Staffordshire has consistently recorded the best 999 performance figures in the UK, using controversial methods that have turned conventional thinking on emergency pre-hospital care upside down. Flamboyant former NHS manager Ray Rowden, now visiting professor at York University, is another maverick. He is pro-NHS modernisation and a Labour Party member, but by no means respects the party line or NHS establishment niceties.

There are also one or two figures associated with the Tories, including William Wells, chairperson of NHS southeastern region, who was a minor Labour hate-figure in his role as the ardently pro-free market chair of the Royal Free Hampstead Trust in the early 90s.

But, in a sense, it is less the individual talents of the taskforce members that give it its powers than the collective authority, affecting staff and political opponents, that they bring to the modernisation project.

The vast array of stakeholders gives the impression of a huge "popular front" of NHS interests arranged behind the NHS plan. The names, as Milburn puts it, "symbolise my determination to ensure that changes in the NHS are driven by people within the NHS".

Key points
The 10 modernisation taskforces will cover:
 faster services
 coronary heart disease
 cancer
mental health
 older people
 children
 inequalities and public health
 the workforce
 capital and capacity
 improving performance

The NHS modernisation agency's role is to "help local clinicians and managers redesign local services around the needs and convenience of patients". Key areas of service redesign will include cutting waiting times in casualty departments and for heart and cancer treatment, and simplifying the way patients access care, from admission to discharge.

 Patrick Butler.

fields.headline: Fundraising on the net
fields.standfirst: Patrick McCurry examines the growing number of internet ventures offering to raise funds for charity.
fields.trailText: Patrick McCurry examines the growing number of internet ventures offering to raise funds for charity.
fields.body:
Despite the fading investor interest in dot.coms earlier this year, a growing number of charity-related internet ventures are popping up, offering the prospect of fundraising income. But how can charities distinguish the good prospects from those that are unlikely to last the pace, and is there much money to be made from the internet?

Gareth Edwards, fundraising development manager for the Royal National Institute for the Blind (RNIB), has become one of the voluntary sector's experts on the web's commercial possibilities. This follows the development of the charities' internet fundraising and e-commerce forum, which he chairs. "Charities have had a lot of proposals from new websites claiming they can make money for the sector, but it's important to look closely at these claims and what the charity will really get out of any arrangement," he says.

The forum meets every two months, with about 50 fundraisers hearing pitches from web entrepreneurs who Edwards has screened. In recent months there have been a number of site launches, such as online shopping malls, which pay charities commission on goods sold if they refer customers, and web portals which offer online donation facilities.

Edwards has several tips for charities that are approached by partnerships with e-commerce ventures. He suggests looking at how well financed the company is and how flexible the contract is. It is important to find out what kind of marketing will take place and who will be expected to provide it.

Charities should also examine whether there is a limit on the number of charities involved, because the fewer taking part, the higher the returns will be. Ventures that offer other forms of payment as well as credit card may be an advantage, given the security concerns of many internet users. Some websites now offer links to direct debit options.

Disability charities should check whether the site is suited to their clients. The RNIB, for example, has turned down some propositions because they are not accessible with the specialist technology used by some visually impaired internet users.

Despite the growth in internet-related partnerships, some people worry that only the large national charities will benefit. Stephen Haxby, corporate fundraising manager at United Response, which works with people with learning difficulties, says raising the organisation's profile on the web is difficult. "The internet is becoming increasingly commercialised and we've made attempts to get on the lists of the main search engines, but we've been asked to pay and have so far resisted," he says.

The National Society for Epilepsy's only commercial arrangement is with Amazon.co.uk, which gives the charity a commission if someone buys a book through a link to Amazon from the NSE website. Eileen Gascoigne, the society's head of information and education, says: "The problem with many of the other commercial propositions we've had is that once you read the small print you realise you're unlikely to get much financial benefit."

The main message seems to be that charities should not regard the internet primarily as a fundraising resource but rather as a "shop window" to the world offering information about the organisation and its campaigns. But the internet and e-mail do offer opportunities to intensify relationships with donors at relatively low cost and there is likely to be increasing income from partnerships with e-commerce ventures.

 For information on the charities' internet fundraising and e-commerce forum, contact Gareth Edwards at gedwards@rnib.org.uk

fields.headline: Preston Sturges: Sullivan's Travels
fields.trailText: Is the film serious underneath its hilarity? Perhaps not entirely, since Sturges, like Sullivan, never quite knew how to do it. But the way his assemblage of characters so often seem to realise their own failings at least betokens a sophisticated, perhaps kindly cynic. People have tended to say that Sturges' films were as confused as he was. If that is so, long live abstracted directors, since they tend to see the world as it is rather than as we might wish it to be
fields.body:
Preston Sturges was a writer-director the like of which we haven't seen since. He was a well-connected anarchist in a system that frowned on such tendencies - unless they made money. Directors such as Billy Wilder owed a great debt to him.

Sturges's America was cheerfully corrupt, absurd and frequently unaware of its own ridiculousness, and his films were so high on comic dynamism that you could readily forgive the wayward lip service to logic.

His glory days were brief. Within 10 years of his directorial debut, The Great McGinty (1940), he was worn out, and he died bankrupt in 1959. But in his heyday he made half a dozen comedies as subversive as any now, and a good deal funnier. Sullivan's Travels was probably his masterpiece.

It starts off with Joel McCrea's Sullivan, a director of farces who wants to get serious with a script called O Brother, Where Art Thou?, being berated by studio bosses because he doesn't know the meaning of the poverty that Brother talks about.

So he borrows a tramp's outfit from the wardrobe department andtakes to the road, with a studio bus full of doctors, bodyguards and secretaries a discreet distance behind him. The more he tries to break away from Hollywood, the faster it comes towards him. After picking up a failed actress who says things like "There's nothing like a deep-dish movie for driving you into the open", the rich man's search for poverty ends in a fight with a policeman that has him incarcerated in a chain-gang.

In a key scene, he and the other convicts go to a black church hall, where the minister instructs his congregation to welcome those less fortunate. And together everyone roars with laughter at a Disney cartoon. Sullivan may not have found seriousness but at last he has found how valuable true comedy is.

Unconvincing as this may seem - and certainly sentimental - it is an unforgettable moment, perhaps telling us that the high art Sturges despised is worthless if merely inspired by middle-class guilt. Even if you don't appreciate this defining sequence in the film, everything else gels perfectly: the ridiculous studio bus full of hangers-on trying to get Sullivan out of the scrapes he falls into, the butlers who object to the whole enterprise, the ghastly wife who thinks he's dead and lays flowers on his supposed grave like a fashionable zombie.

Is the film serious underneath its hilarity? Perhaps not entirely, since Sturges, like Sullivan, never quite knew how to do it. But the way his assemblage of characters so often seem to realise their own failings at least betokens a sophisticated, perhaps kindly cynic. People have tended to say that Sturges' films were as confused as he was. If that is so, long live abstracted directors, since they tend to see the world as it is rather than as we might wish it to be.

webTitle: How did the US election produce this impasse?

fields.headline: How did the US election produce this impasse?
fields.standfirst: It was always a complex procedure - now the complexity is tinged with absurdity. Martin Kettle, Julian Glover and Derek Brown pick their way through the psephological minefield
fields.trailText: It was always a complex procedure - now the complexity is tinged with absurdity.We pick our way through the psephological minefield.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle, Julian Glover and Derek Brown
fields.body:
Who got most votes?
Vice president Al Gore got a quarter of a million more votes than governor George W Bush in an incredibly close race.

So it's president Gore now?
No. He still needs to win in the tightest race of all, in the state of Florida. The contest there was as close as it could be, with the first count indicating that Bush won by less than 1,800 votes out of 6m cast.

So why isn't Bush president?
Because there has been a recount across the state. That put the two candidates even closer together and led some parts of the state to begin a hand recount of the vote which may yet put Gore ahead. Tangled in a mass of recounts and legal cases the final result from Florida may not be known for days.

But why does Florida matter so much? Gore got a majority of the votes across the US
Because US presidents are not elected directly but through an electoral college. In 48 of the 50 states, the candidate who finishes top collects all of that state's votes in the college (in the two oddballs, Maine and Nebraska, the candidate who comes second is given one of the college votes as well). As things stand, neither Gore nor Bush has yet achieved a majority in the electoral college.

How is the electoral college organised?
The college has 538 seats. A candidate needs 270 electoral college votes to win. Roughly, college votes are allocated to states by population. As the largest state, California has 54 votes in the electoral college. New York is second with 33. Seven sparsely populated states, plus the District of Columbia, have three votes each, the minimum allowed.

Who got to vote?
All US citizens aged over 18 have the right to vote - although this is qualified by a range of conditions, including, in some states, the long-term loss of voting rights by anyone sent to prison (a clause which has disqualified many poor, black citizens in the southern states). Most states allow voters to register to vote until 10 days or so before polling day and, in recent years, the process has been simplified. Americans can apply to register online and even when they renew driving licences.

How did it work on polling day?
Again, the rules vary from state to state: but almost everywhere, voting is a different experience from the same process in Britain. For a start, only 1.7% of voters use British-style ballot papers. Traditionally, Americans vote using mechanical levers (a bit like adding up on an old-style cash register). About a fifth of US votes are still cast this way, but computer technology is taking over. Whichever system is used, the votes are counted quickly. Since polling stations close early in the evening, the result is often declared surprisingly early. Adding to the complexity, though, are America's multiple time zones. Exit polls from some eastern states were available before voters have finished choosing candidates in the west. Many observers believe this had a big impact on the result.

What happened after the polls closed?
The votes were counted and results declared state by state. Most international attention focused the presidential race, but Americans have also voted on a huge range of other jobs, including some state governors, senators, members of the House of Representatives and local officials such as police chiefs. In some states, voters also took part in referenda on contentious local issues.

webTitle: Shayler pleads not guilty as trial date is set

fields.headline: Shayler pleads not guilty as trial date is set
fields.trailText: Former MI5 agent David Shayler today pleaded not guilty to three charges alleging that he breached the Official Secrets Act.
fields.body:
Former MI5 agent David Shayler today pleaded not guilty to three charges alleging that he breached the Official Secrets Act.

The recorder of London, Michael Hyam, fixed the date of his trial to April 23 next year. It will be heard by a high court judge.

During a brief hearing at the Old Bailey, Nigel Sweeney QC, for the crown, gave assurances that it was hoped that most of the trial would be in open court.

Lawyers for media organisations attended the hearing to object to a notice from the crown prosecution service that it might apply for all or part of the proceedings to be in camera.

Mr Sweeney said: "Could I make it clear that the crown obviously wish the whole of these proceedings to take place in open court."

But there could come a time when "sensitive" documents needed to be discussed and it could "defeat the very public interest which we wish to protect" if that was done in the open.

The issue is expected to be discussed at a future pre-trial hearing. The trial is due to last between two and four weeks,and may be heard at the royal courts of justice.

Mr Shayler, 34, of Wimbledon, south-west London, was told that his bail will be allowed to continue to the next hearing.

He pleaded not guilty to three breaches of the Official Secrets Act 1989. Two of the alleged breaches, under section 1 (1), alleged that he unlawfully disclosed documents relating to national security.

The third alleged that he disclosed information obtained by interception of communications under section 4 (1), and contrary to section 2 of the interception of Communications Act 1985.

All the offences relate to August 1997 when the Mail on Sunday newspaper printed an article about the surveillance of prominent politicians.

fields.bodyText: Former MI5 agent David Shayler today pleaded not guilty to three charges alleging that he breached the Official Secrets Act. The recorder of London, Michael Hyam, fixed the date of his trial to April 23 next year. It will be heard by a high court judge. During a brief hearing at the Old Bailey, Nigel Sweeney QC, for the crown, gave assurances that it was hoped that most of the trial would be in open court. Lawyers for media organisations attended the hearing to object to a notice from the crown prosecution service that it might apply for all or part of the proceedings to be in camera. Mr Sweeney said: "Could I make it clear that the crown obviously wish the whole of these proceedings to take place in open court." But there could come a time when "sensitive" documents needed to be discussed and it could "defeat the very public interest which we wish to protect" if that was done in the open. The issue is expected to be discussed at a future pre-trial hearing. The trial is due to last between two and four weeks,and may be heard at the royal courts of justice. Mr Shayler, 34, of Wimbledon, south-west London, was told that his bail will be allowed to continue to the next hearing. He pleaded not guilty to three breaches of the Official Secrets Act 1989. Two of the alleged breaches, under section 1 (1), alleged that he unlawfully disclosed documents relating to national security. The third alleged that he disclosed information obtained by interception of communications under section 4 (1), and contrary to section 2 of the interception of Communications Act 1985. All the offences relate to August 1997 when the Mail on Sunday newspaper printed an article about the surveillance of prominent politicians. webTitle: 'Do I have a right to be represented at a disciplinary hearing'

fields.headline: 'Do I have a right to be represented at a disciplinary hearing'
fields.standfirst: Your manager must allow you to be accompanied by your choice of companion at a disciplinary hearing, writes Stephen Cavalier
fields.trailText: Your manager must allow you to be accompanied by your choice of companion at a disciplinary hearing, writes Stephen Cavalier
fields.body:
Q. I was recently told that I had to attend a disciplinary hearing because I got to work late twice. I had reasons on both occasions. My ex-husband had failed to turn up to pick up my child when agreed. I asked if I could have a colleague with me at the disciplinary and I was told that I couldn't. Is this legal?

A. Absolutely not. Under section 10 of the Employment Relations Act 1999, the Act that introduced the right to trade union recognition, a worker has the right to be accompanied by another person at a disciplinary or grievance hearing. The people who may accompany you are:

 someone you choose
 a trade union official employed by the union
 someone who is experienced in accompanying people in hearings and who has references to prove it
 a fellow worker.

If your chosen companion is not available at the time fixed for the hearing then you may postpone it. However, there is a five working day time limit for postponed hearings.

Whatever your circumstances, you have the right to defend yourself, thanks to the new legislation. If your employer refuses to allow you your chosen companion, even though you or your union representative have informed your employer of your rights, then you may complain to an employment tribunal. A complaint has to be made within three months of the date when your boss refused to allow you to exercise your right to be accompanied.

 Stephen Cavalier is head of employment rights at Thompsons Solicitors

fields.headline: Interest rates held
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2000
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Bank of England today announced interest rates are to be kept on hold, confirming City expectations that the official cost of borrowing would not rise.
fields.body:
The Bank of England today announced interest rates are to be kept on hold, confirming City expectations that the official cost of borrowing would not rise.

Chancellor Gordon Brown's £5.7bn pre-budget statement yesterday, a package of carefully targeted tax cuts and spending increases, has not altered the bank's inflation outlook and forced a rate rise.

The bank's nine-member monetary policy committee voted to keep rates at 6%, making it nine months in succession that they have been left unchanged.

In his speech to the CBI annual conference in Birmingham on Tuesday, the bank governor, Sir Eddie George, had injected a note of caution, rejecting calls from industry for a signal that rates had peaked and warning that further rises were still possible.

Some economists have argued that with underlying inflation still comfortably below the government's target and pay pressures subdued, despite falling unemployment, the MPC are right not to act.

fields.headline: What are your prospects?
fields.trailText: It is tough at the top for charity chief executives according to a survey of pay and conditions. On average they clock up over 48 hours a week and 70% work at weekends.
fields.body:
It is tough at the top for charity chief executives according to a survey of pay and conditions. On average they clock up over 48 hours a week and 70% work at weekends.

And the rewards for this effort do not come in the form of cash. The survey of 328 CEOs, conducted by the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations (ACEVO), found that in comparison with the private sector, salaries were up to 27.5% lower.

Chief executive of ACEVO, Stephen Bubb, says: 'It's vital that the sector is able to attract talented leaders. This survey is an essential tool for us to set appropriate remuneration levels across the sector.'

Although recent advertisements for CEOs at Marie Curie Cancer Care and NSPCC show salaries topping the £100,000 mark, voluntary sector leaders miss out on packages offered to their counterparts in business.

Stephen Perrett, managing director of recruitment agency Execucare, says: "Salaries in charities are not that far adrift from the public or private sector up to middle management level but then the gap opens up and senior managers lose out on cars, share options and health insurance."

However, director of Charity Recruitment Adele Bird, says: "A lot of people are prepared to take a salary cut to feel more satisfied with their job." She finds people who want to leave the private sector frequently tell her that they have had enough of lining shareholders' pockets.

There are some perks that go with working in the voluntary sector. With over 190,000 part-time jobs and a third of charities operating flexitime, the sector is leading the way in family-friendly and flexible working patterns.

Research by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations in 1998 showed that 37% of voluntary sector workplaces had a trade union presence, compared with 28% in the private sector.

Bird claims that there is a trend in the voluntary sector towards parity with business but she says: "There will always be something unique about the sector which draws you in and holds you. It is not just about cash benefits."

fields.headline: Short changed
fields.standfirst:
Bricks and mortar not the whole story for publisher

Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: Howard Sharron, who runs a web publishing and software company in Hockley, a run-down industrial district in the heart of Birmingham, was unimpressed by Gordon Brown's measures to attract entrepreneurs into inner cities.
fields.body:
Howard Sharron, who runs a web publishing and software company in Hockley, a run-down industrial district in the heart of Birmingham, was unimpressed by Gordon Brown's measures to attract entrepreneurs into inner cities.

He said stamp duty exemptions on properties in deprived areas would not have enticed his firm, Questions Publishing, when it began producing magazines for teachers 15 years ago."We have never bought a property - and we certainly didn't have enough money to do so when we started out," he said. The firm now has a turnover of £6m and a staff of 80.

Further concessions on converting buildings in rundown areas into flats left Mr Sharron, 47, equally cold, though he said a general improvement of the immediate environment would be "no bad thing".

More appealing to a company which now specialises in online teaching resources was the chancellor's commitment to tax relief on intellectual property and goodwill, an issue over which Mr Sharron has always felt short changed.

"Because the products we produce are branded, we are not allowed to give them a value on our balance sheet," he explained.

"If it was rusting machinery we produced we could include it, but our titles - which are highly saleable - are ignored by the banks, so we always lose out. Our brands are considered intangible assets that could disappear overnight if we got in trouble."

Mr Sharron, who remains the main shareholder in Questions Publishing, also drew encouragement from Mr Brown's pledge to extend capital gains tax concessions to venture capital firms.

"Smaller, out-of-the-way companies have often been overlooked by venture capitalists, who have argued that it is as expensive for them to monitor an investment of £300,000 in a small firm as it is to watch over a £3m investment.

"Any encouragement to spread venture capital is welcome."

He added that small firms would also appreciate the proposed VAT simplification, though it was a minor measure. Mr Sharron said that the chancellor could have done more for hi-tech firms, by, for instance, giving the kind of grants he had seen the manufacturing sector pick up.

fields.headline: Tax break for risk takers' shares
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: Start-up businesses yesterday welcomed new tax breaks on share option schemes, but were disappointed that changes will not come into force for nine months.
fields.body:
Start-up businesses yesterday welcomed new tax breaks on share option schemes, but were disappointed that changes will not come into force for nine months.

Under the new rules, small businessess will be able to offer share options to all employees. The previous limit was 15 key employees. The former £100,000 limit for individual option allocations will be removed, and the total value of share options that a company can issue will be raised from £1.5m to £2.5m.

The scheme, the enterprise management initiative, is aimed at high-risk and e-commerce companies and is far more generous than the company share option plan (Csop) operated by larger companies.

Under the EMI, workers who join start-up companies will be able to exercise their options at any time - there are no rules preventing people cashing in before three years in the style of Csops - and there is no income tax on the gains made. Capital gains tax has to be paid, but this can be reduced to just 10% if the em ployees hold the shares for four years or more.

For someone joining a company who is offered 100,000 £1 share options that rise in value to £3 over four years, the employee makes a gain of £200,000, and will have to pay less than £20,000 in tax.

The inland revenue says it will consult on the proposed changes, delaying implementation until July next year when the 2001 Finance Act comes into force.

BDO Stoy Hayward director Jonathan Davies said: "This is good news for start-ups, but the time delay is a touch frustrating."

The chancellor is now expected to face pressure to reform Csops. Diane Hay of Proshare, the organisation that promotes wider share ownership, said: "Although the changes to EMI are very favourable, the limits on Csops are now very low compared to other countries."

But Ms Hay welcomed further help for companies to relieve them of the potentially huge national insurance liabilities that plague employee share schemes. Legislation will be brought forward to allow companies to settle NI liabilities early rather than letting them rise as share prices rise.

fields.headline: When the system breaks down
fields.standfirst: The systems for assessing the mentally ill need to be urgently restructured, or the consequences will be fatal
fields.trailText: The systems for assessing the mentally ill need to be urgently restructured, or the consequences will be fatal.
fields.body:
When community care for the severely mentally ill breaks down, the consequences can be fatal. It is estimated that one in 10 people suffering from schizophrenia commit suicide. This statistic does not include the less quantifiable incidences of self-harm.

According to recent official figures, 40% of all homicides in England and Wales are committed by people with some kind of mental disorder, including alcohol and drug addiction. Many of these people have already been in contact with mental health services.

These figures do not include violent assaults. They also do not include some of the less dramatic, but no less traumatic, consequences of dumping ex-hospital patients into inner city flats and bedsits, often ostensibly "managed"' by the voluntary sector (which raises much needed revenue from teaming up with local authorities and housing associations). When left to cope on their own the ex-patients, predictably, stop taking their prescribed medication.

When the Department of Health issued guidelines in 1994 on the setting up of independent inquiries in cases of homicide by mentally ill people who had been receiving treatment, they probably had no idea what they were letting themselves in for.

There have been about 110 of these inquiries so far, over half of which have already published reports. The inquiry system itself has been criticised for promoting a culture of blame (which it doesn't), for wasting public money (yes, in some cases) and for continually offering the same recommendations (so what?). While these criticisms are not always valid, there is, admittedly, a lot wrong with the present system, not least the ad hoc, sometimes unconvincing, quality of individual reports.

A recent example is the report into the care and treatment of Phillip Craigie, published by Portsmouth and South East Hampshire health authority. The day after being assessed in a police cell and declared mentally stable, the teenager drove his parents' car at high speed into the back of another car waiting at traffic lights. The occupant, 67-year-old David Close, was killed instantly.

Phillip had given much cause for concern in the days before the police cell assessment. Yet in less than hour it was decided he was not a risk to himself or others - as if these are the only criteria for hospitalisation.

The inquiry panel failed to mention in its report the possibility of sectioning Phillip on the grounds that "he ought to be so detained in the interests of his own health or safety or with a view to the protection of others" (section two of the Mental Health Act 1983). The interests of Phillip Craigie's own health were, I feel, more than sufficient grounds for further assessment in a hospital for a period of 28 days or less.

It is high time the Department of Health formalised the inquiry process by handing responsibility over to the Commission for Health Improvement, or, alternatively, to a new, independent body. Some say our society is obsessed with inquiries, but I would rather it were thus than live in a society which pays only lip service to them.

The inquiry panel failed to mention in its report the possibility of sectioning Phillip on the grounds that "he ought to be so detained in the interests of his own health or safety or with a view to the protection of others" (section two of the Mental Health Act 1983). The interests of Phillip Craigie's own health were, I feel, more than sufficient grounds for further assessment in a hospital for a period of 28 days or less. It is high time the Department of Health formalised the inquiry process by handing responsibility over to the Commission for Health Improvement, or, alternatively, to a new, independent body. Some say our society is obsessed with inquiries, but I would rather it were thus than live in a society which pays only lip service to them.

fields.headline: AA buys Petrolbusters.com
fields.trailText: 11.45am:UK motoring organisation the AA has bought Petrolbusters.com, just in time for the next fuel crisis, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
UK motoring organisation the AA has bought Petrolbusters.com, the website that gained momentum during September's fuel crisis, just in time for the next fuel crisis.

Petrolbusters.com founder James Black said he was chuffed with the £250,000 deal and was looking forward to building up the website even further.

The website was set-up by a small team of e-commerce enthusiasts to disseminate information about cheap petrol, but became national news two months ago when it broadened its service and offered information on which filling stations still had petrol.

An emergency Petrolbusters team is currently standing by for any repeat of the fuel crisis.

Matthew Thompson, director of Centrica Information Services, which owns the AA, said the purchase is the first step in a series of planned improvements to the AA's website, theaa.com.

The plan is to make the AA's website into an "unrivalled source of motoring, traffic and travel information on the web", said Mr Thompson, adding that it would relaunch before the end of the year.

The Petrolbusters.com team is now in discussions with the AA about setting up other motoring-related projects.

fields.headline: BBC mulls 'Radio 4 on demand"
fields.trailText: 8am: Radio 4 controller Helen Boaden is talking to BBC bosses about the possibility of "Radio 4 on demand", writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Helen Boaden, who took over earlier this year as Radio 4 controller from the "scourge of Middle England", James Boyle, is talking to BBC bosses about the possibility of "Radio 4 on demand".

Ms Boaden said: "All BBC radio networks are having discussions about the possibilities of some radio-on-demand." But she added that TiVo-style self-scheduling for radio was "some way off".

Ms Boaden's comments came in response to criticism that many of Radio 4's more popular programmes, such as arts programme Front Row and media show The Message, were scheduled at bad times for working listeners.

Radio 4's strategy of repeating popular programmes on a Sunday could be extended to other parts of the schedule, including weekday evenings.

But Ms Boaden, who is keen not to inherit Mr Boyle's poisoned chalice, promised that she wouldn't alienate her core audience. She has ruled out changes to Britain's longest-running soap, The Archers.

She said The Archers would not lure new listeners to Radio 4, in contrast to Today, which was often younger listeners' first experience of the station.

Speaking at a Broadcasting Press Guild Lunch, Ms Boaden added: "We've got fantastic growth opportunities among our existing listeners - we need to focus on getting them to listen more. We will see more over-45s than ever before."

She said she felt "indignant" when Radio 4 listeners were "assumed to be a certain kind of person just because they are a certain kind of age".

Plans outlined by Ms Boaden included more "blockbuster" book serialisations including Jane Austen's Emma.

She also said that Radio 4 would cut back on "inner voices" drama and focus more on narrative-driven plays.

The Radio 4 controller also defended the station's decision to reduce the number of commissions open to independent production companies.

In the autumn commissioning run the slots open to independent producers had been cut from 285 to 22, provoking fury from the production community.

webTitle: AOL UK links up with Littlewoods

fields.headline: AOL UK joins Littlewoods to market unmetered internet access
fields.trailText: 11.30am: AOL UK is launching a joint marketing campaign with retailer Littlewoods, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
AOL UK is linking up with Littlewoods in a joint marketing campaign to promote its new unmetered internet access.

The deal will see software for the AOL service being distributed in Littlewoods' 275 stores and on its home shopping channels.

In return AOL will promote Littlewoods' products on its shopping channels and on Netscape. The two companies are also planning a series of joint promotions.

Littlewoods' e-commerce director Greg Ball said: "Littlewoods has pledged to sell more online than any other UK retailer over the next five years. To do this we must attract as many customers online as possible."

AOL said yesterday it would open up its unmetered internet access service to the whole of the UK. The flat-rate service was initially only available to existing AOL members and cynics said at the time of launch that AOL might drag its heels on rolling out the service to non-members.

webTitle: Guardian Unlimited advert hits all media

fields.headline: Guardian Unlimited in world first
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Guardian Unlimited has achieved a world first for a media owner - an advertising campaign that runs across six different media platforms.
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited has achieved a world first for a media owner - an advertising campaign that runs across six different media platforms.

The campaign for IBM, which breaks this week, runs across the Guardian newspaper, GU websites, email newsletters, interactive TV, PDA and WAP channels for a month.

Steve Wing, head of commercial development at GU heralded the move as the start of a new era for both media owners and agencies.

"This campaign is testament to the vision, willingness and ability of the commercial and technical teams at IBM, Guardian Unlimited and m digital [IBM's agency] to produce imaginative and ground-breaking work."

The campaign, which promotes IBM's multi-media capabilities, comprises: banners on the GU internet network, banners on GU's Wap and PDA services, sponsorship of daily email news digest The Wrap, IBM buttons on the GU section of NTL's interactive area and ads in the newspaper.

Ashley Harris of m digital, Mindshare's new media unit, said: "This integrated multi-platform campaign will help mould the future digital media landscape."
