fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
High and dry

It's a cruel irony that while much of the west country is awash, Jenny Vowles of Stroud is longing for a drop of water in her house. The saga began with a notice that her supply would be interrupted in early August while maintenance work was carried out in the neighbourhood.

When it was reinstated, the water pressure was so low that it failed to trigger her combination boiler, and so she was left without hot water. Severn Trent promised to investigate, but three months later she is still waiting.

Three engineers' appointments were missed; another was cancelled; three engineers turned up unannounced when Vowles was out; and she was given five different reference numbers by staff who promised to - but didn't - call her back. The only spontaneous communication Vowles has received in all this time is a water bill, which she is refusing to pay.

 "We've clearly not handled Ms Vowles' problem very well to date and we apologise for that," says Severn Trent sheepishly. "We have a lovely way of doing things: customer services pass jobs on to our planning guys, who call the customer and leave their contact number, but this seems to have caused some confusion." The press office had more success in dispatching an engineer, who solved the problem in a single visit. Vowles should be in line for compensation, a spokesman promises.

You're expelled

"Without limit; unrestricted" is the Oxford English Dictionary's interpretation of unlimited. Dixons' definition is more "limitedly limitless". David Lee signed up to its Freeserve package that goes by the name of Unlimited Freeserve Time and promises "unlimited internet calls day and night, 365 days a year". However, Lee was among a number of subscribers expelled from the system because of "heavy use".

 Dixons points to a caveat buried in the terms and conditions which states that users may be disconnected if they make "abnormal demands" on the network. "The 1% of customers that we disconnected were occupying 10% of the network," says a spokesman indignantly.

So what happened to "unlimited" access? "Unlimited is a standard term used to differentiate between two access products," he explains. "Anyone who knows about the net would recognise what it means." Right. Silly us. Time for an update of the OED perhaps? So what does the Advertising Standards Authority make of it? "It would depend on the warning," says a spokesman cautiously. "If the limitations were mentioned in the terms and conditions it might be OK, but the reader is welcome to contact us."

Mobile moans

Dermod Quirke has stumbled across an equally misleading advert in his quest for cheap phone calls. One.Tel boasts of its 3p-per-minute calls to the US, but its website mentions a 15p surcharge for calls to mobiles. The problem is that it's the recipient who pays the extra for mobile phone calls in the US - the caller (and the telecoms company) pays the standard landline cost. "Worse," says Quirke, "there is no way of knowing if I'm being charged 3p a minute or 18p because the dialling codes for mobiles are identical to landline phones."

 One.Tel sounds hurt and says it doesn't levy a surcharge for calls to US mobiles, even though its website indicates otherwise. How about altering the web page so customers don't form such unjust prejudices? "We're looking into that at the moment," says a spokeswoman, "but we've not had any queries about it in the past."

webTitle: Keane not keen on United home fans

fields.headline: Keane not keen on United home fans
fields.trailText: Roy Keane has launched an amazing attack on Manchester United's "prawn-sandwich eating" home fans after his side's nervous victory over Dynamo Kiev in the Champions League.
fields.body:
Roy Keane has launched an amazing attack on Manchester United's "prawn-sandwich eating" home fans after his side's nervous victory over Dynamo Kiev in the Champions League.

Teddy Sheringham's goal was only just enough to ensure the Reds' progression through to the second phase of the Champions League, and captain Keane blamed the crowd for failing to lift the team.

Keane told Radio 5 Live: "Our fans away from home are as good as any but at home you sometimes must wonder do they understand the game of football?

"One or two stray passes here and there and they are on players' backs and it's not on.

"Some people come here to Old Trafford and I don't think they can spell football never mind understand it.

"At the end of the day you need to get behind the team.

"Away from home our fans are fantastic, what I'd call the hard-core fans. But at home they have a few drinks and some prawn sandwiches but they don't realise what is going on out on the pitch."

United's three wins in Champions League Group G this season have all come at Old Trafford, but last night's victory tested manager Sir Alex Ferguson's nerves to the limit, as United faltered.

Substitute George Demetradze missed a virtually open goal for Kiev late on. If he had hit the target the Reds would be out.

Keane conceded: "We need to improve. If we play like we did in this phase we will be out."

fields.headline: Q&A: Postcode lottery
fields.standfirst: Differences in access to NHS treatment have given rise to  the notion of the postcode lottery - that where you live defines the quality and availability of NHS services you can expect
fields.trailText: Differences in access to NHS treatment have given rise to the notion of the postcode lottery - that where you live defines the quality and availability of NHS services you can expect.
fields.body:
What is the postcode lottery?
The postcode lottery is shorthand for seemingly random countrywide variations in the provision and quality of public services - the huge gap between the best and the rest. Where you live defines the standard of services you can expect. So if you live in the "wrong" area, and, in extreme cases, on the "wrong" side of a road, you may get a poorer service than your neighbour or you may not get the service at all and have to pay for it privately. The postcode lottery is a big issue in the NHS, where the gap between the rhetoric of a comprehensive and universal "national" service and the reality is increasingly stretched.

Which services are affected by the postcode lottery?
In practice, there are geographical variations in almost all aspects of care. Recent examples include variations in charges for disabled people's home care; NHS availability of the multiple sclerosis drug, beta interferon; availability of NHS invitro fertilisation services; waiting times for NHS treatment; assessment of children on social service "at risk" registers, access to NHS cancer screening programmes, and availability of drugs for Alzheimer's disease. Devolution has also brought the postcode lottery to the fore: Scotland plans to provide free personal care for people in residential and care homes, meaning that cost of long-term care for elderly people will be significantly cheaper north of the border. In Wales, fee exemption rules on prescriptions are more liberal, leading to the phenomenon of "drug runs" whereby people on the English side of the border drive acrossto stock up on cheaper medicines.

Who is most affected by the postcode lottery?
Generally speaking, the poorer you are, and the more socially deprived your area, the worse your care and access to it is likely to be. This is known as the "inverse care law". Well-off Kingston and Richmond, Surrey, has 50 per cent more GPs than deprived Barnsley, for example. But drug prescribing, and notoriously, abortion services, have been capriciously dependent on the whims, and in some cases, religious beliefs of local doctors, regardless of postcode. And, in the relatively wealthy south-east, shortages of key workers such as nurses mean waiting times for hospital treatment are longer than in less well-off areas in the midlands and the north.

How did the postcode lottery come about?
The government argues that, since its inception in 1948, there have been no national standards of care in the NHS. For five decades, services grew haphazardly: decisions on which treatments and drugs should be made available were made locally and on an ad-hoc basis by individual health authorities and powerful medical consultants. For many, the epitome of the postcode lottery was GP fundholding, introduced during the internal market of the 1990s. Patients of budget-holding family doctor practices (now replaced with primary care groups and primary care trusts) had faster access to hospital treatment than patients of non-fundholding practices, leading to a two-tier postcode lottery. The concept of a postcode lottery is also a by-product of patients and consumers becoming more aware: patient groups have become more adept at lobbying for their consumer "rights" to drugs and services and the well-targeted survey with its shock findings of a "postcode lottery" is a key weapon in their campaigning armoury.

What is the government going to do about it?
In its "new NHS" white paper of 1997, ministers promised to "renew the NHS as a one-nation health service". The government has since introduced measures designed to ensure "fair access and high standards of care across the UK". These include: national service frameworks, which will set national standards of care for key conditions and diseases, such as mental health and heart disease; the commission for health improvement which will monitor quality in NHS services and have powers to send in "hit squads" to take over failing hospitals and Nice - the national institute for clinical effectiveness (in Scotland, the Scottish health technology assessment centre), which will make NHS-wide decisions on the availability of expensive new drugs and treatments. In the 2001 election manifesto, Labour pledges to "further tackle the lottery of care" and says it will force health authorities and trusts to pay for drugs and treatments which are approved by Nice.

webTitle: 'My boss spies on my internet use'

fields.headline: 'My boss spies on my internet use'
fields.standfirst: He has no right to give you a formal warning over your internet use without first informing you that you are being monitored, writes Richard Arthur
fields.trailText: He has no right to give you a formal warning over your internet use without first informing you that you are being monitored, writes Richard Arthur
fields.body:
Q. I work for a local authority and have discovered that my line manager has been checking my computer to see what web sites I have been visiting. I only found out when my boss called me into his office and said he was giving me a verbal warning for misusing council property. He had discovered that I had been looking at an online recruitment site and had filled in an online application for a new job. Does he have the right to do this and can I be sacked?

A. For a start, your employer probably has its own online recruitment site. I wonder how it regards people looking at that? Just a thought - but an important one nevertheless. Workplace surveillance has been an extremely controversial issue over the past few months, with a great deal of confusing and contradictory legislation introduced by the government. The data protection act, code and regulations state that staff must be informed of their employer's intention to monitor their email and internet use.

Similarly, the Telecommunications (Lawful Business Practice Interception of Communications) Regulations, which were introduced on October 24 partly due to the Human Rights Act, make it unlawful to intercept business communications without telling the originator and the recipient of the email of the likelihood of interception. However, all an employer will need to prove in its defence is that it was acting to prevent the unauthorised use of its communications networks.

On the other hand, the Human Rights Act goes further in protecting employees from snooping bosses. Its provisions cover whether the employee had consented to surveillance, whether there had been consultation with individuals and trade unions and it also establishes the principle of employees being given access to private areas for personal communications, ie a private telephone line.

In your case it seems that your line manager is in breach of all of the above legislation by not first informing you that your use of the internet would be monitored. You are therefore within your rights to have your verbal warning wiped from your record. However, that warning does now constitute notification by your line manager of his intention to monitor your internet use.

webTitle: In brief: Anne Frank series not for Spielberg

fields.headline: Anne Frank series not for Spielberg
fields.trailText: Plus: Ford marriage finished; Mario Van Peebles to play X man in Ali biopic; and Tom Sizemore bulks out his schedule
fields.body:
 With the cameras already rolling in Europe, Steven Spielberg has backed out of his role as executive producer on a television series based on the life of Anne Frank, following a protest from one of the teenager's surviving relatives. Buddy Elias, a cousin of Frank's, had written to Spielberg claiming that the ABC TV series was not based on an authorised account of Frank's life. Spielberg already serves as chairman of the Anne Frank Foundation and a spokesman for the director said yesterday that "he did not want to do anything that would upset a relative of Anne Frank's or harm her memory". ABC plans to proceed with the series, which follows the fortunes of the Jewish teenager who hid out for several years with her family in Nazi-occupied Holland.

 Harrison Ford is reported to have separated from his wife, screenwriter Melissa Mathison (who wrote the scripts for ET and Kundun). The couple had met on the set of Apocalypse Now and had been married for 17 years. US tabloids have been linking the split to a supposed relationship between Ford and actress Lara Flynn Boyle after the two were spotted in a New York nightclub. Ford's manager Patricia McQueeney strongly denied the allegations. "I don't know how they invent these things," she told reporters.

 Mario Van Peebles has signed on to play Malcolm X in Ali, Columbia Pictures' Muhammad Ali biopic starring Will Smith as the heavyweight boxing champ. Throughout his career, Van Peebles has juggled acting with directing work: helming the urban thriller New Jack City and the black activism saga Panther, in which he also starred as Stokely Carmichael. The Malcolm X role is thought to be pivotal in the film. The civil rights leader was instrumental in converting Ali to the black Muslim faith, though the boxer later disowned his mentor after Malcolm fell out of favour with Nation of Islam leader Elijah Mohammad. In the meantime, Columbia will be holding open casting for extras on November 11, calling for men, women and children in period clothes from 1962-1974.

 Tom Sizemore appears to be spoilt for choice at present as he struggles to shoehorn two prominent movies into his overcrowded schedule. The bullish actor is in final negotiations to star in both Black Hawk Down, Ridley Scott and Jerry Bruckheimer's tale of imperilled US soldiers in Somalia, and as Al Capone in Sam Mendes' Prohibition-era thriller The Road to Perdition, opposite star Tom Hanks. Both films are slated for production in early 2001 and Sizemore may be forced to shuttle back and forth between them.

fields.headline: Boogie Nights creator recruits Sandler
fields.trailText: Precocious director Paul Thomas Anderson, known for grandiose projects like Boogie Nights and Magnolia, is about to make a bizarre next career move: a comedy starring Adam Sandler
fields.body:
Having tackled Las Vegas (in Hard Eight), the 70s porn industry (Boogie Nights) and pre-millennial tension (Magnolia), writer-director Paul Thomas Anderson looks set to make his strangest movie yet. The wonderkid director is about to film a comedy starring Adam Sandler.

The as-yet-untitled project remains shrouded in secrecy. But sources say that Anderson's script is a fast-paced, often slapstick affair that runs to some 90 pages - significantly shorter than the epic Boogie Nights and Magnolia.

Having secured Sandler, Anderson has reportedly offered the female lead to British actress Emily Watson and is still trying to woo Sean Penn to take a high-profile supporting role. The film will be co-financed by New Line Cinema and Revolution Pictures and will be produced by regular Anderson collaborator Joanne Sellar.

Despite having made his name with weighty, upmarket pictures, 31 year-old Anderson has always confessed a love of the stand-up Sandler, the ferret-faced star of The Wedding Singer and The Waterboy: "I just cry with laughter in his movies," he told a Guardian interviewer earlier this year.

As for Sandler, insiders suggest that he may be planning a Jim Carrey-style move towards more serious movies and claim that Anderson could provide the credibility he's been lacking. Paul Thomas Anderson's next movie starts shooting in January.

webTitle: Fulminating over reform while Americans hold their breath

fields.headline: Fulminating over reform while Americans hold their breath
fields.standfirst: The waiting goes on, but Derek Brown finds that the US press still has plenty to fill its pages
fields.trailText: The waiting goes on, but Derek Brown finds that the US press still has plenty to fill its pages.
fields.body:
Most of the big US papers are behaving with admirable sang-froid in the face of the biggest electoral sensation for decades. For the second day running, they are denied the presidential result that will launch an ocean of inky speculation about the new man in the White House.

Instead, there is a lake of speculation about changes in the voting system that produced such a remarkable non-result.

In Democrat-leaning California, the Los Angeles Times reports that critics of the electoral college system now have "Exhibit A" in their case for reform.

It picks up a proposal by Richard Durbin, a Democrat Representative from Illinois, to switch to a direct popular vote: "His proposal is likely to get serious attention in the year ahead, now that a modern-day candidate stands to lose the presidency despite winning the most votes.

"If Texas Gov George W. Bush prevails in Florida, he will have the necessary 270 electoral votes to win the presidency, even though Gore has a popular-vote margin of slightly less than 200,000."

In strongly Republican Texas, the Dallas Morning News is clearly in favour of election law reform.

"As the votes continued to roll in Wednesday, it appeared increasingly likely that one candidate would win the popular vote and another the electoral vote.

"Yes, the allocation of votes by state 'electors' does force candidates to pay attention to the smaller states, but if that is the most compelling reason for the indirect system, it may not balance the loss of public confidence if the popular vote is discounted. It's a new century.

"We should not bow to tradition if the electorate feels disenfranchised."

The Miami Herald, reporting from the heart of the Florida recount action, says that, in the revised tally, Bush's lead has been shaved from 1,784 votes to just 973.

In its leader column, the paper sets out its own agenda for voting reform, savaging election officials for the flawed design of ballot papers.

"This staggers the mind. In an age where gigabytes of data can be sent around the world in seconds, it defies common sense that Floridians continue to choose their leaders by punching holes in cardboard.

"That ballot is then placed in a box, which is driven with a police escort to a central facility for counting by machines whose technology was dated before World War II.

"We do not believe that Florida's torturous and tortured ballot count is the result of fraud But something went terribly awry - and the fate of the White House may well have been affected. According to election law experts, it may not be possible to correct any errors.

"Courts are correctly loathe to tamper with election results short of a showing of massive fraud. Florida now finds itself humiliated in the eyes of the nation and the world."

The Chicago Tribune laments that while the nation awaits news of its choice of president, the Congress is spending money like water - and making nonsense of the claims by both Bush and Gore that they will cut the national debt.

"The loud, furious and excruciatingly close campaign for the White House managed to mask a vexing problem at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue: Congress is spending money so fast the question of what to do with the surplus soon may be moot.

"George W. Bush and Al Gore set out grand plans to use the budget surplus for tax cuts and new spending programs.

"But while the presidential candidates were out on the hustings making promises based on generous estimates of future surpluses, the 106th Congress was engaging in the one activity not tainted by acrimonious partisan politics - raiding the piggy bank."

The New York Times has a wonderfully telling headline about the Senate election victory of Hillary Clinton - "First lady emerges from shadow and begins to cast her own".

The paper points out that, for the next two months at least, the new senator's life will be somewhat schizophrenic: "Mrs Clinton also said that, over the next two months, she would try to balance her remaining time as first lady with the preoccupations of a senator-elect.

"Today, for example, Mrs Clinton is to attend a White House dinner as the wife of the president. Tomorrow, she is to be the senator-elect on a statewide fly-around, thanking New Yorkers for a 12-point margin of victory over Representative Rick A Lazio that almost no one expected.

"Next week, Mrs Clinton will again be first lady as she accompanies her husband on a trip to Vietnam."

Finally, and to prove there is still a warm undercurrent of wit behind all the po-faced punditry in the US press, there is veteran syndicated columnist William Buckley.

In the Sacramento Bee, and no doubt dozens of other titles, he has a splendidly sardonic look at the results, and how little they mean to him.

"What does the election absolutely prove, never mind the froth above? It absolutely proves that 100,000 stout-hearted Republicans should move to Florida.

"Note: there is no state income tax in Florida, for those who waver in their resolve."

fields.headline: Retaining volunteers
fields.standfirst: Helen Mitchell, PR Manager at BTCV, explains the charity's new scheme to hold on to its supporters
fields.trailText: Helen Mitchell, PR Manager at BTCV, explains the charity's new scheme to hold on to its supporters.
fields.body:
Recruitment is an ongoing challenge for BTCV, the UK's largest practical conservation charity with an estimated 130,000 volunteers. But recently it has changed focus to concentrate on retaining its existing volunteers. The result is a new supporters club, which gives them an unprecedented say in how the organisation is run.

BTCV prides itself on operating for the benefit of volunteers, says the charity's relationship marketing manager, Debbie Jarrett. She explains that this is part philosophy and part business imperative:

"We believe volunteers have a right to influence the development of their organisation. Also, the more involved they become in the decision making process, the more committed they are likely to be. In a crowded market place, with many charities competing for the same volunteers, it's important to build up this customer loyalty."

A couple of years ago, says Ms Jarrett, it emerged that out of all the volunteers involved with the charity, few were joining BTCV's traditional membership scheme.

"Through talking with them, it became apparent that a narrow approach to membership, based only on monetary donations, was restrictive and excluding some of the very people closest to the organisation."

The charity wanted its volunteers to get more involved in running the organisation and particpating at grass roots level.

The response is BTCV's supporters club, launched this autumn by cabinet office minister Lord Falconer under the slogan "Make the Most of Your Time". Anyone who spends five days a year or more working for BTCV is eligible to become a supporter, with the option of a year's free membership. Members can stand for and vote in the elections to the regional and country committees and the council that governs the charity.

"Giving volunteers such a huge say is an innovative and bold step, and with a target of 40,000 volunteers joining in four years, a major financial investment," says chief executive Tom Flood. "But for BTCV, volunteer involvement at all levels of its operation is vital, if we are to remain vibrant and dynamic. Working with the 800 strong staff team, they make a very strong organisation."

The supporters club also encourages people who wish to pay with the relaunch of the charity's paid membership scheme. However, no one is excluded on the grounds of disposable income and BTCV hopes to encourage participation from those in the most disadvantaged communities.

Interest in the scheme has so far been good and Mr Flood says that in the longer term it will be possible to measure whether this way of recognising their gift of time will help retain volunteers.

"Research has highlighted that the reason many people stop volunteering is that no one has thanked them. We hope the Supporters Club will ensure that no BTCV volunteer ever falls into that category."

 Contact: Helen Mitchell, PR Manager, BTCV, Tel: 01491 821612, email: H.Mitchell@btcv.org.uk

webTitle: Indonesians see that film at last

fields.headline: Indonesians see that film at last
fields.trailText: After a struggle almost as tumultuous as the events it depicted, the Oscar-winning Hollywood film, The Year of Living Dangerously, was screened in Indonesia for the first time last night to a packed house at the second Jakarta International Film Festival.
fields.body:
After a struggle almost as tumultuous as the events it depicted, the Oscar-winning Hollywood film, The Year of Living Dangerously, was screened in Indonesia for the first time last night to a packed house at the second Jakarta International Film Festival.

The country's traditionally conservative censors delayed approving the 1982 film - which depicts the bloody fall of Indonesia's first president, Sukarno, in 1965 - until a few hours before the scheduled screening, because the authorities dug their heels in to show they would not be pressured by what they believed was an international conspiracy.

Last week an Associated Press report told the world that permission had been given to show the film, which the former president, Suharto, banned because it portrayed the communist movement of the 60s in a far different light from the venomous version he, like his predecessor, had drummed into the population.

On Tuesday, festival organisers thought they had the go-ahead when the film was returned to them, though without an authorising letter. This arrived yesterday afternoon, hours before the showing.

"It's been a week of living on the edge," said the festival chairman, Shanty Harmayn.

"At times I thought they were going to say no because this has caused such a fuss."

The screening went ahead despite the censors insisting that some of the slogans on communist banners and a female breast be blurred.

"We don't have a political agenda. This is just a film festival," she said. "We wanted to show it because not many films have been made in Indonesia or about Indonesia."

It was part of the category, Indonesia Through Foreign Lenses, which also included Punitive Damage, a 1999 film about the Santa Cruz cemetery massacre in East Timor in November 1991. Now that East Timor is no longer part of Indonesia, this was approved without a murmur.

Acclaimed in the west, The Year of Living Dangerously stars Mel Gibson, Sigourney Weaver and Linda Hunt, who won an Oscar for best supporting actress for her role as a local cameraman with a conscience. The 900-seat theatre had people standing at the back, sitting in the aisles, and between the front row and the screen.

The Jakarta high court upheld an appeal by state prosecutors yesterday and overturned a September verdict to dismiss corruption charges against Suharto. The judges said the trial could continue even if the defendant was not healthy enough to attend court.

fields.headline: New Media Age round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 9
fields.trailText: November 9: Sports portals, including Sportal, are accusing traditional sports governing bodies of being 'paranoid' about internet rights.
fields.body:
Sports portals, including Sportal, are accusing traditional sports governing bodies of being 'paranoid' about internet rights after two separate spats this week. One of the spats was Sportal losing its media accreditation for the Rugby League World Cup.

Virgin Radio is to launch the world's first interactive 3G radio service on the back of the 3G network being launched in the Isle of Man in early 2001.

Pure play new media agencies and e-business consultancies could be forced to seek partnerships in order to survive and retain key employees.

Moonfruit has become the latest dotcom to remodel its consumer business as a b2b offering.

The disappearance of Blackserve founder Paul Castro has led to the site being put into liquidation.

EasyJet has won the fight to retain its slogan 'the web's favourite airline'.

Web agency Red Hot Chilli has set up an autonomous mobile unit, headed by Conrad Buck, previously a technical strategist at Vodafone Airtouch.

Design agency Digit has appointed Toby Evetts, one of the founders of TBWA's digital unit, as director of content.

Website of the week is Radio Times' new film site, radiotimes.com/film, "a film site that should stand out from the crowd". 81/100.

webTitle: Claire Armitstead meets playwright Patrick Marber

fields.headline: So funny it hurts
fields.standfirst: His plays are hugely popular and he has been hailed as the new Pinter. So why does Patrick Marber find writing so painful? Claire Armitstead asked him
fields.trailText: His plays are hugely popular and he has been hailed as the new Pinter. So why does Patrick Marber find writing so painful? Claire Armitstead asked him.
fields.body:
Patrick Marber is late. When I ring him on his mobile he seems flustered. He's trying to hurry, he says. I have visions of flooded roads, of fallen trees on the line from Guildford, where his production of Pinter's The Caretaker is in its last week of previews.

Only later does he admit that actually he was shaving. In his flat around the corner. There is a momentary silence - what a comedy writer like Marber might script as a "beat" - before he launches into a fabulously rococo explanation. He was actually trying to do the Guardian a favour. You see, he did a stubbly photo shoot for another newspaper a few days back, and he thought we might want something different.

So here he is, smooth-cheeked and corduroy-clad, looking more like Lord Fauntleroy's prosperous older brother than the stand-up turned comedy writer turned author of two of the sharpest plays of the last decade, Dealer's Choice and Closer.

Part of the explanation is his dislike of being interviewed. "I'm still finding out how to give good quote and not reveal a thing," he explains. "It's like being England manager: you have to be so good at handling the media. There's an avalanche of words. I don't want to give a lot away but I also don't want to be a recluse."

Well, he riffs, part of him does want to be a recluse - the bit that finds showbusiness stressful and would much rather be living in the country with two dogs, perhaps supporting himself with a little light estate management.

It is hard to quote Marber without making him sound camp, which he isn't. He is effortlessly funny, but his humour is more Woody Allen than Ned Sherrin. Guilt plays a part in it, which he says may be a Jewish thing.

His reluctance to give much away goes hand in hand with a self-lacerating candour: when his poker play, Dealer's Choice, was premiered at the National Theatre in 1995, he let it be known that he had a gambling problem. When Closer spilled its load of cybersex and dysfunction, he said: "On some level I believe that there's no such thing as an honest relationship: all you can hope for is an honest relationship with yourself."

On occasions his mouth has got the better of him. In one interview, he pontificated that all comedy was sadistic: "And I don't think that at all. It was just something I said after a glass of wine in an interview that I was enjoying."

It's not altogether surprising that the quality he most reveres in The Caretaker is that "it never fully reveals its meaning but is very clear and accessible. It's wonderfully ambiguous and wonderfully specific at the same time." He saw it first at the National when he was in his teens, and it made him realise that theatre was what he wanted to do.

Marber's own lean, darkly funny writing has led some to dub him the heir to Pinter, so it seems significant that he has been chosen to direct this 40th-anniversary production of one of Pinter's most beloved plays.

Marber scorns the comparison - "Most younger writers are influenced by Pinter; I'm as much influenced by Stoppard and Oscar Wilde" - but admires his rigour. "I'm not really a cavalier," he says. "I think I'm a bit of a roundhead, in that I like things rigorous and shapely. But maybe as I grow up a bit I will become a bit more of a cavalier: my new play is much more anarchic and much less structurally formal than my earlier ones." At the moment it has 30 speaking roles, though given his obsession with revision, it may yet end up a monologue.

Perhaps equally surprisingly to anyone who has followed his work so far, this new play, slated for the National next summer, is not about city kids getting it on - it's an anxiety comedy about a 50-year-old who ruins his life. It is an exploration of the grandfather Marber never met - his father's father. "He was much loved. People say I'm a bit like him, and I feel his absence."

Marber, now 37, was the son of a financial analyst and the elder of two brothers. Growing up in Wimbledon, he soon proved bright and showed a flair for exams, which he attributes to a book his mother once bought him called The Exam Secret: "It was really a one-page book which said, 'Answer the question', and I stuck to that all my academic life."

This took him to Oxford, and gained him a slacker's upper second. It was no help at all with writing plays, which he professes to find almost unbearably painful. "How do I write? By avoiding writing, and I've done brilliantly at avoiding this next play. I've avoided it for three years. You avoid it for so long that guilt takes you over and you think that if you don't write it this year perhaps you'll never write it."

His girlfriend, actress Debra Gillet, chivvies him along. If it is so painful, why the compulsion to keep doing it? "If I don't have something on the go I feel, 'What's the point of me?' "

It's not that he has been exactly idle while failing to write this new play. Besides directing his own work - Closer took him from London to Broadway - he has tackled Mamet and now Pinter. He contributed a monologue to a charity anthology edited by Nick Hornby and has seen a screenplay through to rejection. It was an adaptation of Patrick McGrath's novel, Asylum.

"It was very faithful to the book and the book was very bleak. It's not an 'I-got-fucked-over-by-Hollywood' story. They were very nice and perfectly honest about it. I was a little upset until I bumped into Patrick and he really liked it, which was good enough for me."

So many young English theatre-makers are being wolfed down by Hollywood that it is surprising to find Marber holding out. He has fended off attempts to film his plays, saying he may do it himself one day.

Though he made his name in broadcasting, as Steve Coogan's comedy sidekick and co-creator of spoof interviewer Alan Partridge, he is not embarrassed to declare himself a man of the "old-fart, text-based theatre". His temperament, he thinks, is better suited to theatre, where you don't have to do everything by committee.

Does that mean he's a control freak? "Oh God, yes. But I don't feel like a freak. If you write something, you have a right to expect your words to be respected. Of course there should be people giving you advice, but you spend a lot of time with those words."

While he does not have Pinter's punctiliousness with commas and full stops, he is demanding about phrasing and timing. His characters, like Pinter's, don't need to deliver jokes to be funny. He muses that he would like to invent a new symbol of punctuation - perhaps a dash beneath a line - capable of implying a certain wryness, of indicating "that a character wasn't entirely serious when he spoke this". So why not go ahead and invent this new form of punctuation? "Because people would think you were an arse."

We're back to his peculiar mix of confidence and diffidence, of a will to control and what seems almost like a wish to throw it all away. This is most striking in his relationship with the gaming table. He is a self-confessed gambling addict, yet he flaunts his habit by playing celebrity poker on television.

A few days ago, he says, he drove past the flat of the student friend who took him to his first casino. "I had always felt I was a self-destructive type but I didn't have a self-destructive habit. I didn't drink much or take drugs. I remember thinking that night, as we were playing, 'Oh yeah, this is my vice. This is the thing I've been looking for to ruin my life.' "

When he began to find that cards were all he thought about, he took himself along to Gamblers Anonymous. "I was in trouble, in an adolescent sort of way. Now I'm like an alcoholic who has a drink. I'm playing a dangerous game but I have certain structures in my life - a relationship, my own property, and royalties."

Besides poker, he plays blackjack. It is what professional gamblers call their "leak": the game of chance that takes all your winnings off you. "I've greatly increased my stake over the years," he says, cheerfully. To what sort of level? "Oh, I couldn't say: that would be vulgar. But it's an amount that hurts when you lose it."

This is surely a terrible incautiousness for a man who describes his own mind as inquiring but cautious, who likes to keep control. Perhaps the excitement of poker has something in common with the impulse that keeps him writing his plays. "I find it incredibly difficult, but once a month you get a moment of joy when you find something you didn't know was there." Life, to misquote Pinter, is funny up to a point. After that, it's not funny at all.

 The Caretaker is in previews and opens at the Comedy Theatre, London SW1 (020-7369 1731), next Wednesday.

fields.headline: Remainders of the day
fields.standfirst: Anthea Turner's much-hyped autobiography sold just 451 copies in its first week - prompting her  publishers to censor sales figures. But she's not alone in such failure. Sally Weale on the books that bomb
fields.trailText: Anthea Turner's much-hyped autobiography sold just 451 copies in its first week - prompting her publishers to censor sales figures. But she's not alone in such failure. Sally Weale on the books that bomb.
fields.body:
There is something incontrovertibly sad about remainder bookshops. After all the hype - the big advances, the newspaper serialisation, the interviews, the signings, the readings, the appearance on Radio 4's Midweek or Woman's Hour - even the best of writers can find themselves consigned to cut-price corner.

While, for the book-reading public, remainder stores represent something approaching good value; for the writer, after the gargantuan effort that has gone into the creation of a book, to see it slashed in price from £20 to £4.99 and heaped high alongside copies of Rude Food, Ken Hom's cookery course and cheap art books must be utterly crushing.

At this stage in the day it may be hard to whip up sympathy for Anthea Turner, but Fools Rush In, her recently published autobiography, which was serialised with gusto in the Daily Mail, and followed up on the pages of many other newspapers, looks as though it may be heading for the remainders' shelves sooner than expected.

It emerged last week that Fools Rush In had sold a grand total of 451 copies in its first week and had entered the bestseller chart at number 531. Until now figures have been readily available through BookTrack, which monitors sales for the publishing industry.

But last week, after Turner's poor performance was gleefully picked up by the media, publishers met with BookTrack and an agreement was reached that figures for sales outside the top 100 should not be released in response to ad hoc inquiries. In other words, publishers are quite happy to tell us all about their success stories but are a little less candid about their failures. Of which, of course, there are far, far more.

Turner's publishers Little Brown paid an estimated £400,000 for her story. Last week they must have been watching David Beckham's success enviously as he found himself at the top of the hardback non-fiction bestseller list, shifting 4,726 copies of his glossy autobiography My World, bringing total sales to 15,235.

Likewise Martine McCutcheon's Who Does She Think She Is? was high in the bestseller list at number four, selling 3,375 copies last week (8,051 overall); Terry Wogan's Is It Me? sold 2,823 (24,392 overall), putting him at number eight, and at number nine, Barbara Windsor sold 2,711 (15,289 overall) copies of All of Me.

Such success stories are, however, comparatively rare in the publishing world. According to booksellers Waterstones, about 15% of all books bought by shops are returned to the publishers. In the case of Turner it is likely to be far more, possibly 50%. Many of those are then bought by remainder bookshops who sell them at hugely discounted prices.

On sale at The Works, a leading remainders bookshop in Camden High Street, London, last week were some of the casualties of the publishing industry, some high profile, others less well known.

There was Jeremy Beadle's Watch Out, reduced from £15.99 to £1; The New Alan Titchmarsh was on sale at £4.99, reduced from £16.99 and Norman Lamont's In Office, published amid much excitement last year, was on sale at £4.99, rather less than the original £20.

Getting publishers to talk about their flops is not easy. They are infernally optimistic. Martin Nield, managing director of Hodder & Stoughton, was one of the few prepared to admit to disaster, though for him it was a matter of bad luck rather than poor judgement.

"We published the Will Carling autobiography. Everyone was right behind it. There was a huge serialisation deal in place," Nield explains. It all looked very promising until Carling left his partner Ali Cockayne and their baby son, amid much negative publicity. "It could not have been worse timing. The sales dropped stone dead. Lots went into the book shops, but it hardly sold at all."

More recently, Charlie Dimmock's Enjoy Your Garden failed to match expectation, despite a major serialisation and plenty of hype. Nicholas Clee, editor of the Bookseller, says: "After they had done so well with Jamie Oliver, they thought Charlie Dimmock would do the same thing for gardening, but I'm not sure it was a huge hit."

Dimmock's publisher Michael Joseph admits to being disappointed: "It did extremely well in book clubs, in the real mass market, but it did not do so well in conventional bookshops. But we controlled serial rights, so from a financial point of view we are all right," one insider confesses.

Often serial rights are controlled by the author and her literary agent, which means that all the proceeds from a newspaper serialisation go to them rather than the publisher, as in the case of the Turner book, which was sold for £250,000 to the Daily Mail. Not a penny went to Little Brown. However, the six-figure sum paid by the Mail on Sunday for the Dimmock serialisation went to Michael Joseph, taking the sting out of the expensive advance.

So do newspaper serialisations help to sell books? Sometimes? Always? Or can a major serialisation satisfy the public's interest and destroy sales? "It is a way of alerting the public - a public which does not usually buy books - that this book is out there," says one publisher.

It did not work for the Nick Leeson book, Rogue Trader, also published by Little Brown which paid £450,000 for the story. It did not sell well despite a prominent serialisation in the Daily Mail and all the concurrent hype and publicity.

"You've got to be a national treasure. There has to be a great deal of affection, which is why you can see Terry Wogan working so well, or Dickie Bird," says Hodder's Nield. Leeson hardly fits into the national treasure category either. Likewise Anthea Turner.

"We turned down Anthea Turner," one relieved publisher confessed last week. "It does not surprise me at all that that book has not sold. She's a C-list celebrity who has hardly done anything in her life. She's not glamorous. I'm flabbergasted they paid £400,000. There are some people who fascinate the public, and others who do not. Anthea Turner was absolutely the wrong horse to back."

Alan Samson, editorial director of Turner's publisher, Little Brown, and a veteran of celebrity books (Cher, Whoopi Goldberg and the Spice Girls), sounded as if he were in deep shock last week. He insisted that she had sold far more than 451, but added: "The vilification Anthea has had has definitely had an effect so far in sales, but the book is not lost yet.

But while David Beckham, Terry Wogan, Martine McCutcheon and Barbara Windsor are tramping up and down the country, appearing at bookshops and signing endless copies of their books (apparently it makes good sense to sign as many books as possible as unsold signed copies cannot be returned to publishers, according to Lynda Lee-Potter, who is also on the publicity trail flogging her book Class Act), Turner will be keeping an uncharacteristically low profile. There will be no book signings, no publicity tour, no readings or public appearances.

"At the moment there's no point," says Samson. "Whatever Anthea does at the moment will be turned against her. If she dived into the Thames to save a drowning dog, people would say it's a stunt by her publishers."

There are always going to be books - high-profile or otherwise - that don't sell. Last year 109,000 books were launched in the UK, that's about 2,000 a week on average. Most do not sell. If there is a lesson to be drawn from Turner's disastrous book, it is this - never believe anyone who claims there is no such thing as bad publicity. There clearly is.

And when you are wandering around your local remainders store, fingering sad little piles of Fools Rush In, remember it could be worse. The real disasters are pulped.

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 10
fields.trailText: November 10: Inaccurate reporting of the US presidential election results has embarrassed the US news networks.
fields.body:
Inaccurate reporting of the presidential election results has embarrassed the US news networks, with CBS anchor Dan Rather telling viewers "If you're disgusted with us I don't blame you." CBS and CNN were both forced to retract initial reports that vice president Al Gore had won the election.

Former UK Confidential columnist Marina Hyde has lost the appeal against her sacking by the Sun on a single count, and is planning to sue News International on the grounds of unfair dismissal, sexual discrimination and unfair dismissal procedure.

Dee Nolan has announced her launch team of journalists poached from nationals and glossies for In Style UK.

Journalists at Reed Business Information have voted by 95% in favour of re-recognition of the National Union of Journalists.

John Brown Publishing has recruited editors to head the first tranche of its WH Smith contract titles.

fields.headline: PR advice for charities
fields.standfirst: Specialists in the voluntary sector share their public relations successes and failures
fields.trailText: Specialists in the voluntary sector share their public relations successes and failures.
fields.body:
Paul Collins, press officer, Action Aid

Tip: humour
"For our campaign against genetically engineered food and patenting food crops, we sent out a spoof patent on conkers during the world conkers championship. We even enclosed conkers in the package sent out to the media. Journalists loved it. It was covered in the Guardian, Express, Telegraph and FT, as well as by hordes of radio stations."

Pitfall: complicated logistics
"We staged an event in London last year and booked our own photographer to cover it. Unfortunately, there were huge traffic problems on the day and the photographer was travelling from Oxford. It was not his fault, but he was so late he almost missed the event. In future, we will always use local people."

Tony Trueman, communications manager, St Mungo's housing association

Tip: creativity and case studies
"We did a survey which showed that relationship breakdown was the biggest reason why people became homeless. It was early winter. The runup to Christmas is full of homelessness stories, so we waited until Valentine's Day to release the story. We also found one of our clients was willing to talk about his relationship breakdown. He was interviewed on Radio 2 and two TV stations."

Pitfall: not anticipating the media's spin on your story
"We released the results of an NOP survey, which showed that tourists were put off coming to London because of the number of homeless people on the streets. We did get some good coverage but, in hindsight, we could have possibly ended up with 'tourists blame homeless' stories in some of the media."

Jonathan Tuckner, head of media, Community Service Volunteers

Tip:good preparation
"We launched a report on how gap-year graduates gain skills that employers value. We gave ourselves enough time. We planned it well. We lined up spokespeople and prepared good case studies. The report ended up on the lunchtime TV news."

Pitfall: not giving other organisations advance warning
"There was one disappointment with this launch. The report mentioned several well known blue-chip companies. The media rang them up for their comments. It could have been a perfect opportunity to get more coverage for the report. But we did not warn them, so they were not prepared."

Marcus Rand, head of media relations, Consumers' Association

Tip: prepare feature articles
"One of our team wrote a general feature article in connection with our food safety campaign. He then just faxed it out to all the regional newspapers. Although it was the obvious thing to do, we were still surprised by how many ended up printing it."

Pitfall: unwanted press conferences
"We held a press conference on the same issue one morning. We turned down requests for radio interviews beforehand to keep the story as fresh as possible. In the end, we did not get much coverage from the conference. Since then we have always asked ourselves: Do we need to hold a press conference? 'What new angle does a press conference give the story? What will a journalist get from a conference which they cannot get from written briefings or a quick telephone call?"

Mark Scothern, director, Derby Council for Voluntary Services

Tip: use personal and individual experiences
"We approached the local paper about increasing coverage for the voluntary sector. The editor agreed to print first person pieces written by individuals about their experiences of volunteering."

Pitfall: unwanted opinions
"In the past, we had a column in the local paper. But the public does not want to read the views of the voluntary sector. This was just social policy analysis. They want to hear real stories from real people. They want to hear how the voluntary sector makes a difference to real people's lives."

fields.headline: How to get shock value for money
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill speaks to Ed Jones, a creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide, about the use charities can make of advertising to further their cause.
fields.trailText: Nicola Hill speaks to Ed Jones, a creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide, about the use charities can make of advertising to further their cause.
fields.body:
"Read this you piece of shit."

So ran an eye-catching advertisement run by Anti-Slavery International in 1995. It is also the image selected by Saatchi & Saatch to lure readers to its new book on social campaigning, Social Work.

"Shock is now considered an approach to be used with caution," says Ed Jones, a creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide. He warns of compassion fatigue but says using painful images is sometimes unavoidable. An example he draws on is Italy's Greenpeace ad, Women and Children First, which shows a baby's head hideously deformed as a result of his mother having been exposed to 'harmless' radiation fallout from earlier tests in Soviet Kazakhstan.

In contrast, he points to the recent adverts by the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, (NSPCC) which depict children's icons, such as the Spice Girls and Alan Shearer, the footballer, shielding their eyes from painful events. "Using the viewers' imagination can be the most powerful tool possible," he says.

However, most charities cannot run to the advertising budget enjoyed by NSPCC. Jones says they should not be deterred. "Big ideas" he says, "can turn small budgets into powerful campaigns."

Jones cites the example of a London creative team who used a single poster to help ban .22 calibre handguns. After the massacre of schoolchildren in Dunblane, Scotland, parliament was introducing a law to ban certain firearms, but not .22 handguns. The team, with no money and no time, decided to act.

They discovered that Robert Kennedy had been assassinated with a .22 gun. Using a stock photograph of Kennedy, they had a poster printed to go on a lorry parked outside parliament on the day of the debate. "If a .22 handgun is less deadly," it asked, "why isn't he less dead?" An amendment was added to include the banning of .22 guns.

When money is tight, voluntary organisations that spend on advertising want a definite return on their investment. Jones says: "Decide on your objective and aim your message at powerful people. You need a spectacular advertisement which will get the issue on journalists' agendas."

However, Jones insists that social advertisements must be rigorously checked. "On any contentious issue, the smallest inaccuracy will be seized upon by opponents and used to discredit the argument."

Jones's advice overall is to be adventurous. "Your message has to be really powerful and life-transforming, otherwise you are wasting your money."

 Ed Jones joined Saatchi and Saatchi in London as a copywriter in 1984. From 1990 - 97 he was director of the Middle East region during the Gulf War and then moved on to be central and eastern Europe regional creative director. Since the beginning of 2000 he has been based in London as the creative director for Saatchi and Saatchi worldwide.

fields.headline: Sowerbutts for Channel 4
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Paul Sowerbutts, managing director of United Wildlife, is moving to take up the same role at Channel 4's programme distribution arm.
fields.body:
Paul Sowerbutts, managing director of United Wildlife, is moving to take up the same role at Channel 4's programme distribution arm.

Mr Sowerbutts will take up his new Channel 4 International post at the beginning of next year, replacing Bernard Macleod, who announced his decision to leave the TV industry in August.

He joins C4I with a brief to continue expanding the broadcaster's programme rights acquisition activity within the UK and worldwide.

Mr Sowerbutts said: "I've always wanted to work for Channel 4 International and the opportunity to develop both the international programming and profile through Channel 4 was too good to ignore."

Before joining United Wildlife last year, Mr Sowerbutts working for UK distributor Itel for 12 years, rising to become deputy chief executive by 1995.

C4I had a turnover of £18.6m last year, up 31% on the previous 12 months.

fields.headline: Ties, triple-centuries and dismissing Bradman
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: I have been trying to find information on the nickname of the MCC tie. Is it "egg and tomato", and why? asks Linda Walker
fields.body:
I have been trying to find information on the nickname of the MCC tie. Is it "egg and tomato", and why? asks Linda Walker

It's usually called the "egg and bacon" tie, and if you'd seen it you'd know why! MCC's full-colour tie is a lurid combination of orangey-red and yellow stripes - it's certainly challenging to find a suit or jacket that goes with it. Some MCC members don't try very hard - I once saw one wearing a purple cowboy-style shirt (complete with tassels) as well as the loud tie. There is also a more sober "city" tie, which is dark blue with little red-and-yellow MCC crests all over it.

Have two batsmen from opposing sides ever scored triple-centuries in the same match? asks Michael Jones

No. Only one first-class match has ever produced two individual triple-centuries, by WV Raman (313) and Arjan Kripal Singh (302*) in the same innings in the early stages of India's domestic competition, the Ranji Trophy, in 1988-89. Tamil Nadu piled up 912 for 6 at Panjim before they declared, then Goa made 230 for 6 before time ran out in what must have been a pretty dull game to watch. The nearest that players on opposing sides have come to doing it was in 1990, when Ian Greig made 291 at The Oval and Neil Fairbrother replied with 366 for Lancashire in another high-scoring draw.

WT Nevell played for Middlesex against the Australians at Lord's in May 1938 - and he got Don Bradman out! Can you tell me more about him? asks Jean Nevell from Sydney

Do I sniff a family connection here? William Thomas Nevell was born in Balham, south London, on June 13, 1916, and died in Worthing, Sussex, on Aug 25, 1978. He was a hard-hitting tailend batsman, and a fast-medium bowler who played a little for Middlesex (1936-38), Surrey (1939) and Northamptonshire (1946-47). In all he appeared in 51 first-class matches, scoring 671 runs and taking 105 wickets. He did indeed get Bradman out at Lord's in 1938. The match was played on May 30-31, and Bradman had achieved the rare feat of reaching 1000 first-class runs before the end of May in the previous game, at Southampton (typically, Bradman is the only player to have done this twice: he also managed it in 1930). According to BJ Wakley's book "Bradman the Great", a monumental piece of research which gives great detail on all The Don's innings, in that match at Lord's Bradman "gave an uncharacteristic display, being missed at long leg off Nevell when 0, off a wild heave, before being well caught [for 5] off another crude stroke, Denis Compton running across from slip to catch a nasty skyer at short leg".

Can you tell me the England squad for the 1996 World Cup? asks Wayne Trott

The squad was: Mike Atherton (captain), Alec Stewart (vice-captain), Robin Smith, Graeme Hick, Graham Thorpe, Neil Fairbrother, Jack Russell, Craig White, Dominic Cork, Phillip DeFreitas, Neil Smith, Richard Illingworth, Darren Gough and Peter Martin. After injuries to White and Fairbrother, Mark Ramprakash and Dermot Reeve were called up, but Ramprakash didn't get a game. It was a terribly disappointing tournament for England, whose only victories came against the less-than-Testing opposition of Holland and the United Arab Emirates. They lost in the group games to South Africa, New Zealand and Pakistan, and then were demolished in the quarter-final by Sri Lanka, the eventual champions.

Who was initially appointed as England's captain for the 1920-21 Ashes tour, but didn't make the trip? asks Tom Ware

MCC's original choice as captain for that first tour after the First World War was Reggie Spooner, an elegant right-hand opener from Warwickshire who played ten Tests between 1905 and 1912. By 1920-21, though, he was pushing 40, and after initially accepting the offer he stood down for business reasons. The new captain was Essex allrounder JWHT Douglas, who was nicknamed "Johnny Won't Hit Today", an affectionate dig at his defensive batting style and his flamboyant set of initials. It wasn't a happy tour: one of the strongest of all Australian sides, captained by the formidable Warwick Armstrong, won all five Tests. Oddly, Douglas had also taken over the captaincy of the previous Ashes tour, in 1911-12. Pelham "Plum" Warner was the appointed captain then, but he fell ill in Australia and couldn't play in the Tests. That was a much happier tour for Douglas: England won the last four Tests after losing the first one.

The Wisden site is superb! I'm trying to find out about my great-great-grandfather, Ernest William Smith, who played county cricket around the turn of the last century. I think he played for Kent or Middlesex, and I know that he probably stopped playing because he'd got drunk once too often. Can you tell me more? asks Nat Stock

Sorry, but there's no trace of an EW Smith in the Wisden archives. Which means no-one of that name has played first-class cricket in England. There was a slow left-arm bowler called plain Ernest Smith, who played a few matches for Yorkshire between 1914 and 1926, but he doesn't sound like your ancestor. There was also an Edwin George Smith, who played two matches for Gloucestershire, alongside WG Grace, in 1875 and 1876. He was born in Cheltenham in 1848, and died there, aged only 31, in 1880. And a little-known fact to finish with: Ernest William were the rarely used real forenames of the celebrated cricket writer EW "Jim" Swanton, who died in January.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous Q&A session, which leads with the early struggles of Steve Waugh, click here

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 10
fields.trailText: November 9: Channel 4 is safe from privatisation under the current Labour administration but will almost certainly be privatised if the Conservatives win the next general election.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is safe from privatisation under the current Labour administration but will almost certainly be privatised if the Conservatives win the next general election.

Fears are growing that too little is being done to tackle the estimated 10 million households that are expected to resist the switch from analogue to digital TV.

ITN shareholders have put flotation plans on hold, pending the publication of the forthcoming broadcasting white paper.

The BBC has signed its first exclusive deal with television presenter Jonathan Ross.

The appointment of a new chair for the Broadcasting Standards Commission has been held up following the Department for Culture, Media & Sport's decision this week to advertise the post externally.

Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group is making its first move into television, joining forces with indie 3BM TV to produce sports documentaries.

Fears are growing that too little is being done to tackle the estimated 10 million households that are expected to resist the switch from analogue to digital TV. ITN shareholders have put flotation plans on hold, pending the publication of the forthcoming broadcasting white paper. The BBC has signed its first exclusive deal with television presenter Jonathan Ross. The appointment of a new chair for the Broadcasting Standards Commission has been held up following the Department for Culture, Media & Sport's decision this week to advertise the post externally. Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group is making its first move into television, joining forces with indie 3BM TV to produce sports documentaries.

fields.headline: 'NHS needs knowledge culture'
fields.standfirst: Growing recognition for librarians' abilities
fields.trailText:
Name Pam Prior
Job regional librarian
Salary circa £42,000
fields.body:
Name Pam Prior
Job regional librarian
Salary circa £42,000

When Pam Prior gave up teaching in 1978 after moving to a different part of the country, she got an administrative job in a hospital. Librarianship, a side aspect of the job, soon had her hooked.

Prior had a joint honours degree in physics and chemistry from Nottingham University so she was able to take the Library Association's professional qualification and become a chartered librarian. Now, 22 years later, she is one of England's eight NHS regional librarians.

Much has changed in the intervening period, not least the nature of the job. "In 1978 you were very much seen as an archivist ­ as someone to keep things tidy. Nowadays there is an increasing recognition of the librarian's ability to organise knowledge and to transfer skills to the end user," she says.

The post of regional librarian is one in which you cannot manage directly. "You have to build structures where you manage remotely. There's an enormous amount of networking."

But Prior does not feel remote from the rewards of the job. "You get instant feedback," she says.

The NHS is a superb service for librarians to be involved in. "You know you're making a difference to the health of the nation. The NHS needs to have a culture that is based on knowledge and you know you're doing something about it."

 Pam Prior works for the NHS West Midlands region

fields.headline: 'Much more than stamping books'
fields.standfirst: Librarians face challenge of mastering technology
fields.trailText:
Name Belinda Hylton
Job assistant librarian
Salary around £16,000
fields.body:
Name Belinda Hylton
Job assistant librarian
Salary around £16,000

When Belinda Hylton moved from Lancashire to south-east England four years ago, she was in search of a career and the opportunity to earn some money.

Hylton, who had a degree in English and art, decided to study for a diploma in information management at Thames Valley University in Ealing, London.

Many of her younger peers already had years of experience as librarians, and to make up ground she worked in the university library. When she finished her diploma it was by chance that she came to work in the health field.

fields.headline: LineOne boss Harwood resigns
fields.trailText: The boss of LineOne has resigned amid rumours that the company is seeking a buyer, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The boss of LineOne has resigned amid rumours that the company is seeking a buyer.

Andy Harwood, chief executive of LineOne, is leaving after more than two years at the company to join his former LineOne boss Andrew Burke, now chief executive at incubator eVerger, as chief financial officer.

Mr Harwood was given the ceo job earlier this year to firm up the management structure after the departure of Ajay Chowdhury. Before taking the ceo position Mr Harwood was finance director.

LineOne will continue to be run by managing director Mary Turner, who was promoted to the position at the same time as Mr Harwood became ceo.

The news comes less than a week after rumours began circulating that LineOne shareholders, BT and United News and Media, had put the internet business up for sale.

At the time all parties refused to comment on sale speculation despite sources suggesting that an information memo on the proposed sale would be published this week.

Potential bidders could include Germany's T-Online, Italy's Tiscali or Terra Lycos, all of which are looking to gain a foothold into the UK.

Before LineOne, Mr Harwood was head of finance and business at BBC Drama.

"I believe eVerger will give me the ability to use the significant experience I have gained over the last two years at LineOne to its full potential," said Mr Harwood.

eVerger was set up in April 2000 by Aegis Group, the company which owns media agency Carat.

webTitle: 5,000 jobs to go in BT shakeup

fields.headline: 5,000 jobs to go in BT shakeup
fields.standfirst: British Telecom
fields.trailText: British Telecom today unveiled plans for a radical restructuring of its organisation, including seeing a total of 5,000 people leave the company by the end of the year.
fields.body:
British Telecom today unveiled plans for a radical restructuring of its organisation, including seeing a total of 5,000 people leave the company by the end of the year.

BT said it had already reduced management by 3,000 and a further 2,000 would leave the business by the end of this year.

But it stressed all the redundancies would be voluntary.

The move came as BT outlined its long-awaited restructuring proposals, which will see the formation of a new network company called NetCo.

BT will also spin off up to 25% of its BT Wireless mobile phone operation, a similar percentage of Yell, its the Yellow Pages directories arm, and make progress towards listing BT Ignite, its internet business.

Chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield said the reshaping was "no less dramatic in its way than the original privatisation (of BT) back in 1984".

The partial flotation of BT Wireless, which includes BT Cellnet, will take place in the second half of next year and that of Yell by the end of this financial year.

BT Ignite will be in a position to be floated off by the end of 2001.

As part of the proposals a new holding company will also be created called BT Group.

The changes meant BT would continue to see productivity improvements, including reductions in its workforce, said Sir Peter.

"We've already exceeded our target of 3,000 for the reduction of management and more than 5,000 people will have left the business by the end of this year," he said.

BT hopes to have reduced its debt by about £10bn by December 2001 from a combination of its disposals and the partial flotations.

The precise shape of NetCo had yet to be defined and discussions would take place about this with the government and telecoms regulator Oftel, he added.

Once this was achieved, BT would look to partially float off this business too, spinning off 25% as a separately listed company.

The new company would be able to focus solely on meeting the needs of licensed operators and service providers, including BT Retail and BT Ignite.

There would also be no conflict between it and the rest of BT, said Sir Peter.

fields.headline: A blueprint for agency collaboration
fields.trailText: The successful implementation of the national service framework (NSF) for mental health depends on effective inter-agency collaboration. At a time when there are many pressures on mental health service providers in the NHS and local authorities, those leading on NSF implementation have to convince a range of agencies to use the framework as "a way of getting the basics right".
fields.body:
The successful implementation of the national service framework (NSF) for mental health depends on effective inter-agency collaboration. At a time when there are many pressures on mental health service providers in the NHS and local authorities, those leading on NSF implementation have to convince a range of agencies to use the framework as "a way of getting the basics right".

Build on inter-agency initiatives The success of many government initiatives is based on inter-agency working. Health action zones are important agents for bringing local agencies together to work on health issues and can provide financial resources for joint initiatives. And health improvement programmes (HimPs), which every district has to develop and agree, are also useful for bringing agencies together to agree future strategies.

It is worth noting that many of the initial plans for implementing the NSF for mental health were strongly influenced by how effectively some of the NSF targets were incorporated into a health improvement programme.

Make primary care work One of the most challenging parts of the NSF is to develop effective mental health services in primary care.

GPs see a large number of patients with mental distress and recognise that, in many cases, problems could best be solved by agencies outside the NHS. Primary care practitioners should see the NSF as a way of helping to reduce the numbers of patients or of finding more appropriate ways of dealing with some of the causes of mental distress. The interests and skills of a GP often determine how mental health problems are dealt with in primary care. This expertise can be built on by involving interested GPs in working groups.

Primary care groups (PCGs) and primary care trusts (PCTs) provide greater scope to address some fundamental issues in primary care and they can begin to take a lead role in developing primary care mental health services. One possible starting point is to map local mental health services provided by all sectors. The NHS plan has provided important additional motivation for developing primary mental health services by providing resources for new staff.

Find the right people for the job Effective inter-agency working also depends on identifying committed individuals at a senior level in different agencies who will champion the cause of mental health. For example, a new social services director may change the relationship between health authority and social services, and the local authority commitment to mental health. Having a mix of people involved in service delivery and working at a strategic level is also important for effective implementation.

Set up working groups Setting up a mental health forum with wide representation of users, carers and local agencies can provide a starting point for bringing agencies together to address mental health. Using multi-agency working groups to look at specific aspects of mental health can provide useful expertise at key points in the planning process. Involving the voluntary and community sector through needs assessment also draws in an active user perspective as well as diverse service providers.

At a time when almost all agencies are changing, presenting ways of solving common problems becomes a powerful argument for working together. Identifying a common problem, such as access to services, and analysing its causes and effects together, can provide a consensus on which to build a vision of the future that is user and carer focused but also meets the requirements of the NSF and NHS plan.

fields.headline: Channel 5's marketing makeover
fields.trailText: 9.30pm Channel 5 bosses are planning a major hike in its marketing budget next year as new owner RTL seeks to shift the station's image away from football, films and fucking.
fields.body:
Channel 5 bosses are planning a major hike in the station's marketing budget next year as new owner RTL seeks to shift the station's image away from football, films and fucking.

Sources at Channel 5 said the planned increase in the programming budget would be accompanied by a change in marketing strategy and an increase in marketing spend.

The move is designed to change the downmarket image that has dogged the channel since its launch.

Channel 5 spends about £7m a year on advertising - a fraction of the £34m spent by rival BSkyB. Until now, the station's marketing strategy has focused on tactical ads for individual programmes and games.

Because of its low marketing budget Channel 5 has relied heavily on shock tactics in its advertising as a low-cost way of getting exposure for the brand. It recently recruited Monica Lewinsky to endorse the brand in a series of sponsorship idents.

And it used images of Anne Widdicombe, Baroness Thatcher and William Hague in newspaper adverts.

The marketing boost would be roughly in line with the proposed 50% increase in programming budget. The broadcaster is planning to up its programming spend from £120m this year to £180m in 2001.

But an agreement on the extra cash is understood to have been held up by directors at United News & Media, which owns 35% of Channel 5. While RTL is backing the increase, United is thought to be reluctant to rubberstamp the increase. The company is expected to quit the television market after selling its three television franchises earlier this year.

A United spokesman said: "Like many companies at this time of year Channel 5 is looking at its budgets." He declined to say when a final decision on the budgets would be made.
