fields.headline: Does Nice ration care?
fields.standfirst: The national institute for clinical excellence is accused of parsimony but is actually increasing NHS spending
fields.trailText: The national institute for clinical excellence is accused of parsimony but is actually increasing NHS spending, writes Steve Brown.
fields.body:
The national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) has not made many friends since it started analysing the effectiveness of drugs and medical technology last year.

In the minds of many patients, doctors and members of the pharmaceutical industry, it has become synonymous with health care rationing.

This reputation for parsimony may be unwarranted, however. Rather than capping spending, it may be inflating it. An analysis of the 15 Nice reports published by the end of October 2000 shows its guidance has added a net extra cost to the NHS of £155.7m a year.

The widespread perception of Nice as a rationer springs from its first published guidance in autumn 1999 - a rapid assessment of the effectiveness of the drug Relenza.

Some studies have shown Relenza can reduce the duration of flu by 24 hours if taken within 48 hours of the appearance of the symptoms. But Nice decided that there was insufficient information on the clinical effectiveness of the pill because the trials used only small numbers of patients. The institute advised doctors not to prescribe it.

Relenza would have cost at least £15m a year. But an examination of the guidance shows that Nice, whose members are drawn from the clinical professions, academics, health economists and patients groups, is attempting to steer a path between clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness and this does not always mean rationing.

The institute has said that the health service should not issue digital hearing aids until further research has been carried out. Even so, its report on hearing aids called for the widespread availability of analogue devices, which could cost the NHS an extra £50m a year.

Some of the institute's less well known guidance will significantly increase costs. Its backing of methylphenidate for the treatment of hyperactive children will cost £44m.

The availability of implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs), which monitor and control heartbeat, for heart attack victims or patients with irregular heartbeats, could cost £35m a year.

Nice produces an estimate of the financial impact of its guidance in each report and an analysis of the 15 reports published by the end of October 2000 shows a net extra cost to the NHS of £185.7m a year.

In fact, NHS costs should rise as a result of the guidance despite arguments that NHS budgets are increasing at a much greater rate than Nice-related spending inflation.

There is some concern that in key areas such as cancer, which are increasingly made up of ring-fenced budgets, Nice guidance will encourage spending on some treatments but rationing of drugs and therapies in others.

This fear was highlighted recently in a survey of cancer specialists in all 143 NHS oncology units in the wake of a decision by Nice that taxanes - drugs for breast and ovarian cancer - should be made widely available at a potential additional cost of £23m a year.

A pressure group, the Campaign for Effective and Rational Treatment (Cert), found that one in nine health authorities and health boards believed they would have to reduce spending on drugs for other types of tumour to pay for the increased use of taxanes. One in three could not find the money to pay for the drugs.

However, Professor Mike Richards, director of the NHS cancer programme, said the survey was "complete rubbish".

"Everybody who should be treated with taxanes is receiving them. We have contacted all the NHS trusts and health authorities in the Cert survey. They have all told us that in fact they are not having any problems."

fields.headline: Grow your own social workers
fields.standfirst: Suffolk council has beaten the social work recruitment crisis by training its own care workers
fields.trailText: Suffolk county council is training its own social workers in house, as a response to a nationwide recruitment crisis.
fields.body:
Social work recruitment is in crisis. With a vacancy rate of around 16% in England who could disagree? Well, maybe Paula Stott. Stott, a training manager for Suffolk county council, thinks that a little lateral thinking is needed. After all, the solution to what seems an intractable problem is sometimes right under your nose.

"There may be a recruitment crisis in terms of new recruits," acknowledges Stott. "But we need to grow our own."

In Suffolk, a homegrown social worker pilot began in spring 1999. The council, with town hall union Unison and Ruskin College, Oxford, set up an inhouse diploma in social work (DipSW) for social care employees who want to become qualified social workers.

Eighteen staff do their usual jobs four days a week. Then, once a week, they attend a county training centre to learn social work theory from council trainers and social work lecturers, including a Ruskin tutor. (Ruskin is responsible for academic standards.) As with full-time diplomas, students undertake a 50-day and an 80-day placement.

The council pays the students' fees and travel costs. Taking into account £78,000 higher education funding council money over three years, the scheme is setting Suffolk back roughly £780 per student per year, excluding cover.

Nitty-gritty

One hundred and fifty staff applied for the inhouse DipSW scheme and 40 were "ideal", according to Stott. "I suspect that it's the same nationally. It's not that people don't want to be social workers but training is not being offered in a way that meets their needs. All these people wanted passionately to be a social worker and they knew the nitty-gritty reality of being a social worker."

Social work students tend to be older than the average undergraduate. And it's tough - if not impossible - to give up your job and go off to study for two years for a DipSW.

Paul Davis, an assessment officer for deaf people and one of the 18 Suffolk students, agrees. "Qualifying as a social worker was really a natural progression from what I'm doing now. I looked into doing it but, quite frankly, I couldn't have undertaken the financial commitment."

Giles Darvill, from the National Institute for Social Work, who is evaluating the course on behalf of Unison and the Central Council for Education and Training in Social Work, says the early signs are good. "The measurable objectives were very good - at least as good as the full-time course."

But he warns that it is not as simple as chopping a full-time course into smaller pieces and serving them up to staff on a day-release basis. "You can't just colonise the workplace with academic courses." The students "have much more social care experience that most full timers" and that should be taken into account. (The partnership is revising the course and considering an Accrediting Prior Experience and Learning (APEL) scheme.)

"It will still be useful to separate off special periods, away from the normal workbase and under the guidance of practice teachers. But it would also be appropriate to use all the students' work experience for study and guidance, linking theory to practice throughout the course, with an extended role for the practice teacher throughout, and a clearer contribution from the line manager to the students learning via supervision," says Darvill.

Souped-up role

fields.headline: Crisis resolution explained
fields.standfirst: Mike Bryant answers your questions about the drive to set up crisis resolution services
fields.trailText: Mike Bryant answers your questions about the drive to set up crisis resolution services
fields.body:
What is crisis resolution?
Crisis resolution means responding rapidly to and supporting adults who are experiencing a severe mental health problem which might lead to admission to a psychiatric hospital. Crisis resolution services offer home care and are available 24 hours a day, seven days a week, as an alternative to hospital treatment.

What is the main aim of a crisis resolution service?
The objective is to help individuals manage and resolve their crisis without going to hospital. If, however, the person presents a severe risk, hospital treatment may be necessary. Crisis resolution services control who can and cannot access hospital beds in order to prevent unnecessary admissions.

Why the interest now?
The NHS plan published in July 2000 called for the creation of 335 crisis resolution teams in England over the next three years to offer an immediate response to mental health crises. £300m has been made available to establish these mental health teams by 2003-2004.

How do people in crisis get help?
Clients can be referred directly to a crisis team by GPs, accident and emergency ward staff, families and friends. Clients who have been treated in the past may also refer themselves. An unusual aspect of crisis resolution is that the service may accept clients from other mental health teams that cannot provide the same level of intensive support.

How do staff help clients?
When called out to see someone, staff - usually a psychiatrist and nurse or social worker - initially assess the factors involved in the crisis. These include housing, money and the client's social situation. A crisis management plan is drawn up. Various interventions will be used to help control the most acute symptoms and reduce the likelihood of relapse. Typically these will involve giving and monitoring the taking of medication along with help with the other issues.

How do crisis teams help to empower service users?
Preventive crisis work involves educating the service user in how to improve and maintain good mental health. This approach involves helping users and their families understand the factors that precipitate mental illness and how they can help themselves before a relapse occurs.

Does crisis resolution work?
Research shows that users prefer crisis services to hospitals and that the crisis services lead to fewer hospital admissions, reduced bed use and shorter admissions when these do occur. There is also a lower level of staff burnout compared with inpatient services. Crisis teams have drastically reduced the use of expensive hospital beds, proving their worth.

fields.headline: A flagship mental health partnership
fields.standfirst: NHS and social care staff have joined forces in Manchester, writes Steve Brown
fields.trailText: NHS and social care staff have joined forces in Manchester, writes Steve Brown.
fields.body:
Suicide rates among young men in Manchester are twice the national average. Psychiatric readmissions are higher than in comparable cities. And the cost of anti-depressant drugs is rising faster than that of any other type of drug prescribed by GPs.

With such problems, the provision of mental health services is vital. Yet the city has long recognised that there has been substantial room for improvement.

The opening in October of a citywide provider of mental health services, the Manchester Mental Health Partnership, is the latest attempt to improve services for some of the city's most vulnerable residents. It aims to eradicate inequalities in services across the city.

The partnership, which brings together NHS sevices and social care services provided by Manchester city council, follows earlier initiatives to improve the coordination and user focus of services, such as the creation of a joint commissioning board and the development of a single specification for mental health services.

All eyes are now on the Manchester partnership, the flagship initiative arising from flexibilities introduced by the Health Act 1999, which aims to remove obstacles to joint work between the NHS and council-run social services. It is far and away the biggest attempt to set up joint provision arrangements.

The new joint provider integrates services previously provided by four NHS trusts and the council's social services department. Its commissioning executive will have a pooled budget of more than £50m.

The journey that began with a consultation exercise in 1999, which confirmed that users were unhappy with current arrangements, has not been easy, particularly as the partnership has broken new ground. The legal agreement that set out the respective functions of the two original partners - the health authority and the city council - has had to be adapted. Since April, three primary care trusts (PCTs) have been established in the city, taking over commissioning responsibilities from the health authority.

This has added to the complexity of the process. One of the aims of the partnership: to ringfence mental health service funds, had to be squared with the PCTs' desires to flex their muscles by spending their budgets in any way they saw fit. A compromise that safeguards investment in mental health services, subject to targets being met, has been reached.

Some issues could be anticipated. On October 1, around 1,500 staff moved to the new body. About 1,200 health employees are now employed by the lead partner, the health authority, while local authority staff have been seconded to the partnership for the time being. Transferring staff have their basic terms and conditions protected by transfer of undertaking (TUPE) regulations, but some of the predecessor trusts had local pay arrangements and the partnership has inherited a wide range of policies on issues such as disciplinary procedures and sick leave. Talks are already under way to standardise terms.

Other problems have been more specific. Agreeing on the partnership's contribution to overhead costs in the trusts that continue to house many of the services has been a challenge. And hopes that the partnership could operate without owning any buildings have been tempered as a result of a clause in the Mental Health Act concerning the detention of patients. Following legal advice, the partnership has, over the summer, been forced to sign formal leases for the relevant buildings.

According to Vanessa Coomber, the partnership's director of human resources and corporate services, the effort has been worthwhile. "It has been hard work, particularly because of the volume of organisational and managerial systems which we had to bring together," she says. "But we've never lost sight of the reason we are doing this. The dissatisfaction among users with the existing service was a tremendous motivation."

The partnership faces annual reviews of its performance. But, with the partnership agreement signed until 2003, it now has two and half years to prove itself.

fields.headline: Effective crisis resolution
fields.standfirst: Setting up a crisis resolution service requires careful planning and consultation, writes Mike Bryant
fields.trailText: Setting up a crisis resolution service requires careful planning and consultation, writes Mike Bryant
fields.body:
Crisis resolution services are set to become a new component within mental health service provision. So how does one set up and run an effective crisis resolution service?

Good planning is the key to ensuring that a crisis service will meet its objectives. Service developers need to start by assessing the local demand for crisis work and questioning assumptions about the need for separate services.

Professor Tom Burns, consultant psychiatrist at the South West London and St George's NHS mental health trust, advocates integrating crisis services within existing mental health teams.

"Crises in mental health are not like heart attacks. They build up over days and weeks - not minutes," says Professor Burns. "We have found being able to respond promptly within the same day is what is needed and requests for immediate response have virtually disappeared. Such a same day response should be well within the capacity of a well functioning community mental health team and offers the added advantage of continuity of care. The patient isn't passed from one group of staff to another."

However if the level of local demand requires a separate crisis team developers should examine how the whole mental health system functions. Too many crisis services are set up as a sticking plaster on top of service infrastructures that are in crisis.

A crisis service steering group should be formed. Membership must include influential service users. The steering group should incorporate the ideas of the stakeholders on whom the success of the crisis service will hinge. Service users should have a substantial influence on service design, objectives and outcomes.

The steering group must address issues common to all crisis services as well as local ones. Common challenges include determining the target population to be served, budgets, the staffing and skills mix, operating hours, liaison with primary care and establishing respite care. Local decisions to be examined might include the catchment area, user needs, service structure, partnerships and service evaluation.

Cuts
The budget will determine the scope of the crisis resolution service. Open All Hours, a report published by the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health in 1997 cited service costs of £481,000 a year for a 14-staff, 24-hour team.

Wider budgetary issues should also be considered to determine the service's viability. Will the crisis service be targeted for cuts in a few years' time?

The team manager should be involved in decisions on the broad operational issues, such as initial and risk assessment strategies, acceptance and exclusion referral criteria and effective client interventions. How will the service address clients with substance and alcohol misuse problems, personality disorders and mental illnesses with a learning disability component?

Staff should reflect the local community and have a wide mix of skills. Training should be provided soon after appointment, emphasising skills in client engagement, initial and risk assessment procedures. Once inducted, staff should be involved in developing operational policies such as the shift hours of the service, emergency guidelines, operational procedures and administration issues in order to "own" policies.

Crisis services should establish access to respite accommodation as American and Australian studies have demonstrated that these can decrease hospital admissions.

Strategies for discharging clients must be decided. After working through the crisis, it is the team's responsibility to ensure activities occur that link clients to support services. Clients should exit crisis services feeling empowered and having learned coping skills for the future.

 Michael Bryant is internet information manager at the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health. Tel: 020-7716 6780.

webTitle: Lionel Joyce: 'I lied to get a job'

fields.headline: 'I lied to get a job'
fields.standfirst: Lionel Joyce concealed his mental illness to get work. Other people should not have to, he argues
fields.trailText: Former NHS trust chief executive Lionel Joyce concealed his metal illness to get to work. Other people should not have to, he argues.
fields.body:
When I joined the NHS in 1973 I lied on my application form. I lied at interview. At my first promotion I lied on the application form and at interview. And I lied at my second promotion.

Only after my third appointment was offered to me, and before accepting, did I see my prospective boss and tell him the truth. I had a history of psychiatric illness.

I have since advised all service users and friends to follow this example. Having been a chief executive for 16 years, I have no doubts about the existence of discrimination. It is very simple. If you tell the truth, that you have been in a psychiatric hospital or had psychiatric treatment, no one is going to presume that you can do a job. Any job.

Only after you have done a job well do they discover that you can do it at all. The discrimination will be for the best of reasons. Employers will tell themselves that these jobs are very stressful and that someone with my history should not be put under that sort of stress.

At the same time, of course, the NHS wants to give the "customer" what the customer wants. It wants to "value" the customer without actually valuing the customer's experience as a useful attribute in the workforce.

Invaluable resource
This causes a major dysfunction in the service. It is estimated that 50% of women of working age will suffer from depression. As the NHS workforce is 70% female, this means that at least 35% of our workforce will be affected. In the case of of the 30% of the workforce made up of men, 25% of those suffer from depression. This means an additional 7.5% needs to be added to the female 35% to make a total of 42.5%.

This invaluable resource of workers with personal experience of mental health problems is buried. The professional press is not swamped with advertisements for "psychiatrists, preferably with experience as a user" or "psychologists with personal experience of treatment" or "nurses with a psychiatric history". Nor does the NHS set up groups for improving patient services, inviting "staff with experience of services to help us improve our performance".

My experience is that this does not happen because discrimination is endemic. The stereotype of a person who suffers mental illness as somebody who in other respects is incapable is deeply ingrained. The middle-aged, white male still rules supreme in Richmond House, in the NHS Executive, in most regional offices and, above all, in the true culture carriers of the NHS, the deans of medical schools and the chief executives of teaching trusts - exclusively white and male.

With the burden of white manhood comes the requirement for mental wellness. So, just as those individuals have to keep their anxieties, their phobias, and their depressions to themselves, so, equally, the service has to keep the illness of its staff hidden and denied.

Whispering campaigns
But it could be different. If we worked on the basis that most staff are likely to have an illness or disability during their working career, our approach would not be passive and reactive (with sick leave and retirement on the grounds of ill health) but proactive. The NHS would say to its staff: "When you become ill, we will build in support and then use your experience as part of your personal profile to help us improve our services."

Whispering campaigns about psychiatrists, psychologists or chief executives being unfit to do their jobs, if they have suffered from mental illness, would be replaced by the view that this is an opportunity for the service to learn about its strengths and weaknesses from personnel who now understand both sides.

We have an opportunity to rethink our approach and put the consumer experience at the heart of the service, firstly through its staff and then by reaching out to patients.

 Lionel Joyce was until recently chief executive of Newcastle City Health NHS trust. He has been at the forefront of major regional health intitiatives and played a leading role in the development of the mental health awards which reward good practice in mental health services.

fields.headline: Hat Trick in US bonanza
fields.trailText: 8.30pm:he US version of Whose Line Is It Anyway? has been recommissioned by ABC, in a deal that will earn Hat Trick Productions millions of pounds.
fields.body:
The US version of Whose Line Is It Anyway? has been recommissioned by ABC, in a deal that will earn Hat Trick Productions millions of pounds.

ABC has ordered a further 66 new episodes of the show, Whose Line, with a standard licence for a single repeat.

The US network has also bought additional eight repeats of each instalment of the show, which will take Hat Trick's earnings from the deal into the seven figure bracket. Getting a network show recommissioned for such a long run in the ultra competitive US market is a major coup for Hat Trick.

The only other UK producer to have enjoyed similar success in recent times is Celador Productions with Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, which also goes out on ABC.

The broadcaster is expected to use repeats of Whose Line, which is relatively cheap to produce compared to sitcoms and drama, at short notice to plug gaps left by cancelled series.

ABC, like all the US networks, is also stockpiling non-scripted programming in case a threatened strike by Hollywood actors and writers takes place next year.

US comedian Drew Carey takes the Clive Anderson role of host in the US version of Whose Line; while Ryan Stiles, a stalwart panellist on the UK show, is also a regular on the American incarnation.

Hat Trick joint managing director Denise O'Donoghue said that unusually for a US production, Whose Line did not require deficit funding. So any extra revenue from repeats is clear profit.

Ms O'Donoghue added: "This is great for us, because it acts as a calling in terms of selling other formats into the US."

Hat Trick co-produces Whose Line with Warner Bros, as part of an output deal through which the two partners are also developing a number of other formats for the American market.

Hat Trick joint managing director Denise O'Donoghue said that unusually for a US production, Whose Line did not require deficit funding. So any extra revenue from repeats is clear profit. Ms O'Donoghue added: "This is great for us, because it acts as a calling in terms of selling other formats into the US." Hat Trick co-produces Whose Line with Warner Bros, as part of an output deal through which the two partners are also developing a number of other formats for the American market.

fields.headline: Future Network woos Sutcliffe
fields.trailText: 8am: Andy Sutcliffe, a reluctant star of a BBC soap about the publishing industry, has been approached by Future Network for a senior publishing role. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Andy Sutcliffe, a reluctant star of a BBC fly-on-the-wall soap about the publishing industry, has been approached by the computer magazine publisher Future Network for an unspecified senior publishing role.

Mr Sutcliffe, who came to national attention when he featured in the Robert Thirkell documentary Trouble Between the Covers about Cabal and its chief executive Sally O'Sullivan.

Mr Sutcliffe has confirmed he has had talks with Future's managing director, Mike Frey.

"I have had ongoing discussions with Mike over a long period of time about the possibility of working at Future," said Mr Sutcliffe, but he refused to be more specific about where he would fit into the company's structure.

Future managing director Mike Frey was unavailable for comment.

Mr Sutcliffe is currently working at John Brown Publishing on a freelance consultancy basis. He was previously managing director of Cabal but left earlier this year, shortly after the programme was screened, amid speculation that he was angry about late payments to freelancers.

Insiders have speculated that Mr Sutcliffe's track record - seven years at IPC where he was group editor for music and sports after being editor of cycling weekly - would put him in a good position for an editorial position within the sport and entertainment division.

Future Network last month announced plans to invest £33m in new launches, including seven online ventures. The company posted a 25% increase in pre-tax profits to 14.7m fror the six months to the end of June.

Future Network has grown rapidly over the past year, adding 17 new magazines to its portfolio.

webTitle: Blu presses for compensation from Italian government

fields.headline: Blu presses for compensation from Italian government
fields.trailText: 8am:The Italian mobile phone farce continues with BT-backed Blu demanding government compensation, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The great Italian mobile phone farce continued yesterday, with BT-backed Blu demanding compensation from the government.

The telecoms company hit the headlines last month after abruptly withdrawing from the Italian phone auction, leaving the government with a shortfall of up to £8bn.

Blu claims its formal exclusion from the auction following the withdrawal damaged the company's image and undermined relations with its clients.

The company is asking for damages of at least $44.28m (£31m) and has made further complaints about the government's request to keep Blu's E2.1bn (£1.26bn) deposit.

Under the auction rules, Blu had to forego its stake if it was thrown out of the bidding process.

The much-anticipated bidding battle ended on the third day, after shareholder disagreements led to Blu's withdrawal.

Some stakeholders turned on BT afterwards, arguing that the company should have increased its 20% holding to finance a bid.

Blu's departure from the bidding table reduced the Italian government's windfall to £12bn, as it left five bidders for five licences.

fields.headline: Making courses that work harder
fields.standfirst: To survive, language trainers must adapt quickly to corporate trends, says Andy Hewitson of Siemens
fields.trailText: To survive, language trainers must adapt quickly to corporate trends, says Andy Hewitson of Siemens
fields.body:
Siemens, the once-slumbering German electrical engineering and electronics giant, has re-engineered itself to become a global hi-tech player, respected by international fund managers, some of whom were initially sceptical about its new image. Top executives at the company have been "walking the talk", pushing through tough measures in an economic environment that has been described by some observers as stiflingly consensus-oriented. In the past year the share price has more than doubled, and next year Siemens will be listed on the New York stock exchange.

"So what?" you may ask. How does this affect language trainers? Business fads come and go, share prices rise and fall, but we go on as the demand for English continues to climb. The fact is that corporate language training in Germany has changed beyond recognition in the past 15 years. Most companies outsource or have axed what are sometimes described as non-core training programmes, leading to a significant drop in the number of full-time positions in language training. The few people who survive have to justify their existence and negotiate with global procurement managers who are only too willing to sign a deal with the language school around the corner to keep costs down.

The key to survival for us at Siemens has been to realign language and inter-cultural training with strategic company objectives, to be seen as indispensable in qualifying staff to function more effectively in jobs that have become increasingly international.

How then do you go about identifying topics that are seen as strategically important? Our approach has been to take a close look at the executive training programmes that middle and senior managers are expected, or sometimes required, to undertake. Scrutinising programmes and talking with the training managers responsible for them is the first step; the next is to become directly involved in these programmes.

Only by offering language and inter-cultural training that focuses on core management issues will language trainers finally become accepted as equal partners in the area of strategic training. Full-time members of staff, fully integrated in company training matters, have a head start over freelance trainers who do not have such ready access to the necessary sources of information. This is one of the most cogent arguments in favour of recruiting full-time staff, because they should be in a much better position to identify trends within the company and make sure they are reflected in training programmes.

Out of these considerations we developed our nine-day residential Language Plus seminar, which is run in cooperation with a business school in England. We see this as a good example of a possible new direction for corporate language training at post-intermediate level.

An increasing number of learners at this level have, for various reasons, become impatient with more conventional programmes. One reason is the pressure of time. Modern managers have trouble keeping up with the pace of change. If in a language course they learn about topics that directly impinge on their work they feel they are getting more added value.

The business topics in our programme are EVA (Economic Value Added), the Balanced Scorecard, Change Management, International Accounting Practices with specific reference to United States GAAP and Scenario Planning. In addition we run workshops on Creativity and Intercultural Issues in modern business practice. There is also a strong focus on presentation skills, social English and effective language learning strategies.

To prepare our students for the workshops with business school lecturers we have devised a wide range of study and practice activities focusing on high-frequency language connected with the topic. Before coming to the seminar participants are required to do preparatory reading and listening activities related to the various topics. They also have to indicate beforehand which topic they would feel most confident giving a talk on.

The sessions run by the business school are designed as hands-on workshops where, for example, students devise and present a future scenario plan for their line of business, after receiving input on the topic.

The role of the language trainer during these sessions is to act as consultant, helping out when there are breakdowns in communication, taking notes for feedback sessions. Students are also encouraged to take language notes, to observe and evaluate different presentation styles, to give critical feedback to the presenters. Trainers are expected to know their stuff, but inevitably they cannot always answer students' highly technical questions. Here the role of the trainer is to help to formulate the questions that are then put to the experts the following day. The programme is rounded off with company visits, evenings with MBA students, and the inevitable pub outings socialising with trainers and guest speakers.

The overwhelming response from our students is that we should be offering more seminars like this that incorporate a wider range of skills. Having participated in Language And our managers return to their desks not only feeling more confident about their language skills but also better informed about key issues affecting their work lives, and perhaps also with new perspectives on their roles as managers.

 Andy Hewitson is head of English language training at Siemens. He will be one of the presenters at the 13th International Association of English Language Teaching's Business English Special Interest Group International Conference at Siemens' training centre in Munich, Germany, from November 17-19. More information about the event is available on www.besig.org

fields.headline: ELT Diary
fields.trailText: Chains linked up
fields.body:
Chains linked up

David Jones, a former executive of Swedish education giant EF, has snapped up two loss-making language school chains, Aspect and International Language Academies (ILA), with $25m backing from Warburg Pincus, the private equity investment firm. Jones acquired the ILA chain, along with its estimated $2.7m liabilities, from the British group Nord Anglia Education for $150,000 in August. This month he bought Aspect for $22m, a third of the price its US owners, Sylvan Learning Systems, paid for the chain in 1998. Aspect has 24 schools in North America, Britain, Ireland, and Australia, while ILA has nine schools in the UK, Australia and New Zealand.

HK backdown

The Hong Kong government has postponed its benchmark tests for English teachers after a six-month campaign by teachers, who branded them "insulting". The government had proposed that 14,000 English language teachers would have to meet minimum language standards by 2005, but the tests, which were to have begun this month, have been postponed till March, and new teachers will be given two years to reach the standard.

Maori lessons

A call to make the Maori language compulsory in New Zealand's schools, which has been endorsed by the main primary teachers' union, has been criticised by educationists as unworkable. The union also supported a recommendation that all teachers should be fluent in Maori. However, the Maori Language Commission said it did not support promoting the language through compulsion.

Korea recruitment

South Korea will more than double recruitment of native English teachers at middle and high schools next year, the education ministry has announced. A total of 392 native speakers will be recruited to train local teachers under the government's English Programme in Korea, which employed 179 teachers last year.

Email: max.delotbiniere@theguardian.com

webTitle: Why we were wrong about bilingual education

fields.headline: Why we were wrong about bilingual education
fields.standfirst: English-only teaching is serving California's Spanish-speaking students better, argues Ken Noonan
fields.trailText: English-only teaching is serving California's Spanish-speaking students better, argues Ken Noonan
fields.body:
For 30 years I worked hard to promote bilingual education as the best way for Spanish-speaking children in California's schools to become academically successful. Two years ago I campaigned against California's Proposition 227, the ballot to eliminate bilingual education, because I believed that it was going to harm Spanish-speaking students. I was certain that students would be confused in English-only instruction and would be lost in the shuffle. I now realise I was wrong.

In June 1998, 61% of California's voters approved 227, which requires that all students be taught "overwhelmingly" in English, and that children who are not proficient in English be taught for at least one year in a structured English-immersion classroom before being assigned to a mainstream class.

Two months later we began the school year with all classes taught in English. I was nervous, certain that it was going to be a disaster. Since then, however, I've watched recent immigrant children in my district learn to speak and read English faster than I had ever thought possible. As a result I've become convinced that English immersion, not traditional bilingual education, is the path to academic success for children who arrive in our classrooms unable to learn in English.

Even before 227 I had begun to question the effectiveness of traditional bilingual education, in which limited speakers of English are assigned to a class where they learn to speak, read and write in their home language first. In Oceanside, which is 55km north of San Diego, that language is Spanish. Until 1998 a student would remain in Spanish instruction for up to four years. Only after being designated fluent in English would a child's learning in English begin in earnest.

As a former bilingual teacher, administrator and co-founder of the California Association of Bilingual Educators, I had come to believe that many students remained too long in classes conducted in Spanish, and that as a result they lost ground in developing their English language skills. I believe that this creates a learning gap that is seldom closed.

On my recommendation the Oceanside School Board adopted a bilingual programme reform that would have moved most students from Spanish to English within three years. But before we could implement that change Proposition 227 was passed. At first I resisted. I tried without success to find some way to preserve bilingual instruction. In the end we had no choice but to implement 227 fully and immediately. Reluctantly I made preparations.

At the end of the first year I was amazed by the results. State tests showed dramatic academic gains for Spanish-speaking students in reading and writing - especially in the early grades, where we had reduced class size to 20 or fewer students and implemented phonics reading instruction. Those changes seemed to have made a difference. But Proposition 227 has been the catalyst for the dramatic changes in student achievement. Without it we would have been teaching these students in Spanish; they would certainly have performed poorly on the state tests, which are administered in English. And we never would have seen how quickly and how early they could learn to read English.

Consider this: two years ago limited-English second-graders in Oceanside scored at the 13th percentile on a scale of 100. This year, at the same grade, limited-English students scored at the 32nd percentile. The significant difference, I believe, is that these students had been taught only in English.

Sceptics claim that Oceanside's scores are so low that they offer scant proof that English immersion works better than bilingual instruction. Oceanside, with 22,000 students in 24 schools, was the lowest-scoring school district in San Diego County for many years. But that is no longer true. The test results of Spanish-speaking students in other districts have risen as well, but at the primary level no district has seen increases as dramatic as Oceanside's.

I realise now I was wrong in believing that teaching limited-English students to read first in Spanish and later, sometimes much later, in English, would deliver the academic success that bilingual education promised. In fact I have come to believe that transferring limited-English students to English well after their peers puts those students at an academic disadvantage when it comes to choosing the most challenging courses in high school and college.

Now I am convinced that English immersion does work, and that it should begin on a student's first day of school. It may also be able to reduce or eliminate that gap in achievement. Now I believe that using all of the resources of public education to move these students into the English-speaking mainstream early and quickly is far more important than my former romantic notions that preserving the child's home language should be the ultimate goal of our schools. Washington Post

 Ken Noonan is superintendent of schools in Oceanside, California

webTitle: Australia limits ELT to deter illegal immigration

fields.headline: Australia limits ELT to deter illegal immigration
fields.trailText: Last month Australia's immigration and multicultural affairs minister, Philip Ruddock, began what his office has described as a year-long global campaign to reform the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and redefine the 50-year-old Refugee Convention
fields.body:
Last month Australia's immigration and multicultural affairs minister, Philip Ruddock, began what his office has described as a year-long global campaign to reform the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and redefine the 50-year-old Refugee Convention, which it argues is not appropriate for 21st-century problems of migration and international conflict. The move comes in the wake of international criticism of Australia's treatment of refugees and alarm at the sharp increase in illegal people-smuggling.

Refugee support groups and organisations working in the Adult English Migrant Programme (AMEP) are worried that the government's increasingly hardline approach may harm the country's internationally respected commitment to social and educational support for immigrants and asylum seekers.

At the heart of Australia's policy shift is the immigration department's belief that its generous protection visa arrangements are being abused by people-smuggling rackets. To combat this the department declared that from October last year unauthorised arrivals in Australia found to be refugees would only be issued with three-year temporary protection visas (TPVs). The TPVs enable asylum seekers to move into the general community and work. They are entitled to access health services and in some cases special social security benefits. But they are not eligible for housing assistance or AMEP classes.

"The objective of limiting benefits including English language tuition in the community was to send a very clear signal that if you came lawfully you would be welcomed, if you came unlawfully, we will honour our obligations, but you are less welcome," said Mr Ruddock. English language classes are provided in refugee detention centres, but refugee workers say the reality inside for many people anxiously awaiting their visa status is such that their teachers experience great difficulty in attracting and maintaining interest in classes.

AMEP, which celebrated its 50th anniversary last year, delivers English language tuition to 30,000 eligible new arrivals. Among them are 12,000 people who migrate to Australia each year under the humanitarian and refugee programme. But under the immigration department's new rules no extra money will be provided to fund places to meet increased demand. As a result, according to the government's own estimates, 4,000 AMEP-eligible clients will miss out on English classes this year.

However, Mr Ruddock is cautiously optimistic that arrivals are declining. "Hopefully the problems we've experienced will [be ameliorated by] the range of measures we've put in place," he said. "There appears to be a 75% reduction in the number of unlawful arrivals, and that should be reflected in TPV grants in the future. We're looking at about 300 or so illegal arrivals in the first quarter of this year, and that would suggest that the total for the year could be 1,000, if those figures hold."

Yet an analysis of the department's figures indicates that unauthorised arrivals by boat for the first three months of the year totalled 903, all of whom were detained. Don Plimer, general manager of one of Australia's largest AMEP providers, is blunt in his assessment of the government's policy. "The TPVs will be an ongoing issue as a means of pressurising people not to come in boats, and the total number of AMEP humanitarian clients will decrease. The government is signalling that it wants the TPVs to go home," he said

"There appears to be a 75% reduction in the number of unlawful arrivals, and that should be reflected in TPV grants in the future. We're looking at about 300 or so illegal arrivals in the first quarter of this year, and that would suggest that the total for the year could be 1,000, if those figures hold." Yet an analysis of the department's figures indicates that unauthorised arrivals by boat for the first three months of the year totalled 903, all of whom were detained. Don Plimer, general manager of one of Australia's largest AMEP providers, is blunt in his assessment of the government's policy. "The TPVs will be an ongoing issue as a means of pressurising people not to come in boats, and the total number of AMEP humanitarian clients will decrease. The government is signalling that it wants the TPVs to go home," he said

fields.headline: Teacher power grows in Bangladesh
fields.standfirst: Local ownership proves that teachers can influence ministers, says Tom Hunter
fields.trailText: Local ownership proves that teachers can influence ministers, says Tom Hunter
fields.body:
Since 1998 the English Language Teaching Improvement Project (ELTIP) has been working in Bangladesh to expand the country's communicative English language teaching syllabus, through textbook and examination reform and in-service teacher training (Inset). Jointly funded by the Bangladeshi and British governments, providing $1.6m and $4.3m respectively, ELTIP has seven British consultants working with about 50 local trainers and support staff.

Six months ago project staff were pessimistic about the future of the unique training programmes developed by ELTIP. A remote central government appeared uninterested in the project, and there was little expectation that it would achieve its target of sustainability after 2001, when funding runs out. Today the future of the project's work looks much brighter. The Bangladeshi education ministry has agreed to use it as a model for future Inset training, and the project's regional English language specialists will be employed by the ministry as ELT trainers. So why are ministers now so keen to appropriate a project which, like many other donor-sponsored initiatives, could easily have been shunted into obscurity? The answer lies in the strong "ownership" policy that ELTIP has promoted at grassroots level.

At the centre of this policy is the formation of clusters of schools to procure ELT training via district education officers. Before ELTIP provides training the three or four schools in each cluster must agree on certain conditions: the head teachers must promise full support for follow-up work, they must allow teachers to go to refresher courses, and they must let them form discussion and support groups.

The result has been to involve head teachers and district officers directly in the management of staff development. At the Residential Model college in Dhaka the principal, Colonel Kaiser, like many other head teachers, is taking the initiative in training. He has organised more workshop training for his teachers and other schools in the cluster.

Professor Sawkat Ali, head of Lamatia Government Girls' School in Dhaka, talks of a "revolution" in teaching methods as a result of the training. "The pupils actually like the lessons," he said. Meanwhile teachers elsewhere are requesting workshops on specific skills such as vocabulary teaching, and have set up informal gatherings that range from women's discussion groups to film nights.

As the project has gained momentum, the enthusiasm from teachers has contrasted with a lack of interest in government circles. ELTIP staff, who have found it difficult to engage with ministry officials from the outset, believe that the rapid growth of the project took the government by surprise. In an environment where progress is usually slow, staff found that officials had not started to implement proper recruitment procedures and financial practices.

The project also had to overcome the underlying problem of the country's unresolved language policy. In the past language has been literally a matter of life and death. The 1971 war of independence with Pakistan, in which 3m Bengali speakers died, is also referred to as "the language war". State planners take a cautious approach to language policy, and there is an unresolved debate about what role English should have, and its place in the syllabus. Over the past five months, however, government officials have undergone a change in attitude towards ELTIP and the ELT curriculum, thanks to a ministerial review of the project in May. The review, ordered by the education minister partly as a result of pressure to extend the project, was led by Sirajul Haq Talukder, the ministry's senior assistant chief of planning.

"I have seen with my own eyes and listened to the evidence of teachers, head teachers and district officers," he said after his tour of remote areas to meet stakeholders in the project. His list of recommendations outlines what action must be taken to support the project officially and to integrate its structure into ministry training.

The review has also galvanised government officials into finding ways to "own" the activities of the project, and officials are liaising closely with project staff to map out recruitment and budgeting. This change in fortunes for ELTIP is proof that in any democracy grassroots opinion is a powerful tool for change. In centralised and "paternal" government organisations the views of subordinates have currency.

In a volatile society such as Bangladesh, where political dissent, demonstrations and national strikes are a way of life, no official can ignore these intense feelings. The lesson from ELTIP is that the development of a strong grassroots sense of ownership in a project is at least as important as developing "official" relationships - perhaps even more important.

 Tom Hunter is ELTIP team leader in Bangladesh

fields.headline: Tobacco advertising: your questions answered
fields.standfirst: Banning tobacco ads is seen as a vital weapon in the war against smoking
fields.trailText: Your questions on tobacco advertising answered
fields.body:
Why is the Government so anti-tobacco?
Smoking is the UK's biggest cause of preventable illness and early death - 120,000 people a year die from smoking every year. Hundreds more die from passive smoking. Treating smoking-related diseases costs the NHS £1.7bn a year. Banning tobacco advertising is one of several weapons ministers intend to use in their war on smoking.

What is the tobacco advertising ban?
The European Union directive on tobacco advertising requires EU member states to ban all "commercial communication and sponsorship whose aim or effect is to promote tobacco products". This would see the gradual phasing out, within the next eight years, of all tobacco advertising and promotion and sponsorship of events (such as, for example, Formula One motor racing).

How will a ban on tobacco advertising help?
Ministers believe tobacco advertising and sponsorship encourages people, especially children, to smoke and makes it socially acceptable. It estimates that a ban would reduce tobacco-related deaths by 2.5% a year, equivalent to 3,000 people. There is some evidence that bans work. Norway banned tobacco advertising in 1975, and according to Action on Smoking and Health, the "great majority of a 9% reduction in consumption was attributed to the advertising ban".

Aren't there controls on advertising already?
Tobacco marketing controls in the UK have evolved since 1965 when cigarette advertising was banned from TV. In 1990 adverts for all tobacco products were barred from TV, cinema and radio. Voluntary agreements between the industry and the government control press, poster and other types of promotion by laying down guidelines - such as a restriction on tobacco posters appearing within 200m of school entrances. The same agreement requires all advertisements for tobacco to carry a health warning.

Have the voluntary agreements worked?
A report by the House of Commons health select committee published in June 2000 concluded that voluntary agreements "have served the industry well and the public badly". The report said: "Our impression is that the purpose of the rules in discouraging consumption and youth smoking has often been ignored by the advertising agencies who seem to pay attention solely to the letter rather than the spirit of the restrictions."

What is the tobacco industry view?
The industry believes that tobacco advertising does not reduce smoking or prevent underage smoking but merely encourages existing smokers to maintain or switch brands. A ban therefore limits fair competition among companies for smokers' custom, limits companies' freedom to go about their "lawful business", and imposes "censorship of commercial free speech".

fields.headline: Health and social care partnerships made easier
fields.standfirst: The Health Act 1999 has major implications for joint working between health and social services
fields.trailText: Steve Brown reports on the Health Act 1999 and its implications for joint working between health and social services
fields.body:
What is it?
The Health Act 1999 came into force in April 2000. It includes the latest attempt to pull down the "Berlin Wall" that divides health services funded and provided by the NHS from social services run by local councils.

What is the point of the Act?
The distinction between health and social care is often unclear to service users, who complain of being pushed from pillar to post in sorting out different parts of their care package. There is confusion over who does what. If a client is given a bath is it a "health" bath or a "social" bath? (If a health care assistant is giving it, then it is probably a health bath; a social care assistant, then it is a social bath. But as far as the bathed client is concerned, it is still a bath, although they may have to pay a means-related fee for a social bath while a bath provided by the NHS is free.) These types of artificial boundaries can lead to a lack of continuity of care and funding disparities. Another classic problem arises where NHS beds are "blocked" by people who no longer need hospital care but whose social care packages have yet to be organised because of social service funding problems.

What exactly does the legislation change?
Joint working is not new. But new "flexibilities" have been introduced to remove perceived obstacles. These include allowing health bodies and local authorities to:
 set up pooled budgets;
 delegate functions, by nominating a lead commissioner or integrating provision; and
 transfer funds between bodies.

Which services are involved?
There are very few restrictions. But the focus has so far been on older people, people with learning difficulties (or learning disabilities), children or mental health.

What will it change?
Services should become far more co-ordinated and designed around users. There will also be cost savings. For instance, keeping an elderly person in hospital can cost more money than the more appropriate package of social care needed to allow the patient to be discharged. With pooled budgets, funds will no longer be tagged as belonging to health or social services, and managers will be able to take more sensible, holistic decisions. One partnership in the pipeline could see health funds used to support the development of cycle paths to meet accident and heart disease prevention objectives.

How are things going?
By October 2000, only 26 projects had been registered with the Department of Health's joint health and social care unit. The word is that the partnerships are proving difficult to get off the ground.

What are the problems?
According to the health department, there are no outstanding legal obstacles to joint working arrangements, but there are still reports of council lawyers turning down proposals. Suspicions remain between health and social care organisations. Health service non-executives and local councillors are concerned about losing control over major parts of their budgets and, in particular, about audit and governance arrangements.

How are these problems being dealt with?
The health department accepts that joining major strategic services was never going to be easy but it is adamant the concerns are a by-product of risk-averse solicitors' vivid imaginations and conservative attitudes to change. It points to the Manchester mental health partnership, the country's largest example of joint provision with a budget of £50m, as proof the issues can be worked through. According to Carole Bell, a member of the department's joint unit: "No further major statutory changes are needed to make joint working a reality." On the governance side, the solution seems to be meticulous attention to detail up front. In North Yorkshire, the health authority and county council have produced an accountability framework document that could be applied to most projects. It lays out procedures that will apply to auditing and accounting and tackles the partners' major concerns, such as how underspending and overspending will be dealt with.

Are health and social care budgetary timetables compatible?
No. Councils must finish drawing up their budgets by the end of March, while health authorities and trusts have no such duty to complete their service agreements by a set date. But the health department says the budgets should not be seen as ringfenced and, as long as mechanisms are agreed for dealing with pressures during a single financial year, there should be no problems.

Aren't there problems with "coterminosity"?
Actually, it is the lack of shared geographical boundaries (coterminosity) that is the problem. Local authority and health authority boundaries are frequently different. The problem is even more acute at the primary care trust level. But it is unlikely to lead to boundaries being redrawn. Instead, local agreements should be drawn up, perhaps involving the transfer of funds between neighbouring authorities to cover the population involved.

How long before these partnerships become widespread?
Councils and health bodies will not be allowed to drag their feet. The government has already indicated in its NHS plan that use of the new powers will become compulsory.

fields.headline: The NHS cancer plan targets
fields.standfirst: The NHS cancer plan commits the government to a series of deadlines for improving care
fields.trailText: The NHS cancer plan commits the government to a series of deadlines for improving care
fields.body:
The NHS cancer plan promises action on: preventive work to reduce risk; earlier detection; improved community support for sufferers; faster access to treatment; national standards of treatment; improved palliative care; and a strengthened research base.

Performance targets include a maximum one-month wait:
 from urgent GP referral to treatment for children's and testicular cancers and acute leukaemia by 2001
 from diagnosis to treatment for breast cancer by 2001
 from diagnosis to treatment for all cancers by 2005

There will be a maximum two-month wait:

 from urgent GP referral to treatment for breast cancer by 2002
 from urgent GP referral to treatment for all cancers by 2005

Other new measures include:

 a target to reduce smoking rates among manual workers from 32% in 1998 to 26% by 2010
 £50m more investment and additional Lottery cash for palliative care and hospices

fields.headline: Brown's green gambit
fields.standfirst:
£2bn package of reduced road and clean fuel taxes fails to head off truckers

Special report: the Budget
Special report: the petrol war
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday sought to appease angry protests by hauliers, farmers and motorists with a £2bn package of cuts in road taxes and fuel.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday sought to appease angry protests by hauliers, farmers and motorists with a £2bn package of cuts in road taxes and fuel.

The self-styled people's fuel lobby said it planned to go ahead with its march on London, but Mr Brown's efforts to head off an early resumption of September's protests clearly drove a wedge among the drivers' ranks, with renewed pressure on them to call off their campaign.

The chancellor appeared to have bought the government a significant breathing space with his pre-Budget package that would cut hauliers' costs by the equivalent of 8p a litre and those of motorists by 4p from March.

Mr Brown, who froze fuel duty last year, said the freeze would continue in his next Budget - against an inflation-driven 1.5p rise - and for a further year if oil prices remained high. The freeze applies to the "red" diesel used by farmers.

The duty on ultra low sulphur petrol will be cut by a further 2p a litre in the next budget, bringing the total to 3p - with the same cut now to be made in the same form of diesel. There will be a 2p cut in duty on lead replacement petrol in this £1bn package.

Drivers of cars such as the Ford Escort, VW Polo and Honda Civic will pay £100 for their annual road tax compared with the current £155. The chancellor extended the lower duty to cars between 1200cc and 1500cc.

Mr Brown hopes that these measures will peel off motorists from hauliers, who initially wanted a 26.2p cut in the price of a litre of diesel.

Several leading protesters among the hauliers who blockaded oil refineries in September dismissed the concessions as mere tokens, while others welcomed them or said they needed more time to consider a complex package.

David Handley, chairman of the people's fuel lobby, which led the revolt in September, said the planned day of disruption would go ahead. "We will be in London on the 14th. The protest goes ahead ... by the time this gets implemented we will go out of business."

Even the official lobbies, the road hauliers association and the freight transport association, split apart, with the RHA saying it needed instant relief and the FTA acknowledging that the government had listened to its pleas.

Mr Brown set out a £750m package for hauliers which included a 50% cut in vehicle excise duty for lorries worth up to £4,000 for each vehicle and the reduction of the current 100 rates or bands to just seven from his March budget.

The chancellor said this would cost £300m a year while it would cost an extra £265m to rebate vehicle excise duty fees for this financial year, with full payments due by the end of January.

But he made plain these were consultative proposals which would, if implemented, save the owners of 250,000 lorries £2,000 and an average £1,750 per trucker for the whole industry. The package, Mr Brown claims, is worth 3p a litre or the level of the cut in duty promised by the opposition.

The chancellor held out the prospect of a "Britidisc" or vignette for foreign hauliers using UK roads to pay towards the upkeep of the country's roads - from which British truckers would be exempt.

But ministers said the new scheme could not be implemented before 2002 and would require careful consultation with the European commission. They also left unsaid how much the vignette - widely estimated at £1,000 to £1,500 - would cost.

The government also offered a £100m "ring-fenced" fund to encourage hauliers to switch to newer, cleaner lorries - a "scrappage" allowance to help the owner-drivers adapt to computerised logistics and make them more competitive.

fields.headline: Brown attempts to woo greens and motorists
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Special report: the petrol war
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government yesterday courted the votes of motorists and environmentalists with a £1.5bn package of measures to encourage drivers to switch to greener fuels and cut the cost of motoring.
fields.body:
The government yesterday courted the votes of motorists and environmentalists with a £1.5bn package of measures to encourage drivers to switch to greener fuels and cut the cost of motoring.

The duty on both ultra-low sulphur petrol and diesel will be cut by 3p a litre from the next Budget while existing duties for all forms of fuel will be frozen at their current levels. They would have gone up 1.5p a litre in March.

A further 5.4m car owners will pay £55 a year less for their vehicle excise duty as the chancellor Gordon Brown will extend the £100 fee to all cars under 1500cc - backdated to this month.

But the chancellor's efforts to please Escort Man and Polo Woman as well as the green lobby came with a sting in the tail - the cuts in duty on greener petrol depend on the oil companies making it available.

So far ultra-low sulphur petrol can be bought at just 800 of Britain's 12,500 forecourts, including 600 in Scotland.

But the chancellor said the switch to the same form of diesel had been achieved in two years - and the oil companies, led by Shell, said it would be available nationwide by the spring.

But the AA, which welcomed the overall package, said it was not convinced that the industry would be able to produce enough ultra-low sulphur petrol.

The chancellor said his measures were worth £1.5bn to motorists - equivalent to a 4p cut in duty in real terms or 1p more than that offered so far by the Conservatives.

John Dawson, AA policy director, said Mr Brown was "returning much of the £3bn in windfall tax receipts that he has available from higher than expected oil prices."

Michael Meacher, environment minister, said the 10p a litre rise in the price of oil in the past two years had "done our environmental work for us" while the overall package would benefit poorer and rural people.

Mr Brown sought further to enhance his green credentials by offering "major" cuts in duty in his next budget for alternative fuels such as diesel made from oil seed rape or hybrid cars using hydrogen-powered fuel cells.

Drivers who take their colleagues to work or on company business will be repaid 2p a mile for every passenger they carry while smaller works buses will qualify for tax exemptions.

Even cyclists benefit, with VAT for helmets abolished and the mileage rate for bikes used on business trips raised from 12p to 20p a mile.

Car drivers should enjoy a uniform mileage rate, irrespective of the size of car, from 2002.

But several green lobby groups regretted the freezing of petrol/diesel prices. Mark Crawford, chief economist with the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, said he believed that the measures would do nothing to combat climate change.

What is Ultra-low sulphur fuel?

Ultra-low sulphur petrol (ULSP) could soon outsell standard unleaded thanks to yesterday's tax cut.

It can be used in any car that takes unleaded and produces less sulphur dioxide. It helps to prolong the life and efficiency of catalytic converters, which reduce carbon dioxide, hydrocarbon and nitrogen oxide emissions. It claims to enable manufacturers to increase the fuel efficiency of cars. Fewer than 1,000 of the 12,500 petrol retailers across Britain stock ULSP at present.

fields.headline: Protest gets lost in detail
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Special report: the petrol war
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The plan was that farmers, hauliers and protesters from across the country would gather in a small conference room in the Quality Hotel, Walsall, just off Junction 10 of the M6. They would be there to listen to Gordon Brown's statement.
fields.body:
The plan was that farmers, hauliers and protesters from across the country would gather in a small conference room in the Quality Hotel, Walsall, just off Junction 10 of the M6. They would be there to listen to Gordon Brown's statement.

There was to be a live video link with David Handley, chairman of the People's Fuel Lobby, who was "in Whitehall".

In fact, there was no video link and there were very few protesters from across the country. It was said the weather had put them off.

Before the announcement, there was confusion over what would happen if they liked what Mr Brown had to offer. When the statement came, there was even more confusion. The faces, once so hard on the picket line, were puzzled.

How did he work out that 8p total cut? How could he cut tax on fuel that people could not even buy on a garage forecourt? What good would be the suspension of the road fund licence on tractors to the farming community?

When he had finished, Mark Francis, deputy chairman of the PFL and a haulier from north Wales, whispered: "It's not enough."

The chancellor moved on to pensions and the television was switched off.

Mr Francis, aware that the audience in the room was thin but the television audience could be large, said: "I appeal to everybody in the country to remain calm, to stop and think about the announcement. Mr Brown seems to offer many tokens and concessions in all sorts of areas.

"Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be an immediate concession. He has offered a reduction in fuel that isn't presently available.

"I feel they have given some ground. We certainly need a little bit more time to discuss and think about what he said. Please don't start rushing back [to the barricades]."

The slow procession of lorries from Jarrow and the rally in Hyde Park would go ahead.

Elsewhere, David Bromley, joint boss with his wife Joyce of Hill Top Farm Transport in Stalybridge, Greater Manchester, stayed silent and motionless as he watched Mr Brown on a huge TV set.

But when the chancellor announced the Brit disc system (so that "non-British lorries should pay their share to Britain for using British roads"), Mr Bromley growled: "About time, too".

In September, the couple were so outraged by fuel costs that they began the blockade at a fuel depot in Trafford Park, Manchester, which crippled the city's fuel supplies.

Nothing Mr Bromley heard yesterday will stop him protesting. "I'm disappointed but it's no more than I expected. Brown has missed the point of the protests altogether."

Last year Hill Top's turnover rose 20% and profit fell 35%, with fuel costs up by a quarter to a total bill of £126,000.

"Brown is trying to get the public on his side, to convince them that the hauliers will do well out of what he has given them. It's just spin."

Part 3: families and pensioners

fields.headline: Brown's £4.7bn to buy off protesters
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday unveiled concessions worth up to £4.7bn next year as he sought to appease pensioners and fuel protesters without throwing away his hard-won reputation for fiscal prudence.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday unveiled concessions worth up to £4.7bn next year as he sought to appease pensioners and fuel protesters without throwing away his hard-won reputation for fiscal prudence.

Concentrating his efforts on the elderly, the chancellor exploited the buoyant state of the government's finances to announce a £5 a week rise in the basic pension for a single person - more than double the rate of inflation - and £8 a week for a married couple.

Within hours of presenting his pre-budget report to MPs, Mr Brown appeared to have succeeded in defusing anger among pensioner groups over the 75p a week increase in the basic pension for this year.

However, his olive branch to road hauliers - consultations on a £1.75bn series of measures that would cut fuel prices, reduce excise duty and provide subsidies for "greener" lorries - was dismissed as an insult by protesters' leaders.

Mr Brown announced his proposals six days before the expiry of the 60-day deadline imposed by the campagigners when they called off their blockades of oil refineries in September. But despite being told that the total package would be worth the equivalent of 8p off a litre of fuel, some truckers' leaders called it "very, very poor" and insisted that it would not buy them off. They had demanded between 15p and 26p off a litre of fuel.

Brynle Williams, the Welsh farmer at the forefront of the last fuel protest, said there would be no blockade of refineries, but added: "The general public will see through this for what it is. He has tried to seduce us with tokens like three pence off a litre, but it is not going to work."

Mr Brown's aides said the extra money for pensioners could be more than met from higher than expected tax revenues, and the aim of the fuel concessions had been to drive a wedge between hardline protesters and mainstream motorists, who were wooed with a proposed cut in duty for clean fuel and a £55 cut in road tax for cars up to 1,500cc.

City analysts said they expected the package to have no impact on interest rates . They said the ultra-cautious forecasts for public finances left ample scope for tax cuts in next spring's budget.

Mr Brown taunted the Conservatives to say how they would pay for their proposed tax cuts. "Those who would spend this money on tax-cutting should now tell us which hospitals, which public services they would cut," he said. "We have made our choice: investment, targeted tax cuts, keeping mortgage rates low, more for pensions and families, a stronger, fairer Britain."

The Tories denounced a graceless u-turn by "a chancellor in full retreat" who had stolen their fuel proposals.

With the votes of 22m car owners and 11m pensioners at stake six months before the expected May 3 general election, most of Mr Brown's pre-budget package was geared to take effect from April 1. But after the drubbing Labour received in the polls this autumn, he also offered up-front cash.

Lorry owners will get an immediate rebate of vehicle excise duty worth £265m this year. And Mr Brown told delighted Labour MPs that the pensioners' winter fuel allowance would be raised from £50 to £200, instead of £150 promised earlier. The cheques will go out on Monday.

Although pensioners' groups said they would continue their fight to restore the link between the state pension and earnings, Labour MPs were delighted. Mr Brown also rattled off a series of reforms to stimulate savings and enterprise, boost the inner cities, provide £200m for school repairs, worth between £4,000 and £30,000 to every school.

In a bullish account of the public finances, Mr Brown said he would have a £10bn surplus this year. However, the opposition focused on the increase in taxation from 35.3% of GDP in 1997 to 37.3% this year. Without his concessions to the haulage industry, taxation would rise to 37.5% next year - election year - a point the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, was quick to denounce.

Part 2: the fiscal stance
Part 3: families and pensioners
