webTitle: Arab boy haunts army from grave

fields.headline: Arab boy haunts army from grave
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Six weeks after Israel admitted that its soldiers "probably" unleashed the rain of bullets that killed a Palestinian boy cowering in his father's arms, a new army attempt to avoid the blame backfired yesterday.
fields.body:
Six weeks after Israel admitted that its soldiers "probably" unleashed the rain of bullets that killed a Palestinian boy cowering in his father's arms, a new army attempt to avoid the blame backfired yesterday.

A bizarre propaganda campaign sought to erase the most horrifying image of the intifada, that of Mohammed al-Durreh, a 12-year-old boy, first terrified and then dying in 40 minutes of Israeli gunfire.

On October 23 the army's Gaza commander, Yom Tov Samia, supervised a re-enactment of the boy's death on September 29 outside the Israeli army command post at Netzarim junction. The aim was to pin the death on Palestinian gunmen.

The event was organised by a maverick inventor, known to Israelis for his conspiracy theories about the 1995 assassination of their prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin. It involved the reconstruction of the bullet-scarred wall and concrete water butt where Mohammed and his father vainly sought shelter, later bulldozed by the army as a "security measure".

But the attempt backfired. An embarrassed chief of staff, Lieutenant-General Shaul Mofaz, disowned the investigation, the newspaper Ha'aretz reported yesterday.

Ophir Pines-Paz, an Israeli MP, said: "One gets the impression that instead of genuinely confronting this incident, the Israeli defence force has chosen to stage a fictitious re-enactment and cover up the incident by means of an inquiry with foregone conclusions and the sole purpose of which is to clear the IDF."

Today the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, goes to Washington to urge President Clinton to support an international protection force for the West Bank and Gaza, and to stop Israel from turning its tanks and combat helicopters on his people.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, will oppose such a force when he meets Mr Clinton on Sunday. He is expected to claim that the Palestinians have failed to rein in protesters.

Israel's propaganda campaign follows international demands that its soldiers be charged with war crimes against the Palestinians, about 175 of whom have been killed during recent weeks. Of these, more than 20 were less than 15 years old.

However, the Palestinian Authority said yesterday it opposed a visit to the West Bank and Gaza by the UN human rights chief, Mary Robinson, because she also planned to meet Israeli rightwing leaders.

Two more Palestinian teenagers were shot dead by Israeli soldiers in Gaza yesterday, when the army used tanks and live ammunition against protesters at the Karni border crossing. Their deaths follow the killing of a female Israeli customs officer near the Rafah border crossing with Egypt - the first attack claimed by the Fatah Uprising, a rogue group from Mr Arafat's political faction.

With the violence unabated, Israel's military remains shaken by the attention given to Mohammed al-Durreh's death.

"Often a popular demonstration becomes a firefight. This is how the Palestinians obtained the death of the child Mohammed al-Durreh who became the symbol of this intifada," said a senior Israeli intelligence official. He added: "The Palestinian Authority is exploiting his death in an almost sickening fashion."

fields.headline: French farmers call for slaughter
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The only chef to hold six Michelin stars, Alain Ducasse, said he would stop serving French beef at his restaurants yesterday as the country's main farming union called for a cull of up to 5m older cows.
fields.body:
The only chef to hold six Michelin stars, Alain Ducasse, said he would stop serving French beef at his restaurants yesterday as the country's main farming union called for a cull of up to 5m older cows.

The prime minister, Lionel Jospin, sought to calm public panic about the spread of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), known as mad cow disease, after the president of the FNSEA farmer's union, Luc Guyau, said he had asked the government to "do what it can" to make sure animals born before 1996 did not enter the food chain.

Mr Jospin urged all involved to "cool down", and criticised hard-hit farmers for fanning consumer fears by deciding to stop selling meat from cattle born before mid-1996, the date France introduced strict measures to counter BSE.

"No one should be surprised if there are economic consequences for the beef industry when one does not provide any concrete answers but instead goes along with a kind of general psychosis," he said.

The agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, insisted beef was safe. "I eat beef, my children eat beef, all the scientists who are mad cow disease experts eat beef and so do their children," he said. "I think we are now in the realm of psychosis and irrationality."

Spain joined the list of countries banning the import of French beef yesterday. But in London the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said Britain had no intention of putting an embargo on beef products from across the channel.

France's main wholesale food market at Rungis said beef sales had slumped by 60% week-on-week.

webTitle: Watchdog criticises worsening punctuality of trains across network

fields.headline: Watchdog criticises worsening punctuality of trains across network
fields.standfirst:
More about transport
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Train performance figures have slumped alarmingly over the past year with only three of the 25 train companies, including Great Western and Gatwick Express, showing any improvement in punctuality.
fields.body:
Train performance figures have slumped alarmingly over the past year with only three of the 25 train companies, including Great Western and Gatwick Express, showing any improvement in punctuality.

Figures released yesterday by the shadow strategic rail authority show that the punc tuality of Great North Eastern Railway, the company at the centre of the Hatfield rail crash, is the worst on the network. Its punctuality rate between July and October dropped by 11% on the figure for the same period last year. Only 75.8% of its trains are running on time, although this figure has an inbuilt cushion letting trains arrive 10 minutes late.

Other poor performers were Virgin's West Coast and CrossCountry lines, and Anglia (inter-city), whose punctuality rate dropped by 8%. Only 81.5% of its trains are running to time.

Elsewhere, all the London commuter companies are less punctual than a year ago. The worst are Thameslink and Silverlink, which have both dropped by 6%. The figures are based on events before the Hatfield accident, and the period includes the September fuel crisis and engineering works on the west coast main line.

Last night the train operators reacted angrily to remarks made by Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, at the CBI conference, that Railtrack had no say in the design and specification of trains.

Brian Clementson, of the train operators' group for rolling stock, said: "Gerald is wrong. Train operators are keen to see this matter resolved and have set up a wheel-rail interface group that will work with Railtrack to investigate corner gauge cracking." He said it was premature of Railtrack to suggest that the phenomenon was simply due to heavy trains.

A spokesman for the freight company, English, Welsh and Scottish Railways, accused Mr Corbett of trying "to create smokescreens". He suggested that Railtrack should concentrate on track maintenance.

Tom Winsor, the rail regulator, yesterday told Lord Cullen's inquiry into rail safety that the state of the network reflected the underinvestment in the railways before privatisation. But it also reflected Railtrack's stewardship since 1994, and the company was better placed now to make "very significant improvements in the network".

Mr Winsor said there should be no conflict between performance and safety, though Railtrack seemed to be advancing the argument that there was. "I do not agree with that," he declared. He said that Railtrack was fully funded to make safety improvements, and that it could be given extra money for safety if the need existed.

Tom Winsor, the rail regulator, yesterday told Lord Cullen's inquiry into rail safety that the state of the network reflected the underinvestment in the railways before privatisation. But it also reflected Railtrack's stewardship since 1994, and the company was better placed now to make "very significant improvements in the network". Mr Winsor said there should be no conflict between performance and safety, though Railtrack seemed to be advancing the argument that there was. "I do not agree with that," he declared. He said that Railtrack was fully funded to make safety improvements, and that it could be given extra money for safety if the need existed.

fields.headline: Dead man's win stuns Republicans
fields.standfirst:
Missouri: Seat for widow may prompt appeal

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Voters in Missouri made history yesterday when they elected a dead man to represent them in the Senate.
fields.body:
Voters in Missouri made history yesterday when they elected a dead man to represent them in the Senate.

Mel Carnahan, the popular Democratic candidate who died in a plane crash last month, won 50% of the state's vote in one of the strangest electoral contests ever held in America.

Mr Carnahan's name was kept on the ballot paper as he died too late to be removed. Local party officials chose his widow, Jean, to take his place in the event of a victory, which eventually came in the early hours of Wednesday morning after a controversial count.

The closeness of the race combined with continuing questions about the legality of electing a dead man was expected to prompt an official appeal from the Republicans.

Jean Carnahan compared her husband to other leaders who were cut down in their prime when she finally made an acceptance speech after a tense, emotional night.

"Lincoln never saw his nation made whole again," she said. "Martin Luther King never finished his mountaintop journey. My husband's journey was cut short too. And, for reasons we don't understand, the mantle has now fallen upon us." Mrs Carnahan is to sit for two years rather than the usual six because of the unusual nature of the election. Using a favourite phrase of her husband's that was a campaign rallying cry after his death, she thanked her husband's supporters for "keeping the flame alive".

John Ashcroft, the sitting senator and twice governor in the state, won 49% of the vote.

Any appeal against the decision could focus on the fact that candidates have to "inhabit" a state to be elected under the constitution.

However, Republican officials were yesterday suggesting they could appeal against a further oddity.

A state circuit judge decided to keep booths open for several hours longer than expected in St Louis on Tuesday after the high turnout led to huge queues. The appeal court later closed the polls but not before they had been open for an extra 45 minutes.

webTitle: No answer found on CJD cluster

fields.headline: No answer found on CJD cluster
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Doctors and health officials investigating a cluster of five deaths from the human form of BSE have as yet been unable to formulate a theory to link all the cases.
fields.body:
Doctors and health officials investigating a cluster of five deaths from the human form of BSE have as yet been unable to formulate a theory to link all the cases.

Leicestershire health authority is trying to establish whether there is a common factor in the history of the victims, four of whom had links to the village of Queniborough.

The investigation is concentrating on the preparation and selling of meat products during the 1980s, after having eliminated other possibilities such as the water supply, surgery, vaccines and baby foods.

All five who died from variant CJD between August 1998 and last month had lived in the Wreake and Soar valley areas of the county for much of their lives.

Philip Monk, consultant in communicable diseases, said: "Between 1980 and 1991 all of the cases lived in an area defined by a circle within a radius of 5km.

"We have reached a stage where some risk factors have been found to be unlikely. We are on the way to finding a possible linking hypothesis. However, we have not yet found a theory that can link all the cases."

Although the investigators hope to make a progress report to government advisers on variant CJD later this month, a verdict on whether there was a single cause for the cluster is unlikely before early next year.

webTitle: Leader: It's bush, or else it's Gore

fields.headline: It's Bush, or else it's Gore
fields.standfirst:
If the system is wrong, change the system

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The argument that Al Gore won Tuesday's American presidential election is at first glance overwhelming. The Democratic candidate campaigned tirelessly for the citizenry's support, barnstorming back and forward across the country again and again. His party launched an enormous get-out-the-vote effort with Jesse Jackson, the civil rights leader, knocking on doors in Pennsylvania and Mr Gore and his running mate, Joseph Lieberman, cajoling and pleading in Florida until the very last moment.
fields.body:
The argument that Al Gore won Tuesday's American presidential election is at first glance overwhelming. The Democratic candidate campaigned tirelessly for the citizenry's support, barnstorming back and forward across the country again and again. His party launched an enormous get-out-the-vote effort with Jesse Jackson, the civil rights leader, knocking on doors in Pennsylvania and Mr Gore and his running mate, Joseph Lieberman, cajoling and pleading in Florida until the very last moment.

In the event, and despite much criticism of his election strategy and personal manner, Mr Gore's endeavours appeared to have paid off. With almost all votes tallied last night, he led George W Bush, his Republican rival, by approximately 250,000 votes nationwide - by 49% to 48% of the popular vote - with Green presidential candidate Ralph Nader picking up the remaining 3%. Even though some postal ballots have yet to be added in, and despite the recount in Florida, these totals are now considered unlikely to change significantly. So, by any rational measure, surely, the banner headline would be: Gore Wins!

Not so. Bemusingly for a country that prides itself on a democratic tradition which it energetically exports round the world as a paradigm for modern nation states, the outcome remains in suspense. The problem lies within the electoral college where, despite his popular "victory", Mr Gore may well fail to gain the edge. Although the Democrat is currently only 10 college votes away from the winning magic number of 270, a Bush win in Florida would give the Republican another 25 votes to add to his accumulated total of 246 and thus hand him the contest on a plate. Why? Because it is the electoral college, not voters at large, that ultimately decides who takes the glorious walk down Pennsylvania Avenue.

A travesty, you may cry. A gross distortion of the will of the people. And indeed that may be the case put forward by Democrats and others in the coming days should Mr Gore fail to carry Florida and be pipped at the post in this extraordinary fashion. Although there are precedents for different results in the popular vote and electoral college, they date from the 19th century and had more to do with Tammany Hall frauds and disputed tallies than with a straight, unalloyed contradiction of outcomes, as now. What is more, the college is undoubtedly an oddity. It dates from an era when communications were poor, when the emphasis was on states' rights within a federal system, when it was felt important to oblige candidates to obtain a broad geographical spread of support - and when governing elites in Washington in any case tended to distrust the vagaries of pure, unadulterated democracy. Many will maintain that such an anachronistic mechanism cannot nowadays be allowed to upset a clear if slim popular mandate. Should not Mr Bush do the decent thing and cede the election to Mr Gore?

Although it seems logical, it would be a very bad precedent. The Republicans can argue with justice that they fought the election under an agreed set of rules that included the electoral college system. They will doubtless maintain that were the situation to be reversed, Mr Gore would be unlikely to give away his prize. They will certainly portray Mr Gore as a bad loser, as a man prepared to hold the country to ransom and cultivate a damaging constitutional crisis out of selfish, narrow ambition. Any encouragement given to delegates to the electoral college who may sympathise with Mr Gore's predicament to switch sides (which has happened occasionally in the past) would also rightly be condemned as gross interference in the long-established democratic process.

If Mr Gore wins in Florida, where the result of the recount is promised late today, then these dilemmas will be avoided, at least this time. He will be the victor in both popular and electoral college terms. But if he loses, his only proper course is to accept a bitter defeat as gracefully as he can - and then, if he has the spirit for it, launch a new campaign for electoral reform. Mr Bush, if he wins, should likewise quickly ask Congress and the Supreme Court to investigate whether the electoral college is still a useful and necessary tool. Such deeply divisive dichotomies must be avoided in future. It is time to trust fully the people in whose name politicians aspire to rule.

fields.headline: Stephen Barry
fields.standfirst: His role as an artistic director and administrator in leading regional theatres heralded a new era for subsidised drama in Britain
fields.trailText: Stephen Barry, who has died of cancer aged 55, was chief executive of two Edinburgh theatres, the Festival and the King's, and was one of the first people to run a creative arts institution after the European manner: as a producer within the subsidised system. He made his post comparable to that of a German intendant, negotiating the complexities of regional politics and the funding system and taking responsibility for artistic policy, though - despite his experience - only rarely directing plays
fields.body:
Stephen Barry, who has died of cancer aged 55, was chief executive of two Edinburgh theatres, the Festival and the King's, and was one of the first people to run a creative arts institution after the European manner: as a producer within the subsidised system. He made his post comparable to that of a German intendant, negotiating the complexities of regional politics and the funding system and taking responsibility for artistic policy, though - despite his experience - only rarely directing plays

Because of the Festival theatre's role in the Edinburgh International Festival, Barry was running one of the most important venues in Britain. He had gone to the Scottish capital in 1997, when a restructuring of theatre in the city was imminent and he was perceived as the hand to guide it.

Earlier, when Sheffield city council secured money from Europe for the £12m refurbishment of the Lyceum theatre in 1990, it decided, with the Crucible Theatre Trust, that the two buildings should be run as a single operation, uniting the turn-of-the-century, proscenium arch splendour of the touring house with the uncompromising concrete thrust stage and studio of the rep.

Strong Arts Council advice led to Barry's appointment, following his success at the Theatre Royal in Bath, where another beautiful and traditional touring theatre had been restored to its former glory. But the decisive factor for the Sheffield board was that he had also worked as an artistic director himself.

Stephen Barry was born in Welwyn Garden City. His father was editor of the News Chronicle, and his first contact with the theatre was through his mother, the actress Vera Lindsay. A distant relation of the playwright Stephen Poliakoff, she was also an art collector who started the Covent Garden artists' markets, and she gave her son much of the passion and drive which he was to combine with an otherwise very English education at Marlborough College.

Barry studied drama at Manchester University, under Hugh Hunt and the inspirational maverick pioneer of theatre-in-the-round, Stephen Joseph. He trained as a director with Bernard Miles at the Mermaid theatre, before becoming assistant director at the Yvonne Arnaud theatre, Guildford, and then staff director at the National, when Laurence Olivier was running it at the Old Vic.

He was still only 26 when he got his first experience of directing in the West End, in a production of Time Out Of Mind, starring Alec Guinness. After further freelance work and a spell as a researcher with Granada Television, in 1974 he took on the artistic direction of his first theatre, in Harrogate.

In 1978, Barry became artistic director of the National theatre of Western Australia, in Perth, where he announced himself with a production of Alan Ayckbourn's trilogy, The Norman Conquests. He was the last Englishman to date appointed to run a major Australian theatre. He directed both native stars, like Judy Davis in Pam Gem's Piaf, and visiting talent, such as Warren Mitchell in Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman, and commissioned a play from the Australian poet Dorothy Hewitt.

Barry returned to Britain in 1982 and was artistic director of the Redgrave theatre, Farnham, until 1986, when he switched to a new role in the touring theatre based at the Theatre Royal in Bath. Although a chain of fine old theatre buildings across the country was renovated in this period, welcomed by a regional public hankering after traditional theatre forms as well as the more adventurous but less star-driven reps, little thought had been given to what work would go into them. Their decline had been partly due to the grim quality of work put in by their previous commercial owners.

Barry was one of the first executives to recognise the need for the new administrations to enter partnerships with the national companies to bring their work to the regions, and to form new alliances to create original work for this new network of theatres. He was instrumental in setting up a formal consortium of regional theatres to do this. In Sheffield he directed The Norman Conquests again and continued to direct pantomimes, but his role was mainly that of a subsidised impresario in the last 15 years of his life. He was particularly committed to the programming of contemporary dance, launching a kind of continuing festival under the title Danceworks In Sheffield and finding an audience that few thought existed.

He was vibrant and funny in company, hands-on in management style, combative when he felt the need. He worked with three artistic directors in Sheffield - Mark Brickman, Michael Rudman and Deborah Paige - through a period in which a major decline in subsidy made for a significant reduction in the quality of the work produced in the Crucible. But the striving for quality was never in doubt and the success of the Lyceum, in the days when Kenneth Branagh's Renaissance and the Peter Hall company were touring stellar productions of classics, was immediate and sustained.

Edinburgh offered the prospect of better resources and the chance of working with Scottish Opera and Ballet as well as the pick of Britain's large-scale drama. Barry was awaiting debates on the future funding of the performing arts in the new nation state with some anxiety when he died.

He is survived by his wife Jackie, a former actress he met while working in Guildford, their son Tom and daughter Anya.

 Stephen Leon Reid Barry, director and arts administrator, born July 4 1945; died October 18 2000

webTitle: Hague was party to initial dome plans, says Blair

fields.headline: Hague was party to initial dome plans, says Blair
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: William Hague was party to secret plans by the Tories to attract up to 30m people to the dome - nearly six times the present number of visitors - a leaked memorandum from the millennium commission revealed last night.
fields.body:
William Hague was party to secret plans by the Tories to attract up to 30m people to the dome - nearly six times the present number of visitors - a leaked memorandum from the millennium commission revealed last night.

The disclosure came hours after Tony Blair launched an attack on Mr Hague on the eve of the damning report from the national audit office's examination of the £1bn dome fiasco.

Mr Blair's attack came as Mr Hague urged that the dome minister, Lord Falconer, should resign if he is criticised in the report, which is due today.

On the day after thieves tried to steal the dome's diamond display, Mr Blair told the Tory leader: "The only difference between the robbers yesterday and you is that the Tories are never caught at the scene of the crime."

Yet, he added: "Do you remember the cabinet committee GEN 36 established in February 1996 by the then prime minister to consider aspects of the dome, funding, its financial management, who should be appointed to it, where it was sited, how it was designed?"

Mr Hague, he said, had been a member of it. "I will accept criticism from members of the public on the dome, but not from you," he declared.

Mr Blair insisted the decision to build the dome had been taken by the committee, of which Mr Hague had been a member.

It had also decided on the Greenwich site, the appointment of senior managers, the lottery money and financing of the dome, and had made projections of visitor numbers.

Mr Hague rejected the attack saying: "It defies credulity that the prime minister thinks it was now all to do with the previous administration."

Visitor numbers had been reviewed and confirmed by this government, and he quoted Mr Blair as saying the dome was the most exciting thing happening in the world in the year 2000, would last for decades and was an international landmark.

"If the report tomorrow seriously criticises this government for its mishandling of the dome, will the dome minister now take responsibility and resign," he said.

Last night's leaked memorandum shows clearly that the original proposals endorsed by the millennium commission on May 24, 1995, planned a minimum 15m visitors. The first set of guidelines proposed in July 1996 said the aim was to acheive between 15m and 30 m visits a year for the main millennium exhibition.

When the dome site was chosen in February 1996 a figure of 10.9m-16m visitors was suggested, which was reduced to 10m in February 1997, when Michael Heseltine, the former deputy Tory prime minister, was in charge.

The memo does show that when Peter Mandelson took over in May 1997 the figures were revised upwards to 12m.

Tories were last night furious that Mr Blair had disclosed Mr Hague's role in the original plans, but the information about the committee is contained in a parliamentary answer from John Major in 1996.

Tories are suspicious that the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, has broken Whitehall rules on secrecy in allowing the memorandum to be leaked yesterday.

fields.headline: Dick Morrissey
fields.standfirst: Bright star of the fusion between jazz and rock
fields.trailText: Dick Morrissey, who has died aged 60 from cancer, was one of Britain's brightest jazz stars and a man who had a key role in the early fusion between jazz and rock during the 1970s.
fields.body:
Dick Morrissey, who has died aged 60 from cancer, was one of Britain's brightest jazz stars and a man who had a key role in the early fusion between jazz and rock during the 1970s.

As jazz fashions seesawed between freer forms and fusion, Morrissey moved towards the latter, notably during the early years of a much-acclaimed partnership with guitarist Jim Mullen that saw them working with the Average White Band, the Scottish group who became the first British exponents of blue-eyed soul.

Born in Surrey, Morrissey went to school in Sutton and was a self-taught musician. He began as a clarinettist in his early teens, but subsequently learned all the saxophones, plus flute. In his late teens he worked with the bandleader Harry South, first appearing in the London clubs as a tenor saxophonist, the instrument with which he was always most closely identified.

John Coltrane's approach to the tenor had yet to make much of an impact in Britain, and Morrissey came up with a startling and warmly appreciated blend of Stan Getz and Sonny Rollins, the phrasing of one allied to the abrasive tones of the other. He was also influenced by the example of Tubby Hayes, whose lightening-quick forays through complex harmonies he was probably the first to emulate.

Morrissey soon established himself as leader of various quartets at Ronnie Scott's club, working with Phil Seaman and Harry South. In 1961 he recorded his first solo album, It's Morrissey Man! fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Seaweed in takeover bid | Nasa puts down rover
fields.body:
Seaweed in takeover bid
It grows eight cms a day and takes to warm sea like a duck to water. Caulerpa taxifolia is green, fernlike and a contender for the title of killer alga. It has been seeking to dominate in parts of the Mediterranean and has now made a bid for the new world. It gained a tendril-hold in Huntington Harbour, California and spread to cover 20,000 square metres. And, according to a team from the University of Geneva, reporting in Nature today, the alga is the same strain that hit the Med and may have originated in Australia. Ironically, the most obvious terrestrial invaders in the Mediterranean and California are also Australian: the gum trees.

Nasa puts down rover
Bad news for space invaders: Nasa will not now be making a miniature asteroid explorer. The dream of the 2002 Japanese Muses-C expedition to an asteroid was that the robot spacecraft would gingerly approach and tenderly drop a robot rover on its surface. This would have infra-red and visible-light cameras, packed into something that would fit in the palm of the hand, weigh 2.5lbs and have been a prototype for a generation of probes to crawl over the surface of comets and planetary moons. Nasa scientists had hoped to develop it for $21m. Costs soared, the accountants stepped in. "In the end, there was no viable alternative," said Nasa's Jay Bergstralh.

Omaha Beach: the return
The institute of nautical archaeology at Texas A&M University and the US naval historical centre are to head back to the Normandy coast next summer, 57 years after D-Day, for a new kind of dead reckoning. Brett Phaneuf and colleagues from Texas did sonar searches off Utah and Omaha beaches this summer and found Sherman tanks, landing craft and other wrecks at depths of five to 30 metres. They also found amphibious British tanks which, though rigged to float, sank straight to the bottom as soon as they were released. The idea is to complete the survey and protect the sites from looting.

fields.headline: Estonia sells its gene pool
fields.standfirst: A genetic database project is an ethical timebomb, writes  Michael Gross
fields.trailText: A genetic database project is an ethical timebomb, writes Michael Gross
fields.body:
Do you happen to have a few hundred million pounds ready? Do you want to buy a population of 1.3 million people? If so, contact the "Eesti Geenikeskus", the Estonian Genome Foundation. It is looking for investors to fund what would become the world's biggest database of medical and genetic data, a database that will essentially comprise everything that can be found out about the Estonian people. The whole people.

To find suitable investors, the foundation publicises its project (www.genomics.ee) on the web , displaying a persuasiveness that would put double-glazing companies to shame.

Estonian people, in case you didn't know, are just perfect. Quite steady, as they have been settling in their present location for at least 5,000 years, but not too isolated from the rest of the world. Their family trees can normally be traced back into the 17th century. More than a third of the people old enough to take a degree have done so, and the life expectancy is 70 years.

Most importantly, they have willingly accepted the deal. Opinion polls suggest that more than 90% of the 1.445 million Estonians are ready to part with 50ml of their blood and a detailed account of their medical history. A law regulating the details of the procedure is expected to pass parliament without problems.

What seems to have won over the Estonian politicians was the hope of becoming world leaders in something for the first time. The only other project on a comparable scale started in Iceland last year, following a protracted public debate that ended with the approval by parliament in December 1998.

However, the Icelandic gene pool is much smaller and more homogeneous than the Estonian one. Icelanders descend from a small number of settlers and have remained isolated for centuries. While there are now 275,000 today, there have been fewer than 50,000 until very recently.

What the Icelandic company deCODE is beginning to do, and what the Estonians are hoping to do on a bigger scale and with more generalisable results, is to relate those very small parts of our genes that make us different from each other to the observable effects that our genes have in terms of diseases, appearance and so on.

Most of the building blocks of our DNA will be found to be identical in all (or a vast majority of) human beings. But there are a few hundred thousand positions in the genome where differences are common. The sequencing of the human genome, which is now nearing completion, will allow scientists to pin down such variable spots, which can then be used as markers to describe the genetic identity of each person in a process called genotyping.

Each living person has a large number of genetic traits, such as eye colour, body shape and inherited abilities or disabilities, which cannot be easily related to the genetic markers. So far, only relatively rare medical conditions have been successfully matched with genetic markers.

If a number of people have both a rare disease and a rare genetic marker, this is unlikely to be a coincidence. In order to assign the more common traits, such as blue eyes, diabetes or heart disease, to their genetic origins, one needs a large number of people - a million will do nicely.

In such a big sample, the traits will also be represented in large numbers, so you will, for instance, have half a million people with blue eyes in the database. Looking at the hundreds of thousands of variable genetic markers of those half-million people, one might find a combination of a few markers that is present in all of them but not normally in those people with other eye colours. While such a finding could be a coincidence in half a dozen blue-eyed people, it would be a significant scientific result if confirmed in half-a-million people.

So far, the scientific arguments in favour of such a study are perfectly reasonable. If we were talking about mice or guinea pigs, there would be no reason not to carry it out. The trouble is, we are talking about human beings whose lives maybe affected by genetic information becoming public. In contrast to Icelanders, who argued about their genome project for a year, Estonians appear to be blissfully unaware of the side-effects that the combination of medical and genetic information could have.

Under the subheading "risks", the Estonian Genome Foundation lists nine scenarios in which their project could run into problems or be beaten by competitors, but doesn't waste a single thought on the possibility that the 1.3m subjects of their research could suffer as a consequence of the project.

While a collection of genetic, genealogical or medical data would be relatively harmless, the connections between the three contain ethical timebombs of different kinds. The database may contain evidence proving that tens of thousands of people are not related to the man they consider to be their father. Anybody hacking into the data should find a rich supply of people to blackmail. Similarly, other information could be of sufficient value to some to encourage illegal access and use of the data. Simply replacing the subjects' names with codes and making a law to say that the misuse of genetic data is forbidden will not be sufficient to protect the privacy of the research subjects.

While the ethical dilemmas surrounding genetic screening have been debated at length in Britain and other European countries, Estonians don't seem to be aware of these problems. The Weekly Crier, a web news service from the Baltic countries, cites a medical professor, Tiina Tasmuth, one of the few critics of the project as saying: "People here don't ask why, as they do in the west." If they did, the honest answer would probably be most likely to sound like "money". After all, the investors who will eventually fund the project will want something in return, such as patents on new genetic tests, the uses and misuses of which we can't even imagine today.

 Michael Gross is a science writer based at the Oxford Centre for Molecular Sciences. New editions of his books Life On The Edge and Travels To The Nanoworld are coming out in paperback at Perseus Books in January.

fields.headline: Urban myth of the jungle
fields.standfirst: Despite its image, Amazonia has been shaped by humans for centuries, writes  Henry Gee
fields.trailText: Despite its image, Amazonia has been shaped by humans for centuries, writes Henry Gee
fields.body:
T he town of Cholula in Mexico is dominated by a picturesque Spanish church on a hilltop. When the Spaniards arrived in the area they, along with many of Cholula's indigenous residents, assumed the hill was a natural feature of the landscape. But they were wrong. What they were building on was the overgrown and much-decayed remnant of a pyramid abandoned centuries earlier. Although not nearly as lofty as the great pyramid of Cheops in Egypt, the pyramid of Cholula covered a far greater area - so huge that it was taken to be a part of the scenery.

There is a lesson here that archaeologists are beginning to apply more generally in the neotropics - the species-rich region of tropical central and south America. When we encounter seemingly primitive peoples living on a savannah or in a rainforest that looks as though it came straight out of Tarzan or the Lion King, we assume that they are somehow "in tune" with nature and have learned to live as innocents in a pristine habitat that we westerners disturb at our peril.

So far, so wrong - and so patronising. For it turns out that these locals live in a landscape they have managed and manicured with some success for thousands of years. It may look like a jungle to us but it is, in reality, a completely human construct. The lie is given by the productivity of a system capable of supporting denser populations than could be sustained by simple hunting and gathering or, as it happens, by the western habit of cattle ranching. Do not think of Amazonia as a wilderness: think of it, instead, as a botanical garden.

In today's Nature, the landscape archaeologist Clark Erickson of the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, reports on more than 500 square kilometres of tree-dotted savannah in the Baure region of the Bolivian Amazon, inland from the better-known high-altitude Inca heartland in the Andes.

To the casual observer it is Amazonia au naturel , but Erickson's tutored gaze sees the hand of man wherever he looks. In the few hundred years before the Spanish conquest, Amazonian contemporaries of the Incas tailored this landscape to suit their every comfort. "Rather than domesticate the species they exploited," says Erickson, "the people of Baure domesticated the landscape."

Erickson's savannah is contoured by a dense, interconnecting network of earthen causeways, settlement mounds, raised fields, and thousands of kilo metres of ridges, up to two metres across and half-a-metre high, that zig-zag across the landscape. These ridges are too narrow and wind too crazily to have been roads or even paths, and are often broken by V-shaped incisions, associated with ponds. What are these mysterious ridges? On the basis of their location and form, and comparisons with practices seen elsewhere in south America, Erickson has inferred their use: fishing.

This seems odd, given that the savannah is, most of the time, dry grassland. However, during the wet season, the Amazon and its tributaries burst their banks and spread across the landscape. The zig-zag ridges, built up with vegetation, rocks and even basketwork, would have made effective fish weirs, yielding enough protein to support a substantial population. The zig-zags would also have hindered water from draining back into the rivers at the end of the rains, creating ponds that could have been exploited well into the dry season. Today, savannah ponds associated with the zig-zag ridges may last all year round. They teem with fish and edible snails, and the oasis-like surroundings encourage the growth of palm trees. Palms yield nutritious fruits as well as timber and fibre. Even rotting palm logs have uses, as nurseries for protein-rich grubs of the palm beetle.

The ponds and associated vegetation would have been magnets for a variety of game. So rather than going hunting, the fish-trapping Amazonians let the wildlife come to them. To the western eye, it looks lush and natural.

The reality is rather different. "In the past 12,000 years," says Erickson, "indigenous peoples transformed the environment, creating what we now recognise as the rich ecological mosaic of the neotropics."

Twelve millennia seems like an exaggeration given that Erickson has carbon-dated his fish weirs to the 15th and early 16th centuries. Hyperbole? Apparently not. Other researchers in the neotropics are coming to realise that the region has been one large garden for thousands of years. Native Americans are known to have cultivated many plants for their starchy roots and tubers for a long time. The potato, for example, is a neotropical native.

However, suggestions that many of these plants were first grown in tropical forests have been controversial, partly because it is hard to find convincing remains of roots and tubers in archaeological sediments from the humid tropics. It is no accident that archaeologists (palaeontologists too, for that matter) prefer to go digging in dry deserts. But Dolores Piperno, of the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, and colleagues have overcome these problems. In Nature on October 19, they showed how manioc, yams, arrowroot and maize were cultivated in the jungles of Panama as long as 5,000 years ago.

This turns conventional wisdom on its head: far from the last wilderness, the rainforest could have been the birthplace of neotropical agriculture. If so, it is likely that the range of what we think of as "wild" species in rainforests, and their ecological associations, have been shaped by human practices for many thousands of years.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature.

fields.headline: Spanner in the works
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Welcome to the federal super-mess, its leadership of the free world buried amid a paper mountain of used Florida ballot papers. The nation is split from top to bottom with almost malign precision.
fields.body:
Welcome to the federal super-mess, its leadership of the free world buried amid a paper mountain of used Florida ballot papers. The nation is split from top to bottom with almost malign precision. A president who loses the popular ballot but wins in the creaking machinery of the electoral college? Probably. A Senate virtually tied, whose vote has no trace of proportionality to it so that the wastes of North Dakota count for as much as all California; a House of Representatives desperately divided on partisan lines which only crudely reflects the wishes of the electorate. Is this the will of the people? Any other sophisticated country, anywhere else in the world, would be talking animatedly about constitutional reform in such a bind. But don't hold your breath. This is America.

When the wagons of democracy are so rickety, it is no surprise if wheels fall off. The smallest change can produce a grinding hiatus. Take Ralph Nader and the Greens. There were four battleground states left undecided when most of America went to bed on Tuesday night - Iowa, Wisconsin, Oregon and, of course, Florida: in all of them the size of the Nader vote far outstripped the gap between Gore and Bush. If Gore winds up at the bottom of the never-everglades, there'll be plenty of Democrats who will put the blame on Ralph - just as Nader is saying already that "Al Gore has nobody to blame but Al Gore." But, in reality, the system is not up to coping with or interpreting such splits.

Nader, at around 3% of the popular vote, has nothing to show for what was essentially an insurgency from within the Democratic party: no seats, no hope of future federal election funding. The causes he espouses - abolishing the death penalty, gun control, emptying the privatised prisons, reform of campaign funding, the extension of healthcare to all - are further from realisation than they were before the polls opened.

Such progress along that path as Gore offered (in a limited, cautious way) is off the agenda for at least another four years. George W Bush sits on the opposite side of the planet - and the Democrats have a library full of polling verdicts to tell them that if they stray too far left, too far from the cloying centre, then they will lose again next time. When Nader says he won't go away, he effectively pushes everything he believes in still further into the future.

That is no way to run a huge and various modern country. The system as it has grown excludes: it excludes the poor and the illiterate and the desperate in their millions, it encourages the apathy and disillusion which, even among the confected excitement, characterised this race. If genuine strands of dissent can't be included within the fabric of the two historic parties, then they have to be found a place which sits beside those parties. Not to do that merely guarantees further rents in the intricately woven cloth of US society.

Ah yes! But here come the legions of pundits and constitutional historians raising the prospect of change only to dismiss it. What would Thomas Jefferson have made of such reformist talk? The guys at the heart of the action have a vested interest in not altering its course, remembering the George Wallaces and Ross Perots of relatively long ago and writing off far smaller revolts - like Nader's - as ephemeral.

Fine. Yet you can have too much of history. The grisly fact of this election is not that the people haven't spoken, because they have: the problem is that they have said almost entirely contradictory things in almost equally large numbers. A great fat "don't know". Does that mean, as some would have it, a kinder, gentler Washington? Do not believe it. The men of supposed goodwill trooping across your TV screens are the heirs of Newt, new Gingriches of gridlock. They weren't sent back to the house on the hill to be statesmen; they're streetfighters.

There will be no "coming together" when the next hill race, two years on, can break the stalemate. There will be no meaningful reform of the obscene billions of dollars - double even the 1996 number - lavished on Tuesday's contests. There is no pat compromise between school vouchers and education as usual, or between drug companies and the impoverished sick. And yet there is also a natural clustering around the sweet centre when the votes are called and the big campaign money pours in.

The temptation in the wake of Tuesday is to pin everything on personalities and the supposed gaffes of the campaigns. How on earth did Gore manage to neglect his trump card of a buoyant economy for so long? Why does nobody think Bush competent? In reality, however, these are only transient matters, the stuff of spin doctors and the breed of "experts" who made such a TV ass of themselves. The important question now is how America moves forward after six years of prosperity without progress on Capitol Hill. That situation hasn't got better after this contest. It has grown measurably worse - and the introversion it begets should make us all shiver a little.

Ralph Nader, to be sure, overdoes the malevolency of corporate power and soft money. You sometimes think that AT&T or Microsoft are his equivalents of George W's rogue terrorist states. There needs to be some proportion here. But proportionality matters in a far greater context.

America needs a system which forces it to work together - and to vote together. The big parties, losing membership and appeal, aren't smart enough to put true inclusion first any longer. The sophistry of inclusion - like Bush's convention pitch to blacks - doesn't work. What? Surely not PR for the United States of America. Hogs may fly! But put the proposition another way.

America is an intensely democratic country with freedom in its bones. That, more then brute power, is what gives it world leadership. It is also a practical country. In practicality, its checks and balances don't function well any longer. In practicality, the balance between the shrunken giants is too enervating. In practicality, too many of its citizens can find no way of claiming a stake in a system which turns its back on them. No child will be left behind? I'm afraid not.

The anxious frothing about the difference between the popular vote and the electoral college is more than mere debating. America has started at last to think about the quality and relevance of its democracy. It would be good if, once started, it could keep thinking through to a finish. You can't start using words like "legitimacy" without defining your terms from first principles.

fields.headline: Lida Baarov
fields.standfirst: Beautiful Czech actress who turned down Hollywood to become Goebbels's mistress
fields.trailText: When the Czech actress Lida Baarová, who has died aged 86, first went to Berlin in 1934 and began mixing with leading Nazis, she felt as if she was in heaven. The regrets came later. Six decades on she told me of the offers to go to Hollywood, which she had turned down. If she had got out of the clutches of the Nazis, she observed, she could have been as famous as Marlene Dietrich.
fields.body:
When the Czech actress Lida Baarová, who has died aged 86, first went to Berlin in 1934 and began mixing with leading Nazis, she felt as if she was in heaven. The regrets came later. Six decades on she told me of the offers to go to Hollywood, which she had turned down. If she had got out of the clutches of the Nazis, she observed, she could have been as famous as Marlene Dietrich.

Perhaps. But at the time she basked in the attention she received from Adolf Hitler's followers, particularly his propaganda minister, Josef Goebbels. She will be best remembered for the affair she had with him, which threatened his career, rather than for her acting.

Like many of the Nazi elite, she and her German actor husband, Gustav Fröhlich - with whom she had co-starred in her first German film Barcarole (1935) which had made her a household name - lived in a Berlin villa on the picturesque Wannsee, just three doors down from Goebbels. He ardently pursued her, entertaining her in his villa and lavishing her with expensive gifts. When Fröhlich, who had starred in Fritz Lang's 1927 film Metropolis found out, legend has it that he challenged him to a duel. Another story was that Fröhlich's friends found Goebbels at Baarová's flat and beat him up.

Fröhlich was briefly detained in a concentration camp, but it was Goebbels's wife, Magda, who went to Hitler about her husband's behaviour. Hitler was furious, refusing Goebbels permission to divorce Magda and marry Baarová. Instead, he commanded Goebbels never to see his mistress again. Baarová fled to her native Prague, abandoning a glittering career. Historians tell it slightly differently: through the head of the Berlin police, Hitler ordered her extradition and banned her films. "Life is so hard and cruel," Goebbels wrote in his diary, although his passion for Nazism was greater than his love for Baarová. But the resulting despair is said to have driven him to threaten suicide.

Despite his stated disapproval of the "inferior Slav", even the Führer showed romantic interest in the actress. They first met when he visited the studio where she was filming with Fröhlich. He later invited her for tea.

She drove herself in her BMW, which, she noted, Hitler found "a little strange". He told her of her similarity to Gerri Raubel, one of his ex-lovers, who had shot herself. At another tea-time meeting, he tried to persuade her to renounce her Czechoslovak nationality. "But I told him 'I like being a Czechoslovak citizen.' " The tea-time invitations stopped coming.

Born in Prague, the daughter of a civil servant, Baarová became a star of the Czechoslovak cinema at 21 after her first film, The Career of Pavel Camrda (1931). In 1934, the German company UFA signed her up, and the role as Giacinta in Barcarole followed. Her final German film was Der Spieler (The Gambler) in 1937.

Her flight to Prague brought no security, for the Germans invaded in March 1939, completing their dismemberment of her homeland. From 1942 she made films in Italy, but after the fall of Mussolini she returned to Prague. Accused of collaboration in 1945, she was imprisoned until late 1946. She then married a theatre agent, Jan Kopecky - who was related to the Communist interior minister. After an abortive attempt to escape from Czechoslovakia the couple were, curiously, allowed to leave; they went to Argentina and then to Spain.

In the 1950s Baarová acted in several Italian and Spanish films, including Federico Fellini's I Vitelloni (1953). She divorced in 1956, moved to Salzburg and took Austrian citizenship. In 1970 she married a Salzburg gynaecologist, Kurt Lundwall, who was 20 years her senior; he died three years later.

She had returned to the stage in 1960 in Düsseldorf. But even in Austria many never forgave her. In 1967, at the Graz theatre, she was met by groups of egg-throwing protesters. By 1975 she was appearing in the German stage version of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's The Bitter Tears of Petra Von Kant.

Baarová was rediscovered in the 1990s. A film biography was shot in Salzburg in 1995. In later years she turned to drink, saying that her acquaintance with Goebbels had "made my life hell". Even in her final interviews three years ago, she denied that there had been an affair.

Yet she appeared unrepentant, saying she had been "young and naive", and not remotely politically aware. "I was not a Nazi, but like other women I was afraid to say no to such men," she said. About the Nazi crimes, she simply shrugged. "I feel indifferent," she told me. " I just want to forget the whole episode."

Her autobiography, Escapes, was published in 1983; a second volume, The Soft Bitterness of Life, is due out soon. One of her last wishes had been to return to Prague, but she never managed it. Police found her body in her Salzburg flat.

 Lida Baarová (Ludmila Babkova), actress, born May 12 1914; died October 27 2000

fields.headline: The Geller we know
fields.trailText: Since Uri Geller has quoted me (Letters, November 8), I should like to make it clear that I am not engaged in any programme of experimentation into the paranormal. However, in 1974 I attended a conference where Matthew Manning, a psychic who is now involved with healing, gave a number of demonstrations of metal bending under conditions which appeared to preclude their being faked. I also believe that Mr Geller is genuine, though I do not have such strong evidence in his case.
fields.body:
Since Uri Geller has quoted me (Letters, November 8), I should like to make it clear that I am not engaged in any programme of experimentation into the paranormal. However, in 1974 I attended a conference where Matthew Manning, a psychic who is now involved with healing, gave a number of demonstrations of metal bending under conditions which appeared to preclude their being faked. I also believe that Mr Geller is genuine, though I do not have such strong evidence in his case.

I agree with Mr Geller about the behaviour of the press, but even more so that of hostile scientists, who seem willing to present an argument against the paranormal, or concerning other issues such as cold fusion or the memory of water work of Jacques Benveniste, that is erroneous or inconclusive, and then act as if the matter were settled for all time.

Prof Brian Josephson
University of Cambridge
bdj10@cam.ac.uk

For many years, the James Randi Foundation has offered a prize of $1m to anyone who can verifiably demonstrate any supernatural phenomenon or ability under properly controlled conditions. Funny how no "professional" psychic has ever even attempted to win the prize. Uri Geller's either richer than I thought and hates charity, or this is simply an unexplained phenomenon.

Mark Lewney
Dept of physics & astronomy, University of Cardiff
Mark.Lewney@astro.cf.ac.uk

Fans of Reading FC remember with gratitude the mystical crystals Uri Geller buried beneath the hallowed turf of the old Elm Park ground. Unfortunately, our greatest celebrity supporter's powers seemed to bend shots away from goal rather than into it.

Peter Davies
Edinburgh

Uri Geller has moved on from bending metal to bending ears, I see.

John Polley
Andover, Hants

fields.headline: Gems raiders 'just reckless villains'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The foiled attempt to steal £350m worth of diamonds from the Millennium Dome seemed to have been the work of reckless, low-ranking villains rather than criminal masterminds, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The foiled attempt to steal £350m worth of diamonds from the Millennium Dome seemed to have been the work of reckless, low-ranking villains rather than criminal masterminds, it emerged yesterday.

Police sources also revealed that the team behind the attack had planned to steal the gems once before, but was thwarted when its getaway powerboat broke down after it was lowered into the Thames.

The robbers were completely unaware that this episode, and their every movement since, was being monitored by Scotland Yard's Flying Squad and detectives from Kent police.

The National Criminal Intelligence Service was also involved in the operation, codenamed Magician.

Five men were arrested at two homes in Kent following the raid at the dome, which involved four masked men crashing into the Money Zone in a bulldozer.

Two other men were arrested - one was waiting in a powerboat next to the dome, another was monitoring police messages from a van parked on the opposite bank of the Thames.

Police were yesterday examining several guns found at addresses in Collier Street, Kent, and the nearby village of Horsmonden.

One of the 11 men being questioned was said to be Jimmy Wenham, a traveller turned scrap metal dealer, who recently failed to win a seat on a parish council in Kent.

 Eight people arrested in connection with the dome raid were charged last night with attempted robbery, police said.

fields.headline: Medical dilemmas
fields.trailText: It was with a heavy heart today that I gave my blessing to my daughter's application to join a nursing agency in the United States and abandon her fourth-generation of nursing service in this country.
fields.body:
It was with a heavy heart today that I gave my blessing to my daughter's application to join a nursing agency in the United States and abandon her fourth-generation of nursing service in this country.

The final straw? Whilst working for the hourly-paid nursing "bank" at Guy's Hospital in London, she happily continued when the clocks were put back. Then she was informed that the extra hour of a 13-hour shift was to be worked for free. I hope the "course in the technical language used in hospitals" planned for the 5,000 new Spanish nurses recruited to our crumbling NHS (Hospital welcomes Spanish nurses, November 8) will include instruction in parsimony.

Dr Colin Blogg
Consulting anaesthetist Oxford
colinblogg@doctors.net.uk

The NHS national plan threatens that, unless newly appointed consultants in the NHS contract exclusively for the NHS, a new "specialist" grade of doctor will be created. This grade of doctor would spell the end of quality British medicine as we know it.

Apparently this is because I owe a debt of service to the NHS. The NHS has "trained" me and therefore I owe it. It seems that I should be grateful that at the age of 32, I am still over three years away from a consultant post (that is if there are any in neurology to apply for by then). I should be grateful that I have worked on average 65-75 hours per week, exclusively for the NHS since qualifying in 1991. I have given my 20s to the NHS and will give all of my 30s. Many are still "junior" doctors at the age of 40. Exactly who owes whom?

Dr Trevor Pickersgill
Chair, junior doctors' committee, BMA
pickersgill@ntlworld.com

What really annoys your junior doctor diarist (G2, November 8) is that all the other people in the hospital who aren't doctors go home at 5pm. What really annoys me is that he forgets to mention the nurses, who do most of the "looking after".

No coffee and toast for him if he turns up at my nursing station in the night . . .

Drew Smith
Oxford

I was a little surprised to learn that the Queen Mother had required an out-of-hours visit by a doctor for what appeared to be a routine matter, ie to check on her condition. She or her daughter might like to know that NHS Direct is available to give advice and the government intends all out-of-hours calls to be dealt with by NHS Direct.

Dr Helen Alpin
Leeds
helenalpin@hotmail.com

fields.headline: On record
fields.trailText: Rob Evans's disturbing report raises the question as to what records Porton Down holds on German medical war crimes and on poison gas in the Holocaust (The guinea pigs, G2, November 8). In April 1945, the German poison gas expert, Kurt Gerstein, surrendered to two British technical officers at Rottweil in the Black Forest.
fields.body:
Rob Evans's disturbing report raises the question as to what records Porton Down holds on German medical war crimes and on poison gas in the Holocaust (The guinea pigs, G2, November 8). In April 1945, the German poison gas expert, Kurt Gerstein, surrendered to two British technical officers at Rottweil in the Black Forest.

Gerstein's testimony on the workings of Nazi gas chambers became key evidence in the Eichmann trial. British military chemists from Porton went on to evaluate the German homicidal gas chambers. While public record office documents reveal energetic British investigations of German medical war crimes, the actual materials have gone awol along with many interrogations of Nazi doctors.

All of the German medical evidence gathered by the British military at the end of the war should be collated for ethical and historical reasons

Prof Paul Weindling
Oxford Brookes University
pjweindling@brookes.ac.uk

webTitle: Russia talks over Ukraine in war of words

fields.headline: Russia talks over Ukraine in war of words
fields.trailText: While I agree that "independent Ukraine is struggling to shake off centuries of Russification", Ukraine is not waging war on the Russian language (Report, November 7). In recent years the number of Ukrainian schools has increased, but many people are unaware or unwilling to accept to what extent ethnic Russians still have disproportionate advantages over Ukrainians.
fields.body:
While I agree that "independent Ukraine is struggling to shake off centuries of Russification", Ukraine is not waging war on the Russian language (Report, November 7). In recent years the number of Ukrainian schools has increased, but many people are unaware or unwilling to accept to what extent ethnic Russians still have disproportionate advantages over Ukrainians.

There are about 2,400 Russians schools for more than 2m pupils who constitute 30% of the total number of pupils, while only 20% of Ukrainian citizens are ethnic Russians. Around 35% of students are educated in Russian and most newspapers are published in Russian. Some ethnic Russians wish to preserve the privileged position they enjoyed under Soviet rule and are trying to deny Ukrainians' human rights, thus provoking some to irrational action.

By labelling Ukrainians as nationalists and Nazis the small but vociferous groups of Russian chauvinists are trying to discredit and belittle the rights and natural demands of the Ukrainian nation and justify their resistance to the revival of the Ukrainian language and culture.

V Vassylenko
Ambassor, Embassy of Ukraine

As an expatriate who spent most of the 1990s in Ukraine, I witnessed numerous "incidents" between Ukrainian and Russian-speakers.

There is a widespread perception among Ukrainians in Lviv that their country's leaders, after nearly 10 years of independence, have not created conditions where Ukrainian-language cultural industries can compete for audiences. Big money and power prefers to fly in Russian pop stars from Moscow or establish Russian-language press outlets. In a "free market" they have every right to do this. But for resentful and economically disenfranchised Ukrainian-speakers, this preference is like salt on a festering wound.

Language tensions provide fertile ground for the extreme right. A greater danger, however, may arise when mischievous political forces in Russia fish in these troubled waters to "defend" Russian-speakers, much as the Third Reich intervened on behalf of Sudeten Germans in Czechoslovakia before the second world war.

Peter Bejger
San Francisco, California
petroboy@earthlink.net

fields.headline: Chariot of ire
fields.standfirst:
Minister's message to Livingstone
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The culture secretary, Chris Smith, yesterday invited Ken Livingstone to visit an exhibition on London's statues which is being created inside the arch supporting the largest bronze sculpture in England, the vast war chariot on top of the Wellington Arch at Hyde Park Corner.
fields.body:
The culture secretary, Chris Smith, yesterday invited Ken Livingstone to visit an exhibition on London's statues which is being created inside the arch supporting the largest bronze sculpture in England, the vast war chariot on top of the Wellington Arch at Hyde Park Corner.

Mr Livingstone provoked outrage in some quarters last month by suggesting that the statues of 19th century generals in Trafalgar Square should be removed, because no one knew who they were.

Yesterday, as the arch was floodlit to mark its restoration, Mr Smith suggested Mr Livingstone should visit when it opens to the public next spring. "He might like to come and have a look at the exhibition about London statues and learn a little more about their history." Mr Smith called English Heritage's £1.5m restoration of the arch and sculptures "brilliantly executed".

The arch was rescued from threatened collapse three years ago,when seeping water was cracking stonework and rusting supports.

fields.headline: Doubts over Nader's role
fields.trailText: Despite my wish that Ralph Nader had been a serious contender in the presidential election, I find it profoundly depressing that his 96,000 votes in Florida look like they are going to result in a president who is against the Kyoto climate agreement, who wishes to despoil Alaska, and will destabilise arms control by going ahead with the latest madcap "star wars" scheme (Nail-biting finish as US goes to the polls, November 8). I wonder if some of them today would cast their votes differently now they know the consequences of their actions.
fields.body:
Despite my wish that Ralph Nader had been a serious contender in the presidential election, I find it profoundly depressing that his 96,000 votes in Florida look like they are going to result in a president who is against the Kyoto climate agreement, who wishes to despoil Alaska, and will destabilise arms control by going ahead with the latest madcap "star wars" scheme (Nail-biting finish as US goes to the polls, November 8). I wonder if some of them today would cast their votes differently now they know the consequences of their actions.

Dave Hanson
Hull

Tara Mack has thought her way out of the dilemma experienced by anyone who refuses to endorse an unpalatable option even though it is clearly to be preferred to an even worse option (Comment, November 7). This is a voter's dilemma typical not only of America. Here in Australia, supporters of minor parties like the Democrats and the Greens are constantly being told by Labor supporters that a vote for such parties is a vote for the Liberals. But democracy gives me a very special right, and that is the right to vote for what I believe is best for the country.

And since we have a preferential voting system which allows me to direct my preferences - if my candidate is not elected - down the line until it plays a role in determining whether a Labor or Liberal candidate is elected, I have the satisfaction of knowing that I have given Labor my support against the Liberals, if they turn out to need it.

James Paterson
Sydney, Australia

Jacob Weisberg (It's sectarian idiocy, November 7) seeks to answer the wrong question. Nader does not want Bush as president - but nor does he want Gore. That is the point of his running. The choice before the American electorate is between two politicians whose allegiance is to their corporate financiers. One of these two will win (has won).

The real question is why does an incumbent vice-president who has presided over an unrivalled economic boom have to worry about a left candidate? The answer is that the benefits of this boom have been almost exclusively delivered to those who were already rich. A great swathe of Nader's votes are likely to have come from those so disillusioned with mainstream politics that they probably wouldn't have voted. Al Gore had eight years as vice-president to deliver real social change for the majority of Americans. He didn't. If he loses (has lost) don't blame Nader. The Clinton/Gore administration made the mistakes, Nader just pointed them out.

Tom McKenna
Leicester

The point of Nader's campaign was to wake voters from their torpor and try to gain the 5% of the vote needed by the Green party to be eligible for federal funds in the next presidential election. Nader's platform is his own, the coherent stance on issues belying a more or less single-minded source, but his attempt to rattle the cage of American politics is in the interest of all US citizens who wish to vote not tactically, but for the candidate they support. Only when the polemics of "either/or" are transcended can we hope to end an exclusive electoral system in which every four years we have idiots in America voting for idiots in America.

Molly Rogers
Coventry

(And yes, I am an American)

Harry Evans is uncharacteristically off beam with his suggestion that the US press is anti-Democrat. This is like accusing the old Pravda of having it in for the politburo (A slavish press connives to hide GW's shady side, November 7).

Quentin Letts
London
quentin.letts@dailymail.co.uk

fields.headline: 'Terror empress' surrenders to police
fields.trailText: After more than 25 years on the run, a founder of the Japanese Red Army, which brought terror to various parts of the world in the 1970s, gave herself up to the police yesterday in western Japan.
fields.body:
After more than 25 years on the run, a founder of the Japanese Red Army, which brought terror to various parts of the world in the 1970s, gave herself up to the police yesterday in western Japan.

Fusako Shigenobu, who is accused of masterminding several hijacks and hostage seizures in a long campaign said to be against capitalism, surrendered to detectives in Takatsuki, near Osaka, outside a hotel where she had checked in disguised as a man.

The national police agency said she had been charged with hostage-taking during the 1974 seizure of the French embassy in the Hague in the Netherlands.

Her arrest was hailed as a triumph of law enforcement. "It's great that a person who has been involved in various terrorist acts since the late 60s has been arrested," the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, said.

Tokyo has been embarrassed on the international stage by the Red Army group, which Ms Shigenobu, a drop-out from the prestigious Meiji University, helped to establish in Lebanon in 1971 with the declared aim of fighting capitalism and the Israeli state - though the extorting of large cash payments also seemed close to its heart.

Even at its peak the group had only 40 members, but it gained worldwide notoriety by acts of terrorism which often forced Japan and other big powers to make concessions.

Its most bloody and indiscriminate assault was the 1972 grenade and gun attack on Tel Aviv's Lod airport, where 26 were killed and 80 injured.

Ms Shigenobu's role in that action is unclear, but she is alleged to have helped to plan the hijacking of two planes and the seizure of two embassies between 1973 and 1977, acts that won the release of several prisoners and cash payments of millions of dollars.

Working from havens in Lebanon, Syria, Libya and North Korea, the group remained active well into the 1980s. But with the end of the cold war many of its former state backers fall away. Its funds dried up, its refuges disappeared, its members aged.

Ms Shigenobu's role in the movement earned her the nickname "the empress" in the 1970s. Her attractive looks and espousal of free love made her the pin-up of Japanese leftwing radicalism.

Now 55, she looked more like a middle-aged housewife yesterday when police officers put her on a bullet train to Tokyo. Even so, she raised her handcuffed wrists to give a thumbs up, shouting: "I'll fight on!"

She is the fourth member of the Red Army arrested this year. In March the police took three into custody at Narita airport, Tokyo after they had been expelled from Lebanon.

The government hopes to extradite several others from North Korea, which is seeking economic aid, and the police agency says Ms Shigenobu may have information on about six still at large in Japan.

Red Army attacks

May 1972: Gun and grenade attack on Tel Aviv's Lod airport: 26 dead, 80 injured

July 1973: Japanese Airlines plane hijacked and forced to fly to Libya; blown up after passengers and crew freed

Jan 1974: Explosion at oil refinery in Singapore

Sept 1974: French embassy in the Hague seized. Red Army escapes to Syria after winning release of prisoners

Aug 1975: Compound of US, Swiss, Japanese and Canadian embassies in Kuala Lumpur seized. Escape to Libya after jailed members are released

Sept 1977: Japan Airlines plane hijacked. Escape after Tokyo agrees to free six prisoners and pay $6m

May 1986: Mortar attack on Japanese, US and Canadian embassies in Jakarta

June 1987: British and US embassies in Rome rocketed

April 1988: US military club in Naples bombed, five dead
