fields.headline: Second sight
fields.trailText: Twenty years on we can see the defects in the Conservatives' formula for privatisation and competition in telecoms - not as bad perhaps as the railways but still serious.
fields.body:
Twenty years on we can see the defects in the Conservatives' formula for privatisation and competition in telecoms - not as bad perhaps as the railways but still serious. I was in charge of the 1969 act that converted the old GPO into a Morrisonian nationalised industry.

The sledgehammer monopoly I was perpetuating on Labour's instructions made me uncomfortable. By 1981 I was managing director of BT's inland operations. The Conservatives' preparations for privatisation made me much more uncomfortable, but there was nothing I could do. I left BT in 1983 but have continued to work in telecoms.

BT's recent tribulations effectively spring from its failure to exploit the hugely growing cash flow and the R&D capability it inherited from the public sector. BT still makes the running in this country and we have fallen behind developed countries in technology and service innovation. The nationalised industry had world-class mileage - Prestel, the forerunner of the internet, was a celebrated example.

Since privatisation, BT has tamely followed where others have led. The reasons are obvious. Just like the railways, short-term stock-market pressures have provided a direct disincentive to investment. The price-cap system used for BT and other utilities was presented as promoting "efficency" while leaving profits unconstrained - an extraordinary kind of regulation.

The real objective was to push up the share price and get Conservative ex-ministers seats on boards. The reduction in BT manpower is held up as proof that the policy of capping price increases works. This is phoney. BT's manpower actually increased to a peak six years after privatisation in 1990.

It then contracted simply because the workload dropped as a result of falling growth and the completion of the modernisation programme of the nationalised industry. And the price cap helped depress investment by putting a premium on minimising capital charges on current account.

The claims for the effects of competition in network telecoms do not stand up either. Oftel recently announced that in a comparison with France, Germany, Sweden, Italy and two US states, British prices for business communications came out unexpectedly high.

Competition from the cable companies can hardly be said to have stimulated BT, for they have been struggling for years, hampered by burdens of idle investment forced on them by Conservative governments obsessed by the idea of infrastructure competition. This business of having competing local telecoms' infrastructures provides a remarkable example of how the Conservatives substitute ideology for industry logic.

The loss of economies of scale due to network duplication is so high and the usage per telephone line so persistently low that even with the extra business from cable TV, the resulting idle capital burden can never be absorbed by operating economies. The cable companies have found this out to their cost.

Radio has come to the rescue of the consumer, but the unnecessary cost of infrastructure competition will dog wire service for a long time. Telecoms is suffering from the same lousy structure created by the Conservatives for the railways.

When they took over in 1979, BT was already too big and diverse to manage properly. I began a subdivision process in 1982, reversed after I left. The stock market wanted a nice big monolith with nice big profit figures. The present wired service set up of rival vertical firms providing networks and services goes back to Alexander Graham Bell.

It is bogging down the internet and new economy in endless squabbles and delays. BT is at last in the mood to subdivide, and should get on with it. How about New Year's Day as a deadline?

This will provide an unrepeatable opportunity to get the structure of the industry right. Oftel is pointing the way. We need to push unbundling to its logical conclusion. We must completely separate services and retailing from network provision and operation. Then it will be necessary to free up all services to deregulated competition; re-unify the wired network infrastructure nationally and hammer out a "third way" ownership formula. If the firms won't co-operate, government should intervene.

 John Harper's book Monopoly And Competition In British Telecommunications is published by Pinters (Cassells)

Competition from the cable companies can hardly be said to have stimulated BT, for they have been struggling for years, hampered by burdens of idle investment forced on them by Conservative governments obsessed by the idea of infrastructure competition. This business of having competing local telecoms' infrastructures provides a remarkable example of how the Conservatives substitute ideology for industry logic. The loss of economies of scale due to network duplication is so high and the usage per telephone line so persistently low that even with the extra business from cable TV, the resulting idle capital burden can never be absorbed by operating economies. The cable companies have found this out to their cost. Radio has come to the rescue of the consumer, but the unnecessary cost of infrastructure competition will dog wire service for a long time. Telecoms is suffering from the same lousy structure created by the Conservatives for the railways. When they took over in 1979, BT was already too big and diverse to manage properly. I began a subdivision process in 1982, reversed after I left. The stock market wanted a nice big monolith with nice big profit figures. The present wired service set up of rival vertical firms providing networks and services goes back to Alexander Graham Bell. It is bogging down the internet and new economy in endless squabbles and delays. BT is at last in the mood to subdivide, and should get on with it. How about New Year's Day as a deadline? This will provide an unrepeatable opportunity to get the structure of the industry right. Oftel is pointing the way. We need to push unbundling to its logical conclusion. We must completely separate services and retailing from network provision and operation. Then it will be necessary to free up all services to deregulated competition; re-unify the wired network infrastructure nationally and hammer out a "third way" ownership formula. If the firms won't co-operate, government should intervene.  John Harper's book Monopoly And Competition In British Telecommunications is published by Pinters (Cassells)

fields.trailText: The Catholic archbishop of Cardiff, the Most Rev John Ward, 71, was in hospital in Cardiff yesterday with deep vein thrombosis.
fields.body:
The Catholic archbishop of Cardiff, the Most Rev John Ward, 71, was in hospital in Cardiff yesterday with deep vein thrombosis.

He was taken to hospital hours after a BBC Panorama programme attacked his conduct in ordaining a priest who turned out to be a paedophile, and the day after, in light of the forthcoming programme, he had apologised to congregations and promised to step aside.

His spokesman said he was having treatment and tests for the blood clotting associated recently with air travel, economy class syndrome.

The archbishop agreed last week, after meeting the papal nuncio in Britain, to the appointment of a co-adjutor, a caretaker bishop to share his duties and replace him on his retirement. Senior church sources said that the move, though not unprecedented, is an indication that the archbishop was being eased out, though the process of appointing the bishop could take up to a year. The nuncio, Archbishop Pablo Puente, is thought to have made known the Pope's displeasure.

Previously Archbishop Ward had brushed aside criticisms he was warned before he ordained Joe Jordan in 1998 that he was a risk to children. A fortnight ago Jordan was jailed for eight years for offences against two boys. The archbishop's previous press officer, Father John Lloyd, was jailed for eight years in 1998 for paedophile offences.

fields.headline: Suitcase linked to Lockerbie
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Lockerbie
Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: An Air Malta employee carried three suitcases aboard a Frankfurt-bound flight on the day of the Lockerbie bombing, the trial at Camp Zeist, Holland, was told yesterday.
fields.body:
An Air Malta employee carried three suitcases aboard a Frankfurt-bound flight on the day of the Lockerbie bombing, the trial at Camp Zeist, Holland, was told yesterday.

One was for him, the second for his girlfriend, and the third was being delivered to an Air Malta colleague in Frankfurt, the judges heard.

A statement from Air Malta cargo manager Saviour Mallia said: "I had collected the suitcase from my colleague's father's house. It contained clothes." He handed it over in Frankfurt.

The trial has already heard that the Lockerbie bomb, a cassette player packed with Semtex, was packed in a suitcase padded with clothing bought in Malta. It was tagged for onward transfer to London Heathrow and New York, aboard Pan Am flight 103.

Evidence from convicted Palestinian terrorist Abu Talb was delayed yesterday for defence inquiries. The judges agreed to apply formally to Syria for a document in connection with the case.

The case, in which two Libyans deny the bombing, continues.

webTitle: Nudist in solitary for two months

fields.headline: Nudist in solitary for two months
fields.standfirst: Special report: deaths in custody
fields.trailText: A man said yesterday he had spent two months in the segregation unit at Brixton prison in south London for refusing to wear clothes.
fields.body:
A man said yesterday he had spent two months in the segregation unit at Brixton prison in south London for refusing to wear clothes.

Vincent Bethell is on remand awaiting a crown court trial date for charges relating to a campaign for the right to nudity, believing "it is not a crime to be human" and hence no crime to be naked.

He said by telephone that he was locked naked in his 11ft by 7ft cell most of the day and night, but was writing a novel and exercising by jogging on the spot. He had no visitors, he said, being kept out of the visitors' centre for fear of offending inmates and visitors, and no outside exercise, for fear he cut his feet.

On arrival, he said, staff had tried to cover him with a bed sheet. "I was immediately labelled 'mad', 'weird' and 'insane' and I had to undergo an intimidating psychiatric assessment. Thankfully I was deemed sane."

He went on: "It is quite grim in the unit. Since I have been here one person committed suicide by hanging himself from his cell window. Another attempted suicide in a most shocking manner - not having anything to slash his wrist with, he bit his wrist out with his teeth."

A prison service spokesman was unable to comment on individual cases, but confirmed that prisoners who refused to conform with dress requirements would be kept in the unit.

webTitle: Mother may have been killed by dog

fields.headline: Mother may have been killed by dog
fields.trailText: A young mother who was feared murdered at her home may have had a fit and been attacked by her pet dobermann, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A young mother who was feared murdered at her home may have had a fit and been attacked by her pet dobermann, it emerged last night.

Kirsty Ross was discovered in a blood-spattered room at her home on Tuesday night and detectives feared she had been killed by a knifeman.

But early indications from a post mortem examination showed that the 25-year-old had wounds on her neck consistent with being bitten by a dog. Police said the final result was not yet known and it was not clear whether Ms Ross was bitten before or after she had a fit.

Police were called to the terraced house in Helston, Cornwall, just before 9.30pm on Tuesday night after she was discovered by a relative.

Her 22-month-old daughter, who was found unharmed on a sofa in the same room, was being looked after by family members last night.

Neighbours had earlier said Ms Ross and her boyfriend had received death threats which arose when her partner's brother became a key witness in a criminal trial.

Detective Superintendent Stuart Newberry, of Devon and Cornwall police, said: "When [the relative] went into the house he called the ambulance but she was already dead."

webTitle: Claim for bullying at school fails

fields.headline: Claim for bullying at school fails
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A teenager yesterday failed to win damages from her education authority, West Sussex county council, for allegedly failing to protect her from bullying.
fields.body:
A teenager yesterday failed to win damages from her education authority, West Sussex county council, for allegedly failing to protect her from bullying.

Leah Bradford-Smart, 19, from Crawley, was seeking £75,000, claiming she had suffered post traumatic stress disorder since being bullied from the age of nine.

In the high court Mr Justice Garland rejected the claim, believed to be one of the first such to reach the courts. In a significant ruling he said education authorities could not be held responsible for bullying that took place off school premises, even on a school bus.

The court had heard how the teenager had apparently been subjected to a campaign of sustained bullying while attending Ifield middle school, Crawley, between September 1990 and July 1993. She told the court that when aged nine bullies had branded her an "exhibitionist" and "prostitute" who "flaunted her body" because another girl had seen her in a paddling pool at home with just her knickers on.

Miss Bradford-Smart claimed to have been chased around the playground, thrown against fences, and on one occasion to have been pushed into the road in front of a car as she waited for the school bus. She said she had pretended to be sick in order to avoid having to go to school.

The council argued that there was very little, if any, sign at the time that she was being bullied, and she and her mother had "greatly exaggerated" how often any such bullying was brought to the school's attention.

Rejecting the claim, the judge refused leave to appeal.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Mario Tennis N64 | Rome: Caesar's Will | FIFA 2001
fields.byline: Greg Howson,  Andy Bodle and Jack Schofield
fields.body:
Mario serves up a ball on court
Mario Tennis N64
£44.99 Camelot/Nintendo ****
OK, it's only a fortnight since the release of Mario Party 2 but, unless you have a serious aversion to lardy plumbers, Mario Tennis is well worth checking out. As expected, it eschews the gorgeous authenticities of Sega's Virtua Tennis and instead offers a typically colourful Nintendo rendition of the racquet sport.

So instead of Henman we get Lugi, Yoshi and Boo, the ghost. Oddly enough, despite the juvenile exterior, Mario Tennis plays a very grown-up game with marvellous subtlety in control and design.

The faintest flick of the joystick can alter the shot, making this a surprisingly skilled undertaking. Not that this should deter newcomers, as Mario Tennis is easy to pick up and play. Initially, it all seems very straightforward as you serve up lengthy rallies and make rapid progression in the tournaments, although it's not too long before it gets tough. But perhaps the most fun to be had is in multiplayer, doubles in particular, which are murderously competitive.

Single players shouldn't worry, though. The key to all Mario games is the sense of progression; there's always something new to discover or unravel. Mario Tennis is no different, with the player encouraged to win tournaments and uncover new courts and characters.

Unfortunately, one of these hard fought finds - the fiery Bowser court - is a disappointment. While playing on a tilting court, simultaneously avoiding shells and lava balls, sounds amusing, the difficulty in following the ball renders it a temporary curiosity at best. Still, the odd dodgy level aside, Mario Tennis has served up another ace for the Nintendo team. (GH)

This Roman scandal is a damp squib
Rome: Caesar's Will
PC CD-rom £29.99 Montparnasse Multimedia **
Ah, simplicity. Gone are the days when videogames were plug and play, when you could just boot up and start shooting, with nary a peep at the manual (if there was one at all).

But hold, what's this? Why, a simple, modest game with the flimsiest of instruction leaflets, a concise intro, and a stress-free interface that lets you dive right into the action.

But mind your head - this action pool is pretty darned shallow. You are Hercules, an investigator in Rome in 44BC. Caesar is still warm in his grave, but don't worry, they know who did that. The case at hand is the poisoning of a certain Titinius.

Prime suspect is his wife, Aurelia; you know she's innocent, but unless you can track down who really dunnit in 30 days, she's for the chop.

Play basically involves stumping round 16 different locations in the city, picking up everything you find in the hope that it will eventually become useful, and interrogating everyone in sight.

The only real choice comes in the three modes of dialogue with which you can choose to approach people.

So, no gore, no laughs, nothing terribly strategically challenging, and not even any pretty pictures to look at. The graphics are low-resolution, low-definition, low-fidelity. There are even clipping problems (remember the days when you could give monsters a high-five through the wall?).

But the voice acting is surprisingly decent. The programmers have tried to make their reconstruction of Rome accurate, and the AI is probably highly advanced - characters' attitudes towards you evolve according to previous conversations. There's also plenty of fascinating info to be had on togas and latifundia and such. But even the educational value is questionable - Cleopatra, for example, is described as "son of the king of Egypt Ptolemy XII".

If this is Montparnasse's idea of making learning fun, I'd hate to sit one of their AS level papers. (AB)

Same old game needs a good kick
FIFA 2001

Sony PlayStation £29.99 EA Sports ***
Every year, this is the UK's best-selling game, but it is getting increasingly hard to understand why.

This does not mean there is anything wrong with Fifa 2001. The problem is that it is pretty much the same as Fifa 2000, which wasn't all that big an improvement on Fifa 1999.

In fact, the most novel thing about the latest version is the powerful smell of turf you get from the scratch and sniff disc.

Turn to the packaging for help and you'll find that EA's first puff says: "Play more strategic football with the new default camera angle."

It is true, too. Fifa 2001 provides a slightly more distant view, and when you can see other players, you are more likely to pass to them.

It also makes the players a bit less detailed, but that hardly matters. Graphics junkies gave up on the PlayStation years ago.

Of course, you also get updated leagues and teams for 2001. I would have thought this was not as important in an action game as it is in more cerebral, stats-oriented foot ball management games, but this Christmas, more than 400,000 British Fifa fans could well prove me wrong. In fact, the people in EA's accounts department are probably banking on it. (JS)

webTitle: EU draws in its horns on expansion

fields.headline: EU draws in its horns on expansion
fields.standfirst:
Brussels praises reforms in east but will not open the door early to hasten membership talks

Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: The European Commission showed marked caution about extending EU boundaries eastwards when it issued its annual report yesterday on the enlargement process.
fields.body:
The European Commission showed marked caution about extending EU boundaries eastwards when it issued its annual report yesterday on the enlargement process.

Its failure to advance the target date reflected concern that the union's existing citizens show scant enthusiasm for bringing in the former communist countries.

The report points to "remarkable progress" in the performance of most of the aspiring member states, but says that Turkey still fails to meet the basic criteria in respect of its human rights record and its treatment of its Kurdish population.

Günter Verheugen, the commissioner in charge of enlargement, said the union would "be in a position to welcome new members" from the end of 2002. But he failed to dispel the growing conviction that newcomers will not in fact be admitted much before 2005.

Jacek Saryusz-Wolski, the Polish minister for European affairs, told the Guardian last night: "We still expect negotiations can be closed in 2001."

Enlargement is the union's biggest single challenge aside from the workings of the single currency, aimed at nothing less than the economic and political reunification of the continent after the divisions of the communist era.

But the commission president, Romano Prodi, alluded clearly to the lack of enthusiasm for the project in the current 15 member states, as repeatedly highlighted in recent opinion polls.

In France and Germany, the two biggest members, only 21% of those polled by Eurobarometer consider enlargement a priority. The average in the union is 27%.

"Negotiations are not everything," Mr Prodi said. "We need democratic support. The citizens of the European Union need to be convinced of the benefits of enlargement. So do the citizens of the candidate countries."

Mr Verheugen was even blunter: "Enlargement can only succeed if it is a social project involving all citizens and not just an elite."

Britain, which is championing the process and has pressed in vain for a firm target date for ending the accession talks, welcomed the report.

In Warsaw last month, Tony Blair said he wanted the first newcomers in by 2004.

Negotiations began with Poland, Hungary, Cyprus, Estonia, Slovenia and the Czech Republic in 1998, and were extended to Bulgaria, Romania, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta and Slovakia in January.

Mr Verheugen told MEPs in Brussels that advances made in the individual countries showed that reforms enacted by these prospective members were paying off. But more delays could lessen the support for membership in candidate countries, he said.

In Poland, the biggest and most important of them, an anti-Brussels backlash was already evident.

The report shows that many of the candidates have met the EU's requirements - the Copenhagen criteria - on human rights, the rule of law and democracy. But Turkey, not yet a formal candidate and still the most controversial, does not, largely because its treatment of the Kurds.

The report highlights continuing concern about corruption as elites in candidate states come to terms with free-market economies.

It says that Poland, Hungary, Estonia and the Czech Republic seem likely to meet the economic criteria "in the near future". Cyprus and Malta have already done so. But it expresses concern about continuing high unemployment.

The next steps to enlargement are supposed to be decided at the EU summit in Nice next month.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Crook, Co. Durham
fields.trailText: Crook, Co. Durham
fields.body:
It's that time of year when large intimidating spiders appear indoors, driven to find shelter from sharp frosts and - lately - from torrential downpours. Three times in the last week I've woken to find alarmingly large specimens staring down at me from the ceiling.

They've joined the lacewings, ladybirds, a small tortoiseshell butterfly and an angleshades moth that will spend the winter hidden safely behind bookcases and picture frames.

Generally I'm happy to share the house with these refugees from the cold, but I'm less enthusiastic about the queen wasp that chose the thumb of my gardening gloves as a hibernation site - an agonising discovery. Insects that hibernate like this - in the adult state - are in the minority; most spend the winter as larvae or pupae, often inside dead plants.

Two months ago our local road verges were thick with purple flower heads of knapweed. Now they've run to seed, but most are home to the grubs of picture-wing flies - tiny flies that rest on leaves on hot summer afternoons, rhythmically raising and lowering their wings.

The test for the presence of picture-wing fly grubs is simple - just squeeze the knapweed seed head. Knapweed's other common name is hardheads, but some of its seedheads feel harder than others.

These contain picture-wing fly larvae, fat on knapweed seeds and secure inside a woody gall that they've induced the plant to produce at the base of its florets. Most other seed heads of the daisy family, including thistles and burdock, provide similar shelter for insect larvae through the winter.

Three times in the last week I've woken to find alarmingly large specimens staring down at me from the ceiling. They've joined the lacewings, ladybirds, a small tortoiseshell butterfly and an angleshades moth that will spend the winter hidden safely behind bookcases and picture frames. Generally I'm happy to share the house with these refugees from the cold, but I'm less enthusiastic about the queen wasp that chose the thumb of my gardening gloves as a hibernation site - an agonising discovery. Insects that hibernate like this - in the adult state - are in the minority; most spend the winter as larvae or pupae, often inside dead plants. Two months ago our local road verges were thick with purple flower heads of knapweed. Now they've run to seed, but most are home to the grubs of picture-wing flies - tiny flies that rest on leaves on hot summer afternoons, rhythmically raising and lowering their wings. The test for the presence of picture-wing fly grubs is simple - just squeeze the knapweed seed head. Knapweed's other common name is hardheads, but some of its seedheads feel harder than others. fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | In Business
fields.body:
A decade after the summary execution of Nicolae Ceaucescu, the traditions that the Romanian dictator implanted in his police force survive. Max Easterman has been investigating their behaviour for Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4), with the help of a dissident former officer. Adrian Pitu enrolled in the rosy afterglow of the revolution and rose steadily through the ranks. This promotion gave him an ever wider view of the force's continuing brutality and corruption.

Hans Moravec has been building robots since childhood and is still at it 40 years later. Peter Day met him at the Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh to hear his vision of what we can expect by 2050. Moravec tells In Business (8.30pm, Radio 4) that computers will by then be as smart as humans and deployed accordingly. It's a prospect that Bill Joy, chief scientist for Sun Microsystems, regards with horror. He thinks we should consider far more deeply where such research may lead.

fields.headline: Prudence rules in battle to placate critics
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Short of feeding bread to the ducks in the park and brandishing aloft the red box in Downing Street, there's now not a lot of difference between the pre-Budget report in the autumn and the real thing in the spring. It's only the fact that the term mini-Budget still conjures up memories of crisis management in the past that prevents yesterday's statement from being called by its real name.
fields.body:
Short of feeding bread to the ducks in the park and brandishing aloft the red box in Downing Street, there's now not a lot of difference between the pre-Budget report in the autumn and the real thing in the spring. It's only the fact that the term mini-Budget still conjures up memories of crisis management in the past that prevents yesterday's statement from being called by its real name.

Naturally, Gordon Brown paid lip service to the idea that the PBR was all about consultation, but everything about the occasion - the sense of theatre, the scope of the announcements and the small forest that had to be chopped down to produce the accompanying documentation - meant that this was a day when real decisions were taken and real cash spent.

As ever, the chancellor announced a dizzying array of micro-measures - tax credits, minimum income guarantees, cheques for headteachers. But the mini-Budget was really about the five Ps - prudence, productivity, pensions, petrol and politics.

According to legend, Mary Tudor was supposed to have had the word Calais engraved on her heart at her death. In Brown's case it would be prudence, since he has an almost preternatural fear of the economy re-entering a period of boom-bust. So, while there was an extra £2.6bn in spending for next year and almost £4bn in each of the following two years, the Treasury will be reaping more than that in higher tax receipts.

The spectacular improvement in the public finances means that both Labour's fiscal rules will be comfortably met. There is no question of the government having to borrow to finance current spending now or at any time in the immediate future, while the ratio of debt to GDP is falling like a stone.

Pet obsessions

Indeed, so prudent has Mr Brown been that the tax take as a proportion of GDP will be considerably higher at the next election than it was in 1997.

Productivity is another of the chancellor's pet obsessions. Like Nigel Lawson before him, he is a genuine supply-sider, believing that only by reforms of labour, product and capital markets can Britain close the productivity gap with the US. As such, the parts of the PBR that for most people went in one ear and out the other were the parts that really excited Brown. There were proposals for changes to corporate taxation, simplification of VAT, an extension of tax breaks for research and development, tax relief for share options, incentives to boost investment in the inner cities, plans for a shake-up of the way the City works. Measures such as these will take years, even decades, to work but ultimately may prove to be the most important slice of the package.

That said, today's headlines will be dominated by what the chancellor offered to the elderly and truckers. The government's problems with petrol and pensioners are an indication of how Brown's focus on long-term issues left him oblivious to short-term pressures building up around him. Labour's approach to pensions - and to the welfare state more generally - has been to move away from universality and to extend means testing. The theory was that help would be targeted at the neediest through the minimum income guarantee, with the basic pension raised in line with the increase in inflation. But last year inflation was running at 1.1% and the pension went up by 75 pence a week.

Universal benefits

The resulting backlash explains the generosity of yesterday's package, a melange of universal benefits and means testing. As such there were big increases in the state pension together with a £200 "winter warmer" to every household, but also a hefty rise in the minimum income guarantee and plans for a pensioner tax credit aimed at those ineligible for income support but living not far above the poverty line.

Brown was caught unawares by the scale of the fuel protest, particularly since he had abandoned the automatic excise duty escalator in the Budget in March. Up until then, higher fuel duties had been seen as a win-win play, providing revenue to cut the budget deficit inherited by Labour while also being environmentally-friendly.

Yesterday's package offered more concessions to the protesters than had been suggested but probably not enough to placate the hard-liners. But the real point was to sever the link between militant truckers and ordinary motorists, who were wooed with lower vehicle excise duty and cheaper ultra-low sulphur petrol.

Whether Brown has done enough to placate his critics remains to be seen. What is clear, however, is that this was a package with an election in mind. With polling day perhaps less than six months away, the mini-Budget was really about fighting fires while leaving something in the bank for tax cuts in the spring. The fifth P - politics - was the most important of the lot.

The speech in full
Part 1: the economy
Part 2: the fiscal stance
Part 3: families and pensioners

webTitle: Flying in to Florida: the candidates' men

fields.headline: Flying in to Florida: the candidates' men
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: James Baker
fields.body:
James Baker

George W Bush's choice to represent his interests in the supervision of the Florida recount is a longtime, though not always wholly trusted, counsellor of the Bush family.

Another Texan, Mr Baker was treasury secretary in Ronald Reagan's second administration before becoming secretary of state for most of the presidency of George Bush Sr between 1989 and 92, a period which included the collapse of communism in Europe and the Gulf war.

He was compelled against his will to become President Bush's campaign organiser for his re-election effort against Bill Clinton in 1992. He was widely blamed for a lacklustre performance.

His re-emergence in a heavyweight role at such a delicate time suggests that Mr Baker may play a part in a new Bush administration.

Warren Christopher

Al Gore has entrusted his 11th hour battle for the presidency to one of his most trusted advisers, who always seems to pop up when key decisions need to be taken.

The 75-year-old veteran lawyer and political insider headed a Lyndon Johnson era inquiry into the Watts riots in Los Angeles in 1965 before serving as deputy secretary of state in charge of human rights policy under Jimmy Carter.

Mr Christopher was the surprise choice to be Bill Clinton's secretary of state in his first presidential term. He did the job for four years, a period dominated by the beginnings of the Middle East peace process and by crisis in the Balkans. He played a key role earlier this year when Mr Gore asked him to select a shortlist of potential vice-presidential nominees.

fields.headline: Economy shaping up well for the election
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's economy is expected to be in good shape in 2001, the year widely tipped to see the next general election.
fields.body:
Britain's economy is expected to be in good shape in 2001, the year widely tipped to see the next general election.

Though economic growth and household consumption will be slightly lower than this year' s figures of 3% and 3.5% - the easing will be modest while inflation is expected to be bang on target, according to Gordon Brown.

Even Britain's hard pressed manufacturing industry is on the road to modest recovery though still lagging the more buoyant services sector.

Despite higher oil prices and exchange rate uncertainty the chancellor argues that the government has set the framework in place for sustainable improvement.

Manufacturing output, which stagnated last year, is set to grow by 1.25% this year and then accelerate to up to 2.25% growth in 2001, with further, if slower growth in the following two years.

In the pre-Budget report Mr Brown forecast that, after hitting 3% this year, gross domestic product should increase by between 2.25% and 2.75% in each of the next three years.

That slight easing in the pace of growth should be enough to keep the economy on track to hit the inflation target over the medium term, according to the treasury but will not, however, be enough to prevent the economy from hitting Mr Brown's previous projections that it will pass the £1,000bn mark in 2002.

Overall the chancellor is relaxed in his assessment of the economic outlook. Growth in household spending is expected to slow but will be underpinned by a pick-up in government consumption which is expected to rise by 4% in each of the next two years.

Though the forecasts for the performance of the economy have not taken into account the impact of September's fuel protests, the pre-Budget report states that they "appear to have been modest at the whole economy level".

The economy is operating above its potential at present with the output gap estimated to have risen to around 0.5% . Mr Brown and his Treasury team, however, reckon the economy can sustain strong output growth for the time being, but note the warning from the Bank of England's monetary policy committee that it is important growth in aggregate demand does not outpace potential output growth for too long. In fact the Treasury is forecasting that demand and output will slip back below trend rates in 2001.

The treasury shows some concern about the tightness of the labour market, noting that the challenge ahead is in expanding the effective supply of labour sufficiently to allow the economy to expand without running into skill shortages and associated cost pressures.

However it believes that, though underlying earnings are growing at 4.1%, the increase can be sustained with out triggering inflation, because of productivity increases of around 2% a year.

Mr Brown is predicting business investment to increase by between 2.25% and 2.75% by 2002, with spending as a proportion of GDP predicted to remain close to its recent record high.

Nor is the chancellor ruling out a further push from spending on information and communications technology as firms roll out e-commerce strategies.

The pre-Budget report shrugs of comparisons between the run down in the household savings ratio - from 10% in the mid-1990s to 5% last year and 3% in the second quarter of this year with a similar fall in the days of boom-and-bust in the late 1980s, citing "structural and cyclical" differences.

In addition increases in interest rates since the second half of last year are expected to restrain gross borrowing while the government is taking measures to boost savings. As a result the savings ratio is expected to recover gradually though the report notes that "any further weakening would pose risks to the economic outlook".

Mr Brown is expecting that the balance of payments position this year will improve on his Budget forecast. Then he was predicting Britain's trade imbalance would be the equivalent of some 2.25% of GDP, but the deficit has now been cut to 1.5%.

fields.headline: Brown tries to be prudent and political
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Budget Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The parallels between the electoral cliffhanger in Florida and Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report are clear. The proposals announced yesterday were driven by electoral rather than economic balancing. In Britain, as in Florida, the over-55s have numbers on their side. They account for half our electorate, and they are more likely than younger people to turn out to vote. In Britain, as in Florida, the state retirement pension and health care are key issues for older voters. But the health service and the state retirement pension are paid for by younger people who have jobs and cars, and they look to the government to deliver tax cuts, whether on their incomes or their fuel.
fields.body:
The parallels between the electoral cliffhanger in Florida and Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report are clear. The proposals announced yesterday were driven by electoral rather than economic balancing. In Britain, as in Florida, the over-55s have numbers on their side. They account for half our electorate, and they are more likely than younger people to turn out to vote. In Britain, as in Florida, the state retirement pension and health care are key issues for older voters. But the health service and the state retirement pension are paid for by younger people who have jobs and cars, and they look to the government to deliver tax cuts, whether on their incomes or their fuel.

This was a report aimed above all at pensioners, but also at road hauliers, working families and motorists. There was also good news for schools, small businesses, depressed areas, churches and campaigners against world poverty. The main reason why the chancellor's trade-offs are political rather than economic is that the economy is exceptionally healthy, following nearly eight years of continuous growth. Furthermore, the outlook remains promising. It has been possible simultaneously to tighten the overall fiscal stance, make large inroads into the national debt, cut some taxes and increase pension spending.

Gordon Brown would have regarded the restraint he has made his colleagues show over the last few years as wasted if he had been obliged to respond to the pressures to give away more of his projected £16bn surplus. If it is right to run deficits during recessions, it is right to run surpluses during booms. The deluge of the last two weeks will have served to remind the ever prudent chancellor that a rainy day will come along sooner or later. Having secured what appears to be a stable low-inflation environment for the first time since the 1973 oil price rises, he was not going to risk it by injecting a large and sudden increase in purchasing power.

What is perhaps the most impressive thing about this report is that it appears to be more generous than it is. By responding to the concerns of the citizen as motorist, by cutting fuel duty for low-sulphur petrol and diesel and vehicle excise duty for small family cars (those between 1200 and 1500cc) the chancellor appears to be flexible and generous. But to the citizen as drinker, income tax or VAT payer there was no hint of relief. The political impetus to deliver now on a single key tax issue enabled him to avoid the potentially much bigger and more expensive challenge of universal tax cuts.

Moreover, even the generosity to pensioners is not what it seems. Next April and the one after there will be pension increases which are large by the standards of recent years. These are well above the likely increase in prices and earnings but future upratings of the basic state pension will continue to be made in line with prices.

There are two reasons for this. The first, as pointed out by the chancellor, is that a growing proportion of pensioners have incomes above £20,000 a year, about the level of average earnings. Restoring the earnings link would benefit this group as well as middle-income pensioners. Lower income pensioners would not benefit at all, since the increase would be offset by a reduction in means-tested benefits under the minimum income guarantee.

The second reason is cost. The restoration of the earnings link has been estimated by the National Institute of Economic and Social Research to be the equivalent of an increase of 5p on income tax. Moreover, with a growing population of pensioners, the long-term financial commitment would be too great for any government to contemplate. The move from 2003 towards a system of support for older people - the pensioner tax credit - is designed to enable future governments to confine their generosity to middle and lower income pensioners. This is likely to lead to continuing erosion of the value of the basic state pension compared with an earnings-linked scheme.

Overall, in terms of their economic impact, the plans outlined were entirely responsible. If they can also deliver for the government the support of motorists and pensioners, they will have achieved their true purpose.

Pamela Meadows is a visiting fellow at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research

webTitle: Pre-Budget statement: Giveaway holds back best for later

fields.headline: Giveaway holds back best for later
fields.standfirst:
 'All the groups have got something'
 Nothing to worry the Bank of England
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown set the stage for modest pre-election tax cuts by maintaining an ultra-cautious approach to managing the public finances. Although the giveaway was bigger than expected, the chancellor kept a tight rein on the purse strings and appears to have kept plenty in reserve for next March's Budget, said City analysts.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown set the stage for modest pre-election tax cuts by maintaining an ultra-cautious approach to managing the public finances. Although the giveaway was bigger than expected, the chancellor kept a tight rein on the purse strings and appears to have kept plenty in reserve for next March's Budget, said City analysts.

The package of measures announced yesterday will initially cost £720m this year, rising to £2.6bn next year and £4bn in 2002-03, though cuts in duty on clean fuel and reductions in vehicle excise duty will eventually cost the exchequer another £1.75bn.

However, the chancellor has not yet redistributed substantial savings from rapidly falling unemployment and debt interest payments and economists said his forecast for tax revenues was still on the conservative side, leaving ample room for manoeuvre in the run up to polling day.

Despite yesterday's giveaway, the fiscal stance is forecast to be marginally tighter than predicted at the time of last March's Budget.

Instead of a surplus of £6bn in 2000-01, the chancellor has pencilled in one of £10bn. The City had expected a figure nearer £15bn.

For 2001-02, the surplus is estimated to be £6bn, £1bn higher than forecast in March, and the deficits in subsequent years are all predicted to be slightly smaller. The improved outlook for the public finances mainly reflects the buoyancy of tax receipts, which the Treasury estimates will be more than £4bn ahead of March's prediction, covering the initial cost of yesterday's giveaway.

Money has been put aside for the additional costs of the proposed transport measures, still subject to consultation.

While acknowledging that income tax, national insurance contributions and North Sea revenue will all be ahead of expectations, the Treasury reckons that corporation and capital gains tax will yield less.

But analysts said that by erring on the side of caution the chancellor could be pleasantly surprised by the amount of money at his disposal in the spring.

"They still look quite cautious on tax receipts... there is a lot of uncertainy and they could easily come in stronger," said David Walton, senior economist at Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank.

The Treasury suspects that the switch to a new system of quartlery instead of annual corporation tax payments artifically boosted revenue in the first half of the year. It is anxious not to make a mistake of assuming the gains are permanent.

"I think he is being a little cautious on next year's fore cast for the surplus, which is appreciably below the market forecast but I think that just reflects the normal Treasury caution," said Mark Ramsden, of Stone & McCarthy.

With the fiscal stance remaining tight, few economists expected the Bank of England to react by raising interest rates at the end of its monthly meeting today.

Jonathan Loynes, of the consultancy Capital Economics, said: "He seems to have done virtually everything that people were hoping for. All of the various groups - pensioners, drivers and road hauliers - seem to have got something. But the beauty is that he has kept the projected path for borrowing as it was in the Budget, if not slightly tighter.

"So I don't think there will be any costs in terms of higher interest rates. We've been of the view for some time now that rates have peaked at 6% and I would stick by that. The fact that the fiscal stance is at least as tight or if not tighter than was projected in the Budget means that the monteray policy committee won't have anything to be concerned about on the inflation front."

Both of Mr Brown's fiscal rules - keep the debt to GDP ratio stable below 40% and borrow only to invest - are met with ease.

fields.headline: Thumbs up from Square Mile
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's widely trailed pre-Budget measures created few ripples in London financial markets with dealers more concerned with the outcome of the presidential election in the United States.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's widely trailed pre-Budget measures created few ripples in London financial markets with dealers more concerned with the outcome of the presidential election in the United States.

The release earlier in the day of the Myners review into institutional investment, which is likely to have implications for the gilts markets, was another distraction.

Brian Hilliard, chief UK economist at Société Générale, said there was little by way of surprise in the speech but said that it was well received.

"I think the markets will be happy with it," he said.

Nick Parson, currency analyst at Commerzbank in London said the general response was one of "grudging respect".

"I think he has done enough to buy off the fuel protesters without jeopardising the public finances," he said.

Mr Parsons said the "really killer numbers" were the debt to GDP ratios - falling to 32.3% this year and to 30.9% in 2001-02. It would be hard to accuse the chancellor of fiscal irresponsibility, he said.

In the City the main FTSE 100 index - which had been some 1.5 points ahead when the chancellor began his speech - closed the day 10.5 points higher at 6,477.4.

The pound was trading at around $1.415 and at 60p to the euro on foreign exchange markets last night, little changed on the pre-Budget speech.

"There are no particular surprises. It is largely neutral and the concessions are within the parameters expected," said Jane Foley, currency strategist at Barclays Capital.

"A rate hike is largely off the agenda and certainly the report has not changed the consensus for the monetary policy committee. There is little for sterling to get excited about and it will carry on taking its primary impetus from the euro-dollar."

Jeremy Batstone, head of research at NatWest Stockbrokers, took a similar view, arguing there was nothing in the report that would lead the Bank of England to raise interest from their current level of 6% when the monetary policy committee meets today.

"Eddie George, Bank of England governor, and his cohorts at the Bank of England will be pretty pleased," he said.

Mark Miller at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter agreed there was little in Mr Brown's statement to put pressure on the monetary policy committee to raise rates.

The speech in full
Part 1: the economy
Part 2: the fiscal stance
Part 3: families and pensioners

fields.headline: Small businesses offered flat-rate
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The smallest businesses will be able to calculate their VAT in a new way, which tax experts say should free up the administrative burden they face.
fields.body:
The smallest businesses will be able to calculate their VAT in a new way, which tax experts say should free up the administrative burden they face.

Under a package of measures designed to "ease the impact of VAT" on small businesses, Gordon Brown said he would consult about a "flat rate scheme" for businesses with a turnover of under £100,000.

Richard Watson, VAT partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers, described the proposal as a "real step change." Instead of having to add up all VAT liabilities and credits separately, small firms would be able to calculate their liabilities as a percentage of turnover.

Mr Watson said that, while this might involve a higher tax charge for some businesses, because the scheme appeared to be voluntary those companies which might be hit would be able to stick with their current method of paying VAT.

In his statement the chancellor said he wanted to generate the same amount of VAT payable but simplify the process, although he stressed the scheme was open to consultation.

Other measures proposed by Mr Brown to reduce VAT administration involved include extending the cash accounting scheme to another 40,000 traders by raising the turnover limit from £350,000 to £600,000. Under this scheme, traders are charged tax on money they receive rather than invoices they issue.

The chancellor also intends to allow at least 100,000 more businesses to file their VAT returns on an annual rather than quarterly basis.

He claimed that the VAT threshold would remain the highest in Europe as a result of increasing the limit in line with inflation. This would allow another 8,000 business to operate without charging VAT to customers.

The government also aims to offer better advice to small businesses by setting up a national centre for their general inquiries.

webTitle: Intensive farming blamed for swollen rivers

fields.headline: Intensive farming blamed for swollen rivers
fields.standfirst:
New methods 'increase water run-offs'
Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Farmers, green groups, academics and the environment agency waded deeper into the flood debate yesterday - pinning much of the damage of the past few weeks on intensive farming and offering new ideas on how to avoid the same problems happening again.
fields.body:
Farmers, green groups, academics and the environment agency waded deeper into the flood debate yesterday - pinning much of the damage of the past few weeks on intensive farming and offering new ideas on how to avoid the same problems happening again.

"Since the second world war farmers have moved to sowing crops in the autumn, not the spring," said Geoff Mance, director of water management at the environment agency.

"This increases yields but also means that rain can no longer collect in furrows and filter into the ground. Instead it runs off the surface, increasing the speed in which rain reaches rivers and causes floods."

Studies on small river catchment areas, he said, had shown that the run-off of water from farmland had caused 15-20% increases in peak river flows. Planners "must consider the future impact of their decisions on land use".

Soil scientists at the land research centre at Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, yesterday called for urgent investment in flood prevention by changes in land use.

"As farming has become more specialised and practices like manuring have gone, so the level of organic matter in the soil has decreased," said Dick Thompson, a development officer.

"That causes a hard cap to form on soil, which prevents water from seeping into the ground. If we can control water before it reaches rivers we will have a chance of success against the floods."

The National Farmers Union, which has 120,000 members, denied that farmers were the cause of the floods but admitted that land use practices influenced flooding. "Once the ground is saturated water will run off irrespective of land use," said Jacob Tompkins, environment policy adviser at the NFU.

The union is now working with the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, the Wildlife Trusts, the environment agency, the countryside agency, and the Ministry of Agriculture to explore ways in which water can be held on the land, using "soft" flood defences, rather than trying to stop water from entering communities with "hard" building works.

The idea being developed is to promote a "virtuous ecological circle". If river systems were left more natural, and wetlands and reed beds were restored, this would not only improve wildlife habitats but also delay the peaks of flooding and help to recharge water aquifers for later in the year when water is scarce.

It would also, said Mr Tomkins, help to reduce pollution.

fields.headline: Is this the president?
fields.standfirst:  Recount in Florida amid accusations of dirty tricks :    Gore camp considers Supreme Court challenge :    Democrats get popular vote but Bush claims win
fields.trailText: Americans awake today still not knowing the identity of their next president and facing the possibility that Al Gore, who won most votes in Tuesday's election, will mount a supreme court challenge if the White House is awarded to George W Bush.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and  Duncan Campbell in Nashville
fields.body:
Americans awake today still not knowing the identity of their next president and facing the possibility that Al Gore, who won most votes in Tuesday's election, will mount a supreme court challenge if the White House is awarded to George W Bush.

Officials in Florida expect to complete the recount of their state's 6m votes by 5pm local time today, a task which will allow either Mr Bush or Mr Gore to lay claim to the most powerful elective office on the planet.

Until that happens, America's vaunted electoral and constitutional system is in a state of suspended animation, with both of the presidential candidates stranded just short of the 270 electoral college votes that are required to win the White House.

Mr Gore has captured 260 electoral college votes so far, with Mr Bush on 246 votes. Florida's winner-take-all 25 votes would take either man past the winning post, even though Oregon's seven votes remain undecided.

Mr Gore held a 250,000 vote lead in the popular vote across the country. If Mr Bush becomes president it would be the first time since 1888 that the candidate who attracted most popular support had failed to become president - and the first time since women and black Americans won the right to vote.

Gore officials said that discussions have been under way for several weeks within their office about the country's peculiar electoral college system.

"It is constitutional hot water," said a member of the team. "There is obviously concern that you could have a situation where someone wins the popular vote but loses in a state where that has taken place," a Gore official said yesterday.

The decision to recount in Florida followed the completion of a first count which showed Mr Bush only 1,655 votes ahead.

Both sides dispatched heavyweight teams of officials to Florida to observe the conduct of the recount, which is being watched with amazement not just by Americans but by political leaders and television viewers around the globe.

Mr Bush sent his father's former secretary of state, James Baker, while Mr Gore countered with another former holder of the same office, Warren Christopher, backed up by a 17-strong team of lawyers in Washington.

Dramatic as the contest in Florida already is in the light of the recount, even this could be eclipsed if Mr Gore decides to launch a separate court challenge against alleged irregularities in the Florida election.

The most prominent allegation being made yesterday was that hundreds of voters in Palm Beach county were issued with unorthodox ballot papers which meant they inadvertently voted for the conservative Pat Buchanan.

The Rev Jesse Jackson also alleged that many Haitian Americans were denied their right to vote in neighbouring Broward county.

There was a "bad smell" about the election result in Florida, Mr Jackson said, adding that foreign observers should be invited in to watch the count.

Last night he and members of his Rainbow Coalition were organising a church meeting of voters in disputed precincts in the state.

Mr Bush made a single public appearance with his running-mate, Dick Cheney, outside the Texas governor's mansion yesterday in which he did everything that he could to present himself as the president-in-waiting, ready to claim the office as soon as today's recount had been completed.

"This morning brings news from Florida that the final vote count there shows that Secretary Cheney and I have carried the state of Florida," Mr Bush began. "And if that result is confirmed in an automatic recount, as we expect it will be, we have won the election."

"America has a long tradition of uniting once elections are over," Mr Bush continued. "Secretary Cheney and I will do everything in our power to unite the nation, to call upon the best, to bring people together after one of the most exciting elections in our nation's history."

The statesmanlike words masked one of the most pulsating and nerve-wracking election nights in American history, in which Mr Gore had already telephoned Mr Bush in Austin to concede the election before he was told of the Florida recount.

He then called Mr Bush a second time to retract his concession.

It was a night in which Mr Gore turned the tables on the late opinion polls by coming out ahead of Mr Bush in the popular vote, with 49% of the vote to Mr Bush's 48%, a margin of around 250,000 votes in a total national poll of 100m. The Green candidate, Ralph Nader, took 3%.

If Mr Bush is confirmed as president it will cap a hat trick night for the Republicans, in which they just held on to the House of Representatives in spite of two Democrat gains, and in which they also retained control of the Senate by a whisker, in spite of a succession of losses.

The dramatic decision to order a recount in Florida came in the early hours of yesterday morning and was the climax of an extraordinary night of changing fortunes for both camps.

Within an hour of the close of polls in Florida, the US television networks had called the state for Mr Gore. Two hours later, following a tirade from Austin, the networks put Florida back in the toss-up category where it still remains today.

The outcome in Oregon, where all the votes are cast by post, remained in doubt last night as counting continued there.

Mr Bush's campaign also refused to concede that they had lost in New Mexico, saying that the postal vote there could swing the state back to them at the last minute.

Turnout in the election was 51%, a slight increase on the 1996 figure of 49%, which was an all-time record low for a presidential election.

fields.headline: Region by region floods and travel disruption
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the weather
Special report: transport in Britain
More about transport
fields.trailText: Yorkshire
fields.body:
Yorkshire

Floods Severe flood warnings on the Derwent, Elvington to Barmby, Malton and Norton. Severe flood warnings on the Ouse at Naburn and Ancaster Malbis, from Barlby to Selby. On the Aire, Gowdall (East Yorkshire) and Kellington. Also on the Don at Doncaster, Fishlake and Kirk Bramham. More than 2,000 people evacuated from homes stayed in rescue centres overnight.

Rail Flooding and landslides have forced the closure of train lines from York to Scarborough and Church Fenton, Leeds to Shipley, Sheffield to Chesterfield, Goole to Knottingley and at Selby.

Roads A19 at Selby closed at tollbridge. A6102 Manchester Road closed. A638 closed between Ackworth, West Yorkshire, and the junction with the A628 at Budsworth.

NW and Wales

Floods Severe flood warning put in place on the Lower Dee at Wrexham. No evacuations.

Rail Train line closed Huyton to Liverpool.

Roads A55 Gwynedd down to one lane between Llanfairfechan and Bangor services. A541 in Flintshire closed at Pontblyddyn.

North-east

Floods Severe flood warning on river Wear at Chester-le-Street. No evacuations reported.

Rail No trains running between Newcastle and London on the East Coast mainline. Line closed between Newcastle and Carlisle.

Roads Roads reopening across parts of Northumberland, Co Durham and east Cleveland, the areas worst affected.

Midlands

Floods Stafford town centre was flooded, and on the river Severn severe flood warnings were in place from Shrewsbury in Shropshire to Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, while levels were high in Worcester and rising at Upton upon Severn. 40 people were moved to temporary accommodation in Burton-on-Trent, Staffs. Most were allowed home later.

Rail All six rail routes into Derby and four out of five routes into Nottingham blocked. Midland mainline trains between Sheffield and London St Pancras cancelled, affecting services in Leicestershire, Northamptonshire and Bedfordshire.

Roads A38 between Weeford and Burton-upon-Trent, Staffs, closed northbound. A5132 Willington to Swarkestone closed.

SE and East Anglia

Floods Severe flood warning on the river Thames between Teddington and Shepperton in Surrey. Waters were beginning to threaten Hampton Court Palace. The river burst its banks at Maidenhead in Berkshire. Two severe flood warnings in Surrey after the river Wey burst its banks, putting Guildford and Weybridge at risk. Severe flood warnings on the river Arun in West Sussex, the Tiese, and the Medway in Kent. About 150 residents of Trowlock Island, near Teddington, evacuated.

Rail London to Brighton line blocked for the second day running.

Roads A329 in Reading, Berkshire, closed at Loddon Bridge roundabout. A129 Mountnessing road closed both ways between Billericay and Brentwood, Essex. Travel around Maidstone, Kent, affected - A274 closed.

South-west

Floods No severe flood warnings.

Rail Train lines blocked: Tiverton to Exeter St David's, Barnstaple branch line, Swindon to Gloucester.

Roads No major problems.

Scotland

Floods No severe flood warnings.

Rail Disruption to services between Edinburgh and London due to flooding in Yorkshire and the north-east of England but no lines closed.

Roads Landslides in the Highlands. A939 south of Grantown-on-Spey restricted due to landslide.

Information from the Environment Agency, Railtrack and AA Roadwatch

fields.headline: Just the job
fields.standfirst:
Start-up welcomes extra recruitment lure

Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Laurence Rosen, who founded temp agency Office Angels in 1986, yesterday welcomed the government plans for share options schemes as "wonderful". Mr Rosen, whose new company Huntress Search, a net-based recruitment agency began trading this week, said yesterday's changes will make it easier to hire staff.
fields.body:
Laurence Rosen, who founded temp agency Office Angels in 1986, yesterday welcomed the government plans for share options schemes as "wonderful". Mr Rosen, whose new company Huntress Search, a net-based recruitment agency began trading this week, said yesterday's changes will make it easier to hire staff.

Mr Rosen plans to hire about 150 employees over the next 12 months. Amid growing labour shortages, especially in IT, share options are becoming essential to the package used by start-ups to lure skilled workers. Until yesterday, Huntress was restrained by limits on start-up option schemes which allow the tax-privileged benefits to be given to only 15 employees. But Huntress, which started trading with 43 staff, already exceeded the ceiling.

Mr Rosen, the company's chief executive, said: "For a start-up company, there is no question that offering a share of the business's success through options is a very attractive incentive indeed. We have been able to offer the scheme to 15 staff, and the prospect of extending it to more is wonderful news for me and for other start-ups."

Huntress plans to expand to around 200 staff over the next 12 months, and Mr Rosen says it hopes to float on the stock market within three or four years, partly to give an exit route for backers such as Foreign & Colonial, which has invested £5m. If a float is successful, the staff's share options would become highly valuable, because the gain made on the sale of the options will be free of income tax, and suffer capital gains tax of just 10%.

Mr Rosen says share option packages are sought after despite the meltdown in technology stock values since the dot.com boom earlier this year. "The idea of options has taken a bit of a battering: there's not much point in having one million options issued at 20p and then find they are only worth 1p. But people are not fools; they know how the stock market works and they still believe in options, especially over the medium term."

fields.headline: Drug firms win help to combat the killers
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The drugs industry gave a warm welcome last night to a promise of help from the chancellor to cut the cost of developing affordable vaccines for killer diseases in developing countries, such as Aids, malaria and tuberculosis.
fields.body:
The drugs industry gave a warm welcome last night to a promise of help from the chancellor to cut the cost of developing affordable vaccines for killer diseases in developing countries, such as Aids, malaria and tuberculosis.

Mr Brown said he was concerned that the level of research in the area was minimal because drug firms fear they cannot make a profit without pricing underprivileged patients out of the market.

He has ordered Treasury officials to begin an "urgent" review of ways to help meet the cost of research, either through tax incentives or government subsidies. Results of the review are likely within a year.

The Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry reacted positively. A spokeswoman said: "This is something the industry will welcome. We've been saying for some time there's a need for joint action between the industry and the government to look at issues related to getting medicines to the third world."

Mr Brown's pledge follows a series of initiatives elsewhere. In March, Bill Clinton met the bosses of the world's biggest vaccine makers to discuss ways of delivering antidotes more effectively to children in developing countries. Microsoft chief Bill Gates has set up a charity to support work in the area.

There was a warning that the government should avoid targeting help merely at "eye-catching" diseases. Stephen Inglis, research director of the Cambridge-based vaccines specialist Cantab Pharmaceuticals, said: "There are many, many diseases beyond those mentioned by the chancellor which are perhaps less in the public eye. There are plenty of bacterial infections, for example."

Mr Inglis also pointed out that even after the cost of research, manufacturing and distribution can make the price of drugs too high. Millions of children still die from measles in developing countries, despite the fact that vaccines are on the market.

fields.headline: Advisers' ties and Isa age limit are cut
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The chancellor yesterday signalled a revolution in the way pensions and investments are sold by ditching 12-year-old rules that force product sellers to choose between being tied or independent.
fields.body:
The chancellor yesterday signalled a revolution in the way pensions and investments are sold by ditching 12-year-old rules that force product sellers to choose between being tied or independent.

He also announced that the annual limit of £7,000 on the amount people can invest in Isas will be retained for a further five years, until April 2006, and that 16- and 17-year-olds will be able to put money into Isas for the first time.

The go-ahead for a new breed of "multi-tied" advisers, able to sell the products of a range of companies, was condemned by the Consumers' Association and independent financial advisers' groups.

The move was interpreted as a government attempt to boost sales of stakeholder pensions through banks. The vast majority of banks are tied, limiting them to selling the products of one pension provider.

The Consumers' Association said the rule change was "half-baked and misguided. If the banks want to offer better products, all they have to do is ditch their tied arrangement and become independent."

The heavily trailed announcements on Isa changes were widely welcomed. Halifax said they represented "a terrific encouragement to save" and NatWest said it was expecting an influx of account applications following the decision.

Under rule changes announced yesterday:

The investment limit for Isas - due to fall to £5,000 next year - will remain at £7,000 for the next five years;

From April next year 16- and 17-year-olds will be allowed to open cash Isas, extending tax-free saving to 100,000 under-18s who work and pay tax;

The rules for Peps - which were replaced by Isas- will come into line with those for the new accounts, giving Peps holders access to a wider range of investment opportunities.

But there is a measure preventing parents from exploiting children's Isa allowances.

webTitle: Dick Morris: Commentary on US elections

fields.headline: Commentary
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: We live in a democracy in the United States. Maybe. It is an absolute outrage for George W Bush to become president if, as current trends suggest, he loses the popular vote by 250,000. The electoral college is an anachronism that we Americans have tolerated because it never got in the way.
fields.body:
We live in a democracy in the United States. Maybe. It is an absolute outrage for George W Bush to become president if, as current trends suggest, he loses the popular vote by 250,000. The electoral college is an anachronism that we Americans have tolerated because it never got in the way.

Since 1888, it has faithfully reflected, and indeed amplified, the popular vote.

But if current vote totals stand up, Mr Bush will win the presidency even though more people voted for Al Gore.

This is not democratic.

In the United Kingdom, one party will sometimes win the majority of the popular vote but fail to win a majority of the seats in parliament. It is even possible that the party that came in second will get to form a government. But the UK has a parliamentary system in which parliament, with its single member districts, is the sovereign authority.

The current estimate of Mr Gore's margin of 250,000 votes is hardly inconsequential. After all, John F Kennedy's margin over Richard Nixon in 1960 was only 100,000 votes. To disregard a margin of this magnitude would be a great disservice to democracy. There will be those who will say that the US election is held under the electoral college system and that it should be respected even if it contravenes democracy in so obvious a way.

But the constitutional system in the US does not bind electors to voting the way they are instructed.

The electoral college was set up by the constitution in an era when it was difficult to tabulate the popular vote in so large a nation within a reasonable period of time. Technically, electors to the college have discretion to vote as they wish.

Routinely during the era of the civil rights struggles, southern Democratic electors would refuse to vote for their party's candidate for president and would revolt, casting their ballots for racist third party candidates for president such as George Wallace.

There will be huge pressure on electors to disregard their instructions and their party and vote to make Al Gore the president if his lead in the popular vote stands. It is almost inconceivable that the United States of America would have a president who lost the vote of the people by any kind of a significant margin.

In 1876 and 1888, the candidate who won the popular vote (Samuel Tilden and Grover Cleveland respectively) was denied the White House.

In those earlier, simpler times, such a decision was not extraordinary. But in the modern era, when tallying the preferences of 100m voters spread over thousands of miles presents no technical problem, there is a clear and compelling need for the will of the people to be heard and heeded.

In all likelihood, the trade unions and minority voters who constitute the core of the Gore vote will not take the theft of an election over a technicality without protests.

And nor should they. One must expect a stormy controversy if the verdicts of the electoral and popular vote continue to be at variance. Street demonstrations would be likely. The US will descend to the realm of a banana republic.

Unless the recounts spare us this fate, democracy in America is about to go on trial.

Dick Morris was chief strategist for President Clinton in his successful 1996 bid for re-election, and now heads the political website www.vote.co.uk
