webTitle: Cheers for Hillary but tears in Hope

fields.headline: Cheers for Hillary but tears in Hope
fields.standfirst:
Clintons: Democrats suffer as president's home state votes Bush

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As a jubilant Hillary Clinton celebrated her landmark victory in New York yesterday, friends of her husband back in his Arkansas hometown had little reason to cheer.
fields.body:
As a jubilant Hillary Clinton celebrated her landmark victory in New York yesterday, friends of her husband back in his Arkansas hometown had little reason to cheer.

Most Arkansans voted for George W Bush in a state poll that was not even particularly close. After eight years of "A Man from Hope" in the White House, local citizens were willing to elect the son of the man he defeated.

In her victory speech, Mrs Clinton sought to end the intense bipartisan bitterness that characterised the New York and Arkansas races. "I promise you tonight, I will reach across party lines to bring progress for all of New York's families," she said. "Today we voted as Republicans and Democrats. Tomorrow we begin again as New Yorkers. I am determined to make a difference for all of you."

A weeping President Clinton looked on silently as she thanked him and daughter Chelsea for their support. "I would not be here without my family," she said. Mrs Clinton is the first wife of a president to be elected to the US Senate.

Her victory, by a comfortable margin of 55% to 43%, will ensure that the most divisive family name in US politics will remain powerful long after her husband leaves office.

The champagne and confetti in the New York ballroom seemed a million miles from Arkansas on election night, where the rain-soaked party faithful gathered amid tornado warnings to celebrate the slim victory of a Democrat who was standing for local office a few miles from the president's Hope birthplace.

As Mike Ross, a Clinton acolyte, waited for the results of his bid for a house of representatives seat, even some of his supporters were willing to admit that they had voted for Mr Bush on Tuesday. George Ivey, who lives in nearby Prescott, said: "I can't tell you what I really think [about Clinton] among all these Democrats. But I wouldn't vote for Gore because he's spent too much time with him."

Mr Ivey and his wife had voted for Mr Ross because "we've known him since he was a little-bitty boy and he's a good Christian". Political pundits suggested yesterday that retribution for the Monica Lewinsky affair had helped Mr Bush to win a swath of southern states.

Arkansas is increasingly proud of its place as the buckle of the bible belt. Signs along the road to Hope issue a stark warning that drivers should prepare to meet their god, and local citizens elected a Republican Baptist minister to follow Mr Clinton as state governor.

Relations between the president and the state he left for Washington eight years ago have been strained for some time. But they have reached a nadir in this election year.

Disgust at Mr Clinton's private life prompted an attempt to disbar him from legal practice in Arkansas that is still going through legal procedures. The president is understood to have threatened to withdraw plans to build a $125m library in the state capital if he is disbarred.

Local Clinton opponents managed to present his presidency as both morally corrupt and bad for one of America's poorest states. Chris Carnahan, executive director of the state Republican party, said: "The president has literally done nothing for Arkansas except bring down retribution."

Mr Bush campaigned vigorously and successfully to turn this disaffection for the only Arkansan to become US president into an audacious bid for the state's six electoral college votes.

But Mr Clinton still attracts an incredibly loyal band of supporters in his home state. Vaughn McQuary, the chairman of the Arkansas Democratic party, blames the unrelenting bitterness of his Republican rivals for some of the slurs. He is planning a big celebratory party after the inauguration and describes this year's elections - with its Clinton successes and defeats - as "really bitter-sweet".

Joann Martin, who has known the Clintons since the mid 1970s and worked at campaign headquarters in Little Rock on election day, said: "Of course, there were times when I was disappointed, but I have always compared it with raising my three sons. There were times when they didn't behave as well as they might, but it didn't mean that I quit loving or respecting them."

As an afterthought, she added: "Arkansas is better off as a result of his presidency and history will prove that."

webTitle: US airline blamed in Concorde crash report

fields.headline: US airline blamed in Concorde crash report
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: A report by experts investigating the crash of an Air France Concorde outside Paris in July contains potentially devastating evidence against the US carrier Continental Airlines and subcontractors in Israel, a newspaper alleged yesterday.
fields.body:
A report by experts investigating the crash of an Air France Concorde outside Paris in July contains potentially devastating evidence against the US carrier Continental Airlines and subcontractors in Israel, a newspaper alleged yesterday.

Le Parisien cited a leaked report stating that Continental manifestly failed to ensure that proper maintenance procedures were followed in Israel when a strip of metal was fixed to the engine of one of its DC-10 jets. Three weeks later, this jet took off from from Charles de Gaulle airport just before the Concorde.

Investigators have already said that the 16-inch piece of metal, found on the runway used by both planes, almost definitely brought the Concorde down by shredding one of its tyres. Chunks of rubber then hurtled into the aircraft's unprotected wings, puncturing one or more of its fuel tanks and igniting a fire that turned the supersonic jet into what one expert has described as "a gigantic cigarette lighter".

Less than two minutes after take-off, the plane plunged into a hotel in nearby Gonesse, killing all 109 people on board and four on the ground.

Le Parisien said the report, by metallurgical experts from the French government's Armaments Directorate General found microscopic traces of rubber on the epoxy-coated metal strip that matched the chemical composition of the Air France Concorde's tyres.

The report confirmed that "part 139", a wear strip from an engine thrust reverser assembly, came from the forward starboard engine cowling of Continental Airlines' DC-10 flight 55, that it was not the original part supplied by the engine manufacturers General Electric, and that it had fallen off the same plane several times in the past.

The refit alleged to have been deficient was carried out in Israel on July 9, three weeks before the Concorde crashed, the report said, apparently by engineers subcontracted by Continental. But it said General Electric's specifications were not followed. These say that only the 12 existing rivet holes should be used when refitting the strip. More than 30 holes were drilled in the part.

"Even if Continental tries to pass the blame on to a subcontractor, it could very well find itself legally responsible," a French accident lawyer said.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
What began life in Mr Tony's dreamily grandiose little head as "the first sentence of the next manifesto" will end, it seems, as Britain's biggest and costliest car boot sale. As the National Audit Committee report due out tonight will disclose, Dome sponsors have been told that all the contents will be disposed of at a special auction in January, unless they pay to have them taken away. Special equipment such as escalators barely a year old will be in great demand, but problems are expected with the sale of Body Zone contents complicated by tricky questions of intellectual property rights. Dome paperwork is in such utter chaos, the report out tonight will reveal, that no one is certain who owns what. According to one former executive, there are still thousands of unexamined document files in containers scattered round the site. Marvellous form. Still, as long as no one from the government takes one iota of responsibility, and leaves the whole mess to that poor French stooge, that's the important thing.

John Kampfner's article on Monday's media pages was a delight, as the former BBC political correspondent railed against the lies and bullying used against hacks by New Labour. This principled stand does him credit, and no doubt had he got the job as the Labour party head of communications he applied for earlier this year, he would have fought valiantly to change things "from the inside".

Our thanks to Paul, who calls from County Down to report on Ruth Gledhill's Songs of Praise appearance. Filmed in a Stoke ballroom, Ruth's section was based around the premise that dance is a form of worship, Paul explains, and concluded with the Times's religious correspondent swirling across the floor (with husband Andrew) in a red chiffon gown. "My brother and I were rolling around the floor in laughter," says Paul. Nothing wrong with that, though. You can worship the Lord just as well through mirth as through the holy gift of dance.

With "Caring Conservatism" a possible diversion for whoever succeeds Hague after the Labour landslide next year, a nascent Tory star emerges in Keynsham. Parliamentary candidate Chris Watt impresses with a savage attack on a poorly designed disabled toilet, which he visited at the suggestion of wheelchair user Jenny Shrubshall. "I was truly disappointed to see the lack of consideration," said Mr Watt, blaming Bath and North East Somerset council for it being "impossible for a disabled person to use". Perhaps the attack lost some of its sting when it emerged that the toilet was built by Tory- controlled Wansdyke district council, but a brave effort all the same, so hats off.

October's Falkland Islands Newsletter arrives, and what a triumph it is for the picture editor. The front page splash has a large colour photo of two penguins, while the article on page nine, although not illustrated, begins: "Even penguins have joined the hi-tech world of the Internet!" On page 10 is a piece about counting penguins, while page 11 is dominated by a large shot of a penguin incubating an egg. Page 12 has two penguin snaps, while page 13 has two penguin illustrations (and some seals). And that's it. Except for page 24, which has two more penguin pics, and an accompanying leaflet, Falklands Conservation, which is illustrated by penguins on the front, with more inside.

After lunch in Shepherd Market, Mayfair, a senior Reader's Digest executive wandered off for a cab when he was addressed in a seductive tone by an attractive young woman in a doorway. "Company, love?" she cooed. "Reader's Digest," he replied politely, and strolled off. Ah, if only Jeffrey Archer had taken the same no-nonsense approach after dinner that night at Le Caprice...

webTitle: Republicans pushed all the way in Congress fight

fields.headline: Republicans pushed all the way in Congress fight
fields.standfirst:
Capitol Hill: The Democrat millions were spent in vain

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Republican revolution that stormed Capitol Hill under Newt Gingrich in 1994 held on to the US Senate and House of Representatives by a whisker, beating back a heavily financed and well organised Democratic challenge in both houses.
fields.body:
The Republican revolution that stormed Capitol Hill under Newt Gingrich in 1994 held on to the US Senate and House of Representatives by a whisker, beating back a heavily financed and well organised Democratic challenge in both houses.

Paralleling the closest presidential election in years, American voters have delivered finely balanced outcomes, but have left the Republicans with narrow majorities in both houses.

The outcome is a big blow for the Democrats, who had set their sights on recapturing the House after six years, and who must now focus on using their blocking minority in the Senate in forthcoming legislative battles.

With two Senate contests in Republican-held seats in Michigan and Washington state undecided, the Democrats still had hopes of achieving a 50-50 split in the 100-seat body, where the Republicans had a 54-46 majority before the election.

The Democrat gains would not be enough to give the party control of the Senate, irrespective of the outcome in the battle for the White House.

If George W Bush is the president, then by convention the vice-president, who would be Dick Cheney, would hold the casting vote in any 50-50 tie. If Al Gore is president, then Joe Lieberman would have to vacate the Connecticut Senate seat to which he was re-elected on Tuesday, enabling Connecticut's Republican governor, John Rowland, to appoint a Republican to replace him. And so the Republicans would have a majority.

In that event, Mr Lieberman's insistence on continuing to run for the Senate while also running for the vice-presidency will come near the top of a long list of items on the post-mortem agenda of the closest US election of modern times.

While Hillary Clinton's win in a Democrat held seat in New York sucked up most of the national and worldwide publicity, the election produced more than its usual share of dramas in other states too. History was made in New Jersey where the Democratic candidate Jon Corzine, a former chairman of Goldman Sachs, narrowly defeated Republican Bob Franks after breaking all previous spending records for a Senate race. Mr Corzine spent an estimated $60m (£40m) of his own money on winning the seat.

In addition to Missouri, Democrats also picked up wins in Delaware, where the governor, Tom Carper, ousted the incumbent Republican veteran William Roth, chairman of the Senate finance committee, and in Florida, where Bill Nelson defeated Bill McCollum, one of Bill Clinton's impeachment prosecutors.

Another Democrat gain came in Minnesota, where Senator Rod Grams was defeated by Mark Dayton.

There were Republican successes too. In Virginia the former governor, George Allen, succeeded where Oliver North failed six years ago, defeating the longtime Democratic incumbent Chuck Robb. In Nevada, where the sitting Democrat had retired, Republican John Ensign comfortably outpolled his rivals.

The Democrats were also frustrated in their efforts to capture the House of Representatives.

The Republicans held on by their fingertips, leaving Dennis Hastert of Illinois holding the speaker's gavel in spite of a major challenge led by the Democratic minority leader, Dick Gephardt.

With two seats still to be declared in the 435-seat House, the Republicans held a 220-211 advantage, with two independents also winning re-election. The Democrats appeared likely to make a net gain of two seats, though some recounts seemed likely before the final totals were declared.

"I think we're in pretty good shape. It may be a very tight majority, but it's going to be a majority," Mr Hastert said yesterday.

The most significant Democratic scalp was that of the sitting Republican Congressman James Rogan in the Pasadena area of southern California. Mr Rogan, another Clinton impeachment prosecutor, was ousted by Adam Schiff.

The Democrats also picked up another California Republican seat when Mike Honda captured the Santa Clara district vacated by moderate Republican Congressman Tom Campbell, who lost a Senate challenge to the re-elected Senator Dianne Feinstein.

A third gain came in New York, where the seat formerly held by Rick Lazio, the defeated Republican Senate candidate, went to the Democrat Steve Israel. There were other gains in Utah and Arizona.

But Republicans picked up seats in Virginia, Minnesota and Connecticut to keep the party's majority intact.

fields.headline: Call for clarity in pensions investments
fields.standfirst:
 Call to scrap minimum funding requirement
 Maxwell era rules must go
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Rules introduced to protect pension fund members after the Maxwell scandal should be scrapped and replaced with a more "open and transparent" regime, the head of a government-backed review into institutional investment recommended yesterday.
fields.body:
Rules introduced to protect pension fund members after the Maxwell scandal should be scrapped and replaced with a more "open and transparent" regime, the head of a government-backed review into institutional investment recommended yesterday.

Paul Myners, head of Gartmore fund management, outlined a three-pronged alternative to the so-called minimum funding requirement (MFR) which would involve extending fraud compensation, separating pension fund assets from the control of the company and requiring pension funds to issue public, "transparency" statements on their investment strategies.

By scrapping the MFR, Mr Myners, who is chairman of Guardian Media Group, aims to enhance investor protection and free pension assets for investment in areas such as venture capital. MFR requirements have tended to encourage pension funds to invest a proportion of their assets in long-dated government bonds.

Establishing fund managers' attitudes to investing in such venture capital was one of the main tasks given to Mr Myners when Gordon Brown asked him at the last Budget to review the way institutional investors take their decisions.

Mr Myners' initial report was welcomed by the National Association of Pension Funds. The Association of British Insurers said the proposals would require a "close examination of the role" of Opra, the Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority, with which Mr Myners says trustees' should lodge their transparency statements.

Pensions consultants William Mercer expressed concerns that Mr Myners' proposals weaken the protection of members in pension funds. Gordon Pollock, worldwide partner at William M Mercer, said employers should be required to make a certain level of contribution if their schemes are underfunded.

Mr Myners' call to abolish the MFR was regarded by Michael Saunders, economist at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, as negative for long-dated government bonds.

While Mr Myners has until the next Budget to publish his full findings, he said he was making his views on the controversial MFR known yesterday to coincide with two separate but related government consultation exercises.

The first is on the MFR, which Mr Myners described yesterday as "seriously inadequate as a form of protection". The second is the impact of financial services regulation on investment by pension funds in so-called limited partnerships, one of the structures by which investors could back entrepreneurs. The government said yesterday that it would incorporate Mr Myners' recommended changes to the legislation under the Financial Services and Markets Act to change investment restrictions on pension funds to make it easier to invest in these limited partnerships.

However, Mr Myners' suggestions for the eradication of the MFR, which dismisses many other proposals drawn up the industry such as setting up insurance policies, may not be adopted by the government, which yesterday said it would consult with the industry on the ideas.

The proposals for reforming the MFR follow submissions to Mr Myners' consultation paper which led him to conclude that the existing rules, put in place after the Robert Maxwell affair, were distorting investment strategies.

Mr Myners said MFR, which he contended was "never designed to tackle fraud", was encouraging employees to move away from offering defined benefit pension schemes linked to employees' final salaries.

He said the MFR had given pension fund trustees a false sense of security and weakened their sense of "fiduciary duty". His new proposals, particularly for final salary schemes to set out in "clear and straightforward language" the details of their investment strategies, are expected to put greater onus on trustees.

What happens next

By the time of the Budget next year, Paul Myners, the fund manager who is heading the government-backed review into institutional investment, is expected to provide Gordon Brown with an outline of how investment professionals make decisions about where to place their assets.

The industry also believes Mr Myners will set out ideas for placing greater responsibility on pension fund trustees. Mr Myners has indicated that the final report to the chancellor would be the avenue by which he suggested the time frames and methods under which pension fund performance should be measured.

Annual performance measurement has been cited as one of the reasons for deterring investment in venture capital because it can be more volatile.

Part 2: the fiscal stance
Part 3: families and pensioners

fields.headline: Leaders hastily retract early congratulations
fields.standfirst:
Reaction: Diplomats had no protocol for poll confusion

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Within minutes of the American television networks declaring George W Bush the next president of the United States, world leaders scrambled to be first to dispatch telegrams of congratulations to his headquarters in Austin, Texas.
fields.byline: Owen Bowcott  and  Jonathan Watts  in  Tokyo
fields.body:
Within minutes of the American television networks declaring George W Bush the next president of the United States, world leaders scrambled to be first to dispatch telegrams of congratulations to his headquarters in Austin, Texas.

Effusive messages arrived from Russia, China, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, the Netherlands, the European Union, Turkey, Indonesia and Australia, all anxious to establish close relations with the man apparently destined to be the most powerful on the globe.

Quick off the mark was Germany's president, Johannes Rau, whose statement declared: "We know you as a good friend of our country and look forward to the continuation of close friendship of our people during your time in office."

A short while later, as American pollsters hastily revised their earlier firm predictions, his spokesman was attempting to prevent the telegram being distributed to news services. "What can we do?" the official in Berlin admitted. "It is complicated. One wants to be among the first sending congratulations and warm wishes."

The story was the same in scores of embassies and foreign offices. After the initial chorus of welcomes, there was a rash of retractions. Some retreated into diplomatic silence. The Dutch government said: "Given the fact that at this moment uncertainty exists about the outcome of the American presidential elections, the earlier statement ... has been retracted."

Protocol offered no easy line of withdrawal. "We welcome from the bottom of our hearts Bush's victory in the presidential election," Hiromu Nonaka, secretary general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic party, said before events outdated his greetings.

Japan's equivalent of the CBI, Keidanren, put out a press please. "It has become clear that the US presidential election results may not become final for some time, due to state of Florida turnout.

"However, trusting three major US television networks, namely ABC, CBS and NBC, as well as CNN, [we] issued [our] chairman Imai's comment in Japanese based on once announced 'final' result."

In Europe, most centre-left governments were privately hoping for a Gore victory. "We are much looking forward to working with Mr Bush," the European commission president, Romano Prodi, said.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said relations with the US would remain strong. "I am confident that we can build the same relationship with the new president," he told the BBC.

Only Sweden openly expressed regrets. "It's a pity, but that is the wish of the American people and we have to work with their choice," said the prime minister, Goran Persson.

fields.headline: Everyone is happy and all is well in Gordonland
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: We all love Gordon Brown's budget statements. Outside it's pouring with rain, rivers are about to flood our houses, trains don't run, and the capital is about to be clogged with lorries, tractors and, we learned yesterday, hot dog vans. The reek from the onions alone could punch another hole in the ozone layer.
fields.body:
We all love Gordon Brown's budget statements. Outside it's pouring with rain, rivers are about to flood our houses, trains don't run, and the capital is about to be clogged with lorries, tractors and, we learned yesterday, hot dog vans. The reek from the onions alone could punch another hole in the ozone layer.

But in Gordonland all is well. In Gordonland, which I think has the same emerald green colour as the Teletubbies' meadow, everyone is happy and glad all the livelong day. Inflation is down. So is unemployment. The economy is growing and exports are booming. Mortgage rates are down, investment is up, and it only rains at night.

It was also heartwarming to welcome back Gordon's old friend Prudence. We thought she had been cruelly ignored but yesterday she had many, many mentions in Gordon's cheery speech. He even smiled twice, which for those of us who only see his public appearances, has an unnerving resemblance to a funeral mute who's just heard a dirty joke.

The Gordonland scripts aren't exactly Shakespeare. "Hello, Prudence, it's good to have you back!" cries Vera the Vicar. "And did you know, thanks to a reduction in VAT on church repairs, subject to EU approval, we'll soon have that weathervane back on our steeple!"

Harry the Headmaster is happily waving a cheque for £7,000. "Thanks to this we can give sweets and crisps to all the boys and girls instead of horrid old school dinners," he says. "And with the 3p per litre cut in ultra low sulphur petrol, I'll be able to afford an extra pipeful of tobacco as well as driving myself to school!"

In Mother Brown's tea shop Polly and Percy Pensioner are celebrating their good fortune with toasted currant buns. "Not only has our pension gone up, but we can keep our house warm this year thanks to the preservation of the Christmas and winter fuel allowances! And with a cheque for £200 on its way, there'll be in-line roller blades and Royle Family videos for all our grandchildren this Christmas!"

It's all absurd. As Michael Portillo pointed out, in Gordonland only nice, kind numbers are allowed. Horrid, nasty, rough statistics about low savings, productivity and industrial decline are banned.

And the talk of toughness masked the fact that the chancellor has given much to the fuel protesters. Labour MPs sat silent and uncomfortable as he moved his dumper truck towards the the lorry drivers, tipped a load of money out in front of them, and asked them to say "when". Tories jeered happily.

Next he announced a quite fantastically complicated pension scheme which will allow our old folk to spend their golden years filling up complicated forms. "For this year specially - the first year of the transitional arrangements - the winter allowance will be paid not at £150, but at £200 for every pensioner household!"

He sounded like Chris Tarrant - "But I don't want to give you £150, I want to give you..." - and the Labour benches cheered like a studio audience grateful for their free tickets and the chance to keep warm.

It was almost impossible for the shadow chancellor to reply to this travel brochure for Elysium. He didn't really try. Instead he allowed his voice to go all husky, as if a man with a cold had just heard some very bad news. The chancellor, he said, had no right to spend the £16bn; it wasn't his, it was "the people's surplus", making it sound like the late Diana, Princess of Wales.

"He has returned to us a little bit of the people's surplus, but he couldn't come to this House and say 'I'm sorry'." Mr Brown sat back looking as sorry as a pet cat who's learned to work a tin opener.

"And did you know, thanks to a reduction in VAT on church repairs, subject to EU approval, we'll soon have that weathervane back on our steeple!" Harry the Headmaster is happily waving a cheque for £7,000. "Thanks to this we can give sweets and crisps to all the boys and girls instead of horrid old school dinners," he says. "And with the 3p per litre cut in ultra low sulphur petrol, I'll be able to afford an extra pipeful of tobacco as well as driving myself to school!" In Mother Brown's tea shop Polly and Percy Pensioner are celebrating their good fortune with toasted currant buns. "Not only has our pension gone up, but we can keep our house warm this year thanks to the preservation of the Christmas and winter fuel allowances! And with a cheque for £200 on its way, there'll be in-line roller blades and Royle Family videos for all our grandchildren this Christmas!" It's all absurd. As Michael Portillo pointed out, in Gordonland only nice, kind numbers are allowed. Horrid, nasty, rough statistics about low savings, productivity and industrial decline are banned. And the talk of toughness masked the fact that the chancellor has given much to the fuel protesters. Labour MPs sat silent and uncomfortable as he moved his dumper truck towards the the lorry drivers, tipped a load of money out in front of them, and asked them to say "when". Tories jeered happily. Next he announced a quite fantastically complicated pension scheme which will allow our old folk to spend their golden years filling up complicated forms. "For this year specially - the first year of the transitional arrangements - the winter allowance will be paid not at £150, but at £200 for every pensioner household!" He sounded like Chris Tarrant - "But I don't want to give you £150, I want to give you..." - and the Labour benches cheered like a studio audience grateful for their free tickets and the chance to keep warm. It was almost impossible for the shadow chancellor to reply to this travel brochure for Elysium. He didn't really try. Instead he allowed his voice to go all husky, as if a man with a cold had just heard some very bad news. The chancellor, he said, had no right to spend the £16bn; it wasn't his, it was "the people's surplus", making it sound like the late Diana, Princess of Wales. "He has returned to us a little bit of the people's surplus, but he couldn't come to this House and say 'I'm sorry'." Mr Brown sat back looking as sorry as a pet cat who's learned to work a tin opener. The speech in full Part 1: the economy Part 2: the fiscal stance Part 3: families and pensioners

webTitle: The rollercoaster heart-stopping night that made US history

fields.headline: The rollercoaster heart-stopping night that made US history
fields.standfirst:
Results drama: Last-minute reprieve proved a fitting climax to an extraordinary day

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Like a condemned man on his way to the scaffold, Al Gore had already accepted what seemed to be the inevitable and was on his way to bid a sad farewell to a rain-drenched crowd of supporters in the heart of Nashville. Then, as in all good cowboy movies, came the last-minute reprieve, although this was one that Governor Bush would certainly not have wanted to sign. He is not known for pardons.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell  in Nashville and  Julian Borger  in Austin
fields.body:
Like a condemned man on his way to the scaffold, Al Gore had already accepted what seemed to be the inevitable and was on his way to bid a sad farewell to a rain-drenched crowd of supporters in the heart of Nashville. Then, as in all good cowboy movies, came the last-minute reprieve, although this was one that Governor Bush would certainly not have wanted to sign. He is not known for pardons.

No studio executive would have bought this plot, said film director and Democrat cheerleader Robert Reiner who was in the square. "Truth is stranger than fiction," he said as the vice-president's limousine took a last minute detour from what would have been his concession speech and headed back to his hotel to his first sleep in 48 hours.

The dramatic reversal was the climax of an extraordinary and historic day which left the 3,500 journalists in Nashville and Austin raiding their sack of cliches. It was a rollercoaster and a nail-biter, it was right to the wire and too close to call, it was a heart-stopper and a heart-breaker.

In Austin, the Bush clan had been celebrating in the Texas governor's mansion. No one more so than the candidate's father, George Herbert Walker Bush, who had been nervous throughout the night but finally thought he had become only the second president in US history to see his son follow him into the White House.

We are not told what happened when the call came in to Don Evans, the Bush campaign manager and "first buddy" at about 2.15 pm, from the Gore campaign manager, Bill Daley, saying there was a hitch.

A few minutes later, Mr Gore was on the line, withdrawing his concession of defeat. "Circumstances have changed since I first called you. I need to withdraw my concession until the situation is clear," he is reported to have said.

Snatched
When he heard his victory had, at least for now, been snatched from him, Mr Bush apparently remained calm. There was no word about what his parents did.

The air of Bush impregnability had been punctured just before 7pm. The extended Bush family had just sat down to a dinner of Parmesan-crusted chicken with grilled shrimp, preserved lemon and sundried tomatoes at the Shoreline Grill restaurant. It was a long-planned event, intended to be a handing of the political torch from father to son.

But the meal was still half-finished when mobile phones and pagers began to go off around the table. In quick order, the television networks announced that Mr Gore had taken Michigan and Florida, transforming the political map, and putting all the pressure on Mr Bush to eke out a majority in the electoral college.

The Bush dynasty lost its appetite. The meal was ended, the limousines called, and a change of plan announced. Instead of heading to Austin's plush Four Seasons hotel to watch the climax of the count on a bank of television screens surrounded by close aides and major campaign contributors, Mr Bush and his parents went home to the governor's mansion, sending only a few of the candidate's siblings to keep the hotel crowd happy.

Out in front of the pink granite bulk of the Texas state capitol, the Republican crowd took the Michigan and Florida announcements like body blows. For all the efforts of country and western singers to keep spirits high, all the energy appeared to have left the 10,000-strong rally, which began to feel the cold and the driving rain. Then the networks, broadcast on huge screens above the crowd, declared that Pennsylvania had gone Democrat, and the misery deepened.

For the Gore camp, the early announcement by CNN that Florida had gone Gore was greeted with cheers at the Sheraton hotel where they had gathered to await the results. The media were informed by Doug Hattaway, Mr Gore's national spokesman, that the vice-president and his running mate Joe Lieberman had celebrated the news as they were dining with their wives Tipper and Hadassah at nearby Loew's hotel. They had embraced. Then they had returned to making satellite calls to television and radio stations along the west coast in a final bid to win Oregon and Washington.

When the news of Gore victories in Pennsylvania, Michigan and Illinois and then Hillary Clinton's success in New York came through, the mood for Democrats was buoyant as aides scribbled calculations and clearly felt victory was within their grasp. The press camp was told California showed a 20% Gore lead.

At the governor's mansion, there was a flurry of activity at 8.30pm. A small group of reporters was summoned to the living room in the private apartment upstairs, to find the governor, his wife, Laura, his father and mother, Barbara, sitting around the fire in a tableau of family comfort.

In an apparently staged coincidence, Mr Bush was on the telephone to the Pennsylvania governor, Tom Ridge, telling him: "Call me when you hear something."

It was a masterful piece of counter-spin. The Texas governor questioned the early calls by television networks on Pennsylvania and Florida. The normal confidence was back, and he was bullish and joking once more. Only his parents were anxious, he said. The elder Bush declared himself "nervous and proud". Barbara Bush said: "We haven't been up this late in years."

At 9.54pm, following ferocious protests and complaints from the Bush headquarters, CNN became the first major broadcaster to throw its prediction into reverse, returning Florida to the "too close to call" column.

The extraordinary move by the networks triggered an explosion of yells and cheers outside the Austin capitol. It was relief mixed with a return of certainty of victory and a sense of vindication: the media - which most rank-and-file Republicans, especially in Texas, suspected of a liberal bias - had been caught red-handed it seemed.

In Nashville, all bets were suddenly off and the body language of the Gore camp as they consulted in corridors was telling a different story. There were already angry mutterings about Ralph Nader and how his votes might have cost Mr Gore the election. From then on it was, well, rollercoaster is the only word to describe it. Up with New Mexico. Down with Arizona. Up with Iowa. Down with Nevada. Then into limbo with Florida.

In Austin, the long wait for the Florida result took its toll on the Bush crowd. It was unseasonably cold and wet, and families with young children began to peel away around midnight. Others went in search of food or dry clothes and umbrellas. Many just gave up and headed for bed.

But at 1.18am a yell rose up from the rainsoaked stalwarts who had stayed. Hundreds of Republicans who had been streaming from the capitol pushed back towards the rally and the huge media platform which loomed over it. First one network, then another had called Florida for Mr Bush and graphics depicting the governor's smiling face set against the red, white and blue of the Stars and Stripes flashed up on the huge screens.

The same pictures flashed up on a similar giant screen in the War Memorial plaza in Nashville and a soaking crowd of about 1,000 Gore supporters gasped and shouted "No, no!" Some were in tears, some stood drenched to the skin, unable to believe that what a few hours previously had seemed like victory had been plucked from them.

Aides told the media Mr Gore would make a brief concession speech in the square. As Van Morrison songs were played over the loudspeakers and a lone Bush supporter ecstatically waved an American flag and claimed the Bush victory was "God's vengeance against Satan", the camera crews and reporters gathered for what they believed was the final chapter.

Over in Texas, a huge cheer broke out when the news came that Mr Gore had called Mr Bush to concede the election. The House of Representatives was also going the Republicans' way. It really was all over, the Texas Republicans thought. One by one the crowd turned towards a spotlit podium where they were told Mr Bush would appear to give his victory speech within minutes. They waited, but half an hour went by and no word came. The screens filled with the bluish tinge of the spotlit war memorial in Nashville, where Mr Gore's concession speech was due to precede Mr Bush's address.

In Tennessee, Mr Gore had been in his car, staring at his speech, when the call came. The campaign field director, Michael Whouley, had paged the travelling chief of staff, Michael Feldman, to tell him that only 6,000 votes separated the two candidates in Florida, with a significant number of votes outstanding.

Premature
The result, he said, had been called too early and the gap was narrowing by the minute. The late ballots were going Mr Gore's way and at one point the gap was a paltry 200 votes.

For the second time in one night, CNN and the other networks had suffered from premature extrapolation. Mr Feldman called Mr Daley, who told the vice-president. It must have seemed like a miracle. Mr Gore withdrew his concession and rang Mr Bush to tell him the news.

In the dramatically floodlit square beneath the imposing Tennessee capitol building, Gore aides were suddenly energised, shaking their heads in disbelief, hinting there was still one more twist in the plot. Soaking media folk frantically rang newsdesks. Senior Gore adviser Bob Shrum hurried into the square. The amiable Doug Hattaway, who had looked greyer and gloomier as the night proceeded, was smiling again as he was buried under a media scrum of golf umbrellas and thrusting microphones.

At 2.45 am the official announcement was made in the square that Gore was withdrawing his concession. His motorcade with its police motorcycle outriders, blue lights flashing, diverted from Union Street as his supporters cheered and chanted "stay and fight!". Mounted policemen appeared at the top of Union Street, ghostly riders in the night. Soaking supporters defiantly waved "Tipper Rocks!" placards and clung to each other and hope. Bill Daley, the urbane Gore campaign chairman, appeared on the podium where Mr Gore had been about to speak. "I don't think there has ever been a night like this," he told the suddenly enthused crowd. Mr Daley, credited with holding the campaign together during its darker days, said that with 99.99% of nearly 6m votes counted, the candidates were separated by a mere 1,200 votes. He said Mr Gore and Mr Lieberman were fully prepared to concede but the Florida call had been premature. "Our campaign continues!"

The postmortems continued in the square and at the press centre in the Nashville Sheraton hotel. Had there been fraud? How could a predominantly Jewish precinct in Florida have voted in such reported numbers for the racist Pat Buchanan? Were absentee ballots mainly from the military and did that mean a Bush majority after all? Rumours floated up and down the staircase leading to the nerve centre of the hotel.

There was a missing ballot box. The absentee ballots came mainly from a Democrat stronghold. No, it was a Republican one. Mr Hattaway appeared again to say there would be no further news until at least 9am on Wednesday. Hope was alive again, albeit slim.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Youth held over robbery of MP
fields.body:
Youth held over robbery of MP

An 18-year-old is on bail after being arrested and questioned yesterday in connection with the robbery of Tony Banks. The Labour MP was punched and robbed of £60 by four youths while walking home in east London on October 31.

Postman denies murdering wife

A postman disposed "bit by bit" of his wife's body, the Old Bailey heard yesterday, and only her skull had been found on Sidcup golf course in Kent. Roger Frisby, 32, admits killing June Frisby, 36, at their home in Plumstead, south London, but denies murder. The case continues.

Accolade for Les's Fish Bar

Les's Fish Bar in Crewe, Cheshire, was chosen yesterday as chippie of the year. Les Manning, 42, said his family had three generations in the trade, "but this is our biggest achievement to date."

Baby death mother cleared

A jury at Manchester crown court yesterday cleared Marie Trueman, 32, of Dukinfield, of a charge of wilful neglect of her three-month-old daughter, Courtney, who died when left inside a car "like an oven" outside their home for more than two hours.

Gambling's feel-good factor

New Scientist reports that researchers at the University of Bremen found that gamblers get a similar sensation to that of smokers, drinkers or drug-takers.

webTitle: Paula Yates: TV star killed by heroine binge

fields.headline: TV star killed by heroin 'binge'
fields.standfirst:
Coroner speaks of 'foolish and incautious' behaviour by Paula Yates but says evidence does not point to suicide
Special report: drugs in Britain
Interactive guide to drugs banned by the IOC
fields.trailText: The television presenter Paula Yates died of a heroin overdose in a "foolish and incautious" binge after having apparently overcome her drug problem, an inquest found yesterday.
fields.body:
The television presenter Paula Yates died of a heroin overdose in a "foolish and incautious" binge after having apparently overcome her drug problem, an inquest found yesterday.

The coroner, Paul Knapman, said the amount she snorted would not have killed an addict, but as "an unsophisticated taker of heroin" Miss Yates had no tolerance to the drug.

Recording a verdict of death by non-dependent abuse of drugs, he told the court: "The evidence does not point to this being a deliberate act of suicide. It seems most improbable that she would attempt to kill herself with her daughter in the house. Her behaviour was foolish and incautious."

Miss Yates, 41, died at her home in Notting Hill, west London, on September 17, after moving back from a break in Hastings.

The last adult to see her was a former heroin addict she had met at the Priory clinic, but her four-year-old daughter Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily, whose father Michael Hutchence died three years ago, was alone with her when she died.

Pathologist Iain West told the court he had found morphine in her blood, but no trace of alcohol or other illegal drugs. "The powerful narcotic drug depressed the cells of the brain which basically stopped her breathing," he said.

Miss Yates's close friend Belinda Brewin, who visited her on the evening before her death, told the court: "She was slightly staggering, her eyelids were drooping, she was slightly incoherent. I could tell that she had been taking drugs.

"I said, 'What the hell are you doing this for after all this time?' She hadn't taken drugs, illegal drugs, for nearly two years. She said it was the pressure of being back in London."

After bathing Miss Yates because she had been sick, Mrs Brewin left the star in a "quite coherent" state. Unknown to Mrs Brewin, Charlotte Korshak, a former heroin addict, was upstairs throughout the visit and was the last person to see Miss Yates.

Miss Korshak, 21, told police that Miss Yates had taken heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and acid "from time to time".

But she said she did not see Miss Yates take any drugs on September 16 and when asked by the coroner if she had supplied Miss Yates with illegal drugs replied: "Absolutely not." She told the court she left her friend "fine, in a really good mood, happy".

Miss Yates's body was found by her longstanding friend Josephine Fairley Sams, who visited the house after trying to call her repeatedly. She was let in by Tiger Lily. "I rushed upstairs to tell Paula to wake up and took one look at her and knew she was dead," she told the court.

"She was naked, half-out of the bed. I touched her and she was very cold."

Miss Yates found fame in the 1980s as co-presenter of Channel 4 show The Tube, and as girlfriend and later wife of Sir Bob Geldof. They had three children - Fifi Trixibelle, 17, Peaches, 11, and Pixie, 10 - but in 1995 she left him for INXS singer Michael Hutchence. An acrimonious divorce and custody battle followed.

Amid a blaze of headlines she gave birth to Hutchence's daughter, Tiger Lily. But only 14 months later he was found hanged by a belt in his Sydney hotel room in November 1997. Miss Yates refused to accept the coroner's verdict of suicide. Her life was rocked again when it was revealed that her father was not the late TV presenter Jess Yates, as she had believed, but another TV personality, the late Hughie Green. Following Miss Yates's death Tiger Lily was made a ward of court and is being cared for by Sir Bob, who already had custody of his three children.

After the inquest Miss Yates's solicitor, Anthony Burton, read a statement on behalf of her friends. "An inquest tells you how someone died, not how they lived. It gives no clue to the fullness and joy of Paula's life. Her friends will always remember her as loving, affectionate and witty."

Miss Yates's body was found by her longstanding friend Josephine Fairley Sams, who visited the house after trying to call her repeatedly. She was let in by Tiger Lily. "I rushed upstairs to tell Paula to wake up and took one look at her and knew she was dead," she told the court. "She was naked, half-out of the bed. I touched her and she was very cold." Miss Yates found fame in the 1980s as co-presenter of Channel 4 show The Tube, and as girlfriend and later wife of Sir Bob Geldof. They had three children - Fifi Trixibelle, 17, Peaches, 11, and Pixie, 10 - but in 1995 she left him for INXS singer Michael Hutchence. An acrimonious divorce and custody battle followed. Amid a blaze of headlines she gave birth to Hutchence's daughter, Tiger Lily. But only 14 months later he was found hanged by a belt in his Sydney hotel room in November 1997. Miss Yates refused to accept the coroner's verdict of suicide. Her life was rocked again when it was revealed that her father was not the late TV presenter Jess Yates, as she had believed, but another TV personality, the late Hughie Green. Following Miss Yates's death Tiger Lily was made a ward of court and is being cared for by Sir Bob, who already had custody of his three children. After the inquest Miss Yates's solicitor, Anthony Burton, read a statement on behalf of her friends. "An inquest tells you how someone died, not how they lived. It gives no clue to the fullness and joy of Paula's life. Her friends will always remember her as loving, affectionate and witty."

webTitle: How to get online with Windows

fields.headline: How to get online with Windows
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Start here...
fields.body:
Most internet service providers (ISPs) supply a CD that is supposed to make it easy to get online. Often, it doesn't. It is usually easier to do the job manually, and it can take less than a minute.

If your PC already has a modem and Microsoft Windows 95, 98 or Me installed, the only things you need to know are the ISP's phone number, your log-on name, and your password.

First, go to the My Computer icon in the top left of your screen and double-click to open it. Then open the folder called Dial-Up Networking, and double-click the icon labelled Make New Connection. This will start the "connection wizard". (In Windows Me, you can get to this folder via Start|Settings|Control Panel.)

Type in a name for your ISP, such as Freeserve, and click the Next button. On the next panel, type in the phone number, and click Next again. Finally, click Finish. That's it.

You now have a new icon named after your new ISP in the Dial-Up Networking folder. Double-click this icon to run it, and check that the correct phone number is shown. If it isn't, you are probably in the wrong country: click the Dial properties button and make sure you have the correct country and area code set.

Now type your details into the boxes marked User name and Password, click on Connect, and your PC will call your ISP. That's all there is to it.

If you want to use half a dozen different ISPs, simply repeat the procedure for each one.

It is useful to have your ISP's icon on the desktop, instead of having to open the Dial-Up Networking folder each time. To do this, right-click your new ISP icon and select Create Shortcut. Windows will ask if you want an icon on your desktop: click Yes. (Windows Me users can simply drag the icon on to the desktop.) If you like, you can select this shortcut and press F2 to give it a better name.

All this assumes that you have subscribed to an ISP and been sent a letter with your log-on name, password and phone number. Usually this will be an 0345 or 0845 or similar number that is the same wherever you live. If you don't have it, you can usually get it from the help line, from a magazine, or from the service's website.

With many services, such as Freeserve, you can sign up while online, perhaps from a friend's computer. (This can be useful if you are a Mac user.) In these cases, you know the user name and password because you chose them yourself. However, you must also look for the right phone number to dial, and write it down.

When signing up online, it's important not to download anything, or you may end up in the same position as if you had used a disc. Just get the user name and password accepted, then drop the line.

An ISP's CD is usually designed to get you online so that you can sign up for their service. However, it is better to do this using BT Click. You can set up BT Click using Dial-up Networking, and use it with any name and password you like. Just make them up. Use the phone number 0845 7576333. (But because this service seems anonymous, don't think you can use it for evil purposes. BT logs your phone number to avoid this service being abused.)

You can therefore use BT Click to sign up for Freeserve or whatever. And if Freeserve is not working very well, you have BT Click as a back-up service.

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: More Lara | PS2 update | Minesweeping
fields.body:
More Lara
Tonight, Tomb Raider the movie is scheduled to peek out from behind its cloak of secrecy, or start cranking up the hype machine, whichever you prefer. At 7.30pm there will be a live webcast from Pinewood Studios, with "Interviews, Chats And More!" The website is at www.tombraidermovie.com.

More Zelda
The next game in the Zelda series, Majora's Mask, is scheduled to arrive next Friday for the Nintendo 64. You play Link, and the novel bit is that you can turn into different characters by putting on different masks, Nintendo says. However, there's no time for sightseeing, because you have only 72 hours to save the world. Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask will cost £45 and needs an Expansion Pak.

PS2 update
American gamers exhibited "PS2 hysteria" when the Sony PlayStation 2 went on sale last month, according to Matt Gravett, game analyst for PC Data in Reston, Virginia. He says they were buying $50 games even though they weren't sure of getting any hardware to play them on. Two PS2 games made the top 10 games chart (see below). Other PS2 best sellers included SSX (Electronic Arts), Armoured Core 2 (Agetec) and Smuggler's Run (Take 2 Interactive/Rockstar). Fortunately nothing like that could happen in the UK, where Future is launching the 180-page Official PlayStation 2 magazine tomorrow.

Minesweeping
If you get caught playing Minesweeper in class, now you can claim to be working on a significant maths problem. At least, that's the implication you could draw from Richard Kaye, a maths lecturer at the University of Birmingham. Kaye reckons that if someone were to figure out an algorithm for determining all combinations of mine placement in a large-scale version of Minesweeper, they would have solved the "P versus NP" problem.

Unfortunately you'd have to do some real maths homework to be able to answer the inevitable question: And what's that? Still, you can always start at Kaye's Minesweeper page at www.mat.bham.ac.uk/R.W.Kaye/minesw/minesw.htm.

fields.headline: The gamers go to Hollywood
fields.standfirst: With a $70m budget, Shenmue is the Dreamcast equivelent of a Cecil B DeMille epic. Greg Howson reports
fields.trailText: With a $70m budget, Shenmue is the Dreamcast equivelent of a Cecil B DeMille epic. Greg Howson reports
fields.body:
It took four years to develop, with production costs of $70million and 337 actors, but this isn't the latest Kevin Costner epic. It is a videogame called Shenmue.

Yes, the industry that is displaying increasingly celluloid tendencies - sequels, formulaic retreads and star vehicles - is beginning to match Hollywood's expensive production costs. Shenmue is released for the Sega Dreamcast in December and is the most costly game ever produced.

The $70million includes R&D for the planned sequels. However, even a cursory glance reveals where the money was spent. The sumptuous visuals are the most impressive on any games console to date, but it's the interaction that is most striking. Set in a realistically realised Japan of 1986 your aim is to investigate the murder of your father by speaking to everyone that you can.

Time ticks (a game day corresponds to roughly one hour real time) as you converse with more than 300 characters, each with their own foibles and daily routines, and it soon becomes clear that this is no ordinary Dreamcast title. Stewart Turner of Sega explains why the game cost so much: "Basically it's down to the sheer size of the game with 330 actors and a quality script, plus the ability to interact with almost anything."

But Shenmue is only the most extreme example of these rapidly increasing videogame production costs. Tony Beckwith of developers Climax Brighton, remembers how things have changed: "In 1987 the most expensive ZX Spectrum games cost £10,000 to make. By 1992 the first SNES games cost about $100,000-$150,000 and the development costs of a multi-format game (PlayStation and PC) in 1997 were around $2,000,000". These figures are set to rocket with the imminent launch of new consoles like PlayStation 2 and Microsoft's Xbox, and Beckwith estimates the average game for these machines will cost at least $5 million to develop.

Even the handheld Game Boy has been affected. Cameron Sheppard of GB developers Crawfish, has seen costs rise: "Prices on the new Game Boy Advance are looking likely to be between £170,000 and £340,000 - double what people were paying for a Game Boy product two years ago."

So why have development costs risen so fast? The reason is partly down to the increasingly mainstream nature of the videogame industry. Over 70 million PlayStations have been sold worldwide and characters like Lara Croft have become household names. This, along with the increased graphical power of the new consoles, has raised consumer expectations.

Sheppard explains: "The development process of each game, regardless of format, is akin to producing a movie with a lot of similar skills applied - producer, scriptwriter, musician, artist - and budgets have grown in order to produce the polished product that the players have come to expect."

As production costs spiral, many smaller developers have been looking at other cheaper, yet potentially lucrative, platforms such as Wap and interactive TV. And, with companies like Motorola exhibiting at the recent ECTS games trade show, it is clear that wireless gaming has a future even if these titles will initially be simplistic affairs that are more Blair Witch than Waterworld.

However, for the main players in the market, it seems as if the cost of producing videogames will continue to rise, with the attendant threat of risk-aversion and dull sequels. Shenmue shows that a big budget game can succeed on a creative level, although whether the stylish yet slow-paced title will ever recoup its costs remains to be seen. But, with movie-like production values becoming the norm, it is certain that Shenmue will not be the last multi-million pound game.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Groove.net | Indy Israel | iBeacons
fields.body:
Groovin'
Groove.net is a new peer-to-peer software system that, like Napster and Gnutella, allows users to share computer files over the net. But Groove promises to add instant messaging, either with text or voice, video and threaded discussions. And what's more, Groove is opening up its source code so that the platform can be integrated into most networks, and so that coders can build software packages to work off Groove.

Which all sounds great, in theory. But Groove is the brainchild of Ray Ozzie, who previously gave the world Lotus Notes, one of the most maligned pieces of office software. Also, the beta version will work only on PCs, which rules out a lot of design agencies, newspapers and publishing houses. Still, it is a brave attempt, and an interesting piece of software that might beat Napster and become the first commercial file-sharing protocol on the net.

Hot to trot?
If you want to look at the daftest idea for a website this year, turn your browser to http://amihotornot.com. But be warned, it is incredibly addictive. The idea is to get people to upload pictures of themselves and then everyone else gives them a rating out of 10. Now, either some people are incredibly brave, or they have some very cruel "friends". Lots of fun, especially if you decide to be kind and give all the ugly ones 10 out of 10.

Meet here
The web is so full of listings sites that a listing site listing them all is probably long over due. But what about a listings site that actually arranges like-minded people to go along to events together? Step forward www.dobe.com, a brave attempt by the UK-based Institute for Social Inventions. The site, which provides free bulletin boards, is still in beta. The events themselves range from walks in the country to picnics, and the site has even branched out with a US version.

Indy Israel
An Independent Media Centre (IMC) has been launched to cover the Arab-Israeli conflict. IMC-Israel describes itself as "a democratic website where anybody can publish news/views, pictures, audio and video without being censored". It has been active since October 8 and is claiming more than 6,500 hits per day.

A number of independent media centres (IMCs) exist across the globe. One was established in the UK to cover the May Day demonstrations and, more recently, an IMC was set up to cover the events around the IMF meeting in Prague.

Unfiltered reporting from Israel has been done before. Sites such as www.palestine-info.net (Palestinian) and www.virtualjerusalem.com/israelwire (Israeli) have been covering Arab-Israeli politics. But the Israeli IMC is the first to include material from both sides. See www.indymedia.org.il.

iBeacons
Avery Architects, the firm responsible for the London Imax cinema, has designed an internet beacon for 21st century village life. Every village, town and city would be encouraged to erect a beacon to mark the millennium, says Avery. These should be sponsored locally, and could be variable in size and material to suit local conditions, but the standard version would be 9.27m high. Every beacon has one or more phone card operated interactive screens, which give local environmental read-outs from the sensors and global ecological data from land lines or satellites. See www.avery-architects.co.uk/beacon.html for details.

Unseen Jam
Controversial comic Chris Morris has released a skit that was originally included in the first series of the radio show Blue Jam in 1997. After "intense editorial discussions", the sketch was deemed unacceptable but was smuggled into programme six at the last minute and broadcast almost in its entirety before being faded by a transmission engineer. See www.warprecords.com/warp for another look.

New and noted
 To mark the release of their new Best of album, Blur have launched their own net radio station at www.blur-radio.com.

 The International Fund for Animal Welfare has launched a new anti-blood sports website at www.banhunting.com.

 Whittard, the tea and coffee shop has gone online at www.whittard.com.

 Durex.com is hoping to promote safe sex with an online Egg Invaders game.

 TheRumour.com is a new celebrity and gossip site aimed at 18-24 year olds.

 Bargain hunters may like www.halfpriceorless.com, which sells beauty products, toys and games, and clothes.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Madonnline | CDs grow up
fields.body:
Madonnline
Madonna - pictured performing an acoustic set on US television last week - is playing her first live online concert later this month.

There has already been a stampede for the limited number of tickets for the non-virtual gig at the Brixton Academy, London.

But the thousands locked out on November 28 could find some consolation online - especially if they can find a super-fast net connection - as Microsoft Network has secured the webcast rights for the show.

Users who have "extremely fast internet connections" (read: are using the computer at work) will be able to tap in to a 700kbps stream, which MSN claims will offer "near-DVD-quality" pictures and sound.

Other streams will be available at a "near-VHS-quality" 300 kbps, and 128, 80 and 56 kbps. A 28k sound-only link will also be available.

MSN will also be running a series of features and competitions in the run-up to the gig.

Fans will be able to chat online with Madonna on November 24 at 7pm, and enter a competition to win signed merchandise.

MSN already holds the world record for the most viewed webcast, when 3 million net users tuned in to watch Paul McCartney's return to the Cavern in Liverpool last year. See www.msn.co.uk/madonna (NM)

CDs grow up
TDK and Calimetrics have announced what they believe should become the next generation high capacity CD-R/RW format.

Scheduled to debut at the Comdex exhibition in Las Vegas next week is Multilevel high-density CD hardware and media. The companies claim that this new system ups the storage capacity of a CD-R/CD-RW disc from 700MB to 2 gigabytes. It can also download data three times faster than a conventional drive.

It achieves this through a combination of new chip technology for the drives and an innovative method of burning data on to the media.

The downside is that the new discs are completely incompatible with all existing CD drives.

The Multilevel drives are expected to reach the US market in the third quarter of 2001, where they will face fierce competition from other new high-density storage systems including DVD-RAM and DVD+RW.

Wap-asonic
Panasonic has become the last of the major mobile phone players to deliver a Wap phone. Its GD-93 model, which becomes available this month on the BT Cellnet and Vodafone networks, apparently uses software culled from the company's Japanese i-mode models.

Like its sibling, the GD-92, its headline feature is the ability to send and receive emails through an existing account, although setting this up is rather involved.

The model also shares its predecessor's other trump card - a built-in recorder to record your favourites tune as a ring tone. It also has a built-in modem and voice recorder.

Finished in silver, the GD-93 weighs 80g, has a talk time of around 210 minutes and a battery standby of up to 170 hours. It is on sale now for around £80.

Surf your camera
Working on the premise that its big 3.5inch LCD screen is ideal for examining websites and emails, Ricoh has grafted web-browsing software to its RDC-7 digital camera. The new model, re-christened the RDC-i700, goes on sale later this month for around £1,000.

By inserting a modem card into the camera users can send and receive data and image emails, surf the net and even create HTML files and upload them to a website.

The camera is a top-end 3.3 mega pixel model that also sports a 3x optical zoom, video facilities, 8MB of internal memory and a slot for a CompactFlash card. It's on sale later this month via Johnson's Photopia. (AN)

There has already been a stampede for the limited number of tickets for the non-virtual gig at the Brixton Academy, London. But the thousands locked out on November 28 could find some consolation online - especially if they can find a super-fast net connection - as Microsoft Network has secured the webcast rights for the show. Users who have "extremely fast internet connections" (read: are using the computer at work) will be able to tap in to a 700kbps stream, which MSN claims will offer "near-DVD-quality" pictures and sound. Other streams will be available at a "near-VHS-quality" 300 kbps, and 128, 80 and 56 kbps. A 28k sound-only link will also be available. MSN will also be running a series of features and competitions in the run-up to the gig. Fans will be able to chat online with Madonna on November 24 at 7pm, and enter a competition to win signed merchandise. MSN already holds the world record for the most viewed webcast, when 3 million net users tuned in to watch Paul McCartney's return to the Cavern in Liverpool last year. See www.msn.co.uk/madonna (NM) CDs grow up TDK and Calimetrics have announced what they believe should become the next generation high capacity CD-R/RW format. Scheduled to debut at the Comdex exhibition in Las Vegas next week is Multilevel high-density CD hardware and media. The companies claim that this new system ups the storage capacity of a CD-R/CD-RW disc from 700MB to 2 gigabytes. It can also download data three times faster than a conventional drive. It achieves this through a combination of new chip technology for the drives and an innovative method of burning data on to the media. The downside is that the new discs are completely incompatible with all existing CD drives. The Multilevel drives are expected to reach the US market in the third quarter of 2001, where they will face fierce competition from other new high-density storage systems including DVD-RAM and DVD+RW. Wap-asonic Panasonic has become the last of the major mobile phone players to deliver a Wap phone. Its GD-93 model, which becomes available this month on the BT Cellnet and Vodafone networks, apparently uses software culled from the company's Japanese i-mode models. Like its sibling, the GD-92, its headline feature is the ability to send and receive emails through an existing account, although setting this up is rather involved. The model also shares its predecessor's other trump card - a built-in recorder to record your favourites tune as a ring tone. It also has a built-in modem and voice recorder. Finished in silver, the GD-93 weighs 80g, has a talk time of around 210 minutes and a battery standby of up to 170 hours. It is on sale now for around £80. Surf your camera Working on the premise that its big 3.5inch LCD screen is ideal for examining websites and emails, Ricoh has grafted web-browsing software to its RDC-7 digital camera. The new model, re-christened the RDC-i700, goes on sale later this month for around £1,000. By inserting a modem card into the camera users can send and receive data and image emails, surf the net and even create HTML files and upload them to a website. The camera is a top-end 3.3 mega pixel model that also sports a 3x optical zoom, video facilities, 8MB of internal memory and a slot for a CompactFlash card. It's on sale later this month via Johnson's Photopia. (AN)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
MP3 charity
Wouldn't it be nice if Napster et al provided the means for voluntary donations to be given directly to those artists currently having their music downloaded free? I would be more than happy to donate a few quid in the knowledge that my failure do so might contribute to their demise.

If implemented, this proposal would help people think more deeply about their responsibilities as consumers, and, who knows, may even lead to more charitable giving generally. It should also serve to stave off any further civil action if it can be shown that artists have not suffered substantial monetary loss. As for record companies, who cares?
Tony Troy
tony.troy@virgin.net

Rights wrong
Every click you make (Online, November 2) made the usual noises about human rights being violated by employers accessing their employees' emails, phone calls and so on. I want to confess to being a violator.

Before retirement, I ran a hi-tech company. I bought the kit, paid the mortgage, the electricity and the phone bills. I offered work in a congenial, sociable atmosphere. I deliberately paid 25% over the going rate. In return, I expected our employees to work hard, and allowed them free use of email, phone lines and internet.

Mostly this situation of trust worked. Sometimes it didn't and I had to violate some human rights. On one occasion, a woman who started "work" early (we ran a trust-based flexitime system) was found to be on the phone to her boyfriend for an hour every day, before the rest of us got in. I abused her rights by shouting at her.

On another, a man who wanted to work into the nights on a "personal" project (I told you we were soft) ran up a £150 phone bill downloading hardcore porn from foreign phone numbers. I abused his rights by taking the money off his wages. Oh, I am also an entirely unreconstructed (whatever that means) Marxist, and was the only paid-up union member in the company.
Allen Ives
tony.troy@virgin.net

(Un)civil rights
Yet another story about nasty employers snooping on their employees' emails.

Using internet resources provided for work for personal reasons costs money - in wasted time that could be spent actually working - in ISDN dial-up charges and/or bandwidth. It would be difficult to hide a 30-minute personal phone call but someone can easily surf the web or send out tens of megabytes in email attachments through a central server and incur the same, or greater, costs without drawing any attention.

An off-colour message sent to the wrong person can expose a company to legal action and cost thousands of pounds in damages. These are real costs and real risks.

If people are concerned about their civil liberties being infringed, they should send their (un)civil emails from home. There should be no expectation of privacy on their employers' premises, using their employers' computers and running up their employers' phone bill.
Robert Lawrence
monged@ntlworld.com

Desperate bid
I am surprised nobody has suggested the obvious reason for hacking into Microsoft's source code. Desperate users trying to de-bug it! Richard Page
richardpage@veg-edible.clara.co.uk

Equal battle
The article Battle to be Equal (Online November 2), needs to be framed in the broader context of the recognition of the rights of people with disabilities under disabilities legislation in Australia.

The Online Council of Australian Ministers has agreed to the adoption of internationally recognised standards such as those developed by the world wide web consortium accessibility initiative ( www.w3.org/wai ). At a Commonwealth level, there is a requirement that websites meet standards by December.

One of the difficulties in meeting these standards is the lack of a good knowledge base about the practicalities of such standards, which at first sight appear abstruse.

With the disability charity Vision Australia, Vicnet is one of the few organisations providing training workshops for government webmasters, and many webmasters have now been offered training and support. Workshops have also been offered in New Zealand.

It would be useful if the practical training sessions such as those we have developed were also held in the UK and other countries, or else the standards will continue to seem theoretical, and excuses for non-implementation of even basic accessibility techniques will still be made.
Larry Stillman
larrys@vicnet.net.au

Vital vetting
In response to Dr Mark Griffiths' letter expressing his concerns about pre-paid debit cards allowing children access to unsuitable goods and services on the net, while I cannot speak for other providers, I can point out that reputable card providers make it a priority to accept only e-retailers that provide suitable products to that particular demographic group. As each retailer has to be individually configured to accept our card system it is a simple matter of ensuring that only carefully researched and vetted online stores have access to the payment system and the children who use it. Matt Johnson
Eurospend Ltd seanstewart30@hotmail.com

Biggles credit
To give credit where due, the Biggles illustration in Online (November 2) was drawn by Mike Western, taken from the Biggles strip which he drew in 1961 for the weekly comic paper TV Express. David A Simpson
david-a-simpson@beeb.net

Generation X
In What's New (Online, November 2) you say "UK phones are at the 1G (first generation) level with the first 2G systems based on GPRS just coming in to use". In fact GSM, which is widely used today, is a 2G standard. First generation cellular networks employed analog transmission. 2G networks are digital. GPRS is a 2.5G standard, an intermediate standard to 3G. Philip Walsh
philiprwalsh@supanet.com

fields.headline: Designs on the web
fields.standfirst: Matt Luxon is founder and managing director of the web design company Hildebrand Interactive
fields.trailText: Matt Luxon is founder and managing director of the web design company Hildebrand Interactive
fields.body:
Is the internet still exciting? The net is still just beginning. A lot of the things that annoy us about it - the slow downloads and search problems - demonstrate what an early phase we are in. The main problem is our inability to conceive the web as a medium in its own right. We seem to focus on forcing traditional media models into the web format.

So you think we're not utilising the net to its full potential? No. And not only on an individual level, but on a global level, too. A lot of people still see the net in terms of commerce, but increasingly we're using it more for entertainment and education. One of our clients, Elan Technologies, a medical software company, is going to make electronic patient records available internationally through the web. If you think of the impact that will have on the NHS, it makes you think about all the different areas that the web could affect.

How would you rate the standard of design on the net? It is so diverse - kids with their own homepages right through to professional companies dedicated to exploring the medium. Saying that, there is a lot of bad design. It's great that anyone can get online relatively cheaply and communicate with the rest of the world, as that helps keep the web weird and wonderful. But in our market, the DIY attitude can also really damage carefully maintained brands.

So what do you think constitutes a good website? Usability, content, attractive design, intuitive navigation and functionality. The key thing is that the people who are building the site take the client's needs into consideration. If users get the experience they want, then they'll come back. What is often lacking is the quality of copy on websites.

Any personal favourite sites? I like any site that tries to push the medium and do something different. I like the site we've just done for Jah Wobble at www.molamdub.com because it forces the user to interact with the music. I think www.heavy.com is a great site, too. It's quite irreverent but it uses some very cool technology. Even though I'm biased, I think the Arsenal site is one of the best football club sites. Another cool site is the Atom Films site.

Do you like gadgets? Definitely. I've got a Compaq iPac, which is brilliant, and I have a Sony VAIO laptop, which is still my favourite gadget. I'm also looking forward to the PlayStation 2, which is about to replace one of my favourite gadgets ever!

How important is broadband going to be? It will make a huge difference. As soon you can browse the net through the television, we are going to see the internet explode. You are then reaching the non-computer-using consumer. There is no longer the barrier of the technology preventing people from experiencing the net. Also, for the first time, television is no longer going to be a passive medium. Even less excuse to get off the couch!

Visit www.hildebrandinteractive.com
