fields.headline: Surfing through space
fields.standfirst:
Jack Schofield meets the man who brought you the internet and is now involved in a project that could bring you a .mars domain name
Net news
fields.trailText: Jack Schofield meets the man who brought you the internet and is now involved in a project that could bring you a .mars domain name
fields.body:
While the internet is taking over the earth, Dr Vinton Gray Cerf - Vint, for short - is working to extend it to the rest of the solar system. And while Cerf is known for his sense of humour, this is not a joke. He's working with Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory to make it a reality.

"We've designed a whole new set of protocols to augment the existing internet protocols, so we could effectively build a network of internets," says Cerf. "We put interplanetary gateways in orbit around the planets and satellites, and we run these new interplanetary networks through deep space. That's a very practical way of reducing costs in the interplanetary research effort.

"And the UK has a critical role in this," he adds. "It is going to be launching the STRV 1D research satellite in the middle of November, and it will be carrying our interplanetary protocols. We've just finished implementing the prototypes, and they work!

"Then there's a moon launch that is possible at the end of 2001, with a lander on it, and that's going to carry the interplanetary internet protocols. Then we are scheduled to be on two Nasa missions to Mars, to land on the planet.

"After that we have missions to launch satellites around Mars: those will become the backbone of a two-planet internet. From there we expand outwards: as each mission goes to the outer planets, they'll carry a little bit of the internet with them. It's like living in a science fiction novel! There's a practical reason for doing all this, but it's also just plain fun."

Being the father of the internet, founding president of the Internet Society, recipient of the US National Medal of Technology and other awards, and senior vice president of internet architecture and technology for WorldCom, has never stopped Cerf having fun. For example, when taking part in a "shoot-out" with Bob Metcalfe, the inventor of Ethernet networking, at an industry trade show in 1998, he donned a cowboy hat and a couple of (holstered) six-guns.

During a heated argument at an Internet Engineering Task Force meeting about the future of the Internet Protocol (IP), the basis of internet communications, in 1992, Cerf stripped down to a T-shirt bearing the words "IP on Everything". He's serious about what the slogan means, but he still chuckles about the pun. "Now everyone wants to put whatever they have on top of the internet, I should have a new T-shirt made that says 'IP Under Everything'," he says.

Not even posing for the Guardian's photographer, for this article, dented his good humour. When he saw I was suffering some strain from holding Frank Baron's light, he suggested that if I did a good job I might be promoted to a hat stand. Anyone with a fraction of Cerf's achievements could easily have become self-important, but he has down-to-earth ways of defusing tension and generating camaraderie that must have been priceless in the net's early days.

Which is not to say the early days have gone, because Cerf is still building the future. In the 1990s, for example, he was promoting the expansion of the number of internet addresses [IP numbers] available. When most people still didn't know what the internet was, he wanted an internet address for every electron on the planet. Now people are finally catching on to the idea of the internet being everywhere, he's pushing into space.

This is not just to solve Nasa's communications problems, but to answer the question Cerf asked himself: "What should I be doing now, that we'll need 20 years from now? One answer is that maybe some day we will need a commercial backbone that is interplanetary in scope, and we'd better be ready, technologically," he says. "We don't have to build all of it right away, but I want to know how to build it."

As he points out, the internet also started as a long-term research project with practical near-term goals. It began in 1969 when Arpanet, the Advanced Research Projects Agency network, was set up by the US Defence Department as a way of sharing expensive computing facilities between universities. Cerf helped to develop it when he was a graduate student at the University of California at Los Angeles, and then at Stanford University, after he joined the faculty in 1972.

The Arpanet was innovative, being based on a packet-switching system conceived earlier by Paul Baran (ie, it works like the postal service, except the packets are computer data rather than physical letters and parcels). But not everyone could be on the Arpanet, and there was the bigger problem of connecting different networks together. The world needed an internetworking system, or internet. That's what Cerf and Arpa's Bob Kahn described in a paper published in 1974, and their TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) system made the internet what it is today.

Cerf joined Arpa in 1976 to manage the various research projects involved in implementing TCP/IP, and in 1983, it finally became mandatory as a way of moving internet data. This made Cerf, by popular acclaim, "the Father of the Internet".

Cerf has sometimes resisted what he calls "this figurehead notion", and he is always ready to put forward the names of other people who helped create the internet. "Things with this scale don't happen unless thousands of people are involved, and something that makes the internet valuable is that it makes it easy for people to contribute," he says. "That collaborative aspect of the net is what contributes to its power."

On the other hand, Cerf has also used his position to influence users, researchers, companies and governments, and at MCI WorldCom, where he works, to build high-speed internet backbones. Things that could have sounded outrageous coming from others were taken seriously by the US Defence Department, and by politicians such as Al Gore, because Cerf said them.

"Yes, there's a bully pulpit element to all this," Cerf says, borrowing a phrase President Theodore Roosevelt used about the White House. "For almost 30 years I've done everything I could to promote the internet. I feel simultaneously privileged to have had so many opportunities to speak to so many people about the internet, but what I honestly hope, and truly believe is the case, is that people have decided for themselves. If the internet is widely accepted, it's simply the recognition of an idea whose time has come. For that you can't take credit."

The IT industries are so quick to align behind winners that those not involved usually remain blissfully ignorant of the bloody battles that precede any standardisation. However, the internet's acceptance has been a long time coming, and it has been a struggle.

Cerf nods. "It's true, many people resisted it," he says. "Its predecessor, the Arpanet, was considered a silly idea that wouldn't work, and it was ridiculed by people who grew up in the telephone tradition. Most of the computer science communities also rejected the idea of connecting up, and Arpa had to insist.

"When it came time to convert from the old Arpanet protocols to the new internet protocols, in January 1983, there was tremendous resistance. Finally, we had to force it on people by turning off the old protocols, so we jammed it down their throats. Then came the lengthy debate between the OSI and internet protocols, and again, that was a 10-year battle."

Far from promoting the internet, most governments - including the US, the UK and the EC - adopted OSI (Open Systems Interconnect) networking in the 1980s, partly to block the advance of IBM's SNA (Systems Network Architecture). The far simpler IP, which had taken root in academe and the research community, was rarely considered, and almost always rejected for commercial use.

The irony is that not only has IP triumphed over rival networking systems, it is also being used to carry voice traffic (Online, October 26) by the telephone companies who used to disparage it.

"It is a delicious irony, but we certainly didn't set out to upset the applecart," says Cerf. "Looking back, we were so thoroughly rejected by the telephony community, we were left to our own resources to build our own private network, unregulated and unmanaged: we were outside their purview completely. But we could see the potential for upset, because we were experimenting with voice on the net as far back as 1975, when the backbone was only [running at] 50kbits/ sec. We used to transmit voice using a form of coding that made everyone sound like a drunken Norwegian: it was a lovely lilting sound.

"As far back as 1979, we were doing studies analysing which would be most cost-effective: two separate networks for voice and data, a hybrid network, or one which was all packets. Even then, the analysis said that an all-packet network, if it were big enough, would be more cost-effective. And guess what: that's what's starting to emerge!"

It has taken the world 20 years to catch up with Cerf, and it may be more than 20 before the interplanetary internet makes much of an impact. But if you start getting email from Martians, you'll know who to blame.

But not everyone could be on the Arpanet, and there was the bigger problem of connecting different networks together. The world needed an internetworking system, or internet. That's what Cerf and Arpa's Bob Kahn described in a paper published in 1974, and their TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) system made the internet what it is today. Cerf joined Arpa in 1976 to manage the various research projects involved in implementing TCP/IP, and in 1983, it finally became mandatory as a way of moving internet data. This made Cerf, by popular acclaim, "the Father of the Internet". Cerf has sometimes resisted what he calls "this figurehead notion", and he is always ready to put forward the names of other people who helped create the internet. "Things with this scale don't happen unless thousands of people are involved, and something that makes the internet valuable is that it makes it easy for people to contribute," he says. "That collaborative aspect of the net is what contributes to its power." On the other hand, Cerf has also used his position to influence users, researchers, companies and governments, and at MCI WorldCom, where he works, to build high-speed internet backbones. Things that could have sounded outrageous coming from others were taken seriously by the US Defence Department, and by politicians such as Al Gore, because Cerf said them. "Yes, there's a bully pulpit element to all this," Cerf says, borrowing a phrase President Theodore Roosevelt used about the White House. "For almost 30 years I've done everything I could to promote the internet. I feel simultaneously privileged to have had so many opportunities to speak to so many people about the internet, but what I honestly hope, and truly believe is the case, is that people have decided for themselves. If the internet is widely accepted, it's simply the recognition of an idea whose time has come. For that you can't take credit." The IT industries are so quick to align behind winners that those not involved usually remain blissfully ignorant of the bloody battles that precede any standardisation. However, the internet's acceptance has been a long time coming, and it has been a struggle. Cerf nods. "It's true, many people resisted it," he says. "Its predecessor, the Arpanet, was considered a silly idea that wouldn't work, and it was ridiculed by people who grew up in the telephone tradition. Most of the computer science communities also rejected the idea of connecting up, and Arpa had to insist. "When it came time to convert from the old Arpanet protocols to the new internet protocols, in January 1983, there was tremendous resistance. Finally, we had to force it on people by turning off the old protocols, so we jammed it down their throats. Then came the lengthy debate between the OSI and internet protocols, and again, that was a 10-year battle." Far from promoting the internet, most governments - including the US, the UK and the EC - adopted OSI (Open Systems Interconnect) networking in the 1980s, partly to block the advance of IBM's SNA (Systems Network Architecture). The far simpler IP, which had taken root in academe and the research community, was rarely considered, and almost always rejected for commercial use. The irony is that not only has IP triumphed over rival networking systems, it is also being used to carry voice traffic (Online, October 26) by the telephone companies who used to disparage it. "It is a delicious irony, but we certainly didn't set out to upset the applecart," says Cerf. "Looking back, we were so thoroughly rejected by the telephony community, we were left to our own resources to build our own private network, unregulated and unmanaged: we were outside their purview completely. But we could see the potential for upset, because we were experimenting with voice on the net as far back as 1975, when the backbone was only [running at] 50kbits/ sec. We used to transmit voice using a form of coding that made everyone sound like a drunken Norwegian: it was a lovely lilting sound. "As far back as 1979, we were doing studies analysing which would be most cost-effective: two separate networks for voice and data, a hybrid network, or one which was all packets. Even then, the analysis said that an all-packet network, if it were big enough, would be more cost-effective. And guess what: that's what's starting to emerge!" It has taken the world 20 years to catch up with Cerf, and it may be more than 20 before the interplanetary internet makes much of an impact. But if you start getting email from Martians, you'll know who to blame.

webTitle: Voters open a legal can of worms

fields.headline: Voters open a legal can of worms
fields.standfirst:
Constitution: System left by the founding fathers faces a profound test

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: If George W Bush does finally carry the state of Florida by a handful of votes, while Al Gore wins the popular vote by what appeared yesterday to be a margin of a quarter of a million, the stage will be set for a profound reappraisal of one of the revered constitutional quirks the United States inherited from its founding fathers.
fields.body:
If George W Bush does finally carry the state of Florida by a handful of votes, while Al Gore wins the popular vote by what appeared yesterday to be a margin of a quarter of a million, the stage will be set for a profound reappraisal of one of the revered constitutional quirks the United States inherited from its founding fathers.

It is called the electoral college, an assembly of 538 delegates (or electors), from the 50 states and the District of Columbia, selected according to the vote in those states.

It is the electoral college, not the people, which ultimately chooses the president and this form of indirect democracy is deliberate. Back in 1787, when the system was thought up, the revered founding fathers did not have total confidence in the ordinary man. The population was liable to be reckless, they thought. The college would serve as a buffer, made up of men drawn from the educated elite who, Alexander Hamilton argued, would "possess the information and discernment requisite" to the task of choosing a president.

It is an interesting aspect of US politics that Americans show even more reverence for traditions than the British. The founding fathers retain a heroic, untouchable status which means that the wording of the constitution and its famous amendments are treated almost as sacred.

Under the current system, the electoral college votes on the first Monday after the second Wednesday in December. This year that will be December 18. Each state has a set number of votes in the college, roughly according to its size, and the affiliation of its delegates is generally decided on a first-past-the-post majority system. Thus, whoever wins Florida will win all its 25 votes. This is true for all states bar two, Maine and Nebraska, which distribute their electors more in accordance with the preponderance of the vote.

The electors, party officials chosen by the majority party in each state, will convene in their home states on December 18 to sign and certify their votes which will be sent to the Senate for counting on January 6.

Controversy
In 1824, Andrew Jackson, the popular choice, failed to muster the necessary electoral votes and John Quincy Adams was elected instead. Coincidentally, that was also the last time the son of a former president rose to become president himself. Adams' father, John Adams, was the nation's second president. In 1876, Republican Rutherford Hayes beat Democrat Samuel Tilden by a single elector, 185-184, despite a popular vote which pointed the other way.

The last time such a controversy arose was in 1888 when Benjamin Harrison lost the popular vote to Grover Cleveland but won the White House on the strength of his victory in the electoral college.

That was then. This is now. There is arguably less tolerance now for the popular will to be so blithely overturned. Certainly, when pundits were predicting that Mr Bush might well win the popular vote, but Mr Gore prevail in the electoral college, Republican rank and file activists around the country were telling anyone who would listen that they hoped the electors sent by the states would listen to the voice of the people and not try to defy its democratic mandate. In other words, the electors should cross party lines and vote according to the overall national election results.

Now the boot is on the other foot, and certainly the Democratic party activists could be expected to call for delegates to bend their state mandates. There have been precedents. In 1988, an elector decided not to vote for Michael Dukakis, although a majority in the elector's home state had voted for the Democratic presidential contender. The elector thought Mr Dukakis had run a bad campaign and voted against him. But that vote did not determine the outcome of the entire election. A change of as few as two votes on this occasion (if, say, Mr Bush wins Florida, and Mr Gore wins Oregon) could do precisely that.

If there is a tie in the electoral college, the House of Representatives chooses the president with representatives from 26 states required to elect a winner. If the House tied with 25 states for each candidate, the Senate would then decide. But what happens if the vote is a 50-50 draw in the Senate? Then the vice-president is supposed to break the tie, and that man is, at the moment, none other than Al Gore.

National crisis
It is highly unlikely it will come to that, but the possibility of a conflict between the popular vote and the electoral college decision does seem increasingly probable.

"There will be a national crisis if the candidate with fewer popular votes wins the presidential election," said Charles Cook, a political analyst, adding that the chances of that scenario are slim. "The president would be legally legitimate but politically illegitimate."

William Mayer, a political science professor at Northeastern university in Boston who specialises in elections, said the days of the electoral college could now be numbered.

"Why bother changing something that has worked for more than 100 years?" he asked. "But if it doesn't work this time around, that's the last we'll see of it. It will be jettisoned."

However, such a constitutional amendment would require a two thirds vote in Congress, a rare occurrence.

More likely would be a reform of the winner-takes-all system and a transition to proportional representation of each state in the electoral college, according the breakdown of the party vote in that state.

Either way, a crisis over the role of the electoral college in a country which generally views its system as a distillation of democracy would be, in the words of one of the potential electors this year, "a complete mess".

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, said he has decided not to refer Microsoft 's acquisition of a 23.6% interest in Telewest Communications to the competition commission.

 Results

Fibre optics company Bookham Technologies yesterday said its crucial expansion in manufacturing capacity is on track. It reported £6.3m losses for the third quarter, up from £4.6m for the previous quarter, and revenues of £7.7m, an increase of two thirds.

 Job creation

Canadian solutions group Nortel Networks is to create 1,300 new jobs by investing $100m (£69m) on expanding its facilities in New Southgate, in north London, and Harlow, Essex, over the next three years.

webTitle:
Vodafone plugs gap with 
Swiss deal

fields.headline:
Vodafone plugs gap with 
Swiss deal
fields.trailText: Consolidation within the European mobile phone sector took another leap forward yesterday with two £1bn plus deals in Switzerland.
fields.body:
Consolidation within the European mobile phone sector took another leap forward yesterday with two £1bn plus deals in Switzerland.

Britain's Vodafone is paying £1.73bn for a 25% stake in state-controlled Swisscom's mobile phone business in a move which is widely seen as plugging the last remaining gap in its European portfolio.

At the same time France Telecom doubled its stake in Switzerland's number two phone group, Orange Communications, by buying the 42.5% stake owned by E.ON for just over £1bn.

Both deals are linked to the outcome of the forthcoming auction of third generation mobile phone licences. The price France Telecom is paying for Orange could go up by 20% depending on how much it has to pay to win one of the four licences on offer, while the Vodafone deal assum es the Swiss Mobilcom will win one of the licences on offer.

Bidding could be fierce. With nine contenders lining up to win one of the licences on offer, Switzerland is unlikely to suffer the fate which befell the Italian auction which had almost as many licences as bidders and which came to a premature close when one of the runners pulled out.

The Italian government has since demanded that Blu - the BT-led consortium which withdrew - should forfeit its deposit, a move which is being strongly resisted by Blu.

Yesterday, Vodafone said it was content with a minority holding in Swiss Mobilcom, which is expected to be floated off from its state-controlled parent in the new year.

"This deal has been on the basis of Vodafone being an associate, minority shareholder," said Julian Horn-Smith, chief executive of Vodafone Europe. However, the British group does have an option to raise its stake to 49% if a further minority stake is sold.

The two deals are the latest in a series of mergers, acquisitions and stake purchases within the industry over the past 15 months. They include Deutsche Telekom's purchase of One2One, Mannesmann's acquisition of Orange and its own subsequent takeover by Vodafone. One of the knock-on consequences of that battle was the sale of Orange to France Telecom.

Other deals include British Telecom's acquisitions of Viag Interkom, ESAT in Ireland and Telfort in the Netherlands.

fields.headline: Spectrum auction may fetch £1bn
fields.trailText: The auction of spectrum for companies wanting to offer broadband services over fixed wireless networks begins tomorrow raising the prospect of another windfall, albeit far smaller than the £22.5bn from the sale of next generation mobile phone licences.
fields.body:
The auction of spectrum for companies wanting to offer broadband services over fixed wireless networks begins tomorrow raising the prospect of another windfall, albeit far smaller than the £22.5bn from the sale of next generation mobile phone licences.

There are three fixed wireless licences on offer in 14 different regions - 42 in total. Analysts expect the auction to raise between £800m and £1bn.

Companies that win the licences will be able to offer broadband services at data rates in excess of 2Mbits a second compared with a maximum of 2Mbits a second for next generation mobile phones.

Services will include fast always-on access to the internet, video conferencing, video-on-demand, high capacity data transfer and the usual online shopping, banking and games.

The fixed wireless system employs a small box fixed to the outside of a building which receives signals from transmitters which can then plug into a fixed-line networks. It is expected to be used by firms hoping to target small and medium sized businesses, typically in areas where cable or fibre-optic networks have not been built.

The Radiocommunications Agency which has organised the auction has conceived of the services to be more niche than the mass market appeal of third generation mobile and the licences. "The government will get far less than it did from the mobile licences which were auctioned at the top of the market mania," said one telecoms analyst. "Fixed wireless has also gone out of fashion and the regional nature of the licences makes them less appealing."

A combined reserve price has been set on the licences of £78m, with the most expensive in London where a starting price of £4m has been set for each licence.

Fixed wireless services are most likely to proliferate in suburban areas or business parks although some of the bidders have indicated they intend to launch fully fledged assaults on the corporate market in metropolitan areas if they win a licence.

The auction has attracted 10 bidders, including Eircom, Broadnet, owned by US cable company Comcast and Chorus, owned jointly by Liberty Media and Independent News & Media. Energis, Norwen and Winstar are also bidding.

A spokeswoman for Energis said: "We are looking to use it as a complementary access technology to our existing options of metropolitan fibre optic networks and DSL when it is available. It will fill in gaps for us. Our experience of the technology is that it can offer an equal service to fibre optics. It can also be deployed more quickly than digging up roads."

The process will begin with three rounds taking place tomorrow via online bids increasing to five or six rounds of bidding a day until no one tops any of the offers on the table.

fields.headline: At this price?  British Energy
fields.standfirst:
The issue explained: Sellafield
Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText: Freak weather conditions and warnings of more floods because of global warming should be manna from heaven for British Energy, the country's biggest nuclear generator, which supplies around a fifth of its power.
fields.body:
Freak weather conditions and warnings of more floods because of global warming should be manna from heaven for British Energy, the country's biggest nuclear generator, which supplies around a fifth of its power.

Company executives continue to press the "green" case to ministers for new nuclear build, pointing to an upsurge of interest in the US. But they know it is far too early - and politically sensitive - to talk about a renaissance of nuclear power.

For one thing, the ineluctable problem of nuclear waste has yet to be resolved while Peter Hollins, chief executive, admitted yesterday that new build is uneconomic when fossil-fuel generators escape charges for their emissions. And, at a mundane level, the volatility of electricity prices matches that of the weather.

Mr Hollins and Robin Jeffrey, chairman-in-waiting, yesterday insisted the group had turned the corner despite posting a £56m pre-tax loss for the first half - largely due to a 15% fall in wholesale electricity prices and unplanned shut-downs. They admit that performance, which led to a halving of last year's dividend, remains unsatisfactory and set out a strategy to improve it.

BE has extended the life of its Hartlepool and Heysham 1 stations by five years, offering annually £29m extra profits before tax, and has both its Dungeness units reconnected to the grid for the first time in 14 months. Mr Hollins hopes for record output next year.

He believes that wholesale prices have bottomed out in advance of the (delayed) reform of the pool, pointing to recent rises as gas prices have doubled. The £150m cost-saving programme, which will see further job losses in the 5000-strong British workforce, should reduce unit operating costs from 1.97p to 1.6p per kilowatt hour in three years.

But the group's fortunes are inextricably tied to North America where its AmerGen joint venture is acquiring its fourth station and the Bruce station in Canada alone promises up to £120m pre-tax profits.

Even there, however, the nuclear option remains high-risk and, while the group may well break even this year and pay a full dividend of around 8p, investors should avoid what was once a stellar stock until the unsettled weather has fully cleared. The 12.5p rise in yesterday's price to 175p is not yet a clear-weather statement.

fields.headline: Orchestream harmony
fields.trailText: Since its June flotation, Orchestream, the network software group, has kept a relatively low profile, which has probably been to its advantage. Unlike the rest of the software and computer services sector, its shares have proved a strong performer. Issued at 185p, the price was 545p last night.
fields.body:
Since its June flotation, Orchestream, the network software group, has kept a relatively low profile, which has probably been to its advantage. Unlike the rest of the software and computer services sector, its shares have proved a strong performer. Issued at 185p, the price was 545p last night.

Yesterday, heavyweight investment bank UBS Warburg started coverage of the stock with a "strong buy" recommendation and 690p target price. UBS reckons the company's software is establishing itself as the standard for next generation private data networks. It expects Orchestream to make £2.7m of sales this year, jumping to £15m next year and £32m the year after. The broker expects the company to achieve profitability at the operating level by 2002.

All of which is good news for niche investment bank Shore Capital, unchanged at 47p. Shore owns 1.1% of Orchestream.

fields.headline: Bid talk boosts Glynwed
fields.trailText: The market's more speculative players are praying for a bid for engineering group Glynwed. Rumours have been swirling around the company for much of this week, but until yesterday no one could quite pin down the story.
fields.body:
The market's more speculative players are praying for a bid for engineering group Glynwed. Rumours have been swirling around the company for much of this week, but until yesterday no one could quite pin down the story.

Late on Tuesday Glynwed shares rose sharply as speculative money flowed into the stock but no one was really sure why. Obviously there was chatter about a takeover approach but then there was also talk that broker Collins Stewart had published a bullish research note. But yesterday things were becoming clearer.

Apparently the group, best known for its Aga cookers, has received an approach from Swiss rival Georg Fischer. But, as dealers pointed out, this is something of an old chestnut.

Earlier this year Fischer was said to have approached Glynwed with a tentative takeover, which if true must have been rebuffed. But with Glynwed's shares refusing to respond to recent robust figures - they hit a year low of 162p last month - the Swiss, it is claimed, have renewed their interest. The gossips reckon Fischer will pitch its offer at around 350p.

However, Glynwed shares closed well off their best levels of the day, up a mere 4.75p to 201.25p, suggesting not everyone was taking the tale seriously. Glynwed finance director William McGrath refused to comment on the speculation.

In the wider market, leading shares limped into positive territory after a strong showing from the heavyweight drug sector as investors gambled on a victory for George W Bush in the US presidential election. The thinking in the City is that a victory for Mr Bush would be good for drug companies as he would not try and curb prices for prescription drugs.

Glaxo Wellcome was the biggest beneficiary, up 58p to £20.79, closely followed by prospective merger partner SmithKline Beecham, 24p better at 946p, and AstraZeneca, 21p stronger at £34.

Tobacco group BAT, up 26p to 506p, also benefited from the Bush effect. Should he win, analysts believe tobacco companies operating in north America will be given an easier ride.

Nevertheless, leading shares closed well off their best levels, which were seen early in the session after a Bush victory appeared to have been confirmed. The FTSE 100 closed up just 10.5 points at 6,477.4, little affected by the chancellor's pre-Budget speech which contained nothing to worry the City. Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 added 8.3 points to 6,813.4 and the Techmark eased 25.39 points to 3,436.76.

Pest control specialist Rentokil was the best blue-chip performer of the day, rising 23p, or 14.29%, to 184p in heavy volume. The demand for the stock appeared to be coming from Scottish fund managers. It seems that Rentokil boss Sir Clive Thompson met a number of them on Tuesday and told them that the firm is recovering. Rentokil is due update the market of current trading on November 22.

Controls and automation group Invensys, up 5.75p to 154.75p, was back in demand but for once not because of takeover speculation. Invensys is due to present interim figures next week and those in the know insist there are no nasty surprises in store. In fact they reckon the company might announce plans to spin off its power systems division, worth an estimated £3bn.

On the downside mining group Billiton dipped 9p to 267p after Deutsche Bank lowered its recommendation and earnings forecasts. Deutsche believes the shares, which were at 234p in mid-October, are now fairly valued.

Marks & Spencer, off 1p at 194p, also fell despite news it had started its share buyback programme, purchasing 2.16m shares for cancellation.

Sausage skin maker Devro picked up 2p to 53.5p as talk of a management buyout came back round again. Mining group Brancote Holdings shot up 21.5p to 170.5p after it said it was in talks with three major north American gold outfits about a possible takeover.

fields.headline: Let's drink to small business success
fields.trailText: An entrepeneur explains what the government has done for the business culture.
fields.body:
Not so long ago, sitting in a City wine bar, I overheard a customer sniping: "What has this government done for small businesses?"

Having listened to this lazy rhetorical question once too often, I had to leap in and ask this guy where he had been for the past four years.

The business culture has changed. My working life is investing in and developing small, high-risk ventures at the cutting edge of scientific advance, and I can see and feel the change.

There are the headline-making initiatives - granting independence to the Bank of England, helping to foster historically low inflation and stable economic growth. It is easily forgotten that government borrowing ballooned to £28bn during the last year of the last Tory government, while Labour has cut the total figure by £46bn. Standard corporation tax has been cut to 30%, while a new 10% starting rate was introduced last April.

There are other measures which fail to get much publicity, such as the fact that investors in high-risk ventures will pay just 10% capital gains tax if they keep their money in place for five years, making first year capital allowances permanent for smaller and medium sized firms, and while much needs to be done in terms of making it easier to recruit and retain good quality staff with incentives like share options, a start has been made.

There is the tax relief on so-called corporate venturing - encouraging large firms to pump money into smaller ventures, promoting innovation - not to mention all the money pouring into regional venture capital funds. Since 1997, the average corporation tax bill for small companies has been cut by nearly 25%. Britain now has the lowest ever corporation tax rates for small companies and the lowest starting rate among major industrialised countries.

Previous Conservative governments did a lot of talking about new enterprise, opportunities for all and the like. But they did not follow through with practical solutions to particular issues.

Britain in the mid-90s was in serious danger of missing out on the new economic wave of the 21st century, and of falling further behind in the quality of its science and technology base.

I and other entrepreneurs told Labour what was needed before it came to power. It could have turned round and said "Fine, we hear what you say but we are now a Labour government." It didn't. It listened, and as a result we have a sea-change in terms of the acceptability of taking risk. It is beginning to take root at the lowest level - with enterprise clubs in schools, for example. More needs to be done, such as ensuring more scientists come through the education system. But the movement is there. Action is being taken.

Wealth creation and quality of life go hand in hand. You have to do it with a social conscience and with sympathy for your environment.

Some people feel uneasy with this. Some of those in Whitehall have a real problem with it. But Tony Blair and Gordon Brown understand the principle that business needs encouragement and that those, like myself, who have been lucky enough to have made some money already need encouragement to reinvest.

I am part of the macroeconomic system. I cannot influence how the Treasury spends the taxes I pay but I know the influence I can wield, backing people in new companies, creating jobs, new value and excitement. That is what I do for a living and by doing so I make a direct impact on society.

The government still has plenty of listening to do. One only has to look at the smaller end of the stock market-listed sector to see some glaring problems. Only 30% of investors in the British market are retail investors, while in Germany the figure is 60%. This no doubt has something to do with the fact that anyone who puts money into the Neuer Markt, the German market for growth companies, pays no capital gains tax.

There is a lesson there. We need to think in terms of small being beautiful. It is great to have multi-billion-pound companies. It is a credit to this government that Robin Saxby at Arm (the chip designer) and Andrew Rickman of Bookham Technology (a specialist in optic fibres) are now here. Their existence encourages so many others. But creating a £10m company, employing 50 people and making profits is a real achievement - for yourself and for society. It's very "Labour" - new or old.

So let's have lots more direct measures, forming something that is probably best described as the "glue" of the enterprise culture.

It will take time to set, maybe 10 or 15 years. There will still be the whinger asking what has this government done for small business. It should by then be safe to ignore him.

 Chris Evans is a serial entrepreneur, specialising in biotechnology. Companies he has backed include Chiroscience, Celsis and Merlin Biosciences

fields.headline: Nader boosted by poll success
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Ralph Nader received more than 2m votes for his Green party and yesterday signalled his determination to build it into a serious "long-term, progressive reform movement" to monitor the two major parties and change the face of US politics. "The real issue is permanent corporate government in this country," he declared.
fields.body:
Ralph Nader received more than 2m votes for his Green party and yesterday signalled his determination to build it into a serious "long-term, progressive reform movement" to monitor the two major parties and change the face of US politics. "The real issue is permanent corporate government in this country," he declared.

The former consumer rights advocate got 3% of the national vote, falling short of the 5% which would have brought the Green party federal funding for the next election. But he said he was far from disappointed, and that he had received more than 5% of the vote in 11 states, including Alaska, where he got 10%.

"We're in it for the long run," he said, adding that "funding is a convenience, not a necessity". His campaign spent less money - $8m - than the two major parties spent on television commercials during a typical week last month.

With his fierce attacks on the two major parties as lackeys of big corporations, his appeal to help the poor, and his sharp criticism of global trade, he built an eclectic following of trade union members disappointed by their leadership, disillusioned Democrats, environmentalists, college students and liberal intellectuals.

He brushed off complaints by Democrats that he drew liberal voters away from Al Gore. "You can't spoil a system that's spoiled to the core," he said.

"The Green party will emerge as the third largest party, the fastest growing party and the best party in its democratic spirit to take back government for our people.

"We sent the message to the corrupt Democratic party that they better give us a clear choice. Otherwise the Democratic party is on a big slide."

In states with close races between Mr Gore and George W Bush, Mr Nader appeared to be a significant factor. Exit polls in Colorado, Nevada, New Hampshire, Oregon, Washington state and Wisconsin suggested that at least half the Nader voters would have voted for Mr Gore if it had been a two-way race. But nearly one in three said they would not have voted at all. In the key state of Florida, Mr Nader won 96,000 votes.

fields.headline: Out of step
fields.standfirst:
'Eyewash to fool us' say foxtrotters

Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: At a Stockport town hall tea dance yesterday afternoon, a slow foxtrot moaned from the organ, the Queen Mother smiled down from the wood carved walls, and the 100 fragments of light from the mirror ball echoed the number of pieces that pensioners wanted to tear Gordon Brown's pre-Budget statement into.
fields.body:
At a Stockport town hall tea dance yesterday afternoon, a slow foxtrot moaned from the organ, the Queen Mother smiled down from the wood carved walls, and the 100 fragments of light from the mirror ball echoed the number of pieces that pensioners wanted to tear Gordon Brown's pre-Budget statement into.

"In one word, it's a load of rubbish," said Gordon Atherton, 68, a retired sales representative from Marple. "The system is getting more and more complicated and hard to understand. Some pensioners have to apply to all sorts of schemes to survive. The pensioners credit system is another complex way of pulling the wool over our eyes."

Mr Atherton's wife, Sheila, 71, said: "If they spend so much to educate us, why do they treat us like fools?"

The Athertons, above, draw £525 state pension a month and have to supplement this with two private pensions and savings.

The state pension covers their house bills, tax and food but it does not allow them to buy more than essential clothes or pay for house repairs. If their savings income is now less than £130 a week Mr Brown will allow them some relief.

Mr Atherton says he has spent his whole life saving for old age and any income relief is welcome. But he adds many pensioners are forced to draw private incomes of more than that and may still continue to subsidise state pensions from their own pockets.

"A £5 increase is better than 75p but we have to ask ourselves what the conditions are. The winter fuel allowance increase is eyewash to fool us. The fuel allowance is the same for singles and couples. I would rather see the money added to the basic pensions than get a perk which is a bit like just offering somebody a box of chocolates. If anyone in this room full of pensioners votes for this government they need their head seeing to."

The Atherton's have brought their own refreshments to the dance.

Edith Alexander, 77, who lives alone on a state pension plus her own savings said £5 would do to start and income relief was welcome. "Now the chancellor should cut petrol costs, road tax and water rates for pensioners. Seventy-five pence was an insult and he still has a way to go to undo that."

Bernard Maxwell, 76, a former street lighting worker for Stockport council, said he and his wife fell into a category of pensioners with good private pensions who are able to maintain what he calls a normal lifestyle. They spend seven months a year in a caravan in Anglesey and travel to Portugal twice a year. "We are very happy with the winter fuel increase and we are very happy with our television licence. Any relief on income is welcome but we are not destitute and so don't fit into the category that would get large amounts of relief. We will still have to pay our own way. We could not do this with perks like alcohol or bingo, so we have to constantly watch what we spend."

fields.headline: Pfizer loses Viagra battle
fields.standfirst: Competitors ready to move in after patent on impotence drug is ruled invalid
fields.trailText: Men suffering from impotence could have a range of drugs to choose from in two or three years, after a High Court judge ruled yesterday that an exclusive patent taken out by Viagra's makers Pfizer covering all compounds in the same class of drugs was invalid.
fields.body:
Men suffering from impotence could have a range of drugs to choose from in two or three years, after a High Court judge ruled yesterday that an exclusive patent taken out by Viagra's makers Pfizer covering all compounds in the same class of drugs was invalid.

Viagra so far has the market to itself. But the ruling by Mr Justice Laddie in the patents court, unless overturned on appeal, will clear the way for the marketing of competing drugs already in clinical de velopment by a number of other companies.

The judgment does not affect Pfizer's patent for sildenafil citrate, the main ingredient of the anti-impotence drug Viagra. But it means that Pfizer loses the right to prevent other companies marketing drugs which work in the same way - by inhibiting an enzyme in the body called PDE5.

The High Court challenge was mounted by Lilly Icos, a joint company formed by the US pharmaceutical firm Eli Lilly and a Seattle-based biotech company, Icos. Fourteen pharmaceutical companies are also challenging the patent at the European Patent Office in Munich.

Mr Justice Laddie ruled that the 1993 patent was "invalid for obviousness" because the scientific knowledge on which it was based was already in the public domain.

Pfizer said it was "very disappointed" by the judgment and was considering an appeal. But it shrugged off suggestions that it would lead to a flood of cheaper Viagra alternatives on to the market.

A spokeswoman said there would be no immediate im pact on Viagra. Other products would have to go through an expensive research and development process and would then have to be licensed. The licensing authority would want new products to be more or at least as effective as Viagra, which was 84% effective, she said.

The first product to reach the market could be Eli Lilly's Cialif - a similar treatment for erectile dysfunction which is in clinical trials and is due to be filed with regulators next year.

Experts were split on the commercial significance of the ruling for Pfizer. Edward Nodder, a specialist in intellectual property at the law firm Bristows, said: "This is a very serious blow for them. The basic concept of Viagra is now unprotected and there's no barrier to others."

However, City analysts expect the immediate financial impact to be negligible - James Culverwell of Merrill Lynch said: "The molecular structure of Viagra is still safe - Pfizer were trying to be aggressive and cover themselves with all sorts of patents."

On Wall Street, Pfizer's shares remained steady.

fields.headline: Social report spin attacked
fields.standfirst: Marketing departments accused of manipulation
fields.trailText: Social reports produced by companies such as Barclays and Ford have been condemned as corporate "spin" by New Economics Foundation (NEF), the organisation which developed modern methods of social auditing.
fields.body:
Social reports produced by companies such as Barclays and Ford have been condemned as corporate "spin" by New Economics Foundation (NEF), the organisation which developed modern methods of social auditing.

In an analysis of the reports by leading companies' covering their impact on society, NEF uncovered "huge discrepancies" between their claims and actions.

Deborah Doane, author of the study, said reporting had been taken over by marketing departments. "The voluntary nature of social reporting has resulted in its capture by the marketing departments and its misuse as an accountability tool. Only when companies are required to produce a social report by law will we see the end of the manipulation by those it should be holding to account."

NEF warns that the technique which was developed as a method of assessing companies' social responsibility has been taken over by the large accountancy firms and marketed as "reputation assurance". Instead of holding companies to account it is now being used to enhance their public images.

The organisation also complains that reporting has be come an end in itself, instead of leading to changes in corporate behaviour. "To date there is no concrete evidence that social reporting results in improved social and ethical performance", the report states.

The organisation says social reporting has failed to "grow up" and failed to penetrate more than 5% of the top quoted companies in the UK and the US.

"Social reporting is behaving like a teenager - easily influenced, lazy, manipulative and with a limited attention span," Ms Doane said.

She cited Barclays' branch closures earlier this year and Ford's failure to improve emissions as examples of companies choosing to ignore uncomfortable facts. Shell is also attacked for failing to respond to criticisms of its actions in Ogoniland, Nigeria. NEF says that BT's action in raising call box charges hit the worst off in UK.

 Corporate Spin: the troubled teenage years of social reporting".

What they say/what they do

Barclays

BP

"Our goals are simply stated - no accidents, no harm to people and no damage to the environment" - chief executive Sir John Browne

In an analysis of the reports by leading companies' covering their impact on society, NEF uncovered "huge discrepancies" between their claims and actions. Deborah Doane, author of the study, said reporting had been taken over by marketing departments. "The voluntary nature of social reporting has resulted in its capture by the marketing departments and its misuse as an accountability tool. Only when companies are required to produce a social report by law will we see the end of the manipulation by those it should be holding to account." NEF warns that the technique which was developed as a method of assessing companies' social responsibility has been taken over by the large accountancy firms and marketed as "reputation assurance". Instead of holding companies to account it is now being used to enhance their public images. The organisation also complains that reporting has be come an end in itself, instead of leading to changes in corporate behaviour. "To date there is no concrete evidence that social reporting results in improved social and ethical performance", the report states. The organisation says social reporting has failed to "grow up" and failed to penetrate more than 5% of the top quoted companies in the UK and the US. "Social reporting is behaving like a teenager - easily influenced, lazy, manipulative and with a limited attention span," Ms Doane said. She cited Barclays' branch closures earlier this year and Ford's failure to improve emissions as examples of companies choosing to ignore uncomfortable facts. Shell is also attacked for failing to respond to criticisms of its actions in Ogoniland, Nigeria. fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Budget airline Virgin Express yesterday blamed the strong dollar and soaring fuel costs for its nosedive into the red but insisted a return to profit was well within its reach.
fields.body:
Virgin Express posts loss

Budget airline Virgin Express yesterday blamed the strong dollar and soaring fuel costs for its nosedive into the red but insisted a return to profit was well within its reach.

The company believes its restructuring and cost cutting programme, coupled with better economic conditions, will be enough to reverse its fortunes.

Third-quarter figures for Virgin Express show a €7.3m (£4.3m) loss compared with a profit last year of €4.9m.

Interbrew in €14bn float

Interbrew yesterday cast aside 700 years of family control by launching a €14bn (£8.5bn) stock market flotation, despite concerns about an ongoing competition commission investigation into its position in Britain.

The company said yesterday that it would raise between €2.6bn and €3.3bn through a public offering of a 21% stake. Chief executive Hugo Powell brushed aside suggestions that the firm should wait until the new year when trade secretary Stephen Byers is due to rule on its recent purchases of the brewing operations of Bass and Whitbread.

Thomas Cook sells division

Thomas Cook yesterday sold its financial services unit, which includes 300 foreign exchange bureaux, to Travelex Group for £440m which raised speculation that the ownership of the travel company might soon change.

The future ownership of Thomas Cook, majority- owned by Preussag of Germany, has been in doubt ever since the Germany firm bought Thomson Travel. Potential bidders for Preussag's 50.1% stake include C&N.

IBT brings Schroders in

The International Biotechnology Trust has appointed Schroders as its investment manager, replacing Rothschild Asset Management, four months after shareholders demanded a "reorganisation and reconstruction" following revelations about shares held by a key director.

The trust has been surrounded by uncertainty since the resignation of administrator Jeremy Curnock Cook in July. He faced criticism when it emerged that he had been awarded share options worth more than £530,000 in several companies in which IBT had invested.

Rolls told to 'come clean'

Union leaders at Rolls-Royce yesterday urged the firm to "come clean" about reports that thousands of jobs are to be axed. The company has described suggestions that 5,000 workers will be made redundant, mainly at its factory in Derby, as speculation.

fields.headline: Daewoo Motor plunges into bankruptcy
fields.trailText: Daewoo Motor, the South Korean car manufacturer, was declared bankrupt yesterday after rescue talks between management and unions collapsed in acrimony.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo and Nicholas Bannister
fields.body:
Daewoo Motor, the South Korean car manufacturer, was declared bankrupt yesterday after rescue talks between management and unions collapsed in acrimony.

Once part of South Korea's second biggest conglomerate, Daewoo Motor has become a symbol of the country's stop-start efforts at corporate reform following the Asian financial crisis of 1997-98.

Its failure yesterday was welcomed by foreign investors as a sign that the government is taking a tougher line against insolvent companies that were once considered too big to fail.

However it threw a question mark over the future of the 750 jobs at the Daewoo technical centre in Worthing, Sussex. Union leaders yesterday called for the centre to be sold to a European company.

Daewoo Motors has debts of about £7bn, much of which was used to build a vast but unprofitable global empire spanning South Korea, India, Eastern Europe and India.

Creditors, who have report edly been covering monthly losses of £63m since the parent company collapsed last year, declared Daewoo Motor bankrupt yesterday after it defaulted on a £27m loan for the second day in succession.

The company's attempt to buy more time failed after union leaders rejected a new restructuring plan that would have cut a fifth of the 19,000-strong workforce. The union said its members would have to be paid £70m in wages arrears before it would consider the proposals.

"We can't wait any longer. Daewoo's bankruptcy has become formal," said Yang Mun-suk, a spokesman for Daewoo's main creditor, the nationalised Korea Development Bank.

The collapse throws into doubt the fate of the company's employees. Creditors are in negotiations to sell Daewoo Motors, which has a global production capacity of 2m cars, to General Motors and its partner Fiat.

By putting the company into receivership, they may have to drop the price well below the £2.8bn they were reportedly asking, but analysts said the move could hasten a sale because it will be easier for new court-appointed management to cut jobs.

Last week, the country's major creditors - many of which are state-run banks - announced that they would pull the plug on 52 struggling companies. Along with Daewoo Motors, this threatens more than 200,000 jobs. Unions have promised a winter of discontent to protest against these layoffs.

Daewoo's British subsidiary said that the group management would now have the le gal power to restructure the business regardless of union opposition, thus making it more attractive to General Motors.

The British company did not rely on funds from Korea, and it would be "business as usual" for its sales network and technical centre.

Since the economic crisis, two other troubled Korean car firms, Kia Motors and Samsung Motors, have been sold to foreign groups.

Ford, however, pulled out of talks to buy Daewoo in September.

webTitle: Cries of foul play cloud the picture in the sunshine state

fields.headline: Cries of foul play cloud the picture in the sunshine state
fields.standfirst:
Florida: 100m votes later it all rests on a handful of ballot forms

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A handful of civil servants, several hundred elderly Jewish retirees and up to 3,000 members of the US armed forces unexpectedly held the political future of the planet in their hands last night.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington, Michael Ellison  in Orlando and Jackie Drennan
fields.body:
A handful of civil servants, several hundred elderly Jewish retirees and up to 3,000 members of the US armed forces unexpectedly held the political future of the planet in their hands last night.

The three groups stood in the crossfire of a succession of unprecedented political pressures yesterday as Florida began the recount that will determine whether George W Bush or Al Gore is the next president of the United States.

The civil servants were the 67 county electoral supervisers responsible for carrying out the automatic recount required by Florida law when a statewide election result produces a majority of less that 0.5%.

That law was triggered when Florida's final count ended in the early hours of yesterday with Mr Bush on 2,909,199 and Mr Gore on 2,907,544. The results of the recount are expected today.

The Jewish retirees are among several thousand voters in Florida's blue rinse belt in Palm Beach county who say they were given misleading ballot forms to complete in Tuesday's elections in which the layout meant they accidentally voted for rightwing candidate Pat Buchanan rather than Mr Gore.

Pressure was rising last night for an inquiry into the unusual ballot forms, with the Rev Jesse Jackson leading the cries of foul and mounting a public protest in nearby Miami. An unopened ballot box from an African-American church was also reportedly discovered yesterday.

Meanwhile 3,000 members of the military and their spouses - thought to be mainly Republicans - are registered in Florida but cast overseas postal votes. These may not be counted until next week and could yet be the most important votes in US electoral history.

The drama is powerful enough. But this story has extra human interest and an uncanny historical resonance.

The human interest comes from the fact that Mr Bush's fate rests on the result in a state in which his younger brother, Jeb, who many had considered to be the more likely presidential candidate, is the governor. That means that the 67 election supervisors are employees of a bureaucracy controlled by one candidate's brother.

The historical resonance derives from the fact that the man driving the accusations of foul play and demanding the recount is Mr Gore's campaign manager, William Daley. It was Mr Daley's father, the legendary Mayor Richard Daley of Chicago, whose unstinting election day efforts on John F. Kennedy's behalf in a couple of gerrymandered inner city areas in 1960 were the key to Kennedy's defeat of Richard Nixon in what, until this week, was the closest US presidential election in living memory.

The recount was ordered after the advantage in Florida tipped back and forth between Mr Bush and Mr Gore after the polls closed.

"As we saw the numbers coming in and we realised that there was a surplus of about 150,000 absentee ballots in our favour, we realised that it was really too early to call it," the Florida Republican chairman, Al Cardenas, said yesterday.

For most of the early hours, the running count of votes in Florida seemed to confirm that the tide was running strongly towards Mr Bush. The Miami Herald even printed a 1am edition with the banner headline "Bush Wins It" which may now go down in US history as a call on a par with the Chicago Tribune's infamous "Dewey Beats Truman" headline in 1948.

But when the votes were finally tallied, the two men were a mere 1,655 votes apart in an election in which 6m Floridians had voted. The state attorney general, Bob Butterworth, a Democrat who chairs Mr Gore's campaign in Florida, went on television to announce the mandatory recount.

"Florida has been put in a position, whether we asked for it or not, of determining who the next president of the United States is going to be," Mr Butterworth said in Tallahassee, the state capital. "We owe it to the state, the country, and maybe to the world to determine that, whatever our vote might be, it's an accurate vote, it's the honest vote, and it's the vote of the people of the state of Florida."

The Miami Herald's 4am last edition headline prudently reverted to "Not Over Yet".

Under hastily confirmed arrangements, the Florida recount was yesterday taking place in each county in the presence of local civil service observers, judicial officials, representatives of the campaigns and the media.

Clay Roberts, of the Florida division of elections, emerged late yesterday morning to say that the process would not be completed until the end of today when Jeb Bush would sign his name at the bottom of the historic validation document that could send his big brother - or his big brother's rival - to take the most important job in the world.

"The issue is not just a recount but an investigation," Mr Jackson told reporters in Nashville yesterday as he headed off to Miami for last night's protest. Mr Jackson said that there had been ballot irregularities in Broward, Miami-Dade and Palm Beach counties. "This does not pass the smell test," he said.

Other demands for an investigation focused on claims that more than 3,000 people unwittingly voted for Mr Buchanan rather than Mr Gore because of the unusual configuration of the ballot papers issued to some voters in Palm Beach county. Mr Gore's name appeared second in a list on the ballot paper, but votes cast in the second box on the ballot were awarded to Mr Buchanan.

"I met hundreds of people who left the balloting boxes crying and in total hysteria that they had voted for Pat Buchanan," local Democratic congressman Robert Wexler said yesterday. "These people have been disenfranchised."

But the final result in Florida could rest with the late and overseas postal voters. Election supervisors sent out 585,000 postal votes of which 416,000 had been returned by Monday and were counted. However, any postal vote that is postmarked on or before election day can still qualify for counting, and overseas postal votes have up to 10 days from election day to come in.

Florida had about 2,300 overseas postal voters in the 1996 election, but the number this year, though thought to be larger, is not yet known. Most are thought to be military voters, attracted to register in Florida because the state has no income tax. A second important group of overseas voters consists of Jewish residents who spend part of the winter in Israel.

Juice, jails and the generation gap

 Florida's population is 15,111,244 (1999 estimate), making it the fourth most populous state in the US

 It has the highest rate of over-65s at 18.3%

 68.6% are white non-Hispanic, 15% Hispanic, 15.2% black (US figures are 72.3%, 11.2%, 12.7%)

 Florida has a high rate of violent crime - 1,024 per 100,000 population compared with 611 in the US as a whole (1997 figures)

 Florida has the most death row prisoners ultimately found not guilty - 20 cases since 1974

 15.2% live below the poverty line (US figure 13.8%)

 Average annual household income is $29,998, compared with $34,076 in the US

 It has the most shark attacks

 Key West has the highest average temperature in the US

 Orange juice was declared the official state beverage by the 1967 legislature

 "The sunshine state" is the official nickname

 250,000 people move to Florida each year

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Record Of A Tenement Gentleman | Happiness | Buena Vista Social Club
fields.body:
Record Of A Tenement Gentleman

(Yasujiro Ozu, 1947)

6pm, FilmFour

In the aftermath of the second world war, Japan had its fair share of displaced persons. The master director Ozu brought their plight to his country's attention with this humanitarian and at times humorous work, a plea for generosity of spirit. It's a typically wise and calm film, telling the story of a homeless boy (Hohi Aoki) who has been abandoned by his father, and the widowed shopkeeper (Choko Lida) who grudgingly takes him in, rediscovering maternal love in the process.

Happiness

(Todd Solondz, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Roughly speaking, this is a story of three modern American sisters and their encounters with some peculiar males of the species. It's a brilliantly perceptive, sympathetic comedy of sexual manners; but with one of the sisters (Cynthia Stevenson) happily married to a psychiatrist (Dylan Baker, pictured) who is also a paedophile, it's also an emotionally challenging, near despairing work, incorporating perhaps the blackest joke in cinema. With Lara Flynn Boyle, plus Ben Gazzara and Louise Lasser as the women's parents suddenly pitched into marital crisis. Quite exceptional film-making.

Buena Vista Social Club

(Wim Wenders, 1999)

10pm, FilmFour

Another fecund partnership of Wenders and Ry Cooder, the musician who made the score for Paris, Texas. This is the story of Cooder pulling together a group of aged Cuban performers in order to make a CD and go on tour. All in their 80s or 90s, the musicians - including Compay Segundo, Ibrahim Ferrer, Omara Portuondo and Ruben Gonzalez - play their stuff and talk about their lives. Wenders works the material into a rich and heartwarming whole. The music speaks for itself, and the photography - from the fading elegance of old Havana to the New York skyline, and the radiant, aged faces of the musicians themselves - is superb.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will play the devil in Terry Gilliam's Good Omens?
fields.trailText: Who will play the devil in Terry Gilliam's Good Omens?
fields.body:
John Malkovich .............4-6

Billy Crudup ...................3-1

Leonardo DiCaprio ........6-1

Robert Downey Jr ..........8-1

After last year's Dogma, a modern morality play with Alanis Morissette as God, all hell has broken loose about religion in movies. But most Hollywood actors agree that the devil is a juicy part. Elizabeth Hurley is a luscious Satan in her latest film, and clean teen Jennifer Love Hewitt will soon get dirty as Lady Lucifer in a contemporary remake of The Devil And Daniel Webster.

Soon to conjure up the Devil is Brazil director Terry Gilliam, just signed to direct Good Omens, about an angel's search to find the Antichrist, based on a story by Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett. So who will play the baddie?

John Malkovich (pictured) uses a lot of sardonic wit - often the mark of a devilish character. "He's a big star, but doesn't take himself too seriously," says Andy Clifton, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "He can work with bad material - like Con Air - but can still be really good."

If they decide to go for a more minor box-office draw, then Billy (Jesus' Son) Crudup stands a good chance. "He's not universally popular," says Andy, "but it seems to be a case of when, rather than if, he becomes a star. And Gilliam doesn't always go for the big stars."

Or punters might just bet on an actor they love, like DiCaprio. "People follow a favourite horse or football team no matter how badly they're doing," admits Andy. "And Gilliam might think it's clever to cast someone unexpected like that to get the film talked about," he adds.

Which would also apply to Robert Downey Jr. "It'd win a special Oscar for best tongue-in-cheek casting of the year," quips Andy. Downey's recent release from jail for parole violation makes him a long shot. "But there are always people who'll bet on the basis that they can win a decent amount of money." webTitle: TV and Radio: Work in progress

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Ben Moor, actor
fields.trailText: Ben Moor, actor
fields.body:
Talk to anyone who's ever heard me sing karaoke and they'll tell you they're lucky. Lucky simply to still be around to tell the tale, I mean. I don't sing well. My voice is flatter than Holland. I'm a melody sieve. I can't hold a tune. That's why it's odd to say that I'm doing my first professional "singing" role in December. Rehearsals started this week and are going well. I've already managed to sing four of the right notes, two of which were even in the right order.

Fanferlizzy Sunnyfeet is an opera for children of all sanities. It's about muesli, goat-women on roller skates, ostrich assassins and flying castles which might or might not work. If I'm being vague here, it's not for the sake of suspense, it's because I genuinely don't understand the story. It's that bizarre. I am the Hobblebuck, a stag with TV aerials for antlers, and I spend most of the show with just my head popping through the stage. It's being put on at Wilton's Music Hall by Broomhill Opera and I feel incredibly lucky to be involved. The space is magnificent for performers, and the talent of everyone in the production is just awesome. Designer/director Netia Jones is a star in the making, and with costumes by Wayne Hemingway, I doubt anything will look better this Christmas.

I'm also involved in Scene And Heard, an after-school drama project for children in Somerstown, north London. Performed by professionals like Richard Herring, Katy Cavanagh and John Lightbody (Tallulah the chicken's boyfriend in those "Big Brother" bumpers) but written by kids aged 9-12, the current show has yet to be written. We've been working on asides and monologues this term (so I'm hoping for one of those). Scene and Heard productions are celebrations of the imagination, and for the theatre professionals involved they're great reminders that we're working in the best job in the world.

 Fanferlizzy Sunnyfeet, Wilton's Music Hall, December 6-16, 7.30pm. Box Office: 020-7420 0222.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: US Elections | A History Of Britain
fields.body:
"No kiss for Tipper the day after."

- Pat Harrison, co-chair of the Republican National Committee. (Newsnight, BBC2)

The BBC's resources were deployed with modest economy to cover the US Elections (BBC1). I looked forward with particular pleasure to the appearances of Michael Crick who, like the Python's lumberjack, seemed to hang about bars ("Welcome to the Old Town Bar." "I'm now at a bar in Greenwich Village.") And why not, indeed? It was going to be a long night.

Much longer than we expected.

By 1am, David Dimbleby was being languid ("Why can't the American public make up their minds?") and Peter Snow was being hyperactive ("They're off! This is a very, very exciting race!') when Gore won Florida.

According to John Simpson, "Gore got up and did a little jig round the dinner table." His gains ran along the bottom of the screen like a ribbon to tie up the presidency in beautiful bows. Dimbleby was trying to coax his guests into indiscretion. "Spill the beans now because it's all over." At the Bush HQ in Texas, the cheering died. "Earlier in the evening they were showing every result but the screens have gone off." Even Peter Snow had his hands in his pockets.

Lou Dubose, who sounds as if he writes books about the lone prairie but is, in fact, the author of The Short And Happy Political Life Of George W Bush, was saying ruefully, "It's shorter than I thought."

Few men have been proved so wrong so fast. The exit polls had gone off half- cocked and Florida was still too close to call. Dimbleby's pundits were now doing complicated long-division sums and remembering the wise words of Yogi Berra. "It ain't over till it's over."

Suddenly the night stretched far ahead.

At the Bush HQ in Texas: "They've turned up the music. They're showing the results again." At the Gore HQ in Tennessee: "There's a feeling here the celebrations started a little to early. The celebratory rally is on hold."

"This is seriously weird stuff," said Dimbleby. "People are opening the champagne, getting drunk and having to sober up again. This is the weirdest election I have ever covered. A zig-zag, zig-zag night." It was variously described as confusing, fascinating, extraordinary, truly spectacular and absolutely nail-biting.

At 4am, Hillary Clinton - that powerful interloper, as Bonnie Angelo put it - won New York. She came on stage in a brilliant turquoise trouser suit and stood well forward. Her powerful supporters wore black and huddled humbly at the back. This, explained Josh King, a former Clinton aide, was political choreography. "It was my little thing. Separate the figure from the rest of the crowd. Put that person front and centre. See Mrs Clinton in blue with all the dark suits." One of the dark suits was President Clinton. He dashed away a choreographed tear. As Senator Clinton left the stage, she was showered with confetti like a bride.

At 5am, David Dimbleby said, "I could do with some fish and chips. It's the excitement." He added that he would also like a British returning officer going up to the podium and telling you plainly who had won.

By 6am, Dimbleby said they might have to sit there for another week. Snow said pointedly that he would have to stand there.

An hour later, Snow croaked (for he was losing his voice), "There's the White House! There they go! He's through 271." And George W Bush's baffled face appeared at last in the computer-generated White House window, lit with imaginary fireworks. Something about that rueful bemusement reminded you of Reagan.

In A History Of Britain (BBC2), Simon Schama found a politician of genius. Here is Elizabeth I on her soapbox at Tilbury. "What she produced for the expectant crowds was pure gold. A shellburst of oratory."

"My loving people... I know I have the body of a weak and feeble woman, but I have the heart and stomach of a king, and of a king of England too; and think foul scorn that Parma or Spain or any prince of Europe should dare to invade the borders of my realm." Four hundred years on, the hairs rise on your arms and walk about like ghosts.

"That," said Schama, stunned into monosyllables, "is what we have queens for."
