fields.headline: It's a dirty job...
fields.standfirst: He left EastEnders more than ten years ago. But the world still knows Leslie Grantham as Dirty Den. Why has he never quite escaped the shadow of soap’s greatest screen villain? He talked about it to Maxton Walker
fields.trailText: He left EastEnders more than ten years ago. But the world still knows Leslie Grantham as Dirty Den. Why has he never quite escaped the shadow of soap’s greatest screen villain? He talked about it to Maxton Walker.
fields.body:
Leslie "Dirty Den" Grantham is sitting quietly in a plush hotel conference room. But all around him, his minders are in a flap because I've forgotten to tell them I was bringing a photographer. Finally he interjects to calm them down. "Look, it's fine. It's OK. Really."

It feels odd somehow, given how we're used to seeing him, that it's not the other way round; that he's not lambasting his people about the mix-up. And it's not the only apparent oddity. I'd braced myself to meet a wild-eyed, snarling hard man. Instead, I'm sitting with a tanned and relaxed-looking bloke with striking white teeth, dressed in a black shirt and smart grey jacket.

When his entourage leaves the room, though, the atmosphere tenses, and it's clear this isn't going to be easy for either of us: "It's just that I hate talking about myself," he admits guardedly. "I'm always being told off for being self-deprecating."

It's 11 years now since Grantham left EastEnders. Since then, he's been a jobbing character actor, playing variations on Dirty Den in a variety of middlebrow dramas. And it's the latest incarnation that we're here to talk about, a drama for Sky One called The Stretch. It's primarily notable because it reunites him with his EastEnders screen wife, Anita Dobson.

Grantham stars as another identikit hard man doing time while Dobson, as his wife, tries to keep his criminal empire on the rails. But why are they reuniting now? "There have been plenty of attempts to get us back together," he says. "But this was a good team and it was a great script, and they got it together. And, I have to say, it was great to work with Anita again."

Before the interview, I'd asked a few people what they wanted to know about Grantham. They said the same two things: what's it like to be a convicted killer (he murdered a taxi driver while doing national service in Germany in 1967, serving 11 years of a life sentence). And why has he done so little since he left the soap?

The first question, I find impossible to ask: he's already suffered enough at the hands of the press. When The Sun uncovered his murder conviction in EastEnders' early days, he was hounded by the tabloids until he started to go round the bend. When I casually broach the subject, he's cursory about it. "I can never change what happened in the past," he says. "But when things came out, it was terrible. I just switched off."

Eventually, he says, he stayed sane by making a game of it, sending decoy cars around to throw the press off the scent, leaping over the back garden wall to avoid doorstepping hacks.

But the second question - about his post-EastEnders profile - riles him. "Some journalist - a Guardian journalist in fact - once said the only thing I've ever done since leaving EastEnders is star in a soap advert," he complains. "It's just sloppy journalism. I've had five months unemployment in 19 years but some guy says 'the only thing he's done is be in the bath'."

Has Grantham changed much since he was an ex-con trying to break into the profession 20-odd years ago? "I think I'm the same prick now as I've always been. I've just got more money," he says. Oh, come off it. He works. He's still famous. He's got money. "Really, I still have something to prove like I always did. I'll never be content until I rule the world." But it's difficult to buy this. Take a look at any EastEnders scene from his early days, you see something in the eyes - something genuinely scary. A driven man; a guy capable of anything. Certainly not the same as the person sitting here now.

Perhaps the most telling moment, though, is a story he tells about his drama-school days. James Cagney - his hero - was in London working on a film. Grantham went down and hung around the studio one morning until Cagney's limo showed up. "He was being wheeled in surrounded by bouncers. I shouted at him that I wanted to be an actor and this voice came back at me: 'Acting's about walking through the door, planting your feet and telling the truth. Good luck.' I learned more from that one sentence than I did in three years at drama school."

I wonder briefly what the point of the story is: did he think Cagney was passing on some kind of spiritual torch? But that doesn't make sense. Grantham doesn't seem egotistical enough to believe that. In fact it's probably just his way of reinforcing his regular guy credentials; of saying, look, I'm just an ordinary bloke really. And part of him does seem to be genuinely nonplussed at his fame. He sums it up himself: "I get footballers, famous actors, coming up to me and wanting to talk. These are the people I adore and they're being very nice to me. And I always think: why me?"

After the interview, when I'm leaving, I pass him on the stairs having his picture taken. And just for an instant, in the gaze of the camera, I see a flash of the steely eyes of the person I was expecting to meet.

And that, I guess, is why people still want to know him.

 The Stretch, Sky One, Sunday, 9pm.

fields.headline: Portillo attacks 'quick fix' retreat
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Budget
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo derided Gordon Brown yesterday as a "chancellor in full retreat" who had embraced "quick fixes" on fuel and pensions to appease voters ahead of the election.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo derided Gordon Brown yesterday as a "chancellor in full retreat" who had embraced "quick fixes" on fuel and pensions to appease voters ahead of the election.

In noisy Commons exchanges, the shadow chancellor accused Mr Brown of announcing a series of concessions which he had vowed never to make.

"This is not the statement that this chancellor intended to make," Mr Portillo told MPs. "In all his public pronouncements he boasts about how he plans for the long term and avoids quick fixes.

"Does anyone seriously believe that we would have had today's statement if it hadn't been for the fuel protests, if it hadn't been for the panic on the Labour benches and if it weren't for the fact that they were planning an election."

Hailing September's fuel protests as the moment when voters realised they had been betrayed by the government over taxes, Mr Portillo mocked the chancellor for pinching a series of Tory policies on fuel. "We accept his tribute to our policy," he said.

Mr Portillo warned that the chancellor's freeze in fuel duties would not be matched elsewhere because increases in spending - above forecast growth rates - would guarantee higher taxes.

"Today he has merely returned a little bit of the people's surplus, but still he plans to take it back in higher taxes if he wins the next election," Mr Portillo said. "His plan to spend more than the country can afford means there will be tax increases. This is micro-economic meddling by a highly interventionist chancellor."

Turning to pensions, Mr Portillo dismissed the rises announced by Mr Brown, saying the Tories would guarantee a better deal by rolling the winter allowance, the Christmas bonus and free TV licences into the basic state pension.

The shadow chancellor also rounded on Mr Brown for abandoning his commitment to end means-testing for elderly people. "Today he has announced the most massive means testing," Mr Portillo said. "It means all the indignity and humiliation of filling out forms."

Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, welcomed the pension increase which came after pressure from the Lib Dems. "The iron chancellor has buckled and agreed substantial real rises in pensions," he said.

However, Mr Taylor condemned the chancellor for subjecting pensioners to the "indignity" of means testing.

Peter Kilfoyle, the former Labour defence minister who resigned from the government, gave the statement a warm welcome. "Earlier on I was asking if there was a doctor in the house because I have never seen so many sick people as I did this afternoon on the benches opposite when my right honourable friend was speaking," he said.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText:
"There is a legitimate question about the way in which the media celebrates one female type to the exclusion of all others, but that is not the issue here. The motivation behind these rather sour remarks about women 'flaunting' their bodies is clear: it is an ancient piece of prejudice that divides women into clever and beautiful, brainy or sexy, and refuses to recognise that we can be both"
Joan Smith on why clever women can have cleavages, Evening Standard

"One thing about sex. It ain't the cookie jar. You're caught with your hand in the cookie jar, you're stealing money. That's tough to get out of. But in Clinton's case, everyone said to themselves, how would I handle it, if I had an affair? What would I tell my wife? The answer is, you'd lie"
CNN's Larry King on the Monica Lewinsky affair and why America was so forgiving of Bill Clinton's failings, Daily Telegraph

"A lot of women were bringing in copies of Playboy. I looked at them, and you really don't see anyone with the labia minora projecting beyond the labia majora. Gynaecologist-cum-plastic surgeon Dr David Matlock, who set up the Laser Vaginal Rejuvenation Center of Los Angeles, on cosmetic surgery's latest boom area, Marie Claire

fields.headline: Head girls
fields.standfirst: This week saw the launch of the first ever Female FTSE Index. Its aim? To keep tabs on the number of women in Britain's top jobs. So how are we doing? Dr Val Singh unravels the results
fields.trailText: This week saw the launch of the first ever Female FTSE Index. Its aim? To keep tabs on the number of women in Britain's top jobs. So how are we doing? Dr Val Singh unravels the results.
fields.body:
The new Female FTSE Index, launched this week, presents a disappointing picture for talented women managers in the new millennium. The report, undertaken jointly by the Industrial Society and the Fawcett Society, and initiated by Harriet Harman, found that women account for only 5% of all directors of the FTSE-100 companies, while 45% of those organisations still have exclusively male boards. Particularly problematic is the appointment of executive, as opposed to non-executive, directors, where the index was able to find just 10 names - and only one of these, Marjorie Scardino of Pearson, is a chief executive.

What are the reasons for this lack of female representation on top UK boards? Some argue that women lack the killer instinct and confidence required for boardroom life, but there is actually little evidence of great differences in the psychological make-up of male and female managers.

So do women suffer from working within structures that have generally been organised by men for men, in which women have played only segregated and supporting roles? A misleading picture is often painted of the extent to which the glass ceiling has been broken and there is no large pool of women waiting to spring into executive board positions.

But this is partly because women are simply not coming forward. Those in senior positions work exceptionally long hours and their commitment and dedication has to be visible and total. Women now have choices. They do not like to play such career games - and move out.

Those who remain face a catch-22 situation. The key criterion for board appointments is corporate experience at board level, but how can women provide this if they cannot get that first appointment? Those who do get appointed often have other credentials, such as a title (Baroness, Dame, Lady and Dr), and a few women appear in the FTSE Female Index with remarkable frequency.

Thus Dame Stella Rimington holds non-executive positions on a number of boards, including Marks & Spencer and BG Group (part of British Gas), while Baronesses Hogg and Dunn appear more than once.

Meanwhile, it would seem that the appointment process itself is indirectly excluding women, through the briefs given by CEOs to headhunters and the interpretation that headhunters make as to the desired "fit" of the new individual to the board.

Despite the recent rhetoric of a move towards more informal, communicative leadership styles, at which women are said to excel, there still appears to be a "think manager, think male" mind-set when it comes to the appointment of directors of FTSE-100 companies.

A research study, carried out by Cranfield School of Management, of European banking managers, found that women managers still see the "successful manager" as male, even though men are beginning to see the "successful manager" as androgynous, strong on both masculine and feminine leadership traits. Such a view leads women to constrain their own ambition within what they perceive to be possible, rather than pushing themselves forward for promotion.

Cranfield's research has shown that young male managers are much more proactive in self-promotion and use more upward and outward influence than their female counterparts, while women deliver high performance and high commitment, but often wait to be invited to apply for promotions. Given that headhunting firms report difficulties in finding suitable women directors, this lower level of networking by women may be an important factor.

Speaking at the launch of the Female FTSE Index, Denise Kingsmill, deputy chair of the Competition Commission, called for shareholders to challenge male dominance and suggested that diversity should be made a corporate governance issue. It is true that the key to the issue may indeed be the business case. Impact on the bottom line may be made by increased socially responsible investment, for example, while corporate reputations may be enhanced where the board reflects the diversity of both employees and customers.

Nanette Fondas and Susan Sassalos studied 115 large US corporate boards, finding that female directors had significant influence in the boardroom. Women brought a different voice and they often had non-linear career paths, as well as higher expectations of a board member's responsibility to the job. They were exceptionally well prepared and determined to see their ideas and opinions have an impact on the decision-making process.

Women directors act as symbols of the organisational culture for women lower down the ladder. Women managers will be encouraged to stay if they see that ladder extending to the top for those with the right ability, regardless of gender. Retention of women managers is an issue that, if not dealt with in the long term, leads to increased and perhaps unnecessary expenditure on replacement.

The Fortune 500 data from Catalyst (a US lobbying organisation for the promotion of women) shows that 84% of top US companies now have women on their boards. However, despite these higher figures compared with the UK, there has also been a slowing down of progress in the US and only 1% of US executive directors are female, compared with 2% of the FTSE-100 directors.

In the US, there was a chasm between women's perceptions of barriers to director positions and CEOs' perceptions. CEOs said women lacked corporate and general management experience, and had not been in the pipeline for long enough, while women said it was because of male stereotyping and exclusion from informal networks, and only then came the lack of experience.

The "old boys' club" still exists and is only very slowly being infiltrated by women. UK top companies, like those in the US, are notorious for the homogeneity of their boards, made up of predominantly white, middle- class, middle-aged men from the same set of schools and universities. Such similarity of background and experience may lead to complacency and "group-think", with nobody willing to rock the boat. This is not good for corporate governance.

Women directors do not all fit that mould. Given that 72% of companies in the top half of the FTSE-100 have female directors, compared with only 44% of companies in the lower half, an interesting question arises. Does the presence of women on the board foster growth and profitability, or is it that when companies reach a certain size, they can afford to take risks and make diverse appointments? If the business case can be made, perhaps we will see more of the top companies with multiple women directors in the future. How long it will take is anyone's guess.

 Dr Val Singh is senior research fellow at the Centre for Developing Women Business Leaders at Cranfield School of Management.

View from the top
How does it feel to be a woman on the board? The Guardian's Carolyn McCall reveals all

The FTSE Female Index is useful because it puts in the spotlight the fact that the glass ceiling has not yet been shattered, which is contrary to what many men in business probably feel. I think a lot of men in business have actually seen more and more women breaking through on to boards and into senior management postions, and most think the floodgates are well and truly open. This survey proves that this is not the case.

However, there has been an enormous change and women are running businesses in many sectors of the economy - advertising, media, consultancy, search and selection, travel and new economy businesses are just a few. They just happen not to be FTSE-100 companies.

Of course it would be great to see more women joining Marjorie Scardino, the chief executive of Pearson and the only female chief executive in the index, but I also think there is an overemphasis on the FTSE-100 which does not recognise the real progress that has been made.

My own experience is that gender has never been an issue in terms of career advancement, although I'm sure this is not always the case. The Guardian Newspapers Board (also the Observer) has four women among its 12 directors. I have never found that women lack what people call the "killer instinct". On the contrary, they are just as capable of quick decision-making and implementation, but are particularly good at what is now called emotional intelligence - an increasingly recognised vital ingredient to successful management.

So, in the future, the balance of these qualities is what boards will look for, not for one or the other. And more women will get into the FTSE-100.

 Carolyn McCall is the managing director of Guardian Newspapers Ltd.

fields.headline: No: 1758
fields.standfirst: Georgina Hristova
fields.trailText: Georgina Hristova
fields.body:
Age: 29.

Appearance: Blonde. Beautiful. Bulgarian.

Last seen: Welded to the arm of Britain's most preposterous restaurant critic (and "critic" is the operative word here, seeing as how he is famed for whining and dining).

Not... 'Fraid so. If music be the food of love, Ms Hristova has stolen Michael Winner's dinner.

What on earth attracted her to him? You shouldn't believe all you hear about Winner. A pompous, overbearing boor - except he is really a kitten in private. A cigar-chomping curmudgeon - except he has given up smoking. Director of some of the worst films ever, except - oh, forget that last one, actually.

Still, one shudders to imagine the chat-up line he used. How about: "My dear, I can absolutely guarantee not to give you a role in my next movie."

And what has happened to disrupt this blissful relationship? Georgina is to be investigated by the DSS after it emerged that she travels the world with Winner while simultaneously claiming income support and housing benefit.

Was the DSS alerted by any suspicious or inexplicable behaviour? What, you mean apart from going out with Winner? Actually, yes: Hristova failed to declare her trips, as benefits claimants are required to do. She says she had only been out of the country on short trips, and that she didn't know she had to declare trips under four weeks. She has been in touch with the DSS to explain.

Surely one should receive benefits for undertaking lengthy foreign excursions with the director of the Death Wish films? Easy there, or he'll be on the phone. (He has got 100 of them at "Winner Palace" in Holland Park, after all.

Winner says: "She is a single mother who has been abandoned and is entitled to benefits. She has not been abroad with me for in excess of four weeks."

Coming soon to a cinema near you: Death Wish 6: The Worryingly Voyeuristic Murder of a Social Security Fraud Investigator.

fields.headline: Blood, sweat and ice
fields.standfirst: If the dome robbers had succeeded, they would have bagged the third biggest diamond ever found. But is this dazzling stone tainted by its connections to a corrupt dictator and a brutal civil war? Ewen MacAskill, Chris McGreal and John Vidal on the trail of the Millennium Star
fields.trailText: If the dome robbers had succeeded, they would have bagged the third biggest diamond ever found. But is this dazzling stone tainted by its connections to a corrupt dictator and a brutal civil war? Ewen MacAskill, Chris McGreal and John Vidal on the trail of the Millennium Star.
fields.body:
It was scarcely surprising that the attempt - as preposterous as it was audacious - to seize the dazzling Millennium Star made news round the world. But there were few headlines when the diamond first appeared, even though its emergence into the world eight years ago was no less remarkable.

The brightness of the diamond today contrasts with its origins in a country ruled over at the time by one of the most corrupt leaders in African history.

The truth about exactly how the Millennium Star travelled from the diamond fields of the Democratic Republic of Congo to the cutting-rooms of Antwerp, New York and South Africa and arrived in the hands of De Beers, the biggest diamond company in the world, is shrouded in rumour and spin.

But last night the Guardian received an extraordinary inside account of the transaction that started the jewel on its journey to the dome. It offers a rare insight into a murky and often dangerous world a million miles away from the velvet display cases of the west's jewellery stores.

Until this week it had been shaping up as a very bad year for the industry. Diamonds have never been as emotive as they have become in recent months - the images of civilians who had suffered amputation at the hands of rebel forces in Sierra Leone and the devastation caused by the civil wars in Angola and the Democratic Republic of Congo itself have aroused public concern about what have been dubbed "blood diamonds". Increasingly it was becoming clear to the public that jewellery prized in the west was often being paid for with lives in Africa.

But then Tuesday's attempted heist provided the diamond industry with a wonderful public relations coup. Many papers yesterday carried a picture of the French actress, Sophie Marceau, holding the £350m diamond. The Daily Mail had it on the front, in colour. What more could the industry have asked for in the run-up to Christmas?

Most papers carried the same potted history: that the Millennium Star had been found in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the early 1990s; that it had been bought by De Beers on the open market; and the company's specialists had spent six months studying it before beginning to make the cuts that would transform it from rough diamond to one of the most prized in the world.

De Beers said yesterday that the information had been supplied to the press by police in London. Could it provide more information about how it had acquired the diamond? And where, exactly, in the Democratic Republic of the Congo had it been found?

Andrew Lamont, the De Beers spokesman in London, narrowed it down: it had been found in Mbuji-Mayi in either 1991 or 1992, but it was impossible to be more specific than that. "If you were a fisherman in Scotland and someone brought you a fish and said they caught it in the North Sea, I would have to say 'it was caught in the North Sea'. It is exactly the same."

He said the diamond would have passed through lots of hands, from a Congolese digger, his boss, several other people, a travelling trader and then one of the trading stations, where a value would have been put on it. Surely, given the size of the stone, some effort would have been made to trace it back? The area was difficult, explained Lamont: it was not the kind of place that had roads and postal addresses.

Later, Andy Bone, another De Beers spokesman, provided more details. The 770-carat rough diamond had been found in 1992 near the town and was bought from a family and community co-operative headed by a village chief. It had been purchased in open competition with other diamond buyers, and had cost millions, the most that De Beers had ever paid for a rough diamond.

He said the village chief had not even had a cheque account and De Beers had helped to set one up.

But last night a reliable source with close knowledge of the sale provided yet another version of the gem's provenance. According to his account, the diamond was acquired and exported perfectly legitimately.

But the details of its first sale are compelling: "The diamond was found by two 'pickers' who dig shallow holes. There are lots of them, living a brutal existence. They went to Mbuji-Maya, a one-horse diamond town where there are many dealers who are often black marketeers, working all sorts of deals. There are a lot of crooks there. Fortunately, they had a "coaxier", or negotiator with them. They didn't speak English. There were no intermediaries."

The source said the pickers and their negotiator simply walked into the local De Beers office. "The office manager must have fallen over. It was about 750 carats, a huge elongated lump with a fabulous colour. He would have given them something immediately and a price was settled at US$6m. The manager guarded it in the De Beers safe for about 10 days. It was a miracle he held onto it for so long. Word gets out there. There are people employed just to listen."

The source said the fee for the diamond was handed over in cash. "There were a lot of problems afterwards. The local president of the mine did not get a cut, it seems. The two men, I heard, were beaten up by the military."

De Beers bristles at any suggestion that the Millennium Star could be a"blood" diamond, stressing that at the time it was found there was no civil war in Zaire (renamed the Democratic Republic of Congo four years ago).

"In the early 1990s, Zaire was formally recognised by the UN and had a legitimate place in the world community," Lamont pointed out. "It had a place in the OAU (the Organisation of African Unity). It had a place in terms of the world political landscape. They were a legitimate government of the day."

The Democratic Republic of Congo is one of the three largest diamond producers in the world and Africa's biggest with official sales of $396m. The industry, however, knows that at least as much again may be mined illegally with the real value of $500m making a mockery of the official figures.

The town near where the diamond was found, Mbuji-Mayi, is today wracked by war and occupied by Zimbabwean soldiers, one of the many neighbours looking for a share of the diamond trade.

Big stones are common around Mbuji-Mayi. Last month a 265.85 carat diamond, known locally as the Ngokas diamond, sold for $17.9m after being found in June in the same area as De Beers bought the Millennium Star.

A decade ago, the town was close to ruin. Mbuji-Mayi was at the same time one of the wealthiest and yet most ramshackle towns in Zaire. Access was controlled, and all foreigners had to buy special passes from the notoriously corrupt mining ministry just to be able to fly there.

Mbotu Sese Seko's regime had given up on maintaining public works in Mbuji-Mayi a decade or more earlier, just as it had let the rest of Zaire crumble into ruin. Roads were worn and ripped into little more than tracks, most of the town had not had electricity for years and the police and army were one vast extortion racket.

But at night, the town was enveloped in the drone of generators lighting the homes of the diamond dealers who dealt with the poor roads by buying themselves sparkling new Mercedes four-wheel drives.

Mbuji-Mayi's main streets were lined with the shops of Lebanese middle men all attempting to lure diamond miners to sell their gems. It is through one of these small buildings, usually with a crudely painted picture of a diamond outside for the illiterate, that De Beers claims the Millennium Star made its way to the international market and display at the dome.

But anything as magnificent as the centrepiece of the Millennium collection would have been hard to keep secret in a town like Mbuji-Mayi, and would probably have attracted the menacing attention of Mobutu himself.

One former De Beers employee said yesterday: "No big diamond lasts very long. The diggers work in teams. They brag. They would have to get rid of it very fast. As soon as word got out that a big stone had been found, the local force - police, army, politician, whoever - would get it. The corruption would kick in."

Around the same time that the Millennium Star was found, a story went around Kinshasa of the discovery of a large new diamond in the centre of the country and of a race between De Beers and Mobutu's cronies to lay their hands on it.

If Mobutu's men got there first, the cost to De Beers would have risen considerably. The hapless miner who discovered the gem was said to have been caught in the middle. De Beers would pay him with money. Others tended to favour lead on such occasions.

The miner got lucky. Mobutu's men did not get to him first, and he not only got paid but was whisked to the safety of Belgium. Lamont said yesterday he knew nothing of such a story.

De Beers came to be a key prop maintaining Mobutu in power, along with the American and French governments. As Zaire collapsed under his maladministration, diamond revenues grew to be a more and more important source of funds with which Mobutu ensured the loyalty of just enough people - including opposition politicians and parts of the army - to stave off any serious threat to his power.

Although De Beers argues that Mobutu was Zaire's legitimate leader, the company was at the heart of an industry that was notoriously corrupt in a country that came to epitomise graft. Much of the diamond revenue went into Mobutu's pocket, and that which did not was of little benefit to Zaire as a whole. Many would argue that diamonds did the country untold harm by perpetuating Mobutu's control until he was finally brought down by a foreign invasion.

But Zaire was more than a source of mines for De Beers. It also served as cover for buying valuable gems from Unita rebels in neighbouring Angola who used the money to fund one of the longest and most brutal wars in Africa - one which is still being waged today. (De Beers has maintained it was never aware that diamonds it obtained originated from Unita.)

Unita sold Angolan diamonds to Lebanese middlemen in towns such as Tshikapa. De Beers swept them up, all the time insisting it had no knowledge of their origin. But few people in Tshikapa, and certainly not the Lebanese diamond buyers, were in any doubt about where the stones came from or who was selling them.

De Beers for years denied it could tell the origin of such "blood diamonds" and therefore it could not be accused of knowingly funding Unita. fields.bodyText: It was scarcely surprising that the attempt - as preposterous as it was audacious - to seize the dazzling Millennium Star made news round the world. But there were few headlines when the diamond first appeared, even though its emergence into the world eight years ago was no less remarkable. The brightness of the diamond today contrasts with its origins in a country ruled over at the time by one of the most corrupt leaders in African history. The truth about exactly how the Millennium Star travelled from the diamond fields of the Democratic Republic of Congo to the cutting-rooms of Antwerp, New York and South Africa and arrived in the hands of De Beers, the biggest diamond company in the world, is shrouded in rumour and spin. But last night the Guardian received an extraordinary inside account of the transaction that started the jewel on its journey to the dome. It offers a rare insight into a murky and often dangerous world a million miles away from the velvet display cases of the west's jewellery stores. Until this week it had been shaping up as a very bad year for the industry. Diamonds have never been as emotive as they have become in recent months - the images of civilians who had suffered amputation at the hands of rebel forces in Sierra Leone and the devastation caused by the civil wars in Angola and the Democratic Republic of Congo itself have aroused public concern about what have been dubbed "blood diamonds". Increasingly it was becoming clear to the public that jewellery prized in the west was often being paid for with lives in Africa. But then Tuesday's attempted heist provided the diamond industry with a wonderful public relations coup. Many papers yesterday carried a picture of the French actress, Sophie Marceau, holding the £350m diamond. The Daily Mail had it on the front, in colour. What more could the industry have asked for in the run-up to Christmas? De Beers said yesterday that the information had been supplied to the press by police in London. Could it provide more information about how it had acquired the diamond? And where, exactly, in the Democratic Republic of the Congo had it been found? Andrew Lamont, the De Beers spokesman in London, narrowed it down: it had been found in Mbuji-Mayi in either 1991 or 1992, but it was impossible to be more specific than that. "If you were a fisherman in Scotland and someone brought you a fish and said they caught it in the North Sea, I would have to say 'it was caught in the North Sea'. It is exactly the same." He said the diamond would have passed through lots of hands, from a Congolese digger, his boss, several other people, a travelling trader and then one of the trading stations, where a value would have been put on it. Surely, given the size of the stone, some effort would have been made to trace it back? The area was difficult, explained Lamont: it was not the kind of place that had roads and postal addresses. Later, Andy Bone, another De Beers spokesman, provided more details. The 770-carat rough diamond had been found in 1992 near the town and was bought from a family and community co-operative headed by a village chief. It had been purchased in open competition with other diamond buyers, and had cost millions, the most that De Beers had ever paid for a rough diamond. He said the village chief had not even had a cheque account and De Beers had helped to set one up. But last night a reliable source with close knowledge of the sale provided yet another version of the gem's provenance. According to his account, the diamond was acquired and exported perfectly legitimately. But the details of its first sale are compelling: "The diamond was found by two 'pickers' who dig shallow holes. There are lots of them, living a brutal existence. They went to Mbuji-Maya, a one-horse diamond town where there are many dealers who are often black marketeers, working all sorts of deals. There are a lot of crooks there. Fortunately, they had a "coaxier", or negotiator with them. They didn't speak English. There were no intermediaries." The source said the pickers and their negotiator simply walked into the local De Beers office. "The office manager must have fallen over. It was about 750 carats, a huge elongated lump with a fabulous colour. He would have given them something immediately and a price was settled at US$6m. The manager guarded it in the De Beers safe for about 10 days. It was a miracle he held onto it for so long. Word gets out there. There are people employed just to listen." The source said the fee for the diamond was handed over in cash. "There were a lot of problems afterwards. The local president of the mine did not get a cut, it seems. The two men, I heard, were beaten up by the military." De Beers bristles at any suggestion that the Millennium Star could be a"blood" diamond, stressing that at the time it was found there was no civil war in Zaire (renamed the Democratic Republic of Congo four years ago). "In the early 1990s, Zaire was formally recognised by the UN and had a legitimate place in the world community," Lamont pointed out. "It had a place in the OAU (the Organisation of African Unity). It had a place in terms of the world political landscape. They were a legitimate government of the day." The Democratic Republic of Congo is one of the three largest diamond producers in the world and Africa's biggest with official sales of $396m. The industry, however, knows that at least as much again may be mined illegally with the real value of $500m making a mockery of the official figures. The town near where the diamond was found, Mbuji-Mayi, is today wracked by war and occupied by Zimbabwean soldiers, one of the many neighbours looking for a share of the diamond trade. Big stones are common around Mbuji-Mayi. Last month a 265.85 carat diamond, known locally as the Ngokas diamond, sold for $17.9m after being found in June in the same area as De Beers bought the Millennium Star. A decade ago, the town was close to ruin. Mbuji-Mayi was at the same time one of the wealthiest and yet most ramshackle towns in Zaire. Access was controlled, and all foreigners had to buy special passes from the notoriously corrupt mining ministry just to be able to fly there. Mbotu Sese Seko's regime had given up on maintaining public works in Mbuji-Mayi a decade or more earlier, just as it had let the rest of Zaire crumble into ruin. Roads were worn and ripped into little more than tracks, most of the town had not had electricity for years and the police and army were one vast extortion racket. But at night, the town was enveloped in the drone of generators lighting the homes of the diamond dealers who dealt with the poor roads by buying themselves sparkling new Mercedes four-wheel drives. Mbuji-Mayi's main streets were lined with the shops of Lebanese middle men all attempting to lure diamond miners to sell their gems. One former De Beers employee said yesterday: "No big diamond lasts very long. The diggers work in teams. They brag. They would have to get rid of it very fast. As soon as word got out that a big stone had been found, the local force - police, army, politician, whoever - would get it. The corruption would kick in." Around the same time that the Millennium Star was found, a story went around Kinshasa of the discovery of a large new diamond in the centre of the country and of a race between De Beers and Mobutu's cronies to lay their hands on it. De Beers would pay him with money. Others tended to favour lead on such occasions. The miner got lucky. fields.headline: Rwanda wants its children back
fields.trailText: Rwanda has requested the return of 59 Rwandan children who have been living in Italy since the genocidal killings that saw an estimated 800,000 people die in 1994.
fields.body:
Rwanda has requested the return of 59 Rwandan children who have been living in Italy since the genocidal killings that saw an estimated 800,000 people die in 1994.

The request, renewed by President Paul Kagame during a visit to Rome at the weekend, has shocked the northern town of Castenedolo, where 41 children have been adopted by local families who have no intention of giving them up.

The case has aroused fierce debate about the rival claims of the children's natural and adoptive families and about the wisdom of returning westernised children to their African homeland.

"This proposal is absolutely irresponsible and not to be contemplated," Castenedolo's mayor, Giovambattista Groli, said yesterday. The children were perfectly integrated into the prosperous town, he said; they speak Italian and the local Brescian dialect but not a word of their original language.

"Our impression is that this initiative is intended to achieve objectives quite different from the return of the children to Rwanda. They want to whip up emotions in order to secure economic benefits for the country. You can't transfer children who have become accustomed to life in a western country to a country that has nothing," Mr Groli said.

The children, now aged between six and 10, were brought to Italy by the Red Cross to escape the killings. A Roman Catholic humanitarian organisation helped to find foster families and adoption procedures were completed for most of them last year.

A juvenile court in Brescia declared that there was no question of their returning to Rwanda, where they had been found in a state of "complete abandonment".

"By now the children go riding, they have holidays in Sardinia and they can't stand flies," a member of the Catholic organisation was quoted as saying.

The issue has raised complex legal and ethical questions, starting with the degree of kinship, in an area of extended clans, might entitle relatives to a child's return.

"I don't think there are many [children] who have no relatives at all. Perhaps the adoptions were a little bit hasty," said Father Mario Bertoni, a priest from a neighbouring village. "They have settled in very well here and I think it would be very traumatic to send them back. It's not as though everything was tranquil in Rwanda."

Children's rights experts say it is unwise to allow international adoptions in the event of war precisely because of the dislocation and confusion caused by conflict. The Italian foreign ministry hopes to achieve a negotiated solution.

A similar conflict between France and Rwanda was resolved with an agreement to allow regular contact between the children and their natural relatives.

Rwanda's ambassador to Brussels threatened legal action yesterday if Italy failed to return the children.

"We are grateful to those who helped them, and the families thank them too, but the situation in Rwanda today, six years later, has changed. The families call for their return, as does the government," Jacques Bihozagara said.

"If the principle of adopting children because they are poor is accepted," he went on, "then the whole of Africa would be up for adoption."

webTitle: Arts: William Blake at Tate Britain

fields.headline: 'Twixt heaven and hell
fields.standfirst: Blake's life was one of squalor and frustration; most people thought him mad. No wonder he dreamed of a green and pleasant land, says Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Blake's life was one of squalor and frustration; most people thought him mad. No wonder he dreamed of a green and pleasant land, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
There are two strangely disturbing objects on display in Tate Britain's William Blake exhibition. The first is an 18th-century "rolling press" of the kind Blake used to print his eye-searing, mind-boggling epic poems.

The second is a plaster life mask of the 66-year-old visionary made in 1823 by sculptor and phrenologist James Deville. The press just happens to look like a guillotine, while the life mask could be a head severed with the geometric certainty for which this terrifying device was infamous.

If Blake had lived at another time, such an association would be unmade and irrelevant. Blake, though, was in his prime at the time of the French Revolution, flashing guillotine blades, and what seemed to be the very real threat of French invasion. The 1790s and 1800s were a time of political and social repression in England's far from green and pleasant land.

The governments of Pitt the younger and their spies scented sedition in the rank air of London's streets as well as in the Sussex countryside. Blake himself was arrested at Felpham and tried for allegedly insulting a soldier and damning the king. Although acquitted, he was frightened for his life.

Blake was born in Soho in 1757 just as the industrial revolution was emerging fully armed with its dark, satanic mills from the iron heart of England. He was swept up in the savage "No Popery" Gordon riots of 1780 and would have seen the sad strings of boys hanging from temporary gibbets as a warning to other peacebreakers of those turbulent weeks.

His London was a filthy, miasmic place, abounding in perverse energy and wild ideas, and this is reflected in his whirling, punky engravings. Blake was to be wrapped up in this sooty, surreptitious London nearly all his life.

Parts of his epic Jerusalem read like a Georgian A-Z ("The fields from Islington to Marylebone/To Primrose Hill and St John's Wood/Were builded over with pillars of gold/And there Jerusalem's pillars stood"). London informs his poetry as surely as it did his dissenting politics and decidedly non-conformist religious views.

And yet it was his early escapes from the Great Wen that brought angels, together with the stars and the heavens, into his dreams and art. When he was about 10 and walking across Peckham Rye, Blake saw a tree filled with angels. Another time he witnessed angelic figures walking between those of south London haymakers.

And, as a teenager, the apprentice engraver saw Christ and his apostles among the medieval statuary he was drawing in Westminster Abbey. The Angel Gabriel came to visit him at home in Lambeth, where the Ancient of Days had once hovered above the stairwell. Blake saw, throughout his poor life, as a pre-school child does, with the mind's eye.

To him, the world of the imagination was often more real than that of the squalid London in which he toiled, earning crusts and porter, and living with his devoted wife, Kate, in usually no more than two tiny back rooms. There was, he said, a mansion waiting for them in Heaven.

To most of his contemporaries, Blake was a nutter or simply inept. Perhaps his most beautiful, and certainly his most spiritual, work is the set of 17 tiny woodcuts he made for Robert Thornton's edition of Virgil's Pastorals.

Each offers a glimpse of heaven - infinity in the palm of the reader's hand - and yet the printers, when they saw Blake's blocks, thought them crude or unfinished. They were used to the buttery-smooth etched lines of, among other fine craftsmen, the highly fashionable Bartolozzi. Thornton included an apology for Blake's designs. Truly, like the Christ he adored, Blake was a prophet without honour in his own country.

In fact, his curious poems, with the bizarre engravings that accompanied them, were not to become acceptable - outside a small circle of admirers that included his peers, the painter Fuseli, the neo-classical sculptor Flaxman, and his disciples, Samuel Palmer, John Linnel and Edward Calvert - until long after Alexander Gilchrist published the first full-length study of Blake, with a little help from the Rossetti brothers, in 1863.

In the first edition of Gilchrist, Dante Gabriel Rossetti even fiddled with some of Blake's verse to make it more palatable to a Pre-Raphaelite readership. It wasn't until Yeats donned Blake's mystic mantle decades later ("Myself I must remake/Till I am Timon and Lear/Or that William Blake/Who beat upon the wall/Till truth obeyed his call" - An Acre of Grass, 1938) that Blake became a part of the modern literary canon.

Blake's poetry, however, is inseparable from his art, and so the Tate exhibition is as much a literary as an artistic shrine. Most of Blake's writhing images of angels, demons and Old Testament characters are illustrations for the books he made so laboriously and of which very few sold.

Had he lived 150 years longer, he would have found such images as Glad Day (1780) or The Ancient of Days (1824) stuck to the walls of a thousand student bedsits, or used on album covers, or forming the inspiration, conscious or unconscious, of dozens of illustrators. Strangest of all, he would have heard the Tory party that liked to be rid of his sort singing "And did those feet in ancient times" at its conferences, as though wilfully misunderstanding Blake's call to intellectual and spiritual revolution.

The Tate show brings together no fewer than 639 works, grouped convincingly into four sections - One of the Gothic Artists, The Furnace of Lambeth's Vale, Chambers of the Imagination and Many Formidable Works. The best of these is the last. Here you can discover the intimate world of the entire 100 engraved pages - all 16 years' worth - of Blake's mighty poem Jerusalem: The Emanation of the Giant Albion.

This vast allegory of redemption was, said Blake in a letter to his patron Thomas Butts, "the Grandest Poem that This World Contains". Quite what Blake meant is unclear, but then, much of his work needs to be absorbed through the eyes and ears of the soul rather than the rational mind.

Blake was an anti-rationalist. The Ancient of Days, setting a compass upon the face of the world, also goes by the name Urizen ("your reason") in Blake's pseudo-Biblical language. Urizen destroys the imagination with his limiting compasses. His spirit can also be seen in that of Newton, whom Blake famously represented naked in one of his large prints finished in pen and ink and watercolour, setting his own compass, and thus what Blake calls his "single vision", on a sheet of paper.

Yet, if Blake's world and beliefs are often ineffable, the images he created speak loudly to the child and to the spirit of imagination most of us are taught to put away when we go to school. Blake's demons and monsters, his funny animals and terrifying Nebuchadnezzar are the stuff that haunts the night-time bedrooms of thousands of dreamy children.

Aside from Waterhouse's The Lady of Shalott, the reason I came to the Tate by myself as a child was to look at the Blakes - God Judging Adam from a blazing chariot of fire, The Ghost of a Flea, Nebuchadnezzar and the Virgil woodcuts.

Blake would have made a good living today, especially in cinema or television. As it was, he was a largely marginalised creature, a kind of permanently angry teenager head-banging in his lonely room, who just about made ends meet. His mortal remains lie in an unmarked grave in the dissenters' burial ground at Bunhill Row, just north of the City of London.

The oddity and strange beauty of his dreamy images should draw a big new audience: despite being the product of a very particular time in British history, Blake continues to speak to successive generations, to anyone who believes in the power of the imagination. He is one of Britain's greats, not just as a poet or an artist, but as a true original, a spirit of the unfettered imagination.

Of course, this is a lousy thing to be in the material world of his or any other age, but his private world is now lavishly on display, together with a handsome catalogue, for anyone to share. This is the largest ever exhibition held on Blake, and one to get lost, and even lose your head, in.

 William Blake is at Tate Britain, London SW1 (020-7887 8008), until February 11.

Yet, if Blake's world and beliefs are often ineffable, the images he created speak loudly to the child and to the spirit of imagination most of us are taught to put away when we go to school. Blake's demons and monsters, his funny animals and terrifying Nebuchadnezzar are the stuff that haunts the night-time bedrooms of thousands of dreamy children. Aside from Waterhouse's The Lady of Shalott, the reason I came to the Tate by myself as a child was to look at the Blakes - God Judging Adam from a blazing chariot of fire, The Ghost of a Flea, Nebuchadnezzar and the Virgil woodcuts. Blake would have made a good living today, especially in cinema or television. As it was, he was a largely marginalised creature, a kind of permanently angry teenager head-banging in his lonely room, who just about made ends meet. His mortal remains lie in an unmarked grave in the dissenters' burial ground at Bunhill Row, just north of the City of London. The oddity and strange beauty of his dreamy images should draw a big new audience: despite being the product of a very particular time in British history, Blake continues to speak to successive generations, to anyone who believes in the power of the imagination. He is one of Britain's greats, not just as a poet or an artist, but as a true original, a spirit of the unfettered imagination. Of course, this is a lousy thing to be in the material world of his or any other age, but his private world is now lavishly on display, together with a handsome catalogue, for anyone to share. This is the largest ever exhibition held on Blake, and one to get lost, and even lose your head, in.  William Blake is at Tate Britain, London SW1 (020-7887 8008), until February 11.

webTitle: Rethink on proposal to ban MS drug

fields.headline: Rethink on proposal to ban MS drug
fields.trailText: Plans to impose an NHS ban on the use of the multiple sclerosis drug beta interferon are being reconsidered by the government's advisers on the use of medicines.
fields.body:
Plans to impose an NHS ban on the use of the multiple sclerosis drug beta interferon are being reconsidered by the government's advisers on the use of medicines.

Patients' groups, doctors and the two manufacturers who complained about the draft guidance from the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) have had their appeals against the process upheld.

A final decision on the drug, which is administered by injection and costs about £10,000 a year per patient, is not expected until early next year.

The Nice appraisal committee which had decided that the "modest clinical benefit" of the treatment appeared to be outweighed "by the very high costs", had not fully explained its reasons for the decision, an appeals panel said.

It also questioned whether adequate consideration had been given to the long-term benefits of beta interferon. Studies indicating that it can delay or even stop the disease will also be considered.

Prescription of the drug varies widely between health authorities. Those calling for its more widespread use argue that while it is not a cure it is effective in treating relapsing-re mitting MS, which comes about when a certain body chemical causes the immune system to attack healthy cells.

About 3% of patients in the UK receive the drug, compared with 12-15% of patients in France (where it costs £6,000) and Germany, and up to 40% of patients in the US

Biogen, which makes the beta interferon therapy Avonex, said it hoped Nice would "finally take into consideration published data as well as the views of clinicians and the MS community".

webTitle: Inquiry prompts call to tighten shipping rules

fields.headline: Inquiry prompts call to tighten shipping rules
fields.trailText: Ministers are to demand tougher international regulations on the safety of hatch covers on bulk carriers, after the captain and crew of the Derbyshire, which sank 20 years ago in a typhoon, were cleared yesterday of negligence.
fields.body:
Ministers are to demand tougher international regulations on the safety of hatch covers on bulk carriers, after the captain and crew of the Derbyshire, which sank 20 years ago in a typhoon, were cleared yesterday of negligence.

An inquiry by a high court judge into the shipwreck, which claimed the lives of the 42 crew and the wives of two of them, rejected the findings of an earlier investigation which blamed the sinking off the Japanese coast on a failure to secure a hatch cover properly.

Instead Mr Justice Colman blamed the disaster on inadequate hatch covers, which bent and buckled when the vessel encountered 80ft waves in a Pacific ocean typhoon in September 1980.

Sea water poured into the space above the cargo, causing the vessel to plunge deeper, increasing the pressure on other hatch covers, which burst, and leading to the huge ship's sink ing two-and-a-half miles to the bottom.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, said he fully endorsed the view that the crew were in no way to blame for the loss "and his specific rejection of the suggestion that the bosun's stores hatch was left unsecured by the crew".

He said the government would press "strongly and urgently" for an international convention to be amended on minimum hatch cover strength - the amendment to be applied not only to new bulk carriers but also to existing ones. He also promised to report to parliament on how the matter was progressing.

He hoped the judge's report would finally provide the answers to the many questions surrounding the sinking.

Twenty scientific and technical experts, six master mariners, and five other witnesses gave evidence to the inquiry over 54 days.

Mr Justice Colman said yesterday that the Derbyshire, 280 metres long and 44 metres wide, would almost certainly not have been lost had it not encountered "extremely severe seas" in typhoon Orchid.

There was nothing to suggest that when Swan Hunter built the 169,000 tonne vessel the hatch cover requirements were deficient or unsafe, he said. This argument has been challenged by the ship officers' union, Numast, which says that several other tankers built at the time had defects.

A report on Channel 4 News tonight will claim that the inquiry did not fully investigate the Derbyshire's design and construction. Donald Thomas, a welder on the ship while it was being built, says the main keel girders were put on by "shoddy welders". The men were on piecework and "putting bits of metal in"; this made the girders "very, very weak".

The judge pointed out that an investigation was in progress into hatch strengths. He recommended regulations covering their use to be amended as soon as the results of the present survey were known. Some 476 bulk carriers are on the seas, of which 68 are of similar length to the Derbyshire.

The hatch strengths on the vessel had complied with international rules which the British government had tried to change, but it dropped its objections when it failed to get the backing of other countries. The judge exonerated the government from blame.

The Derbyshire families welcomed the report. Their solicitor, Stephen Cantor, said they were pleased that there had been "a complete exoneration and vindication of the crew".

Paul Lambert, chairman of the Derbyshire Family Association, said:"I don't think there are any winners because there are still 44 people dead. But the report has come out and said that the assessors were wrong in blaming the crew. It means a lot. That's 20 years of campaigning."

Margaret Noblett, whose husband was a victim, said: "I hope this inquirry will save lives. Every month a bulk carrier disappears. There is obviously something wrong with the way they are built."

webTitle: Fast food feasts boost rat populace

fields.headline: Fast food feasts boost rat populace
fields.trailText: Discarded fast food is one of the main causes behind a big increase in the UK's rat population in the past year, pest controllers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Discarded fast food is one of the main causes behind a big increase in the UK's rat population in the past year, pest controllers said yesterday.

Rat "hotspots" occurred in the northern home counties, particularly Bedfordshire, Oxfordshire and Berkshire, affecting towns such as Newbury where, observers believe, the rodents had become resistant to the pest poisons usually put down.

Overall rat populations last year increased 18% on the previous year, and according to the National Pest Technicians Association there was a 31% increase in summer infestations.

Barry Sheard, who wrote the association's report on the matter, said: "Normally, in the summer, local authorities can concentrate on typical warm weather problems like wasps, but in 1999 it was rats. One of the key problems was the fast food outlets that often stack rubbish in their backyard - it's a haven for rats."

He said that cities such as Birmingham were receiving up to 24 phone calls a day about rat infestations.

"We are seriously concerned that the situation may get out of control like it has in New York. Rats are everywhere there because control was neglected. Now they have a rat epidemic."

Privatised water firms cutting back on rat control in the sewers, warmer temperatures favouring rat breeding, and increased use of plastic building products that let rats chew through air bricks, pipework and drainage chambers, were partly responsible for the rodent increase, said Mr Sheard.

fields.headline: Fancy a dip?
fields.standfirst: This week's attack by a great white was the third in Australian waters in recent weeks. Patrick Barkham reports from the beaches of Sydney.
fields.trailText: This week's attack by a great white was the third in Australian waters in recent weeks. Patrick Barkham reports from the beaches of Sydney.
fields.body:
It could have been a scene from Jaws. A group of middle-aged swimmers was taking a regular early-morning dip on an eerily overcast Monday at North Cottesloe beach. Around 100 people were milling about, watching the gentle surf roll in and sipping cafe lattes in Perth's fashionable beachside bars.

"Is there something out there?" Ken Crew asked his friends as he ploughed along in the quiet of the shallows. A second later, in waist-deep water, his leg was torn off by a 16ft great white shark.

People screamed as the surf boiled red. His friend, Dirk Avery, tried to beat the shark back, but was bitten badly on his legs and feet. Crew was dragged to the shore, but life-savers could only look on helplessly: the 49-year-old father of three had lost too much blood and died on the sand.

The fatal attack was the third off the coast of Australia recently. Last month, a fisherman swam four hours to safety after a great white shark sank his small boat. He survived. Six weeks ago, two south coast-surfers - a honeymooner and a 15-year-old - didn't make it home. They were hauled off their boards on successive days by great whites.

For two days after the latest attack, Perth's normally bustling city beaches were empty, closed to the public. Many Australians were left wondering if their beachside lifestyle, of weekends spent picnicking, swimming, surfing and diving off their country's golden sands, was worth the risk.

But there is life in the Australian dream yet. Stephen Leahy, the national lifesaving services manager of Surf Life Saving Australia, reports "business as usual" around the country's coastline.

Down at the cherished symbol of Australia's good life, Sydney's Bondi beach, the usual bobbing crowd, resembling a school of dolphins in their dark, sleek wetsuits, lines up in the sunshine, 150 yards from the shore, to ride its famous waves. "It's something everyone worries about, but at the end of the day if you want to surf, sharks might always be there," says surfer Luca Ciano, 22, clambering out of the ocean with his board.

Lancashire backpacker Martin Smith, 24, has just taken his first plunge in Australian waters. "I asked the lifeguards where it was safe to surf first, but I'm not worried about sharks. I've been more concerned about the jellyfish." He is visiting Perth on his travels. Will he swim there? "Probably. I can't see why not," he laughs.

The sun has smelted deep creases onto the face of Bondi regular Gary Taylor. He has been swimming at the beach for "62 years, maybe longer" and he has only crossed the path of a shark once. "We don't have shark attacks," Taylor barks. "You've got more chance of being hit by a bloody car as you walk across the promenade." But he says he wouldn't swim "down south" or over at Perth.

Most of Australia's popular beaches have shark nets, but these are not completely shark-proof. "A shark can swim in it or around it or over it," says Taylor, who saw two sharks being pulled from Bondi's nets last year. Australia's lifeguards also offer protection, scanning the horizon for sharks and sounding sirens if a suspicious fin is sighted. "If a shark alarm is sounded this weekend somewhere, people will take more heed of it than they habitually do," predicts lifesaver Stephen Leahy.

Taylor and his mates remember the last fatal attack on a Sydney beach, in 1963. Statistically, the swimmers braving the seas around Australia are safe enough. "There are more than 60m beach visitations in Australia every year and yet there are only three or four shark attacks. Not bad odds," reckons Leahy.

Taronga Zoo's shark statistician, John West, agrees. Before the latest three attacks, there had been just nine Australian fatalities in 10 years. But despite the drastic decline in the numbers of great whites over the past 20 years, people are still getting killed.

West says demographics point towards an increase in fatalities: more and more of the country's steadily growing population is building and buying property by the beach. He believes there are more shark attacks simply because, with the popularity of water pursuits and all their paraphernalia - particularly wetsuits - people are going into the water more often and staying in for longer.

One theory gaining growing currency is that surfers suffer from mistaken identity. "Sharks, particularly whites and tigers, are opportunistic and inquisitive," explains West. "When a shark is swimming along and there is someone dressed up representing a seal - in a black wetsuit and fins - they test it to see if it's edible. When you've got two-and-a-half tonnes of animal with huge razor-sharp teeth testing a very soft human, the consequences are fatal."

Others say sharks are being driven closer to the country's increasingly populated beaches by warmer waters brought about by climate change. Australians are being urged to use common sense when they enter the sea. For Bondi surfer Luca Ciano, taking precautions involves "just staying close to a bunch of people and hoping you're not the one taken".

But surfers are being told to learn about marine life. It is probably safe when seals are "being goofy and fooling around near the surface" nearby, says Mike Wescombe-Down, an experienced Australian surfer and diver. "But when they start moving at reasonably high speed in a direction, that's a good sign something is nearby. Dolphins tend to bunch up in a group when there is a threat as well."

Wescombe-Down is developing a pocket-sized version of the electronic shark deterrent used to protect triathletes from shark attacks in Sydney harbour during the Olympics. He hopes to have the Walkman-sized pack, which emits sonar pulses to ward off sharks, on the Australian market in eight months' time. "The pressure is on us to get this thing out quickly - 90% of our phone calls come from worried parents," he says.

To soothe the shaken-up residents of North Cottesloe beach, Western Australia's fisheries minister ordered the extermination of the shark that killed Ken Crew. "The damn thing could be halfway to Mauritius by now, but we have to do something," says fisheries officer Sandy Van Houwelingen. The chase, with bait, helicopters and police marksmen, has not been abandoned yet.

Despite the shock, public opinion has swung behind the killer shark. Telephones at the fisheries' headquarters were jammed by callers, of whom 75% were against killing it. A special licence is needed to kill the great white - the first shark to be protected and listed on Australia's threatened species register in 1997.

A government scientist, Barry Bruce, says the idea that the 16ft killer could be a rogue shark with a hunger for human flesh is a Hollywood myth. West agrees. "With all due respect to the victim, when you go into the realm and the habitat of the shark you can't really blame the animal for acting naturally."

"There's a bit of a frenzy at the moment," says Wescombe-Down. "People are under the impression that there's a concerted plot by the sharks to make their presence felt, but it's just incredible coincidence," he says. "I think they're just opportunists. Their whole existence is based around eating and occasionally reproducing. They've got no other hobbies."

Australians won't give up their aquatic pursuits that easily. Although he finds sharks "pretty scary", Ciano bears the ancient species no grudges. "The shark is a beautiful animal; he's a killer machine, the best one ever. He has been here for ever and there is no way we could get rid of him."

webTitle: The home page that Mac built

fields.headline: The home page that Mac built
fields.standfirst:
It has taken Neil McIntosh five years to complete his personal website. And he is the first to admit that he has learnt from his mistakes, which he shares here, in all their glory
Net news
fields.trailText: It has taken Neil McIntosh five years to complete his personal website. And he is the first to admit that he has learnt from his mistakes, which he shares here, in all their glory
fields.body:
My home page took five years to publish. That's not an idle boast, and don't think for a second that if you pop over to it you'll find anything that justifies such a long gestation. It's not even really working properly yet.

Worse, it is said that every year on the web is worth seven in the "real" world, which makes the wait around 35 web years. And that does one's already tatty web-savvy, working-at-the-speed-of-the-net credentials no good at all.

What's the problem been? Apart from a near fatal dose of procrastination, and laziness, there have been the shifting sands of web page fashion.

Back in 1995, when I first started out on this foolhardy project, the web was already established and growing at a frightening pace. New tricks, bells and whistles seemed to appear almost daily.

During long winter evenings, my little website, isolated on my Mac's hard drive, grew, mutated and shrank in the face of these fashions. It sprouted - and shed - bright coloured backgrounds, giant graphics, animated gifs flashing and winking all over the place, frames dividing and sub dividing the screen, fancy Javascript routines that ... well, they just crashed your computer.

But every time I would sit back and say: that looks bloody awful. Everything I created looked as bad as the first examples of desktop-published parish magazines that appeared 15 years ago, which blended an orgy of bad clip-art with an ugly rash of typefaces.

If only someone had uttered the magic words - "keep it simple, stupid" a bit earlier.

There are lots of disciples to the "keep it simple" gospel, but the one true prophet is Jakob Nielsen, the web design guru who charges astronomical fees to companies wanting to hear his straightforward message. You can find his words of wisdom at www.useit.org, and it was these pages (remarkably un-designed, funnily enough) that were my road to a virtual Damascus.

Out went nearly all of the fancy stuff. Instead of futile attempts to look clever by using all the tricks of this dubious trade, I decided to go for simplicity. And that extended to much more than the design.

The right package
I'd been intending, for instance, to learn HTML to a standard which would allow me to build the way-cool website I had in my mind's eye. I bought the books, I printed out the websites. I swallowed all the techy propaganda which states that the only way you will ever build a proper website is to learn the programming languages which run it.

This simply ain't so. It might once have been useful to know HTML, a bit in the same way that it was probably once useful for car drivers to understand how their cars worked.

And, to be fair, it's still worth looking into the HTML of pages just to see how they are structured, a bit like it's a good idea to know where the bonnet release lever is on your Ford.

But, in the same way most of us would pop down to our local garage to buy a car ready built, rather than order the parts ourselves, knowing the language inside out simply doesn't make sense, unless you plan to make this your career.

Instead, I bought a web design package. There are lots of these about for Macs and PCs - two years ago I opted for what was, then, called Golive Cyberstudio Personal Edition, which cost £100.

Nowadays, it's called Adobe Golive 5.0 and has doubled in price. But cheaper alternatives - such as Microsoft's Frontpage 2000 (£130) - exist, and do the job well.

The job of these packages is to make building web pages almost as easy as putting together magazine pages in a desktop publishing program. They allow you to drag and drop elements for the page - images, text and the rest - anywhere you want, with all the difficult coding bit being done by the program in the background. The software will even help you organise your site, and put all the resources you need in the right places.

Having taken delivery of your page make-up program, it's a good idea to take a little time to mess around with it, putting together sample pages and testing what they look like in various browsers by loading them up from your hard drive (just go to the file menu in Explorer or Navigator and choose "open file" to look at files on your hard drive).

Browser compatibility remains a sticky part of web weaving, no matter how you design your page - different browsers handle pages in different ways. That's not helped by using a design package, rather than typing in raw HTML, as machine-generated code is often not as efficient as the best human programmer's.

But with a little experimentation, you should find that you can get your pages looking acceptable in the major browsers. Microsoft's Internet Explorer is the dominant browser, according to web research from Websidestory, with 86% of the market, followed by Netscape's Navigator with 13.9%, so these are the ones which really matter.

It is surprisingly easy to lock users out of your site. Already, some parts of my pages simply do not work on older browsers, and I've hit the need for a compromise between functionality and compatibility, which has floored many a dot.com.

As a rule of thumb, the more complex a site, the less compatible it is likely to be. If you want to include lots of tricks and compatibility is important to you, consider producing a plain vanilla, text-only version as well.

First: Stop!
Having experimented a little, the best thing you can do next is move away from your computer and sit down and plan your site. You'll need to decide on a few things before you get going, or life will be much more difficult later on.

First, what are you going to put on your site? It's easy to be far too ambitious at first, so try and err on the side of caution - it's demoralising if you make plans you subsequently can't follow. Obviously, you'll start with the home page itself, but it makes sense to divide the rest of your content up so that the first page is not too big (you should be able to hold your breath, without blacking out, for the time it takes for a page to download using a standard 56k modem). Create submenus for, say, family snaps, a page of links, an online diary or your personal details. You could then use your front page simply to say what's new on your site, or point to the most important bits.

Second, bear in mind that you don't want your site to go too deep. This means users should not have to click on more than two or three links to see anything on your site: users tire of sites which force them to burrow too deep.

Third, decide what your site's name is going to be. With domain names now so cheap, it's easy to buy your own domain name, which will make your site easier for people to find, and give you a cooler email address too.

I bought my domain name from Get Dotted for around £30, and the company also threw in unlimited web space and forwarding through the Freeola ISP.

Freeola's web servers might not be the fastest, but otherwise the service is excellent (with useful step-by-step instructions for uploading pages), and there are plenty of other low-cost domain name registrars who offer great value, low cost deals, too.

Costs and value for money can vary wildly: I bought an address as a present from NetNames, a London registrar, and it cost more than £100. Yet, despite the premium price, NetNames took days, several phone calls, and a flurry of angry emails to get the address "pointing" at the right website. Even they beat Demon Internet, who didn't return my calls .

Your site will look much more slick and download faster if the pages use the same basic graphics and layout, and the process of creating the site will be made much faster by having ready made pages to use. A typical template page will have your site's logo or name, and links to the main sub-menus at the top (and bottom, perhaps), so that users always know where to go to navigate around.

Once you've made your template, insert a picture and some random text, and try uploading it (your ISP or webspace provider should give instructions on what you need to do. Your web building software's manual will tell you how to do it). By putting it on the web, you can get some practice in the sometimes fiddly process of uploading, and you also get to test the design on other machines.

After all this planning comes the most important bit: producing the pages. And here, alas, there's no hi-tech substitute for a large pot of coffee, a free weekend and a bit of hard work.

Try to keep to your plans, and avoid being distracted by the temptation to insert any fancy gimmicks. If, like me, you've looked around the web for tips on designing web pages, you will have found lots of bits of code you can paste in to do fancy tricks: avoid them. One disadvantage of not knowing HTML is that pasting these into the computer-generated code that your web editing software has written can be very tricky. It can be very demoralising to upload everything for the first time to find that a hit counter inserted on every page, for instance, has messed up the whole thing. You can always experiment later when you want to update the site.

Which brings us back to the last important point: updating. The web changes all the time, yet so many sites - personal and corporate - are created then forgotten.

Nobody expects a home page to update every hour, or even every day. But it doesn't matter if your audience is the world, or just your mates: if it's clear you haven't done anything in months, everyone will stop bothering to look.

And after all your planning and effort, that would be a shame, wouldn't it?
