Does all this look like like a little too much effort? Many websites now help you build your pages online, making the process even simpler. The best known include Angelfire and Homestead at, but even the likes of Handbag, the UK women's portal, is getting in on the act at www.handbag.com.

You put together the pages through your web browser, using a series of templates and forms and uploading pictures from your hard disk. Most of the services have additional features which you can add to your pages, from animated graphics, through scripts and games - even digital video.

There are downsides. Some people would argue that if you use these services to their fullest extent, it could be simpler to buy a web design program. Others would argue that these services encourage you to build over-complex, gimmick-laden pages, while restricting those people who have a specific idea of how their pages should turn out. And, of course, it could be easy to run up a big phone bill as you build the site online, unless you have one of the new "always on" broadband connections.

But these sites and their ever-popular gimmicks are growing in popularity, and the services are becoming more and more sophisticated and flexible.

The only downside is that banner adverts may pop up as people browse your site - that's how they make their money. But, for millions, that's a price worth paying.

1 Consider buying a web design package

2 Plan your site carefully

3 Don't be too ambitious

4 Always think of the user

5 Avoid graphical gimmicks

6 Build a template

7 Keep your site's design as consistent as you can

8 Shop around for domain names and web space

9 Make sure pages don't take too long to download

10 Set a deadline for finishing your site...

 Neil McIntosh's site is at www.neilmc.net

webTitle: G2: Jaws' writer defends killer shark

fields.headline: Without malice: In defence of the shark
fields.standfirst: Peter Benchley, writer of Jaws and the man who's done most to give sharks a bad name, says the creature should not be killed
fields.trailText: Peter Benchley, writer of Jaws and the man who's done most to give sharks a bad name, says the creature should not be killed.
fields.body:
Please, in the name of nature, do not mount a mindless assault on an endangered animal for making an innocent - however tragic - mistake.

I've just this minute learned about Monday's ghastly, fatal attack by a great white shark. While I cannot pretend to comprehend the grief felt by Ken Crew's friends and family, and would not conceive of diminishing the horror of the attack, I plead with the people of Australia - who live with, understand and, in general, respect sharks more than any other nation on earth - to refrain from slaughtering this magnificent ocean predator in the hope of achieving some catharsis, some fleeting satisfaction, from wreaking vengeance on one of nature's most exquisite creations.

Though I was not there, though I did not witness the hideous moment, I can say absolutely that the shark was not acting with malice toward the man; not with intent to do bodily harm. It was doing what sharks do: assaulting perceived prey.

Australia has had a run of extremely bad luck recently: three human beings have been killed by great white sharks. But it is important for us to realise that these are freak occurrences that by no means signal a sudden onslaught by sharks on swimmers and surfers.

The oft-quoted statistics remain true: shark attacks are very, very rare, and fatal attacks even rarer. A human being is still more likely to die of a bee sting, snake bite or, Lord knows, automobile accident than by shark attack.

We do not execute the perpretrators of death by car. We should not butcher an animal for an inadvertent homicide.

It's also important that we understand that the shark is not invading our territory, threatening our homes or livelihoods; we humans are the trespassers. And if we choose to swim in the sea, to enter the realm of these wonderful animals - animals that have survived, virtually unchanged, for millions of years, animals that serve a critical function in the oceanic food chain - we are taking a chance.

If we choose to walk into a forest where a tiger lives, we are taking a chance. If we swim in a river where crocodiles live, we are taking a chance. If we visit the desert or climb a mountain or enter a swamp where snakes have managed to survive, we are taking a chance.

No person of sound mind would annihilate all tigers or snakes or crocodiles; we should resist the temptation to mark sharks for destruction.

This was not a rogue shark, tantalised by the taste of human flesh and bound now to kill and kill again. Such creatures do not exist, despite what you might have derived from Jaws.

When I wrote the book and film a quarter of a century ago, knowledge of sharks was in its infancy. We believed that sharks actually attacked boats; we believed that they actively sought out human prey. We believed that their numbers were infinite and the threat they posed incalculable.

Over the years, we have come to know otherwise. Over those same years, unfortunately, the demand worldwide for shark products has soared, and improved technology has given man the tools to slaughter sharks wholesale to meet that demand.

Around the world every year, approximately a dozen people are killed by sharks, while 100m sharks are killed by man. We are already perilously close to killing off the top of the oceanic food chain - with catastrophic consequences that we can't begin to imagine. Let us not, in the heat of anger, reduce the already devastated population of great white sharks by one more member.

Let us mourn the man and forgive the animal, for, in truth, it knew not what it did.

 Great White, Deep Trouble, a documentary about Peter Benchley and his work, will be broadcast on the National Geographic Channel on December 9 at 9pm.

fields.headline: E-sales boost for indie music
fields.standfirst:
The small companies could soon become big players, reports Martin Clark
Net news
fields.trailText: The small companies could soon become big players, reports Martin Clark
fields.body:
In the wake of Napster's surprise tie-up with German media giant Bertelsmann, Britain's independent music labels are set to annouce their own plans to deliver their artists' work digitally.

The Association of Independent Music's digital music trial stole a huge march on the major record labels in July when it opened up a huge catalogue of music for online content providers.

Now the association, known as AIM, intends to use its greatest asset - its hundreds of member labels' collective bargaining power - to revolutionise music industry e-commerce even more.

AIM's commercial wing, Musicindie, has announced an e-commerce partnership with digital content infrastructure experts, DigMedia, in what they say is the biggest venture of its kind in the UK.

Every one of AIM's 450 member-labels will be offered a specialised state-of-the-art e-commerce web platform. This is technology so powerful that the labels could possibly afford it only if they worked together, and it is expected it will help pull together the scattered and disparate independent sector in other ways as well.

This is having your cake and eating it.

In many ways, these labels - representing 26% of the music market - are the creative lifeblood of the buoyant British music industry. To retain that creativity, they say, it is essential that they remain independent.

Now, through Musicindie, they can act with the power - and technology - of a multinational company.

While the labels will all retain their individual websites, they will all use the same DigMedia kit - the "back end" - which will process transactions through one central point.

"This model is unique. There isn't a similar one anywhere," said Dr Malcolm Thomson, DigMedia's Chief Operations Officer. "Labels maintain both their independence and their own websites - they basically run as normal - but benefit by having this centralised e-business engine that each would never have been able to afford as a small label."

DigMedia plans to empower the independent sector in three phases. Initially, participating labels will have stand-alone technology installed in their websites.

This will mean that they can start e-commerce almost immediately, using DigMedia's shopping carts and credit card payment gateways.

Then participating labels will have their sites linked through one central e- business application.

Finally this will be linked into AIM's database.

Gavin Robertson has been the managing director of Musicindie since it launched this spring. The firm's key objective is to find ways to raise the market share of all the independents, without interfering with their businesses.

"There are far too many people saying to labels 'hey, come and do this', when what they really mean is 'hey, give me all your business'. This [DigMedia deal] is the first part of the jigsaw," he says.

Indeed, he is currently raising funding for further secret projects that, it is claimed, are set to make the current announcement look like just the tip of the iceberg for the industry.

"We'll be dealing with how to communicate between the people who want the content and people who own the content. It's all about how to make that communication seamless .

"What gets me about the internet is this need to be evolutionary. It assumes what we've done before can evolve into where we're going.

"At some point you need to start at scratch again and say 'backwards compatibility just doesn't work anymore.'

"If someone had just invented music and all this technology was out there, how would you use it?

"What we're addressing is how it should all work in an ideal world, with the assumption that the new processes, the new 'value chains' that come out of this, will work properly."

DigMedia, based in Edinburgh and San Diego, has a history of providing services supporting the music and media industry. It has been building back-end infrastructures for the sale of digital content since it was founded in 1998 by former executives of Intel, Memory Corp and Datrontech.

Having launched an MP3 player, Soulmate and MusicStore, allowing up to 200 CDs worth of music to be stored, the deal with Musicindie represents a major coup.

"What gets me about the internet is this need to be evolutionary. It assumes what we've done before can evolve into where we're going. "At some point you need to start at scratch again and say 'backwards compatibility just doesn't work anymore.' "If someone had just invented music and all this technology was out there, how would you use it? "What we're addressing is how it should all work in an ideal world, with the assumption that the new processes, the new 'value chains' that come out of this, will work properly." DigMedia, based in Edinburgh and San Diego, has a history of providing services supporting the music and media industry. It has been building back-end infrastructures for the sale of digital content since it was founded in 1998 by former executives of Intel, Memory Corp and Datrontech. Having launched an MP3 player, Soulmate and MusicStore, allowing up to 200 CDs worth of music to be stored, the deal with Musicindie represents a major coup.

fields.headline: E-markets struggle to win trust
fields.standfirst:
Business between buyers and sellers on virtual exchanges could rise to £534bn. Justin Hunt looks at the contest to corner this prize

Net news
fields.trailText: Business between buyers and sellers on virtual exchanges could rise to £534bn. Justin Hunt looks at the contest to corner this prize
fields.body:
Jose Suarez used to run a Moscow-based trading company which exported leather hides around the world. Now, based in Barcelona, he has founded LeatherXchange.com which he hopes will become the leading B2B (business to business) marketplace for the global leather industry.

The exchange has about 500 member companies and lets buyers and sellers trade online in raw and semi-processed hides and skins. Claiming to be receiving about 60 requests for quotes a month, Suarez's exchange has been held back by the fact that customers cannot physically see the animal hides they are ordering.

So next January it will launch an inspection service. There will be four inspectors operating out of Barcelona and Kiev and three out of Moscow who, based on agreed online specifications, will travel across Europe to physically inspect orders of pig, sheep and cattle skins before they are shipped to the exchange's customers.

Suarez says: "The internet is a great communications channel but in itself a virtual marketplace is not going to work. You find someone online and all you have are some cold forms. You need to set up with people who are able to augment the information which exists on the cold forms."

The task of guaranteeing and delivering on virtual handshakes is one of the biggest headaches afflicting ambitious founders of B2B exchanges across Europe. It is a huge market. Recently Forrester Research announced that transactions on B2B exchanges in Europe are set to rise to £534bn by 2005.

Evangelists for this pioneering way of trading are talking about buyers being able to make better-informed purchasing decisions and they say suppliers will have a cheaper sales channel which will be invaluable in fragmented markets. While few people doubt the potential of the internet to transform B2B transactions, the reality is that the industry is struggling to successfully meet very high expectations.

"I think right now it's all hype," says Gartner Group's research director, Petra Gartzen. "In terms of actual transactions going through marketplaces in Europe, there is little going on. It's really minute."

The low level of activity can be explained by the fact that the industry is still very much in its infancy but Gartzen argues that a lot of new B2B exchanges are shooting themselves in the foot by being too buyer-biased and suppliers fear they are losing control of the pricing of their products and services. "The marketplaces need to be focusing on how they can help suppliers maintain their brand in an internet world. They do not have a proper understanding of how to put a value proposition to a supplier," she says, adding that too often exchanges rank suppliers simply on price and do not promote other factors such as quality of service.

Rouzbeh Pirouz, chief executive of Mondus.co.uk, which runs e-marketplaces for IT and office services across Europe and in the US, believes online exchanges do offer benefits to buyers and suppliers. "It's a very easy and targeted way to meetcustomers. Just having a shop front on the internet is not enough to pull in the customers."

Mondus, with 175,000 registered users, recently organised roadshows with the British Chamber of Commerce to promote online B2B transactions. Pirouz will not reveal the actual number of transactions carried out through Mondus but he says he is confident about the state of the market.

"I think a lot of transactions are occurring. Obviously the challenge that B2B marketplaces have is to track and account for as many transactions as possible. A lot of transactions do occur through the contacts that are made."

He adds that an independent third party assessment of Mondus recently found that about 12% of the relationships established through Mondus had resulted in transactions online and offline.

Many exchanges have online feedback mechanisms which are usually geared to buyers reporting on experiences they have had with particular suppliers. Pirouz points out that feedback does not generally focus solely on pricing. Ratings can cover anything from customer service through to delivery times, and buyers can use these online tools to build long term relationships with new suppliers.

All pan-European exchanges know their virtual marketplaces have to be trusted if they are to succeed and they are exploring ways to instil greater trust in potential buyers and suppliers. Intelligo.cz, a new Prague-based B2B e-marketplace for office products in central and eastern Europe is insisting that all customers of its new exchange sign contracts covering the quality of product information they offer. The exchange owners also want to use the contracts to reassure users that any data they submit online will be secure and not passed on to any competitors.

Chief executive Dalibor Wijas says that anyone in breach of their contract will be banned from the exchange. Using credit checks is another way of building trust in an e-marketplace. But so far this has not been possible for Intelligo.cz.

"It's not easy to get that information about small companies in the Czech republic and the small ones are the ones doing business in the marketplace."

The emerging B2B e-marketplaces are also having to deal with some of the thorniest problems plaguing dot.coms. For example credit card transactions are regarded with the same levels of apprehension in B2B exchanges. So much so that UK-based Ace-quote.com, an exchange for IT services, does not offer an online transaction facility for its customers who include corporates, public sector authorities and small businesses. Instead the site generates income from subscriptions and lets buyers and sellers identify each other online before meeting offline to sign deals. However co-founder Helga St Blaize wants to introduce online payments soon.

"I think it's only a question of time. There is not a great deal of confidence in the security aspects of the internet in business transactions where we are talking about a great deal of money. And we are certainly looking at ways of ensuring that both the buyers and sellers are in a secure environment to transact online."

She believes that as buyers begin to know each other it will get to a point where they want to automate the process and she hopes they will do that through the online marketplace.

Many buyers and suppliers who plan to use B2B exchanges face a dilemma. With so many setting up, it is difficult to know which they should integrate with. Mondus feels this will create pressure on exchanges to distinguish themselves and build market share quickly. Pirouz says: "People are not going to be able to integrate themselves with an infinite number of marketplaces which is why I think there will be considerable consolidation within the industry and that should make life simpler for suppliers."

Some suppliers may feel they have little choice but to integrate with exchanges run by their large corporate paymasters. For example a major supplier to the car industry will find it hard to ignore Covisint.com, a B2B exchange which is being developed by General Motors, Ford and DaimslerChrysler.

As the hype for B2B intensifies, plenty of new software vendors have moved into the market. Leaders in the space include Commerce One and Ariba but not a single software company is yet able to provide a complete solution for B2B exchanges covering everything from payments to fulfilment.

What is tending to happen is that large software companies are forging alliances with niche players to try to provide a full range of services. But integrating a series of different packages can be a nightmare for technical directors.

To try to assist B2B players select the right partners and to help tackle technical problems in the fledgling industry, a new B2B trading community has launched in the UK called NetmarketsEurope.com . Based in London, the organisation runs regular workshops where European B2B practitioners meet with leading software sellers and brainstorm issues and problems such as how to scale quickly and find the right people.

Chief executive Simon Torrance says the aim is to try to clear the fog which is engulfing sections of the emerging B2B industry. "We give them an opportunity to huddle together in little wagon circles and share best practice so they feel better about the long journey they are undertaking."

The frenzied B2B hype seems to suggest that these new marketplaces will develop easily and in a tidy way as they successfully follow a straight path to hugely impressive levels of profitability.

But it is clear that most B2B exchanges across Europe still have steep mountains to climb and not all are going to make it.

fields.headline: Crusoe needs a Man Friday
fields.standfirst: Sony's new laptop has too many toys and not enough business uses, writes  Jack Schofield
fields.trailText: Sony's new laptop has too many toys and not enough business uses, writes Jack Schofield
fields.body:
Sony's latest Vaio is the first notebook PC with a power-saving Transmeta processor to be sold in the UK, with the promise of a dramatic improvement in battery life. The PCG-C1VE also has several innovations not usually found in Windows PCs: a built-in Motion Eye camera, a Sony Jog Dial, and a slot for Sony Memory Sticks. However, I suspect most people would find it more attractive if only it were a bit more ordinary.

But the main attraction is Transmeta's Crusoe chip - presumably named after Robinson Crusoe. This wholly new design that uses "code morphing" to provide compatibility with Intel Pentium-style processors. In other words, it translates the x86 instructions intended for Intel chips into Transmeta instructions before running them. This allows a low-power Crusoe to replace an Intel chip, extending the computer's battery life. It also means no cooling fan is needed.

Other manufacturers are also using the chip, and both Sony and Compaq are Transmeta shareholders. However, after experimenting with ThinkPad 240 subnotebooks using Crusoe chips, IBM has decided not to go ahead at the moment. This shook the market just before Transmeta's public share offering on Monday, because IBM is making Crusoe chips on Transmeta's behalf.

Transmeta's approach has drawbacks, too, to judge by Sony's implementation. First, the C1VE sometimes seems very slow, particularly when starting new programs. Transmeta says the chip runs at 600MHz and, to save power, 300MHz, but it does not feel as fast as a 300MHz Intel Celeron.

Second, you lose 16 megabytes of memory, which the Crusoe uses to optimise and store its translations. This means performance improves while you use a program, but you have only 112MB of usable memory, not 128MB.

As for battery life, the previous version of this Sony Vaio, the PCG-C1, was a bit of a disaster: the battery lasted about 90 minutes, depending on use. The C1VE lasted about three hours, when used mainly for email and word processing. This is a long way from the eight hours that would make a big difference to mobile notebook PC users.

But if the C1VE fails to sell, it will not be fair to blame Transmeta. Most problems are due to Sony's design. Yes, the C1VE is really small (248 x 152 x 27mm), really light (1kg), and it looks terrific. It has a built-in microphone, stereo speakers, and an impressive 12GB hard drive. The main problems are the screen size, and the lack of either a floppy drive or CD-rom or Ethernet networking as standard.

The screen has a letterbox shape and you are more or less forced to use the standard resolution of 1024 by 480 pixels, so you have to do a lot of scrolling. Where the Sony screen is less than 10cm deep, the IBM ThinkPad 240 is 16cm while the Toshiba Portégé 3480 measures 17.5cm.

The small screen comes with small fonts that make texts hard to read - and you cannot choose large fonts because that option is greyed out in Windows. I would have liked to increase the screen contrast, but this option is also unavailable.

Then there is the problem of getting software on to the C1VE. Sony has pre-installed Smart Capture and PictureGear programs to use the built-in camera, which can capture still images or moving video. There's also DVgate for capturing digital video streams piped in through the high-speed i.Link (1394 standard) port, and Movie Shaker, for editing them. But the only word processor is Windows WordPad. To do anything else, you may have to download programs from the net using a dial-up connection.

It's bizarre. Mark Hanson, vice president and general manager of Sony's PC product line, told the AP news bureau that the machine "is tailored toward the travelling business professional". Sony must have a very odd idea of what business professionals do for a living. They certainly don't sit on planes editing videos, and if they did, they wouldn't use a machine with such a limited letterbox screen.

For business professionals, the Jog Dial is a waste of time, the i.Link port is an insult, and the Motion Eye camera is at best an amusing diversion. The machine would have much more business cred if all three were junked (dropping the camera would give room for a bigger screen) in favour of a built-in Ethernet port. All the video software could be replaced with Microsoft Office.

Of course, the truth is that the C1VE is a wonderful toy. It could be particularly attractive to teenagers, especially if they already have a Sony Memory Stick Walkman, and a Sony digital video camera with an i.Link port. There probably aren't enough of them around with £1,499 (inc VAT) to spare, but it is nearly Christmas and a good time to be nice to very rich relations, if you have any.

webTitle: The best scene: Bring It On

fields.headline: The best new boy scene
fields.standfirst: Bring It On
fields.trailText: Bring It On
fields.body:
Rancho Carne High School. New student Cliff Pantone (Jesse Bradford) has been obliged to sit beside head cheerleader Torrance Shipman (Kirsten Dunst) in his first class of the day. Towards the end of the lesson, he looks over, coughs, and introduces himself.

"Cliff."

She smiles back.

"Torrance."

He glances at her text book.

"Advanced Chem?"

"'Fraid so. Are you intimidated?"

"Yeah, a little."

She looks satisfied.

"Really?"

"No. Not really."

Torrance notices Cliff's T-shirt. Her eyes widen as she tries not to look impressed.

"So, is that your band or something?"

Cliff looks down at his chest.

"The Clash? Er, no. It's a British punk band. Circa 1977 to '83. Original line-up anyway."

Torrance grins.

"How vintage."

The bell rings. The pair begin to pack away their books. Cliff looks over hopefully.

"So, um... I'll see you around then?"

Torrance heads for the door.

"Looks like it."

See also: Heathers, American Beauty, The Karate Kid, Back To The Future.

Don't see also: Three O'Clock High.

Pointless trivia: Jesse Bradford began his acting career in a TV commercial for Q-Tip cotton buds.

fields.headline: Neighbourhood strategy raises hopes
fields.standfirst: The government's national strategy for neighbourhood renewal has raised hopes but it is unclear who will deliver it. Julian Dobson reports
fields.trailText: The government's national strategy for neighbourhood renewal has raised hopes but it is unclear who will deliver it. Julian Dobson reports
fields.body:
If the national strategy raises high hopes, it also raises huge logistical problems. Just how do you realise such ambitions?

The key mechanism, the government has decided, will be the local strategic partnership. But this throws up difficult issues for the voluntary and community sectors, reawakens old suspicions and risks renewing ancient turf wars.

The responses to the national consultation gave a few hints of things to come. While there was much co-operation, there were also clear tensions.

Dick Atkinson, chair of Birmingham's Balsall Heath Forum, claims: "The nature of professional exclusivity must change if the town hall is to do less, enable more and pass resources straight to the man in the street.

"Already the protests of the unions and professional associations can be heard, they say: 'People won't know what to do. Leave the funds in our safe hands.' So, it is not local people, but many professionals who lack the vision needed to move from a defensive position, fearing the future, to one where they can seize the opportunities and move ahead of the times."

A similar split between the 'community' and the 'experts' emerges in the response from community matters, an umbrella group for local associations and campaigners. "Community matters is concerned by what it sees as an over-emphasis on individual, and in some cases external leadership (for example some of the references to social entrepreneurs and community leader training)," it says. "It is our experience that communities resent such "impositions", and function most effectively with democratic structures and collective decision making."

Power
The urban forum, too, wants more power handed to local voluntary and community groups. It has called for a £200m programme over ten years to fund 100 community and resident groups in deprived neighbourhoods, as well as supporting a further 100 voluntary bodies that work with such residents.

At first glance, it seems that the statutory sector is all for such a handover of power. The local government association has produced a series of comprehensive briefings on the strategy, and has nothing but praise for ideas such as simplifying funding for voluntary organisations and involving resident groups in delivering public services.

However, the underlying conflict surfaces from time to time. The LGA loses no opportunity to remind the government of the key role of democratically elected councillors, and to stake out their ground as custodians of community leadership.

"There is a need to question the current capacity of the voluntary and community sectors as equal partners and as such, capacity building for the voluntary and community sectors itself is important," the association says. "However, care will need to be taken in building up the capacity of voluntary, minority ethnic and faith organisations as many of these organisations will not have been set up with the general purpose of reviving communities."

Recent guidance makes it clear that while local authorities will be expected to involve all relevant partners - voluntary, community, business and other public agencies - they will remain the driving force behind the new local strategic partnerships. These partnerships will supervise and co-ordinate local regeneration activities and will hold the purse strings for programmes such as the new deal for communities.

There is some sense in this. Councils already have a statutory duty to produce community plans, and the Local Government Act 2000 gives them a power to promote the economic, social and environmental well-being of their residents. But the fear is that the cash and the control will remain safely tucked away in the town hall.

"It is our experience that communities resent such "impositions", and function most effectively with democratic structures and collective decision making." Power The urban forum, too, wants more power handed to local voluntary and community groups. It has called for a £200m programme over ten years to fund 100 community and resident groups in deprived neighbourhoods, as well as supporting a further 100 voluntary bodies that work with such residents. At first glance, it seems that the statutory sector is all for such a handover of power. The local government association has produced a series of comprehensive briefings on the strategy, and has nothing but praise for ideas such as simplifying funding for voluntary organisations and involving resident groups in delivering public services. However, the underlying conflict surfaces from time to time. The LGA loses no opportunity to remind the government of the key role of democratically elected councillors, and to stake out their ground as custodians of community leadership. "There is a need to question the current capacity of the voluntary and community sectors as equal partners and as such, capacity building for the voluntary and community sectors itself is important," the association says. "However, care will need to be taken in building up the capacity of voluntary, minority ethnic and faith organisations as many of these organisations will not have been set up with the general purpose of reviving communities." Recent guidance makes it clear that while local authorities will be expected to involve all relevant partners - voluntary, community, business and other public agencies - they will remain the driving force behind the new local strategic partnerships. These partnerships will supervise and co-ordinate local regeneration activities and will hold the purse strings for programmes such as the new deal for communities. There is some sense in this. Councils already have a statutory duty to produce community plans, and the Local Government Act 2000 gives them a power to promote the economic, social and environmental well-being of their residents. But the fear is that the cash and the control will remain safely tucked away in the town hall.

webTitle: Giles calls tune for rusty England

fields.headline: Giles calls tune for rusty England
fields.standfirst: Governor's XI 173 for 5 against England in Peshawar
fields.trailText: Governor's XI 173 for 5 against England in Peshawar
fields.body:
It was an odd one this and no mistake. The day began with unseasonal rain, ending the drought in Afghanistan, and then saw the England team sent to the middle of this most unappealing concrete bowl to the confusing accompaniment of pipes playing 100 Pipers.

Maybe it shocked them, for in helpful conditions England's bowlers produced a lacklustre performance which let their opposition slip the leash. There have been worse days, but there have been rather better ones too.

By the close of a first day which began 90 minutes late and produced only 56 overs in all, the North West Frontier Province Governor's XI had recovered from 113 for five to reach 173 without further loss, thanks to a spirited sixth-wicket stand of 60, in better than even time, between Yasir Hameed and the all-rounder Mohammad Hussain.

All the bowlers looked ring-rusty and in need of a major lift if they are to trouble Pakistan in the first Test in Lahore starting next Wednesday.

The rain began around breakfast-time and even when it ceased the weather remained dank and overcast for much of the day. The pitch, too, had a green tinge to it, and although Nasser Hussain had said before the match that he would ensure the spinners got a good outing, whatever the circumstances, these were conditions set up for the seamers.

Having put the opposition in, England really should have made a better fist of it and ought to have been batting by the end of the day.

Each of the three fast bowlers - Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Craig White - took a wicket. Gough also removed Wajahatullah Wasti from the scene by breaking his left hand, the sometime Test batsman retiring hurt after batting through the abbreviated first session of eight overs without scoring a run.

But as much as Gough bustled, Caddick strode in purposefully and White produced some deceptive pace, especially later in the day when he showed more confidence in the hamstring he strained against the Patron's XI last week, it was scarcely the stuff to set the heart racing or the Pakistan batsmen into a dither.

Caddick all too readily lapsed into shortness and was pulled for his pains. Gough bowled his habitual full length and was prepared to trade punches, but did not look penetrative. And White indulged in a little war - physical and verbal - with the left-hander Mohammad Hussain, who rode his luck but also played some forthright shots in his unbeaten 34.

The bat was beaten from time to time and the opener Imran Farhat, who made 42 of the first 58 runs, was dropped by Graham Thorpe at third slip early on. But too many boundaries were conceded.

The spotlight was on the spinners, however, and, although neither looked anything but ordinary the thin line between success and failure was certainly evident.

Ian Salisbury, on whose wrist spin many hopes have been pinned for the coming series, was coming to the end of his first over when Yasir, attempting to cut, may have got an edge to Alec Stewart. Premature celebrations are not the sole property of presidential elections, however. The umpire turned down the appeal, Yasir survived and Salisbury went wicketless in his nine overs.

Ashley Giles, by contrast, clearly had the force with him. His second over, the first after lunch, brought him two wickets in three balls - one to silly point off bat and pad, and the second thanks to an outrageous second-ball slog from Akhtar Sarfraz that would have disgraced All Muggleton.

Giles is a sufficiently cheerful and realistic fellow - once, when he tried a significantly quicker delivery and saw it leathered through the covers, he didn't go turf-kicking but instead slapped the side of his head in a "you numbskull" fashion - to know that if it is your day you gratefully accept what is on offer. Two for 21 from seven overs perhaps flattered him.

webTitle: Shippy has acclaim at last for the innings of his life

fields.headline: Shippy has acclaim at last for the innings of his life
fields.standfirst: Frank Keating on the life of Jim Hutchinson, the world's oldest first-class cricketer, who died on Tuesday
fields.trailText: Frank Keating on the life of Jim Hutchinson, the world's oldest first-class cricketer, who died on Tuesday.
fields.body:
The world's oldest first-class cricketer died on Tuesday in Doncaster. Jim Hutchinson was just three weeks from posting 104 on the scoreboard. In the summer of 1998, when he reached 102 and 253 days, he had overtaken the previous longest-lived, the South African Rupert de Smidt who had died in 1986, all of 73 years after playing his last game for Western Province.

The oldest Test cricketer remains England's former pace bowler Alf Gover, who will be 93 in February. Not all that far behind Gover, of course, is the nonpareil Sir Don Bradman, who was 92 in August.

Hutchinson's uniquely long innings was serene and contented almost to the end. It was only last winter that his wife Anne, a mere slip of a gel in her late 80s, injured a hip in a fall at their home in East Thurnscoe, south Yorkshire, which meant Jim had to move to a Rotherham nursing home.

He was the personification of the old northern cricketing adage, "if thee wants a good player, just whistle down mineshaft for one". Hutchinson was a Tupton boy and began down the pit at 14. One Saturday in 1920, playing for the colliery XI at Bullcroft near Hull, the opposing wicketkeeper was a Derbyshire member. Three evenings later the 23-year-old was put in a net for a trial and by the Saturday he was making his championship debut against Sussex in Chesterfield.

In the next 11 summers he played 255 more matches (averaging 18 with five centuries) and the Derbyshire yearbook described him as "an effective mid-order bat and perhaps the most outstanding cover-point in the county's history".

When cricket had finished he became chief safety officer at Hickleton Main colliery. Only a year ago, still full of beans and getting about on his zimmer, the centenarian was putting down his longevity to a lifetime diet of "pork chops and onion rings".

His short-term memory, he said cheerfully, was a total blank. But not that of his straight-backed and manly prime: "Crikey yes, of course I faced Larwood. He was another miner like me. He was fast all right, deadly fast, but fair with it.

"Of the batters, Woolley was the one to watch, and to fear. If you wanted a ball hitting, Woolley was the one to hit it for you." Hutchinson played against Bradman in 1930: "he looked a small, shy farmer's boy at the crease but you could tell he had something special all right".

Yesterday, cricket's boffins were still poring over their small print before naming Hutchinson's successor as the world's most ancient. But they did announce England's new oldest living first-class player.

It is Frank Shipston, 94 last August 29, another ex-miner, who played 49 matches for Nottinghamshire (also averaging 18) for eight years till 1933. I was thrilled to hear dear "Shippy" was still alive.

At Douai, the now defunct Benedictine monastery school high in the Berkshire hills, Shippy was our coach, head groundsman and umpire through my time in the 1950s.

With some shining exceptions a majority of former county cricketers, having spent their salad days treading fresh grass under glorious midsummer suns, in my experience then turn into endearingly pessimistic grousers. That was Shippy.

In I'd come, at No6 or 7, Douai invariably needing 100-odd to win, and, first over, I might get lucky and cheerily clunk one into the adjoining tennis courts to, as they say, set out my stall. At which gaunt umpire Shippy would wince and pull a miserably anguished face before, at the end of the over, regarding me with suffering old-spaniel eyes and his confiding whispered mantra, "What's roosh, lad? Joost tek it easy, play down line and roons'll coom, you see, roons'll coom."

But they didn't very often for me, I'm afraid. I regularly let down the despairing Shipston and was usually out, aiming for mid-on's nut, well before the six o'clock Angelus chimed down from the school chapel tower.

And afterwards in the pav Shippy would shake his head at us sadly, then roll a fag, pour a beer and tell us Trent Bridge tales of Larwood and Gunn, the Hardstaffs and Walter Keeton in the sun-burnished days of his own local fame. And now, suddenly, at 94 not out, his own name is fondly famed over all England.

fields.headline: Supporter stable after stabbing
fields.standfirst: Yorkshireman recovering in hospital after violence between supporters on the streets of Milan
fields.trailText: Yorkshireman recovering in hospital after violence between supporters on the streets of Milan.
fields.body:
A Leeds United fan underwent emergency surgery in Italy last night for a pierced bladder after being stabbed 13 times, hours before the Champions League match against Milan.

Lee Dyson, aged 31, from Barnsley, was stabbed after violence in the centre of Milan between rival fans. His condition was described as stable and he was accompanied by members of his family who remained with him at Fatebenefratelli hospital in the city centre.

Two Leeds supporters, Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight, were killed this year in Istanbul before the club's Uefa Cup semi-final first leg against Galatasaray.

Peter Ridsdale, the Leeds chairman, said last night: 'Of course the stabbing is of grave concern to us. We understand that the victim is in a stable condition. We hope he makes a speedy recovery.

'My information about the man concerned it that he is a professional man and not the sort of individual who would get involved in trouble.'

Ian Shand, a consul at the British consulate in Milan, said Milan police had arrested seven Leeds United fans in several other incidents but that no arrests were made for the stabbing. A police spokesman in Milan, Piero Vincenti, said Dyson was stabbed in the face, hands and abdomen shortly after midnight on a downtown Milan street.

About 6,000 Leeds fans were in Milan for the game, the largest away following the club have taken to Europe since the 1975 European Cup final against Bayern Munich in Paris.

Hundreds of officers were on duty to prevent trouble and the heavy police presence ensured there were no further outbreaks of violence prior to the match, although there were further skirmishes and police made eight arrests for minor offences.

Officials in Milan imposed a ban on the sale of alcohol in the city and liaised closely with officers from the West Yorkshire police as part of the security operation.

Ray Fell, chairman of the Leeds United Supporters' Association, said he was 'rather shattered by the stabbing. 'After the deaths of two of our supporters earlier this year in Turkey I hoped it was something we would never have to go through again,' he added. 'At times like this you wonder if the game is worth it.'

Ridsdale meanwhile added before last night's game: 'So far we have tried to shield the team from the news; clearly when you travel you do not want to hear of incidents such as this.' The Leeds chairman admitted that the news of the incident brought back memories of April's tragic events in Istanbul.

'I'm feeling pretty drained by the situation, to be frank,' he continued. 'Incidents like today bring the difficult times flooding back again.'

fields.headline: Liverpool tune into Bohemian rhapsody
fields.trailText: Liverpool will find themselves cast in the curious role of welcome guests at a celebratory party in their honour this evening.
fields.body:
Liverpool will find themselves cast in the curious role of welcome guests at a celebratory party in their honour this evening as a small Czech Republic town hitherto renowned only for the strength and purity of its beer grinds to a halt to enjoy its Warholesque 15 minutes of fame.

The last time Liberec came to a standstill was when industrial action caused tools to be laid down at the local colliery. That is to say nothing much ever happens in northern Bohemia. But now the bunting is up, children have been issued with commemorative flags and the civic elders are giddy with excitement.

Rarely, if ever, has a Uefa Cup tie been so eagerly anticipated by supporters who, almost to a man, concede that elimination is the likely end product.

The irony is that, on paper at least, Slovan Liberec's goose has most definitely not yet been fully cooked. In the tedious first leg at Anfield, two teams of vastly contrasting merit were separated only by Emile Heskey's late goal.

With their small U Nisy stadium capacity (6,808) a problem, the logical thing for Liberec was to cash in by moving the game to a bigger venue. Commendably, logic never entered the equation.

"Yes, we could have switched this game to another town, one with bigger and better facilities," said the Slovan Liberec coach Ladislav Skorpil. "But it's not what we wanted.

"This will be the biggest night in this club's history and we want to play against the world-famous Liverpool in our own stadium, small and humble though it may be. I believe we made the correct decision, taken with our supporters in mind."

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier said Liberec in the first leg "did make it difficult for us by pulling everyone back behind the ball. They need to score this time, so they will have to be a good deal more adventurous. If they push forwards, they might leave a few gaps at the back which we can hopefully exploit."

That will almost certainly have to be done without Michael Owen. The striker will figure only in an emergency, having spent so long recovering from a head wound sustained last month that he has now lost overall fitness.

With Houllier aware that one goal will probably ensure Liberec's big night ends in glorious failure, he is likely to recall Robbie Fowler who, strangely, was used only as a substitute at Leeds on Saturday.

Celtic face a Bordeaux side with several injury problems before tonight's return at Parkhead. The French club have lost Marc Wilmots and Alexei Smertin, and the defender Alain Roche and forward Pascal Feindouno face late checks.

webTitle: Taylor may try out Brown and Hendrie in Turin

fields.headline: Taylor may try out Brown and Hendrie in Turin
fields.standfirst: England to reveal mixture of new and old faces today
fields.trailText: England to reveal mixture of new and old faces today.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor will attempt to strike a balance between innovation and continuity today when he announces his England squad for the friendly against Italy in Turin next Wednesday. He will be keen to see some fresh faces but will keep in mind the need to give the team stability amid the uncertainties which have followed Kevin Keegan's resignation.

Sven-Goran Eriksson has agreed to become Keegan's successor next July but the question of who will be in charge for the friendly against Spain (February) and the World Cup qualifiers with Finland and Albania (March) followed by Greece (June) remains unresolved. The Football Association hopes Lazio will release Eriksson part-time for the World Cup ties but this will depend on the Italian club's domestic and European fortunes.

Either way Taylor, the Leicester manager, and his fellow-caretaker, Manchester United's coach Steve McClaren, look like being asked to run the show both in Turin and when Spain visit Villa Park in February. For the moment, however, Taylor is treating the Italy game as a one-off in which he will seek to justify the FA's faith in him once it had failed to prise Bobby Robson from Newcastle - who by coincidence visit Leicester on Saturday.

The temptation for Taylor to experiment will be strong. As the England Under-21 coach for three years under Glenn Hoddle he is more familiar than most with the qualities of those now pressing for inclusion in the senior squad. Some, such as Gareth Barry and Steven Gerrard, are already getting their chance. Taylor may feel Frank Lampard and Lee Hendrie, capped then ignored, deserve another. United's Wes Brown would have had more than one cap but for injury, and West Ham's Joe Cole cannot be far off. fields.headline: Dunn and dusted for Rovers
fields.standfirst: Barnsley 1 - 2 Blackburn Rovers
fields.trailText: Barnsley 1 - 2 Blackburn Rovers
fields.body:
A magnificent strike by the midfielder David Dunn eight minutes from time gave a resurgent Blackburn Rovers their sixth win on the trot.

Dunn curled home a perfectly executed lob to give Graeme Souness's side the points. The goal, Dunn's eighth this season, was just reward for Blackburn's battling performance. They had fallen behind on 19 minutes when Stuart Ripley scored a gem of a goal on his debut.

Ripley, on loan from Southampton, might have stolen the show against lesser sides but not against Blackburn. Their grit saw them through with second-half goals from the substitute Matt Jansen and Dunn to leave Barnsley's manager Dave Bassett wondering where his next home win was going to come from. They have now lost four and drawn one of their last five home games.

Understandably, Ripley was anxious to impress on his Barnsley debut. And the former England winger could not have written the script better himself as his magnificent 19th-minute strike eased the pressure on Bassett's team.

The 32-year-old spotted the keeper John Filan a couple of yards off his line and promptly cut inside to curl an exquisite right-foot 20-yarder into the far corner. It was a goal of stunning quality and one which endeared Ripley to the home crowd immediately.

Rovers finally managed a deserved equaliser in the 72nd minute. The substitute Jansen, who had been on the pitch for only 10 minutes, prodded home from close range after Kevin Miller had been unable to deal with Stig Bjornebye's left-wing cross.

And Dunn's majestic winner eight minutes from time left Barnsley bewildered as his right-foot lob flew into Miller's top left-hand corner.

webTitle: Foreign affair to end in tears

fields.headline: Foreign affair to end in tears
fields.standfirst: FA's selection is rooted in a fascination with all things continental according to former England manager Graham Taylor
fields.trailText: FA's selection is rooted in a fascination with all things continental according to former England manager Graham Taylor.
fields.body:
Graham Taylor, an avid Buddy Holly fan, once responded to defeat as England's manager by declaring that it was raining in his heart. Two days ago, after watching his Watford team lose to Sheffield Wednesday and end their unbeaten record, he rewrote the words of the Boomtown Rats' hit record by saying he did not like Tuesdays.

Yesterday he was in Kinks mode, accusing the Football Association of being dedicated followers of fashion in appointing the Swede Sven-Goran Eriksson as England coach. But his words for his former employers were so harsh and, at times, so blue that only the Sex Pistols might have set them to music.

Taylor, who was receiving a record 29th Nationwide manager of the month award, said: "It doesn't matter what the nationality of the England manager is, it's the whole structure of the game that should be looked at. But in choosing a foreigner the FA are just following the fashion of the clubs.

"When we English managers tried to tell our teams about cutting down on booze and doing stretching exercises and warm-downs after games, the players said bollocks. But when a foreign coach says it, it is seen as innovative. It's the same at club level. We are doing the same things at Watford as Fulham but they get all the praise because they have a foreign manager."

Taylor suffered appalling abuse during his time as England manager, inspiring the headline "Swedes 2, Turnips 1" after losing to Sweden in the 1992 European championship. But he thinks Eriksson will face even greater humiliation if he is not successful - of which he gives him little chance in the 2002 World Cup.

"If we qualify, do we really think England are going to win in Japan and Korea with the humidity and all the other problems?" said Taylor. "The national team only get priority when we are in a big tournament. By then it is too late."

Taylor believes that he and other former England managers should have been consulted before the new man was chosen. Instead, he says, he got a message on his answerphone from Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director, on the day Peter Taylor was appointed caretaker manager. Wilkinson apparently said he wanted to discuss something but, according to Graham Taylor, never rang back.

fields.headline: United dig for victory
fields.standfirst: Manchester United 1 - 0 Dynamo Kiev
fields.trailText: Manchester United 1 - 0 Dynamo Kiev
fields.body:
After an excellent start Manchester United groped their way uncertainly to the second round of the Champions League here last night. Teddy Sheringham gave them an early lead but then Ryan Giggs limped off and United steadily lost momentum.

Dynamo Kiev dominated much of the second half but vapid finishing consistently let down the neatness and imagination of their movements. Nevertheless United would probably have gone out had not George Demetradze, having been set up by Laszio Bodnar's pass, shot wide from a range of six yards with five minutes remaining.

Controlled, disciplined aggression had to be the theme of United's football last night. They had suffered enough sucker punches in previous Champions League games at Old Trafford to be wary of a gung-ho approach.

Certainly Kiev, quick on the break and dangerous on the wings, had the means to punish any lapses by a defence weakened by injuries to the regular centre-backs, Ronny Johnsen and Jaap Stam.

At the same time Ferguson's side needed to set a brisk tempo. They could afford to be cheerful as well as careful and did not want to find themselves having to pick up the pace later in the match.

Kiev set out to stifle United's movements at their source. From the start David Beckham and Giggs found Vitalii Lysytskyy and Alixandr Khatskevitch dogging them step for step on the flanks; not that this prevented Giggs turning the Ukrainians' defence at the first opportunity.

Manchester United's initial attacking waves broke over Dynamo's defence like an angry tide meeting a solid sea wall. There was a lot of froth and noise but little sign of a breakthrough.

In the 17th minute, however, Kiev sprung a leak and, almost inevitably, Sheringham gave United the lead. The goal was a masterly example of how to improvise after a promising move had seemed about to break down.

Sheringham began it with an inspired pass out of his own half to release Andy Cole, who had Giggs sprinting up in support. The attack lost momentum as Cole dallied over a pass but after Giggs had backheeled the ball back to him he managed to square it to Roy Keane whose close-range shot was parried by Olexander Shovkovskyi, Sheringham scoring from the rebound.

Manchester United had the early lead they wanted but needed the cushion of another goal before half-time. As Ferguson had pointed out the day before, at 1-0 his team would be a kick away from going out.

Without the suspended Paul Scholes, Manchester United were still a threat from midfield. Just before the half-hour a smooth, calculated build-up saw Giggs send Denis Irwin through for a centre which Sheringham nodded down to Keane whose shot was on target but lacked power.

A few minutes later, to Manchester United's distress but Dynamo's relief, Giggs was forced off with a damaged hamstring. His replacement, Quinton Fortune, is an outstanding prospect but this was not the sort of fortune for which United were looking.

As half-time approached the slenderness of United's lead was brought home by the speed with which Kiev counter-attacked after Beckham had given the ball away. Valiantsin Bialkevich ran at retreating defence before finding Khatskevitch to his right. Khatskevitch laid a pass into the path of Kakha Kaladze and while his shot was wild and high the moment reminded United that they still had much to do.

In fact had Kiev's finishing matched the pace and imagination of their football Old Trafford might have been in crisis. Kaladze and Bialkevich were outmanouevring Phil Neville on the left and after Keane had sold himself the pair briskly exchanged passes before Kaladze's attempt at a shot was blocked. Drawing confidence from this Kiev began to dominate United in the second half.

Clearly Beckham felt victory could be secured by his marksmanship. One shot, driven from 35 yards, was tipped over the bar by Shovkovskyi, another curled in from the corner of the penalty area, sailed just beyond the far post.

Anderlecht beat PSV 3-2 in Eindhoven last night to clinch top spot in Group G. PSV drop down to the Uefa Cup.

Manchester United (4-4-2):Barthez; P Neville, Brown, G Neville, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs; Cole, Sheringham.

Dynamo Kiev (4-4-2): Shovkovsky; Vaschuk; Bodnar, Holovko, Nesmachnyi; Gerasimenko, Khatskevitch, Lysytskyy, Kaladze; Bialkevich, Shatskikh.

Referee: C Colombo (France).

fields.headline: Sheringham short-circuits Dynamo
fields.standfirst: David Lacey saw one old-timer make an irresistible case for inclusion in Peter Taylor's squad regardless of age
fields.trailText: David Lacey saw one old-timer make an irresistible case for inclusion in Peter Taylor's squad regardless of age.
fields.body:
A quarter of an hour before the kick-off at Old Trafford last night, we might have been waiting for a reserve game to start. When the announcer read out the team, borrowing that Bayern Munich trick of saying the Christian names and leaving the crowd to shout out the surnames, the response from the sparsely populated grandstands conveyed all the vibrancy of a whist drive.

There was no hint that Manchester United were facing 90 minutes which would determine the shape of their season. Such is the strange condition of football today, when fans no longer take pleasure in congregating in the hour before the game to savour their presence at the occasion and practise the chants with which to encourage their team.

Just over half an hour later, however, with every seat filled, we certainly knew we were at a match of some significance. When a Dynamo Kiev attack broke down on the edge of the United area, Teddy Sheringham's long crossfield pass unleashed a counterattack of the kind that made Manchester United's reputatation. As Andy Cole and Ryan Giggs tried to play each other in for a shot, suddenly they were supported by a flock of red shirts, including that of Sheringham, who had covered around 70 yards by the time he met the rebound from Roy Keane's shot and despatched it into the net. And then, at last, the crowd woke up to their responsibilities. Sometimes they need the broadest of hints.

Sheringham, they say, is playing the best football of his life, revelling in his return to the status of first-choice shadow striker rather than supersub. This was his seventh European Cup goal, in 27 appearances in the competition, and by no means the least significant. At the age of 34, to the dividends of maturity and perception, he adds an apparently boundless enthusiasm for the game and an iron determination to make the best of whatever time is left to him at the highest level.

His opening strike last night would make his inclusion tomorrow in Peter Taylor's squad for England's friendly against Italy next week even less of a surprise. The staunchest advocate of a wholehearted commitment to youth within the national team would find it difficult to deny him a further opportunity to demonstrate the continuing relevance of his craftsmanship.

Giggs had set the pace for United in the early stages, skinning Laszlo Bodnar and Alexey Gerasimenko down the left with familiar panache before firing his cross too close to Olexander Shovkovskyi, then intercepting Andrii Nesmachnyi's ambitious crossfield pass but failing to make use of the time and space he had created for himself. His fine tackle to curtail a dangerous break by Nesmachnyi demonstrated his commitment, and his withdrawal after 34 minutes, seemingly as a precaution against a twinge in the thigh, must have been a relief to the right flank of the Kiev defence.

As half-time approached, Kiev's forwards began to show that the kind of composed approach work associated with Valerii Lobanovskyi's teams did not altogether disappear with the departures of Andriy Shevchenko to Milan and Sergei Rebrov to Tottenham. Valiantsin Bialkevich and Maksim Shatskikh appeared several times in space down the left without managing to create a clear opening. Generally speaking United's patchwork defence was holding together, with Wes Brown's cool reading of Shatskikh's extravagant Cruyff turn another promising signal to England's caretaker management.

The 19-year-old Vitalyii Lysytskyy, Lobanovskyi's latest prodigy, displayed his inexperience by committing a series of minor fouls around the fringe of the Kiev area, offering Beckham the opportunity to work on his free-kick technique.

But United's best chance to put their further participation in the tournament beyond any doubt came when Fortune robbed Bodnar with a quarter of an hour to play, throwing the whole Kiev defence momentarily off balance, but Shovkovskyi was able to drop on to Roy Keane's over-deliberate sidefooted shot.

In reply Kiev stepped up the intensity of their attacks, lacking only the sort of punch in front of goal that Shevchenko and Rebrov used to supply. When George Demetradze, one of Kiev's substitutes, was presented with the chance of the night, alone in front of Fabien Barthez and in a perfect position to meet Bodnar's cross with five minutes to go, he could hardly have missed more efficiently if someone had paid him.

fields.headline: Jefferies departs broken Hearts
fields.trailText: Hearts yesterday announced that their manager Jim Jefferies and his assistant Billy Brown had left the club by mutual consent.
fields.body:
Hearts yesterday announced that their manager Jim Jefferies and his assistant Billy Brown had left the club by mutual consent.

Jefferies led Hearts to the Scottish Cup in 1998 and third place in the Premier League last season. But he has been forced to dismantle his team after the club ran into financial difficulties; David Weir, Neil McCann, Paul Ritchie and Gary Naysmith have all left the club as the chief executive Chris Robinson tried to cut the wage bill.

Though they are fifth in the table they are 19 points adrift of Celtic and recently lost 6-2 to their Edinburgh rivals Hibernian. Fans demonstrated against Robinson after their 3-0 home defeat by St Johnstone two weeks ago but had refrained from criticising their manager. The Under-21 coach Peter Houston will take temporary charge of the first team.

Another Scottish manager, Bradford's caretaker Stuart McCall, has ruled himself out of the running to succeed Chris Hutchings full time.

The former Scotland midfielder announced his decision after a meeting yesterday with Geoffrey Richmond, the Bradford chairman; he said he wanted to continue playing as long as possible. He will remain as caretaker, assisted by the former Wales goalkeeper Neville Southall, until a permanent appointment is made.

"While I feel I am having a positive influence on the park, I believe this is the best way I can assist Bradford," McCall said.

"I do not believe I can do the manager's position justice while I am still playing at Premiership level. The time will come when I hang up my boots, and my ambition in the future is to become a manager should the opportunity arise."

Southampton's Ivory Coast-born striker Patrice Tano has left the club and returned to France after having his contract cancelled only four months after arriving at the Dell.

He was signed by Glenn Hoddle from the manager's former club Monaco on a free transfer in July but has since made only two starts for the reserves and has now been released amid passport difficulties.

Southampton refused to allow Tano to sign a contract at the Dell until he produced a valid French passport and he has been sent home after failing to obtain one.

The Wimbledon midfielder Robbie Earle has decided to end his playing career on the advice of a specialist after failing to recover from a stomach injury. He will remain at the club as reserve-team manager.

fields.headline: Public hospitals rely on private funding lifeline
fields.standfirst: Health service capital investment is increasingly dependent on private finance
fields.trailText: Health service capital investment is increasingly dependent on private sector finance.
fields.body:
The biggest ever NHS hospital-building programme is under way, according to the government. Building is to start on 18 hospitals worth £2.3bn over the next two years, adding to the 38 major schemes already given the green light.

But, unlike traditional NHS hospital-building schemes, most of the capital cost will come from commercial money through the private finance initiative (PFI) rather than from public funds. Under the PFI, private-sector companies build and finance hospitals and run non-clinical services, such as portering and catering, in return for regular "rental" payments from NHS "tenants".

The PFI has undoubtedly transformed the NHS stock of capital assets in a way that public capital has not done in the past. The government claims it offers better value for money by harnessing private-sector innovation and transferring risks, such as cost overruns, that have blighted publicly funded schemes. But critics claim it represents creeping privatisation of the NHS, leads to a reduction in bed numbers, and is more expensive than public funding.

This year NHS public capital resources in England amount to £2.6bn. (A capital asset is any physical entity that will be used for more than a year and costs £5,000 or more. Funding for all these assets, big or small, is separate from revenue funding for doctors, nurses, drugs, bandages or other consumables.)

Some £1.1bn in capital funding is distributed to the eight English NHS regional offices. Just over half of this is handed out to NHS trusts for their general capital expenditure needs, including maintenance and new equipment. Trusts can bid for a slice of the rest of the regional capital pot for projects they can't afford out of their block allocation.

Other capital expenditure is more targeted. This year £168m has been earmarked for projects that support central priorities such as reducing waiting lists and times, improving renal (kidney) services and updating equipment used to diagnose cancer.

The Treasury's capital modernisation fund, set up to support innovative capital investment projects, will provide a further £122m this year. This is being targeted at the modernisation of accident and emergency units and the opening of new "walk-in" health centres.

But demands on these public resources are high. It would take £3.1bn just to clear the service's backlog of building and equipment maintenance. Funding is spread thinly, making major non-PFI projects few and far between. Just four major hospital schemes have been approved since 1997 for direct funding through the public purse.

fields.headline: Marian Keyes's top 10 relationship books
fields.trailText: Marian Keyes's latest book is the bestselling Sushi for Beginners. It tells the story of a group of thirtysomethings who work in the media and are trying to deal with the problems of love, friendship and happiness
fields.body:
Marian Keyes's latest book is the bestselling Sushi for Beginners. It tells the story of a group of thirtysomethings who work in the media and are trying to deal with the problems of love, friendship and happiness.
Buy Sushi for Beginners at Amazon.co.uk

1. Right Ho, Jeeves by PG Wodehouse
Co-dependence at its most charming.

2. Cold Comfort Farm by Stella Gibbons
First published in 1932, this is about city slicker Flora Poste who goes to stay with her country bumpkin cousins in Sussex and effects changes in all their lives. Screamingly funny and wildly subversive.

3. Normal Girl by Marly Jong-Fast
Young, upper east side Jewish woman's interactions with her neurotic mother - a rich enough seam in itself. Throw an increasing dependence on narcotics into the mix and you have an edgy, fascinating, all-too-believable account of alienation.

4. Secret Dream World of a Shopaholic by Sophie Kinsella
Lighthearted tale, with a great truth at its heart, in these shopping-as-leisure, spending-as-therapy times.

5. Gone With The Wind by Margaret Mitchell
Meaty, sagaesque love story between feisty minx Scarlett O'Hara and urbane cad Rhett Butler. Survives repeated rereading.

6. Enduring Love by Ian McEwan
A random event kick-starts the unravelling of a once near-perfect relationship. Excruciatingly painful to read, yet car-crash compulsive.

7. Drinking: a Love Story by Caroline Knapp
Autobiographical account of a love affair with alcohol. Honest and terrifying, the unavoidable conclusion is that addicts only want relationships with their drug of choice.

8. The Travelling Horn Player by Barbara Trapido
The book opens with a girl being visited by the ghost of her dead sister: the rest of the book is an extended flashback, examining the series of criss-crossing relationships and encounters which led to the death. One of the most moving things I've ever read.

9. Fabulous Nobodies by Lee Tulloch
New York wannabe fashionista's love affair with great frocks. She even gives them names and personalities. Lighten up - it's enchanting. Currently shamefully out-of-print.

10. The Third Policeman by Flann O'Brien
Obviously, on the surface, this is an examination of the relationship between man and bicycle - just how much exchange of molecules actually does take place?! However, there is only one true conclusion to be drawn from this book: hell really is other people.

fields.headline: Because It's There
fields.standfirst: Playhouse, Nottingham ***
fields.trailText: Playhouse, Nottingham ***
fields.body:
Even if Ibsen's heroes often end up on mist-wreathed Norwegian peaks, drama and mountaineering are not natural bedfellows. But Jonathan Holloway's bold play scrapes away the myths surrounding Mallory and Irvine's ill-fated attempt on the summit of Everest in 1924; and, although it sometimes adopts the style of revisionist radio biography, it doesn't shirk the problem of putting mountainous ascent on stage.

The focus is on Mallory, who emerges as a mixture of daredevil, aesthete and athlete. At Cambridge he falls in with the Bloomsbury group and is painted in the buff by Duncan Grant, slavered over by Lytton Strachey and directed in Faustus by Rupert Brooke. But his real mentor is Geoffrey Young, who teaches him the joys of not only climbing but of combining it with philosophical debate and clubby fellowship. One point Holloway makes strongly, through an angry Australian abseiling down the face of the dress circle, is that British mountaineering was once deeply class-ridden.

In a sense, that was Mallory's undoing. There was something about him of the reckless, inspired amateur; and for the final assault on Everest he chooses as his companion a 22-year-old Oxford rowing blue with minimal climbing experience. Holloway's thesis, reinforced by the discovery last year of Mallory's mummified corpse, is that the pair did reach the summit. What caused their death was a mixture of darkness, Irvine's inexperience and a recurrence of Mallory's neglected leg wound. Having lived his life according to romantic ideals, the "Galahad of Everest" perished by them.

Holloway's drama has some odd gaps. A literal cliffhanger at the end of the first half is quickly forgotten. The format of a demythologising lecture by the expedition's photographer is soon discarded. But, even if the play is as much social history and character study as drama, it captures the lost Corinthian world that Mallory and his kind inhabited. They attack Everest in tweeds, forget to take signal flares to the summit and refer to the local porters as "coolies".

But the play gets ruthlessly professional direction and design from Giles Croft and Jamie Vartan, whose set shifts from a metallic climbing frame, which the actors perilously negotiate, to a sloping-roofed Everest camp that turns into the snow-capped summit. Hywel Morgan's Mallory is the right mix of Phoebus Apollo and risk-taker, Simon Coury is doubly effective as both his pipe-smoking mentor and Lytton Strachey, and Sebastian Dunn is the doomed Irvine. Holloway may not scale Ibsenite peaks but he evokes an era when mountain-climbing was seen as a form of romantic Arthurian quest.

Until November 25. Box office: 0115-941 9419.

fields.headline: Mao and the magic realist
fields.standfirst:
Anselm Kiefer
Anthony d'Offay Gallery, London ****
fields.trailText:
Anselm Kiefer
Anthony d'Offay Gallery, London ****
fields.body:
Anselm Kiefer's painting serves up history bloody and full of flavour.

Kiefer's history is Germany's and his immersion in the Teutonic forest is an ambiguous cocktail of Tacitus, Wagner and the Third Reich. Kiefer is a magic realist. In Germany, his painting has the same relationship to new art as Günter Grass has to new writing: none. But it shares the Grass's appetite for the poison of 20th-century history, his monstrous relish for truth.

In his new paintings, Kiefer imagines his history as if he had been Chinese. Let a Thousand Flowers Bloom, this series of paintings and huge books, resembling mud-drenched sculptures, evokes Mao Zedong's call to intellectuals in 1957 to contribute their ideas freely to communism. "Let a hundred flowers bloom," said Mao, "let a hundred schools of thought contend." Mao's invitation turned out to be lethal; many intellectuals were forced to work on the land in the cultural revolution.

In Kiefer's massive paintings, the Chinese landscape is whipped up into a wall of colour; it is the space of both Mao's utopian idyll, where poppies float in harmony, and the desolate country of the intellectual forced to labour. Kiefer paints Mao as a Prospero figure who raises his arm in a gesture of revolutionary abundance. One image has Mao's statue casting his spell over a derelict factory, but no flowers materialise. Instead, a stuffed demonic snake whips across the canvas.

As Chinese history fuses with Kiefer's German past, Maoism is represented as black magic. Mao raises his arm in what looks like a Nazi salute. The point of Kiefer's art is to inoculate against the past by exposing the present to history's dirty residue; burning, smothering and other forms of violence determine the texture of his paintings. In Kiefer's China, that means an ambiguous mourning for communism. His Mao is not the icon painted by Andy Warhol. Kiefer's paintings are not ironic: they express real loathing for Mao - a Hitler speaking the language of flowers - yet a real longing for utopia.

History is a traumatised landscape in these paintings, a killing field. Poppies float in a field of brown, mustard and blood-red, as Prospero conjures up a society. In the books that record Kiefer's research, the photographs he took in China disappear under dirt, mud and sand, as an ancient landscape reasserts itself. The Yangtse swells in clotted lumps and Mao's portrait, floating on the tide, remains for generations to decode. What happened here? Kiefer's paintings offer no answers; some might see them as fashionable pessimism. But his paintings monumentalise history without simplifying it.

Until December 12. Details: 020-7499 4100.

webTitle: Dance review: Paul Taylor Dance Company

fields.headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company
fields.standfirst: Sadler's Wells, London ****
fields.trailText: Sadler's Wells, London ****
fields.body:
Anyone taking a cursory look at the programme danced by Paul Taylor's company on Tuesday night might have trouble believing it was choreographed by one man. At one extreme was Cascade (1999) a torrent of lyrical dance that eddied into moments of golden calm. At the other was Taylor's 1981 version of Sacre du Printemps, whose narrative mixes Nijinksy's choreography with Keystone Cops, Russian peasants with Chinese crooks.

But the one truth about Taylor's unruly imagination is that surfaces deceive. The athleticism of Cascade may look ingenuous yet within its leaps and turns are surprising gestures and rhythmic inflections that snag the flow. Steps that seem to bound over the surface of Bach's accompanying score (Concerto for piano and orchestra) dig into unexpected musical details, while duets that seem straightforwardly romantic throw up images of poignancy or regret. And most extraordinary is the long solo at its centre (danced with precision by Lisa Viola), which seems like a communion with mysterious gods.

Alone on the stage, Viola lifts her arms in hieratic incantation then tilts, wounded, back towards the floor: her body fragments under the pressure of unspoken conflict. The choreography teases us to puzzle out how this pagan ritual comes to be enacted within the classical architecture of Bach.

The solo is not only compelling; it is good training for watching Sacre, whose shuffled images resist all logic. Trying to rationalise how a New York dance rehearsal morphs into gangster dive, and how a kidnapped baby instigates mass killing is impossible. But Taylor's parodic choreography and his comic timing wrap the stories up so fast that you will never listen to Stravinsky's score in the same way.

In Piazolla Caldera (1997) Taylor nearly succeeds in reinventing the music of Astor Piazolla, which accompanies the piece. Although his costumes and steps are tango- inspired, this is not a second-hand tango show, for filtered through its barnstorming dance routines are Taylor's views on the needy appetites of sex, the lonely narcissism of the dance floor and the cloudy no-man's land of alcohol. It is a showcase for Taylor's eclectic group and for the genius of Jennifer Tipton. It is also a reminder that it has been more than nine years since the company's last London appearance. Dance fans deserve better.

Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7863 8000.
