fields.headline: Carla Bley 4x4
fields.standfirst: Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester  ****
fields.trailText: Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester ****
fields.body:
Carla Bley, the dignified jazz composer, may at times be whimsical, but has never been in danger of turning fey. Her early jazz experiences with George Russell and the pianist Paul Bley, coupled with her wit and rigorous musicality, have seen to that.

Bley made a single UK visit to Manchester on Tuesday, with the 4x4 multinational ensemble that recorded her latest album. This tight octet condenses all the harmonies, reveries, jokey diversions and volatile backdrops for improvisors that Bley originally developed for big bands. That it sounds much bigger than it is comes down to both Bley's shrewd organisation, and the strengths of the players.

The UK's Andy Sheppard, whose sax sound has grown increasingly meditative and oblique, represents an even sharper contrast with the man who stands next to him, trumpeter Lew Soloff, an American with an engagingly old-style bravura. Soloff threatened the glassware with his high notes, and his fiery up-tempo runs were little miracles of attack and subtle phrasing, while Steve Swallow's airy electric bass sound underpinned the show.

As on her 4x4 album for the Watt label, Bley ran through a mix of old and newer pieces that testify not only to the durability of her tunes, but also to the energy with which she can still charge a group of improvisors to reinvent them. Atmospheric pieces of Bley film music, references to her 1980s tone-poem on the Belgrano sinking, and the squawky slapstick of Chicken cohabited in the disorderly house of the composer's imagination.

As with most Carla Bley performances, harmonies drawn from classical music coexisted with jazz fundamentals. A mid-tempo blues with a wistful side-melody brought a characteristically robust solo from Soloff, beginning with growls and erupting into high-pitched bursts. The trombonist Gary Valente, in his Blues Brothers wardrobe, caught the mood with his huge sound, and Bley and Swallow gave it all a reflective subplot in a delicate duet.

Sidewinders in Paradise ("a little bit of the tropics," Bley announced, as if consoling the devotees who had struggled through floodwaters to get to her) shifted from rainforest instrumental effects to a Latin-funk groove, and brought anotherengagingly solo from Valente, a quicksilver one of whirs, diversions and whistling top-notes from Soloff, and soft meditations from Sheppard's tenor and Wolfgang Puschnig's flute.

But it was Utviklingssang, the ballad opened by Swallow's fragile bass overture, expanded by hooting long notes and eventually an impassioned tenor solo from Sheppard, that brought the house down in Manchester. The ageless maestro still has her magic chord.

As on her 4x4 album for the Watt label, Bley ran through a mix of old and newer pieces that testify not only to the durability of her tunes, but also to the energy with which she can still charge a group of improvisors to reinvent them. Atmospheric pieces of Bley film music, references to her 1980s tone-poem on the Belgrano sinking, and the squawky slapstick of Chicken cohabited in the disorderly house of the composer's imagination. As with most Carla Bley performances, harmonies drawn from classical music coexisted with jazz fundamentals. A mid-tempo blues with a wistful side-melody brought a characteristically robust solo from Soloff, beginning with growls and erupting into high-pitched bursts. The trombonist Gary Valente, in his Blues Brothers wardrobe, caught the mood with his huge sound, and Bley and Swallow gave it all a reflective subplot in a delicate duet. Sidewinders in Paradise ("a little bit of the tropics," Bley announced, as if consoling the devotees who had struggled through floodwaters to get to her) shifted from rainforest instrumental effects to a Latin-funk groove, and brought anotherengagingly solo from Valente, a quicksilver one of whirs, diversions and whistling top-notes from Soloff, and soft meditations from Sheppard's tenor and Wolfgang Puschnig's flute. But it was Utviklingssang, the ballad opened by Swallow's fragile bass overture, expanded by hooting long notes and eventually an impassioned tenor solo from Sheppard, that brought the house down in Manchester. The ageless maestro still has her magic chord.

fields.headline: Barclays 'better' clients to benefit
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Barclays is to cut personal loan rates for customers with good track records in managing their finances while keeping those who have had problems with bounced cheques or going over their credit limit on the higher rates, it said yesterday.
fields.body:
Barclays is to cut personal loan rates for customers with good track records in managing their finances while keeping those who have had problems with bounced cheques or going over their credit limit on the higher rates, it said yesterday.

But the bank, the second-largest personal loan provider with a 9% market share, denied the new policy would penalise those on lower incomes.

Barclays is one of several banks seeking to reward "good" customers with more attractive deals - a trend that has alarmed some observers who claim it could exacerbate financial exclusion by penalising those who have experienced money difficulties.

The Barclays initiative - dubbed "personal pricing" - follows a pilot scheme earlier this year. The bank said existing customers with a good track record in managing their money will be able to benefit from reductions of up to 3% on loans, saving the average customer taking out a £5,000 loan over 36 months around £230.

webTitle: Theatre review:  In Extremis/ De Profundis

fields.headline: In Extremis/ De Profundis
fields.standfirst: Cottesloe Theatre, London  **
fields.trailText: Cottesloe Theatre, London *&#42
fields.body:
This centenary celebration is certainly Wilde, but it doesn't make for a particularly wild night. In fact there is more than a whiff of the genteel literary festival about the affair that pairs an edited version of De Profundis, the letter that Oscar Wilde wrote to his former lover Lord Alfred Douglas while in Reading jail, with a brief two-hander. The latter, In Extremis, is spun from the fact that a week before the trial that was to cost Wilde so much, and while friends were urging him to flee abroad, he consulted a palmist called Mrs Robinson. She told him the trial would be a triumph.

If the National wanted to mark the anniversary of Wilde's death, staging one of his plays would surely have been more generous. This feels more like something cooked up for the Wilde bandwagon than a real celebration. It plays to the idea that we are more interested in the man than in his work and to our need to make his story our own. That said, De Profundis, with its mixture of arrogance and humility, foolishness and wisdom, can hardly fail to move as it details Wilde's acceptance of his artistic and moral destruction.

This is a man imprisoned not by bars but by the madness of love and its expiration. Corin Redgrave plays Wilde in his prison garb, remembering and reproaching both himself and Bosie. He is like a grand mansion once ablaze with lights that has been reduced to a smoking ruin. It is a remarkable performance; my only doubt is whether a theatre is the place for it. Performing in Reading jail to inmates would be a different matter.

The first half, In Extremis, presents a different Wilde, one still cocooned from the realities, a dandy with lemon yellow gloves and what Mrs Robinson calls "sensual, selfish hands". This Wilde looks permanently pained.

Neil Bartlett's play is too insubstantial to be more than a footnote, but there is some fun in the idea of two people who are sufficient charlatans to kid not just each other but also themselves. Sheila Hancock's Mrs Robinson is a girlish waxwork. Funeral lilies haunt the parlour as if a tragedy has already happened when, in fact, disaster is still rushing Wilde's way.

"A triumph," insists Mrs Robinson. And perhaps she was right. De Profundis leaves you wondering whether the events that broke Wilde were also the making of him. It is evidence that amidst the ruins of his life, he took responsibility for his folly and saw not just Bosie for what he really was, but also himself.

Until December 16. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

fields.headline: William Sutcliffe's top 10 relationship novels
fields.trailText: William Sutcliffe is the author of New Boy, Are You Experienced?, and The Love Hexagon, which follows the interrelated romantic and sexual adventures of six young Londoners
fields.body:
William Sutcliffe is the author of New Boy, Are You Experienced?, and The Love Hexagon, which follows the interrelated romantic and sexual adventures of six young Londoners.
Buy The Love Hexagon at Amazon.co.uk

1. A Handful of Dust by Evelyn Waugh
A concise, spare, funny yet brutal account of marital infidelity. Without ever losing a lightness of touch, this novel somehow amounts to one of the most misanthropic books you will ever read.

2. Earthly Powers by Anthony Burgess
An entire lifetime of sexual (and just about every other kind of) angst. The protagonist is gay, but his endless struggle to fend off loneliness with love couldn't be more universal.

3. A Severed Head by Iris Murdoch
Of all the lots-of-people-screwing -lots-of-other-people novels this is probably the best, and certainly the weirdest. With less philosophising and more shagging than Murdoch's other books, it is a joy to see this wonderful writer let her hair (and her knickers) down.

4. The Great Gatsby by F Scott Fitzgerald
There must be hundreds of novels that call themselves "the greatest love story of our time" in the blurb. This is the only one where it's true.

5. Underworld by Don DeLillo
This novel belongs on any list, since it seems to achieve just about everything a work of fiction can. The various marriages, families and love affairs that twine through this epic narrative are as brilliantly conceived as everything else in this truly extraordinary novel.

6. Rabbit, Run by John Updike
No marriage can have faced a sterner examination than that of the Angstroms. Rabbit, Run seems like a stunning dissection of everything that can possibly go wrong in a marriage, until you read the rest of the tetralogy and discover that things can get worse, decade by decade. No one else so brilliantly reveals the extraordinary in the ordinary.

7. The Fermata by Nicholson Baker
Baker explores the dividing line between literature and pornography, and much of the time seems to decide that the latter is more interesting. Rarely have I read a more tumescent book. Which brings me to . .

8. Portnoy's Complaint by Philip Roth
Winner of the literary tumescence prize, there is more to this novel than masturbation. Every variety of sexual frustration is explored here in hilarious detail. For auto-erotomanes everywhere this book has the status of a Bible.

9. The Cement Garden by Ian McEwan
While we're on the subject of sexual perversions, a little incest seems obligatory. This gruesome, twisted, filthy little novel is probably the best thing McEwan has ever written.

10. The French Lieutenant's Woman by John Fowles
Not wanting to end on too smutty a note, this is a proper love story again, with obsessive love thwarted by Victorian morality. If unrequited, suppressed passions are the kind that hit your spot, this is the place to look.
